../resources/summary/1899075584241.json
preprocessing
This single vehicle crash occurred just before dawn during dark hours on a level, dry, left-curve asphalt six lane divided interstate with guardrail\'s in the median and outside the right shoulder. This interstate runs east and west at this location and has three lanes in each side with no traffic controls. Posted speed limit 105 kmph (65 mph).\n   \nV1 (V1), a 1997 Ford Escort sedan driven by a 31 year-old female, was traveling westbound in lane two.  V1 drove into the number one lane and off the right side of the road onto a paved shoulder.  V1 then impacted a guardrail with its front and rebounded back onto the road re-entered all three lanes and ran off the left side of the road impacting another guardrail with its front.  After the second impact, V1 rotated counter clockwise and came to rest on its wheels facing southeast in the median. V1 was towed from the scene.\n\nThe critical pre-crash event for V1 was coded: this vehicle traveling, off the edge of the road on the right side. The critical reason for the critical event was coded to V1 as a driver related factor: internal distraction.  The driver stated that she was looking to the right and reaching for her cigarettes and lighter on the front seat. The driver was in a crash three weeks prior to this crash and was taking the medications: ibuprofen, vicodin and ultram.  For this trip she was on an errand going from a coffee shop top her mother\'s house.\n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005002229001.json
preprocessing
\n     The crash occurred on a two lane undivided level roadway with a posted speed limit of 30 mph (48 kph) on a weekday evening.  It was raining, the roadway was wet and it was dark, but lighted at the time of the crash.\n      \n     V1, a 1995 Ford Escort and V2, a 2000 Chevrolet Express van, were traveling north on the roadway.  V2 was ahead of V1.  V2 pulled to the right side of the roadway into a driveway entrance.  V2 then entered the roadway to the left and attempted to cross over into a driveway on the west side of the roadway.  V1 took evasive maneuvers by braking and steering left.  V1 struck V2 in the left side with its front.  Both vehicles came to rest on the roadway.   \n\n     The Ford Escort (V1, blue) was driven by a 17-year-old male who was transported, treated for a complaint of pain and released from a local hospital. The 15-year-old female passenger was not injured. There was no interview obtained.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when V2 entered the roadway from the driveway across V1\'s path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. It is possible that the driver of V1 made a false assumption that V2 would remain on the shoulder as he passed.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  He was taking two medications, Triclor and HCTZ.\n\n     The Chevrolet Express van (V2, white) was driven by a 23-year-old male who was transported for a complaint of pain, treated and released from a local hospital.  The 45-year-old male passenger was not injured. There was no interview obtained, only a few details from the passenger.  V2 was driven from the scene.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was when this vehicle turned left across the path of V1.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event for this vehicle was an unknown type of driver error.  It is possible that due to the darkness and weather conditions that the driver did not see or misjudged the approach of V1. The passenger advised that driver was turning left into the deli parking lot.  They had been working on-call and had been fixing a heating system, so it may also be possible that the driver had been fatigued.  No other associated factors were coded to this driver.\n
../resources/summary/2005002229021.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on the southbound lanes of a five-lane undivided urban highway. There were three southbound lanes that included a left turn lane for the traffic signal-controlled intersection. Conditions were dark, but the roadway was illuminated and dry in the mid-evening hours on a weekend. The roadway had a posted speed limit of 48 KMPH (30 MPH) and the southbound lanes were straight and level. The crash occurred on a weekend during the hours of darkness.\n\nV1 was a 2002 Hyundai Accent 2-door hatchback driven by a 65-year old female. She was traveling in the first lane of travel, approaching a four-way intersection controlled by a traffic signal. V2, a 1997 Nissan Pathfinder was stopped for a red light in the same lane at the intersection ahead of V1. The driver of V1 stated that she looked to her left at a retail store while braking, thinking that V2 was quite a distance ahead of her. She estimated that she had enough room between her vehicle and V2 as she slowed down to the intersection. She stated she probably didn\'t apply enough braking force, and the front of V1 struck the rear of V2. The driver of V1 was wearing her lap and shoulder seatbelt.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was in her lane stopped at the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an external distraction. This was chosen because the operator of V1 stated that she was looking at a store to her left as she approached the rear of V2. She also stated that she thought that V2 was farther ahead of her than it actually was. Because of this, she was also coded as misjudging the gap distance to V2. Another associated factor coded to this driver was inadequate evasive action. By her own admission, she did not apply sufficient pressure to her brake pedal. The driver of V1 reported that she was taking four medications:  an unknown diabetes medication, a cholesterol-lowering medication, an anti-inflammatory, and an antidepressant. Only the antidepressant had the possible side effects of dizziness and tiredness. She did not wear glasses for driving. She stated she was two-third\'s deaf in both ears but could not afford hearing aids although her driving license had a restriction on it indicating that she should be wearing hearing aids. She was familiar with both her vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider alcohol to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 23-year old male with a 29-year old passenger in the front right seat. Both driver and passenger stated they had minor injuries to the head/neck areas.  The driver stated that he was at the intersection waiting for the light to change with one hand on the gearshift and one hand on the steering wheel. He had one foot on the accelerator pedal and one foot on the clutch pedal thereby indicating his brake lights were not engaged, possibly an associated factor in this crash. The driver and occupant were both restrained by lap and shoulder belts.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle was in his lane, traveling in the same direction, but at a higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of the V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash. At the time of the crash, he was talking to his passenger about family matters while waiting for the traffic signal to change to green. This conversation was not thought to have had an impact on the crash, as the driver was engaging in no driving activity at the time. The driver was in good health and did not take any medications. He was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005002229042.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 48 KPH (30 MPH) and a -2.2% grade.  There was an intersecting driveway to the right with a -13.3% grade.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early morning weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1996 Chevrolet Blazer, was traveling north on the two lane undivided roadway approaching the driveway.  It should be noted that there was a large sign, small hill and telephone pole to this driver\'s right, which may have obscured the approach of V2.  V2, a 2000 Toyota Corolla, was traveling west on the driveway approaching the main roadway.  V2 entered the main roadway and was struck in the left side by the front of V1.  V2 was rotated counterclockwise off the left side of the roadway, over a small curb, onto a private lawn and came to rest facing east.  V1 continued and came to rest in the southbound lane facing north.\n\n     The Chevrolet Blazer (V1) was driven by a belted 50-year-old male who was transported, treated and released for a complaint of pain.  V1 was traveling north on the roadway and saw V2 coming down the driveway off to the right.  He put on his brakes and steered right but hit V2 on the left side.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was the encroachment of the other vehicle from a driveway, intended path not known.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  A possible contributing factor to this crash may have been the sign, small hill and pole to this driver\'s right, which may have limited his sight of V2\'s approach.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Blazer and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n     The Toyota Corolla (V2) was driven by a belted 23-year-old female who was transported, treated and hospitalized for 1 day due to a head injury.  The driver of the Corolla stated that she had "blacked out" and did not recall the accident or the events preceding the accident.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was its unknown travel direction.  This was chosen due to no indication of turning left or right and the incapacitating illness of the driver.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was the physical impairment of the ability to act of the driver.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  She was taking two medications: a birth control pill and an antihistamine.  They did not contribute to the crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005002229062.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 64 KPH (40 MPH).  There was a level curve (radius of curvature 703.125 meters) to the left with a black on yellow warning sign with a suggested speed of 40 KPH (25 MPH).  The weather was cloudy, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 2004 Subaru Forester was traveling south on the roadway and negotiating the curve to the left. A non-contact truck approached from the opposite direction .The Driver of V1 stated he thought he had had enough room but realized he didn\'t so he steered  right. V1 continued off the right side of the road down a small embankment, struck a 65 cm diameter tree with its front and came to rest facing in a southerly direction.  \n\n     The Subaru Forester (V1) was driven by an 82 year old male who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for a head injury.  He stated that he observed the truck approaching, moved to the right, but believed that he was over to far.   After that he does not remember any events of the crash.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was the poor directional control of the driver.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications:  (a) gout no disabling side effects, (b) diuretic possible side effects are lethargy, drowsiness, low blood pressure, and (c) general health medication with possible side effects of drowsiness, tiredness, and dizziness.  He also takes non-prescription anti-inflammatory drug occasionally.  He was wearing prescription glasses that corrected a hyperopic (far-sighted) condition.  He was familiar with the roadway and his vehicle.\n
../resources/summary/2005002229082.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a four-lane undivided straight level roadway with a T-type intersection controlled by a traffic signal.  There were two northbound lanes and two southbound lanes.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 48 KPH (30 MPH).  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was dusk at the time of this late afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1998 Chevrolet Lumina, was traveling north in the left hand lane with the intention of turning left at the traffic signal controlled intersection.  V2, a 1998 Subaru Legacy, was traveling south on the same roadway in the right hand lane. V1 was waved through by a non-contact stopped vehicle in the southbound left lane. V1 turned across the path of V2.  V1\'s front struck the front of V2.  V1 was rotated counterclockwise and came to rest facing in a southeasterly direction in the southbound left lane.  V2 continued and came to rest on the intersecting roadway facing in a southerly direction. \n\n     The Chevrolet Lumina (V1) was driven by a belted 67 year old female who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital with a complaint of pain.  She stated that she had slowed as she approached the light and a non-contact stopped vehicle waved her on.  As she proceeded to make the turn, traveling less than 16kph (10 mph), V2 struck her, spinning her around so she was facing the way she had come.  She indicated that she did not see V2.  V1 was towed due to damage. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver stated she proceeded to make the left turn because another motorist waved her through and she did not see V2.  An additional factor may be that the driver was concerned about returning home as quickly as possible.  She stated that she had just picked up dinner and did not want it to get cold before she got home.  Another associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  She was taking 8 medications:  four for diabetes, two high blood pressure medications with possible side effects of headache, dizziness and fatigue.   One high cholesterol medication and one depression medication with possible side effects of nervousness, drowsiness, tiredness.\n\n     The Subaru Legacy wagon (V2) was driven by a belted 27 year old male who was not injured.  He stated that he was traveling south, there were two vehicles about 40 feet ahead of him, and she turned between them and in front of him.  He stated that she did not have enough window of opportunity.  He braked and steered right, but was unable to avoid the collision.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the encroachment of V1 from the opposite direction over the left lane line.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded to this vehicle.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Subaru and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n\n\n       \n
../resources/summary/2005002229102.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 64KPH (40MPH).  There was an intersecting roadway to the left and a driveway to the right. There was a traffic control signal at the intersection. The weather was cloudy, the roadway was dry and it was dark, but lighted at the time of this late night weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1987 Honda Accord, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway approaching the intersection. It should be noted that the traffic control signal was lighted red. V2, a 1994 Honda Civic was stopped at the signal awaiting a green light, in front of V1. V1\'s front impacted V2\'s rear. V2 was pushed through the intersection and came to rest facing in a southwesterly direction. V1 came to rest facing in a southerly direction.\n\n     The Honda Accord (V1) was driven by an unbelted 19 year old female who was transported, treated and released for minor bleeding to the head. She stated that she did not see the other vehicle, that she was also looking down to retrieve a dropped water bottle as well as attempting to put on her seat belt. V1 was towed due to damage and was destroyed before the inspection could be done.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was another vehicle stopped in lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as an internal distraction, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver stated she was looking down to retrieve a dropped water bottle and attempting to put on her seat belt.  She was wearing glasses to correct her myopic (near-sighted) vision.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Honda Civic (V2) was driven by a belted 25-year-old male. A 22-year-old belted female passenger was listed as having a possible injury on the police report. The driver interview was not obtained due to him living out of state (Mexico).\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Civic and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005002229122.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-lane undivided level roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KPH (55 MPH).  V1 was negotiating a curve to the left with a superelevation of 8.4% and a radius of curvature of 225 meters. There was a warning sign (black on yellow curve) prior to the curve, but did not indicate a suggested speed.  It should be noted that there was an 8 cm. lip on the edge of the shoulder where V1 departed the roadway. The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1998 Toyota Camry, was traveling north on the two-lane undivided roadway negotiating a curve to the left.  V1 drove off the right side of the roadway, through several inches of snow and struck a 50 cm diameter tree with its front.  V1 rotated clockwise back across both lanes of traffic and came to rest facing west in the southbound lane. \n\n     The Toyota Camry was driven by a belted 83-year-old male, who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for minor injuries.  The driver indicated that he became dizzy while he was driving due to a new blood pressure medication that he had just started taking that morning. He stated that he went off the road, overcorrected and does not recall any other events of the crash.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Pre-Event Movement for V1 was negotiating a curve; the Critical Pre-crash Event for was off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was other physical impairment of the ability to act, a non-performance error.  This was chosen because the driver indicated that he felt dizzy due to his new blood pressure medication. An additional associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  He was taking 3 unidentified medications: (a) a new blood pressure medication, (b) a blood thinner and (c) aspirin.  He was wearing hearing aids in both ears for 75% loss of hearing.
../resources/summary/2005002229143.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 55 MPH (89 KPH). The roadway was curved to the right with a radius of curvature of 321.4 meters, a superelevation of 4.7% and a -4.6% grade. There was a black on yellow warning sign prior to the curve, but gave no suggested speed. The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday morning crash.\n\n     V1, a 1997 Jeep Grand Cherokee, was traveling west on the two lane undivided roadway negotiating the curve to the right on a downgrade.  V2, a 1997 Peterbilt 379 CBE towing a low boy semi-trailer, was traveling west on the same roadway ahead of V1 and turning left into a driveway. V2 was partially into the driveway and the trailer was across both east and westbound lanes. V1 attempted to avoid V2 by braking and steering left.  V1 went off the left side of the roadway, up a small snow embankment and rolled over to the right one-quarter turn.  V1 continued a short distance and struck the left side of the tractor-trailer with its top.  V1 came to rest on its right side facing in a southwesterly direction.  V2 was pushed slightly clockwise and came to rest facing in a southwesterly direction.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Jeep Cherokee (V1) was driven by a belted 29-year-old male who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for a complaint of pain.  The belted 29-year-old female right front passenger was airlifted to a trauma center with a complaint of pain.  No interview was obtained from the driver.  Statements and information obtained at the scene from the police indicated that the driver and passenger had been arguing prior to the crash.  It should be noted that the previous day they had had their engagement party. The driver stated that he had failed to observe the tractor-trailer turning and attempted to avoid it. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as internal distraction, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver was arguing with the passenger prior to the crash and failed to observe V2 turning left.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  He was taking three medications, (a) an antidepressant, with possible side effects of seizures and agitation, (b) an anticonvulsive and antimanic, with possible side effects of aggression and emotional upset and (c) a benzodiazepine tranquilizer with possible side effects of sleepiness and inability to concentrate.  It should be noted that the driver stated to EMS personnel that he had possibly blacked out and had just taken two 0.5 mg of the tranquilizer 10 minutes prior to the crash. \n\n     No Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of the Peterbilt (V2) because he was not involved in the first harmful event.  The driver was not fatigued, was wearing prescription sunglasses to correct a nearsighted condition and had just found his destination after being lost.  He was comfortable with his vehicle.\nHe was taking prescription and non-prescription medications.  The two prescription medications were (a) a gout medication and (b) a high blood pressure medication.  The over the counter medication was (c) a general anti-inflammatory.  No other factors were coded to this driver.
../resources/summary/2005002229162.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KPH (55 MPH).  V1 was negotiating a curve to the right with a radius of curvature of 468.75 meters and a 3.2% superelevation.  The roadway also had a -2.7% grade.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early morning crash.\n\n     V1, a 1995 Dodge Neon, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway negotiating the curve to the right.  Operator of V1 fell asleep and drove across the northbound lane and off the left side of the roadway.  V1 continued and struck 2 mailbox posts with its front.  V1 continued a short distance and came to rest facing south. \n\n     The Dodge Neon was driven by a belted 18-year-old female who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for a possible injury to the knee. She stated that she was sound asleep and did not know any details of the crash.  The driver was not taking any medications.  She wears glasses for reading only. V1 was towed due to damage. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was off the edge on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was that the driver fell asleep, which was a critical non-performance error. This was chosen due to the driver\'s statements.  It should be noted that she worked on call, had only 5 hours of sleep prior to the crash and had "been out" the previous night.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.
../resources/summary/2005002229182.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a straight two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 64 KPH (40 MPH). The roadway is a narrow country road with numerous small hills and no lane delineations.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 2004 Honda Civic, was traveling east on the roadway and approaching a hillcrest with limited sight distance.  As V1 crested the hill another non-contact vehicle was slowing or stopped in her lane.  The Driver of V1 took evasive maneuvers by steering to the left and braking.  The Driver of V1 then observed an oncoming vehicle and braked and steered to the right.  V1 continued off the right side of the roadway, up a small embankment striking it with its front.  V1 then rolled over to the left two \xc2\xbc turns and came to rest on its roof facing west.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Honda Civic (V1) was driven by a belted 16 year old female who sustained an abrasion on her hand, but refused any medical transport.  It should be noted that she had only had her license for 6 months.  She was familiar and comfortable with the vehicle.  She was not fatigued and not taking any type of medications.  She was wearing contacts to correct a myopic condition.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when the vehicle traveled off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as overcompensation, a performance error.  This was chosen because the driver was able to go around the first non-contact vehicle, but then corrected  abruptly to the right to avoid the second non-contact vehicle. An associated factor for this driver may be driver inexperience. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.
../resources/summary/2005002229202.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a level two-lane undivided straight roadway with a posted speed limit of 64 KMPH (40 MPH).  Many driveways for retail establishments intersect with the roadway. There is a side road with a control device with a pedestrian signal, which was mentioned by the drivers of both vehicles, 100 meters north of the crash site. The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. The crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\n    V1, a 2000 Pontiac Grand Am, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway. V2 pulled out from a fast food establishment\'s driveway making a left turn in front of V1. V1 impacted the left front corner of V2 with its front right. Both vehicles came to rest in the roadway facing their intended directions.\n\n    The 2000 Pontiac Grand Am (V1) was driven by a 16-year old belted female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released. The vehicle was pushed out of the roadway to a parking lot and then towed from the scene. \n\n    The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle encroached into her lane, from a driveway, across her path. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  It should be noted here that the driver of the Pontiac Grand Am had been licensed for one-half a year and had not finished her high school driver\'s education course. This driver was wearing contact lenses at the time of the crash. The driver of this vehicle takes a birth control medication and an ibuprofen combination drug. This driver also stated she thought the pickup was stopping in the driveway from which it emerged (a false assumption). She also stated a control signal before the crash site was green as she was going through it.\n\n    The Chevrolet Colorado (V2) was driven by a belted 70-year old male who was not injured. There was a belted female passenger in the front right seat who was not injured and was checked out by the EMS. It should be noted that both driver and passenger stated they saw the above mentioned control signal as being red, and therefore, proceeded to turn north on the undivided two-lane roadway. The driver takes several medications for two health issues, high blood pressure and arthritis. The driver wears corrective lenses for reading only. This vehicle was not towed.\n\n    The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as "This vehicle traveling -turning left at intersection." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  It should be noted that the driver of V2 was ticketed for Failure to Yield. The police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests for either driver.
../resources/summary/2005002229222.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound lane of a level two-lane roadway with a posted speed limit of 30 MPH (48 KPH).  The roadway had a very slight curve to the right.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early evening crash.\n\n     V1, a 1989 Volvo 740 GL, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway.  V2, a 1988 Jeep Cherokee and V3, a 1996 Chevrolet Blazer were traveling on the same roadway ahead of V1.  There was heavy stop and go traffic at the time of the crash.  V1 struck V2 in rear with its front.  V2 was then pushed into the rear of V3 with its front.  All three vehicles came to rest facing south in the southbound lane.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Volvo 740 GL (V1) was driven by a belted 34 year old male who was not injured.  He stated that traffic was just rolling, then stopped and then rolling again.  He also stated that he didn\'t realize the vehicles had moved forward, then stopped and were so close.  He indicated that he may have glanced away or just spaced out.  He could not recollect how fast he had been traveling prior to the crash or at the time of the impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when another vehicle was in the lane traveling in the same direction with low steady speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was inattention, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver indicated that he had glanced away or spaced out prior to the crash.  It is also possible that this driver misjudged the velocity and gap distance to the forward vehicle because of the heavy traffic.  This driver was not fatigued and did not take any type of medications.\nHe was wearing over the counter sunglasses at the time of the crash.  \n\n     The Jeep Cherokee (V2) was driven by a belted 40-year-old female, who complained of pain, but refused medical treatment.  The belted 38-year-old male right front passenger also complained of pain and refused treatment.  The right rear passenger was a 5-year-old female in a child restraint who was not injured.  The driver of V2 stated that she didn\'t see anything, had been conversing with the passenger and only recalled being struck from behind then pushed forward into V3.  She was not taking any type of medications and was wearing over the counter sunglasses at the time of the crash.  The driver of the Cherokee was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\nV2 was driven from the scene.\n\n     The Chevrolet Blazer (V3) was driven by an unbelted 22-year-old female, who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for complaint of pain.  The driver of V3 stated that she had just taken her seat belt off in anticipation of turning into a gas station for a bottle of water.  She was in a hurry to get to a school class and concerned about how late she would be by stopping to get something to drink.  She was not taking any type of medications.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Blazer and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  V3 was driven from the scene
../resources/summary/2005002229223.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a four lane physically divided roadway curving to the right with a posted speed limit of 105KPH (65MPH) and a negative 2% grade. The roadway is divided by a grass median and a box shaped guardrail.  This is a fully controlled roadway interstate highway. The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekend day in the late afternoon. The driver left the scene of the crash, with his two children in an ambulance.\n\n   V1, a 4 door sedan 2005 Chevrolet Malibou, was traveling south on the roadway when it lost control and departed the roadway on the left side striking the center guardrail with its front, spinning counter-clockwise and striking the same guardrail with its right rear side encompassing part of the passenger compartment and the rear. It should be noted here that the driver stated, to police, that an uninvolved vehicle moved from the driving lane to the passing lane causing him to take evasive action and then losing control of this vehicle. The vehicle came to rest, off roadway, facing in a northerly direction, with the guardrail resting on a right rear section of the vehicle.\n\n   The Chevrolet Malibou was driven by a 28 year old belted male and there were two young children as passengers. A belted 8 year old child  was seated in the front right and an unbelted 9 year old child was seated in the rear left seat. The nine year old sustained injuries according to the police report. The driver and the other passenger were not injured. It should be noted here that this was a rented vehicle and the driver stated he had rented it in a city 50 miles north of the crash site.\n\n   The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason the for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as unknown reason for critical event. This was chosen due to information on the police report as no interview could be obtained. The police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests for this driver.

This crash occurred on a level two lane undivided straight roadway with a posted speed limit of 48KPH (30mph). The roadway was straight. The intersecting roadway was a two lane undivided roadway Conditions were dry and crash occurred in the early afternoon hours of a weekday.\n\nV1 was a 1996 Ford  Contour was traveling in the east bound lane, then making a left turn at the intersection after an uninvolved truck had just passed in the westbound lane. V2 was a 2004 Honda Motorcycle traveling westbound behind the uninvolved truck.  V1, the Ford Contour, made the left turn immediately after the truck and in front of  V2, the Honda Motorcycle.  V2 impacted V1 on the  right front  side with it\'s front.\n\nThe Ford Contour (V1) was driven by a 43-year old male who was transported to an area hospital with minor injuries. He was wearing his prescription contact lenses and a pair of sunglasses at the time of the crash.  He stated there was a truck in his way and he didn\'t see the motorcycle. He did not stop before making the turn. He stated he was traveling less than 20 MPH at impact.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as This Vehicle Traveling Turning Left at Intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as Driver Related Factor Recognition Error- Inadequate Surveillance. He estimated the impact occurred only a  second or two after he began making the turn. He stated he looked for vehicles as the uninvolved truck was passing and did not see any other oncoming traffic.\n\nThe 22-year old male driver of the Honda Motorcycle (V2) was not able to be interviewed at the scene due to EMS care and did not respond to multiple messages left at his home. Evidence at the scene indicated this vehicle did not have any response time prior to impact. This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as Other Vehicle Encroachment From Opposite Direction-over left lane line. No Critical  Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded for this vehicle and he was thought not to have contributed to this crash.\n\nIt should be noted the driver of V1 was cited by police for Failure to Yield Right of Way.

This crash occurred on at and intersection between two lane undivided roadways. The Precrash roadway of V1 had a elevation of +5.7% and the Precrash roadway of V2 had an elevation of + 18.8% and posted speed limits of 48KMPH (30MPH). The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekday evening.\n\nV1 a 1998 Mercury Sable was traveling in a westerly direction on the two lane undivided roadway crossing an intersection and intending to go straight. V2 a 1995 Nissan Altima was traveling northwest intending to cross the intersection and go in a northern direction. V2 impacted the front left of V1 with its front left. V1 came to rest facing southwest partially off the roadway with its front.\nV2 came to rest on the roadway facing north after having gone through the intersection.\n\nThe Mercury Sable was driven by belted 28 year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released.  She stated that the event happened so quickly she did not have time to react. She did, however, cover her face with her hands prior to impact.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was Other Vehicle Encroachment From Crossing street, Across Path. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle. The driver of V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash. There is no evidence of any illegal drug use, however the driver stated she takes several types of antihistamines for allergies.\n\nThe 1995 Nissan Altima (V2) was driven by a belted 30 year old male who stated he was not injured. He stated that V1 did not stop at the intersection and that he has stopped for 2 seconds before continuing through the intersection. This driver was ticketed by police for driving with a suspended registration.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this Vehicle was This Vehicle Traveling Crossing over (passing through) an intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a Driver Related Factor, Inadequate surveillance. This Critical Reason was coded due to the driver stating he had driven on this roadway many times and knew there were no stop signs. It should be noted at this time that there were no stops signs or traffic control signals on either road of this intersection.\n\nIt should further be noted that a utility pole situated extremely close to the roadway, on  Driver #2\'s right side, with a large bright green sign may have partially blocked this drivers sight line for approaching traffic. It should also be noted that several parked vehicles to the right of this driver might also have limited his sight line.\n\nThe police did not consider illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests for either driver.\n

This crash occurred on a curve of a two-lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KMPH (55 MPH). The weather was clear and the roadway was dry and level. This crash occurred on a weekend afternoon.\n\nV1, a red 2003 Buick Century, was traveling south on the two-lane undivided roadway negotiating a curve to the right when it went over the left side double yellow lines into the northbound lane. V2, a white 1992 Nissan Sentra, was traveling north on the same roadway negotiating the same curve. V1 impacted the front left of V2 with its front left. V1 spun counter-clockwise and came to rest facing north on the southbound shoulder. V2 spun counter-clockwise and came to rest on the northbound shoulder facing south.\n\nThe Buick Century (V1) was driven by a belted 58-year old female who was airlifted to a trauma center and hospitalized due to left leg and abdominal injuries. She stated that she could not remember the actual crash but does remember talking with her passenger and then waking up to see dirt, a broken window and the airbag. The right front passenger in this vehicle was a relative of the driver, a belted 80-year old male with a previous diagnosis of dementia. He was transported to an area hospital. The driver of this vehicle takes several medications for diabetes, high blood pressure, and depression. She also has been diagnosed with sleep apnea. Possible side effects of these medications include drowsiness and lethargy. It should be noted here that a witness described this driver as looking \xe2\x80\x9clike she fell asleep.\xe2\x80\x9d  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V1 was this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an unknown critical non-performance error. It was possible that the driver fell asleep or that she passed out - medical records did not indicate a cause for the crash. Associated factors coded to this driver include her previous medical conditions (sleep apnea, diabetes, high blood pressure, depression), the prescription medications she had been taking, and her conversation with her passenger prior to the crash.\n\nThe Nissan Sentra (V2) was driven by a belted 30-year old male who was airlifted to an area trauma center. There was a belted 27-year old female passenger in the right front seat who was transported to an area hospital. The occupants of this vehicle were not available for interviews and did not return messages. This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors could be coded to this driver due to the lack of an interview. \n

This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway, slightly curving to the right prior to the crash site, with no grade and a posted speed limit of  89 KMPH (55MPH). the weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV2, a 1990 Ford Mustang, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway when it proceeded to pass a box truck (as per the driver of V1). It impacted with V1 a 2000 Pontiac Grand Am, head on in the northbound lane. V2 came to rest on the east shoulder facing south. V1 came to rest on the east shoulder facing north.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was This Vehicle Traveling Over the Lane line on Left Side of Travel Lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as  Driver Related Factor, Inadequate Surveillance (e.g. failed to look, looked but did not see.) There is no evidence of any illegal drug use, however the Police Report for this crash could not be obtained.\n\nThe Ford Mustang (V2) was driven by a 20 year old male who was flown  to an area trauma center with head neck and back injuries.  No interview was obtained as researcher was unable to locate or contact this driver.\n\n The driver of the Pontiac Grand Am (V1) was a 49 year old belted male who was flown to an area trauma center. This driver stated that V1 came from behind a box truck into his lane. It should be noted here that the driver of this vehicle stated he has a heart condition for which he takes prescription medications.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was Other Motor Vehicle in Lane. No Critical Reason for Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.\n\n\n

\n\nThis crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway, curving to the right. with a posted speed llmit of 89KMPH (55MPH). The weather was cloudy and misting after a moderate rain and the roadway was wet. This crash occurred on a weekend evening.\n\nV1, a 1993 Mazda 626, was traveling north on the two lane undivided roadway when it approached the curve at an unsafe speed. The vehicle went over the left lane line, across the southbound  lane and departed the roadway impacting and breaking a guardrail with the left front, then the left rear. The vehicle then continued across both  north and south bound lanes and impacted with a guardrail on the northbound side, with its front right.\n\nThe Mazda 626 was driven by a 22 year old  belted female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released.\nShe stated she was going 45MPH ((72KMPH) and was in the turn when the vehicle started to skid. She stated she tried braking and steering to the right but it didn\'t help. It should be noted at this time that very recently painted roadway lines were extremely slippery and caused several rescue workers to slide and fall down. It may be noted that the lead tire, the Left Front tire, had only 1mm of tread at the time of the crash.\nIt should also be noted that this driver has had to take a 6 hour mandatory driving test  two times.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was  This Vehicle Control Loss Due to Traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded asDriver Related Factor Decision Errors, Too fast for conditions specify (reasons given above).\n\nIt should be noted here there were no warning signs on the northbound side of the roadway, however there was a posted warning sign of 50MPH (80KMPH) on the  southbound side. The roadway is bituminous on either side of the bridge and concrete on the bridge itself.\n\n\nThe police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash.

This crash occurred on a 4 lane undivided roadway slightly curving to the left prior to the crash site. The posted speed limit is 48 KMPH (30MPH) with no grade. The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. The crash occurred on a weekday evening.\n\nV2, a 1999 Mercury Mystique, was traveling north on the four lane undivided roadway when it stopped to allow several southbound vehicle to pass before proceeding to make an intended left turn into a retail establishment\'s driveway. V1, a 2003 Dodge Neon, was traveling in the same direction behind V2. V1 impacted the rear of V2 with its front. Both vehicles came to rest in the roadway facing north.\n\nThe Dodge Neon (V1) was driven by a belted 18 year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released. She stated she didn\'t know what went wrong as she didn\'t realize the vehicle in front of her had stopped. This driver stated she was not in a hurry, does not have any medical conditions and does not take any medication. This Vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was Other Motor Vehicle in Lane, Other Vehicle Stopped. The Critical reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor, Recognition Error, Inadequate Surveillance. It should be noted here that this driver has had only two years driving experience.\n\nThe Mercury Mystique, (V2) was driven by a belted 23 year old female who was not injured. This driver stated she was stopped in her lane for 1 or 2 seconds waiting for oncoming traffic to pass before proceeding to make a left turn. She also stated she did not see V1 approaching her as she was watching traffic ahead of her. This vehicle was  driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was Other Motor Vehicle in Lane Traveling in the Same Direction with Higher Speed. No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle. The police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be involved and did not order tests for either driver.\nNo citations were issued in this crash.

\n\nThis crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway, slightly curving to the left, with radius of 3 meters and a super-elevation of 5/3%. The posted speed limit was 64KMPH (40MPH). The roadway was dry and the weather was clear. This crash occurred on a  weekend morning. \n\nV1, a 2001 Chevrolet Malibu, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway negotiating the curve when it went off the roadway to the right impacting with the left front of V2 and the left front of V3.  This caused a domino effect down the line from V3 through Vehicle #7. A piece of V2 flew up and into Vehicle #8 cracking the bottom right part of the  windshield. All vehicles from #2 through #8 were being sold on a used vehicle parking lot.\n\nThe Chevrolet Malibu (V1) was driven by an 18 year old belted male and had a 19 year old passenger in the front right seat. EMS was refused although the passenger complained of neck and chest pain. The driver stated that he thought his brakes and steering wheel locked up and he was trying to steer away from northbound traffic.  He stated he was talking with his passenger before and during the time of impact.  It should be noted at this time that the driver stated his vehicle had a short history of engine failure as an event of that nature occurred during the prior week. It should also be noted the driver  was inexperienced and not familiar with a loss of  power steering.  The Police and the Researcher tested both the brakes and steering at the scene and did not find a loss of either to have occurred.\n \nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was This Vehicle Traveling Off the edge of the road on the right side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor, Performance Errors, Panic/freezing. This was chosen due to the driver stating that he panicked when he thought the brakes and steering wheel locked up. This driver does not wear prescription lenses and has no known illness for which medication would be needed. No other associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\nV2, a 1993 Ford Escort, and V3, a 1994 Dodge Shadow were parked in a line of used cars, 1 meter off to the right side of the roadway shoulder. No Critical Precrash Event or Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event were coded to these vehicles.\n\nThe Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash and ordered no tests for this driver.\n\n\n\n\n

This crash occurred on a straight undivided 4-lane roadway with no grade and a posted speed limit of 56 KMPH (35MPH). The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekend day in the early afternoon.\n\nV1, 1994 Volvo 850 sedan, was traveling south in the first lane of travel when its front impacted with the rear of V2, a 1992 Subaru Legacy.  V2 was pushed into the rear of V3, a1999 Plymouth Voyager minivan. V1 and V3 came to rest in the roadway facing south. V2 was driven off the roadway by its driver to a parking lot entrance.\n\nThe 1994 Volvo 850 (V1) was driven by a  belted 16-year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released. There were two 16-year old female passengers in this vehicle who were also transported to an area hospital, treated and released. Injuries were reported as minor. The driver stated she thought her seat belt was too loose and looked down to see if it was buckled correctly. She returned her vision to the roadway in time to use her footbrake but was unable to avoid impacting the vehicle in front of her. It should be noted here that the driver was inexperienced and had a junior license.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as internal distraction, a driver-related recognition error. An associated factor coded to this driver was driver inexperience. \n\nThe 1992 Subaru Legacy (V2) was driven by a belted 35-year old male who was not injured. He stated he was stopped in traffic awaiting the change of the traffic signal up ahead when his vehicle was impacted in the rear, pushing his vehicle into V3. He stated he had his foot on the brake but this did not stop his vehicle from moving.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to this vehicle was other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed. No Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash event was coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\nThe 1999 Plymouth Voyager was driven by a belted 37-year old male who had an 18-year old belted male passenger. Both occupants were transported to an area hospital, treated and released. Injuries were listed as minor.\n.\nNo Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to this vehicle because it was not involved in the first harmful event. Associated factors coded to this driver include the use of a prescription medication for high cholesterol and a conversation with the passenger at the time of the crash.\n\nPolice did not consider illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests for any of the drivers.\n

This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1993 Subaru Loyale was traveling southbound on the two lane undivided roadway, negotiating a curve to the left when it lost control, skidded counter-clockwise  and departed the roadway on the east side impacting a utility pole with its right rear side. The vehicle came to rest facing in a northerly direction.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 17 year old belted female who was slightly injured but did not get transported to a hospital. This driver could not be located or contacted for an interview. There is no evidence of any legal or illegal drug use or of any illness.  A witness stated that this vehicle was traveling at an excessive rate of speed for this curve and for road conditions. V1 came to rest on the southbound shoulder. V2 came to rest in a north side parking lot. V2 had been stopped in the northbound  traveling lane waitng for traffic to pass and intending to make a left turn into the parking lot.\n\nThe Ford Expedition, (V1) was driven by a 34 year old belted male who was examined at the scene and refused further medical attention. He stated he was looking at an exterior site, to the right of his vehicle, and did not realize the vehicle in front of him was stopped.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was coded as Other Motor Vehicle in Lane, Other vehicle stopped. The Critical  Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor, Recognition Error, External Distraction. An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications. He was taking two medications: (a) a depression medication with the possible side effects of drowsiness and (b) a pain medication also with the possible side effects of drowsiness.\n\nThe Dodge Ram (V2) was driven by a 38 year old belted female with a belted 16 year old female passenger in the right front seat. The driver stated she was stopped in the roadway waiting for several vehicles to pass before proceeding to make a left turn into a parking lot. She stated she did not see V2 approaching and had no time to react. No Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle as the driver was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nBoth Vehicles were towed from the scene. Police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be involved and ordered no tests for either driver.

V1 continued off the roadway and came to rest on the south side, against a embankment, facing west. V2 came to rest off the roadway on the south side, facing east.\n\nThe Toyota Paseo (V1) was driven by a belted 20 year old male who was not injured. V1 impacted with the rear of  V2 with its front. Both vehicle came to rest in the intersection. V2 was towed from the scene.\n\nThe Ford Taurus (V1) was driven by a belted 19 year old male who was not injured. The driver stated V2 had come to a stop and started to pull forward, but stopped again.\nHe stated he couldn\'t understand why V2 stopped a second time and he thought she would just continue to turn right.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was Other Motor Vehicle in Lane Traveling in same direction while decelerating. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: Driver Related Factor Decision Error False assumption of other\'s actions. V1 crossed over the left lane line into the eastbound lane. The motorcycle returned to its original eastbound lane whereupon V1 impacted with V2 with its front. V1 came to rest in the eastbound land facing west V2 was knocked backwards 33meters coming to rest on its side, in the center of the roadway, facing eastward.\n\nThis crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway slightly curving to the left with no grade and a posted speed limit of  72KMPH (45MPH). preprocessing
This crash occurred in the southbound lanes of a two-lane undivided roadway during the mid-afternoon hours. The roadway was straight with a posted speed limit of 89 KMPH (55 MPH). The roadway was wet and the sky was cloudy. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1995 Toyota Camry station wagon, was traveling on the undivided roadway when it went over the right lane line and its right front impacted the left rear of V2, a parked and unoccupied 1993 Oldsmobile Ciera. The Oldsmobile was parked on the right shoulder. The driver of V1 then steered to the left across the southbound lane and into the northbound lane, overcorrected, came back across the southbound lane, and went off the roadway on the west side. The front right of V1 struck a 15cm tree before coming to final rest against the tree, facing a westerly direction.\n\nThe Toyota Camry Wagon was driven by a belted 52-year old male who was transported to an area hospital. The driver could not located for an interview and did not return messages left at the residence listed on his driver\'s license. The police report indicated that the driver of this vehicle might have had a seizure while driving.  A witness to this crash stated that she saw the driver of V1 looking down and to his right as if at something inside the vehicle before the crash. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded for V1 was this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the right side. The Critical Reason for Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as poor directional control because the driver failed to keep his vehicle in his lane. The driver told medical staff that he had no memory of the crash but did say he had a history of seizure disorder. He could not say whether or not he had had a seizure prior to the crash, although his actions following the impact with V2 indicate that he was conscious following that impact.\n\nPolice did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash and ordered no tests. Medical staff did order a BAC on the driver, and blood was drawn approximately 1.5 hours after the crash. The test indicated that the driver of V1 had a BAC of .358, a level that was considered acute alcohol intoxication. The driver also told medical staff that he was taking five medications for his seizure disorder. Alcohol use, prescription drug use, and the history of seizure disorder were all coded as associated factors.\n\n

\nThis crash occurred on a  3 lane straight roadway with a positive barrier. The posted speed limit is (89KMPH) (55MPH). This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1991 Dodge Caravan minivan, was traveling west on the on-ramp when it failed to yield right of way to on coming traffic, continued off the end of the on-ramp and rode the top of the guardrail before coming to rest facing west.\n\nThe Dodge Caravan (V1) was driven by a belted 52 year old male who refused treatment stating he was not injured. The driver of the vehicle was watching on coming traffic while eating a cheeseburger. He stated that a driver of an uninvolved vehicle refused to let him into its lane. It should be noted here that the driver has an asthmatic condition and required his medication immediately after the crash. He also requested his cigarettes be taken out of the vehicle. He stated he was thinking about health concerns as he had taken medication, to counteract side effects of an antibiotic he was taking, on an empty stomach.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was:  This Vehicle Traveling, End Departure. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: Driver Related Factor, Aggressive Driving Behavior.\n\nThe police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be involved and ordered no tests.\n
../resources/summary/2005002229542.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a two-lane undivided roadway that curved to the right with a super elevation of 6.3 percent. The roadway at this point had a downhill grade of 4.9 percent and there was an intersecting side road on the left. The posted speed limit was 89KMPH (55MPH). The roadway was dry and the weather was cloudy. This crash occurred on a weekday in the early hours of the morning before dawn. The roadway was not illuminated.\n\nV1, a 2000 Peterbilt tractor-trailer, was traveling north on the two-lane roadway when it came up upon V2, a 1998 Chevrolet pickup truck, which was facing north getting ready to make a left turn onto the side road. In an attempt to avoid a collision, the driver of V1 steered to the left while locking up his brakes. As he did this, V2 initiated its left turn. V1 struck V2 on the left side passenger compartment with its front right. V1 skidded off the roadway to the left, impacting a road sign and came to rest off the roadway on the west side, north of the side road. V2 continued off the roadway to the northwest and came to final rest in front of V1.\n\nV1 was driven by a belted 43-year old male who was not injured. This driver stated that V2 was stopped in the roadway and he steered to the left to avoid striking it, as he had no room to maneuver to the right of V2.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for this vehicle was: this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as "too fast to be able to respond to unexpected actions of others," a driver-related decision error. Associated factors coded to this driver include traveling too fast for conditions and the fact that the driver chose an inappropriate/unsuccessful evasive action. Had the driver simply braked in his lane without steering to the left, it is likely that V2 would have completed its turn with no impact.\n\nV2 was driven by a belted 32-year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released. The driver stated she had not stopped in the roadway, as there was no oncoming traffic. She said that she decelerated in her lane to between 1-10 MPH and then initiated her turn. She further stated that before she had turned, she had seen the truck in her rearview mirror and it was "tiny" in her mirror. She could not understand how the truck came down the hill so quickly.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for this vehicle was: other vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction)-over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nPolice did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor and did not order a test for either driver.\n

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a 3 lane positively divided highway, the fifth lane being the off ramp leading to a service center. The off ramp curved to the right with a superelevation of 4%. The roadway was wet and it was raining heavily. This crash occurred on a weekend morning.\n\nV1, a 1995 Nissan Altima, was traveling south on the highway and was exiting on the off ramp to go into the service center when the driver drove off the roadway to the left impacting with the curb, a roadway sign and a light pole. The vehicle came to rest facing west by the light pole. The light pole broke with the light fixture falling to the ground. \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 28 year old belted female who was transported to an area hospital,  with a non-incapacitating injury, treated and released. The Police Officer at the scene cited the driver as stating she stepped on the gas when she thought she was stepping on the brake. The driver of the Nissan Altima (V1) refused the interview.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was This Vehicle Traveling, Off the Edge of the Road on the Left Side. The  Critical Reason for Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor, Performance Errors, Other Performance Error-Used Gas Pedal Instead of Brake Pedal\n\nThe Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash and ordered no tests for this driver.\n\nThe Police Report indicated "unsafe speed"

This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway at an intersection with a 2 lane undivided side road. The posted speed limit on the two lane roadway on which the crash occurred was 89KMPH (55MPH). The posted speed limit on the side road was 48KMPH (30MPH) and the side road had a stop sign. It was dark at the time of the crash and the roadway was unlighted. The roadway was dry and it was cloudy. This crash occurred on a weekday evening.\n\nV1, a 1996 Plymouth Voyager minivan, was attempting to make a  westbound left turn, from the side road, onto the two lane undivided roadway. The driver stated he got halfway out and stopped, assuming the other vehicle would go around him. V2, a 2005 Nissan Altima heading east impacted with the drivers side of V1, with its front.\n\nThe Plymouth Voyager was driven by a belted 89 year old male who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released. The driver stated he thought the other vehicle was far enough away. It should be noted here that the driver takes prescription medications for high blood pressure and two pain killing medications, for a back injury,  which state drowsiness as a possible side effect.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was: This Vehicle Traveling Turning Left at Intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor Decision Error, False Assumptioin of Other\'s Actions.\n\nThe Nissan Altima was driven by a belted 30 year old female and there were two passengers in this vehicle, a belted 34 year old male and an young child in a child restraint. All three passengers in this vehicle were transported to an area hospital, although the child was not injured. The driver and other passenger were treated and released. This driver did not answer requests for interviews.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was: Other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction. No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.\n\nPolice did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor and ordered no tests for either driver\n

preprocessing
\n\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 35 MPH (48 KPH).  This was an "S" type roadway. The first curve was to the left with a radius of curvature of 225 meters and no superelevation which entered a curve to the right with a radius of curvature of 113 meters and a superelevation of 2.5%.  There were no warning signs.  It was raining, the roadway was wet and it was daylight at the time of this weekend afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 1990 Mazda MX6, was traveling south on the two-lane roadway.  V1 entered the curve to the left and began to rotate counterclockwise.  Operator of V1 braked and corrected to the left.  V1 began to rotate clockwise and operator braked and corrected to the right.  V1 went off the right side of the roadway and struck a 90 cm diameter tree with its front.  V1 rotated clockwise and came to rest facing in a westerly direction.  V1 was towed due to damage. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Mazda MX6 (V1) was driven by a 17 year old male who was not injured.  A 17-year-old female passenger in the right front seat was transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  Both occupants were wearing 2-point automatic belts; neither was using the lap belt.  Driver stated that he had just picked up a loaf of bread at a local grocery store and was going home.  He stated that he was traveling 40 MPH when he entered the first turn and that the rear of the vehicle slid to the right.  He attempted to correct by braking, steering left and then right, but ran off the road and hit a tree.  He advised that he had been driving for 15 months, did not have any driver training, but was very comfortable with the vehicle.  He stated he was in good health, did not wear corrective lenses and took no medications.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling too fast for conditions.  This was chosen because it was raining and he stated he was traveling 40 MPH in a posted 35 MPH zone.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was overcompensation.  This was chosen because the driver over steered to the right.  Police indicated unsafe speed and slippery road surface as contributing factors to this crash. An associated factor for this driver may be driver inexperience since he had only been driving 15 months. \n\n\n\n

\nThis crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway, slightly curving to the right, with radius of 375 meters and a super-elevation of 6.3%.  The posted speed limit was 72KMPH (45MPH). The side roadway from which V2 was traveling was a two lane undivided roadway curving to the left with a radius of  94 meters and a super elevation of  4.4%. The roadways were dry and the weather was cloudy. This crash occurred on a  weekday evening.\n\nV1, 2002 Toyota Sienna, was traveling west on the two lane undivided roadway negotiating the curve when it impacted with the left side of V2, a 2000 Subaru Forester, with it\'s front.\n\nThe Toyota Sienna, (V1) was driven by a belted 41year old male who was not injured. The driver stated he thought the other vehicle would wait at its stop sign and not pull out in front of him. The driver stated he steered to his right and braked but was unable to avoid impact.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event coded to this vehicle was Other  vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction. No Critical Reason for Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe Subaru Forester (V2) was driven by a belted 74 year old male who refused medical attention and was not injured  The driver stated he was making a left turn from a side road onto the two lane undivided roadway after stopping at a stop sign for 1-2 seconds. The driver stated he thought V1 was further back on the roadway and he would have time to pull out safely. The driver further stated his left front window was fogged over and he couldn\'t see V1 clearly. It should be noted here that this driver has an unspecified heart condition for which he takes medication and also takes medication for high cholesterol.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event coded to this vehicle was This vehicle turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as Driver Related Error Decision Error Misjudgment of Gap or Other\'s Speed.\n\n Police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be a factor and ordered no tests for either driver.\n

\n\nThis crash occurred on a 4 lane positively divided roadway as the roadway went from four lanes to two lanes going from a precrash grade of -3.7%  to a 3.8% grade. The roadway slightly curved to the left as the lanes reduced and then curved further to the left. The superelevation was .2%. The roadway was wet and it was raining. This crash occurred on a weekday night.\n\nV1, a 2003 Honda S2000 Convertible , was traveling north in lane two passing uninvolved vehicles prior to the road reduction. After the roadway reduction, V1 went off the roadway to the right, impacted with an delineator with it\'s front, riding up a down turned end of a guardrail, vehicle started to roll to the right and went airborne, striking large branch before landing, as it rolled over two \xc2\xbc turns, slid backwards down an embankment over  several downed trees, coming to final rest on its roof facing up the embankment in a northwest direction. The embankment at the area of the rollover was negative 48%. The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1, a belted 46 year old male, was pronounced dead at the scene.\nInterviews with a surrogate and a witness revealed the driver normally drove a bit fast and was trying to pass the uninvolved vehicles before the roadway narrowed.  The surrogate stated this driver was not known to have any prior physical conditions and did not take prescription medications nor did he wear prescription glasses.\n\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was: This Vehicle Traveling Off the Edge of the Road on the Right Side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Driver Related Factor Decision Errors, Too fast for Curve.\n\nThe Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash.\n

This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway with a slight curve to the left prior to the crash site. The roadway was level  and the posted speed limit was 72KMPH (45MPH) It was raining and the roadway was wet at the time of the crash. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1  a 2005 Subaru Forrester was traveling east on the two lane roadway when the driver lost control of the vehicle and overcompensated his steering, going off the roadway to the right and impacting with a utility pole. The top of the utility pole then broke off and contacted with the top of V1. \n\nThe Subaru Forrester, (V1) was driven by a belted 83 year old male who refused treatment at the scene. The driver stated he felt the back end of his vehicle \xe2\x80\x9chydroplaning\xe2\x80\x9d, going to the right and so he steered left, then right in a effort to correct it, and went off the road. It should be noted here that the driver takes prescription medication for gout and a diuretic for high blood pressure. This driver also walks with a cane on his left side.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was: This Vehicle loss of control due to traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: Driver Related Factor: Traveling too fast for a wet road condition.\n\n\nThe Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor in this crash and ordered not tests for this driver. \n\n

This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway which curved to the left with a radius of 194 meters and a superelevation of 4.9%. The posted speed limit was 72KMPH (45MPH) with a recommended speed limit of 48(KMPH (30MPH) for this curve. The roadway was dry and the weather was cloudy. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1997 Pontiac Grand Prix was traveling south negotiating the curve to the left when it went off the west side of the roadway partially onto the shoulder. The driver then overcorrected and departed the roadway on the east side, rolling over  \xc2\xbc turn and coming to rest on its right side facing east. \n\nThe Pontiac Grand Prix (V1) was driven by a belted 16 year old female refused treatment for a non-incapacitating injury. The driver stated she \'hit black ice\' and went off the roadway, however, no \'black ice\' was found at the scene. It should be noted here that this driver is still enrolled in a driver\'s education course and is considered to be inexperienced. This driver has no medical conditions and takes no prescription medications.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was: This Vehicle Traveling Off the Edge of the Road on the Right Side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: Driver Related Factor Poor Directional Control (failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected).\n\nThe Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor and ordered no tests for this driver.\n

preprocessing
This crash occurred in the eastbound lanes (two lanes head east and one heads west) of a three lane undivided, straight roadway in an urban-like setting where the posted speed limit is 48kmph (30mph).  The roadway was dry and the weather was clear. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1991 Chrysler New Yorker, was traveling east when it stopped in lane two (the left turn lane) awaiting traffic to pass before turning into a fast food restaurant.  V2, a 1990 Nissan Pick-up, truck was leaving a service station on the east side of the road.\nV2 was \xe2\x80\x9cwaived\xe2\x80\x9d out of the lot by the driver of an uninvolved vehicle stopped in lane one of the roadway.  As V2 proceeded out of the lot it was struck by the front left of V1.  The driver and a passenger of V1 were transported to an area hospital, treated and released. Another passenger in V1 was not injured. The driver of V2 was not injured.  \n\nV1 was driven by a belted 58 year-old female who claimed to be in good health despite a history of diabetes, which is treated by medication.  She was wearing her prescription lenses that correct a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  The driver of V1 stated she had seen the truck coming at her but had no place to go. She, therefore, put her hands over her face and closed her eyes, having already had her foot on the brake pedal. The airbag of this vehicle deployed and the vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded other vehicle encroachment from driveway, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors include possible inattention as she was conversing with her passenger as well as focusing on approaching traffic as she was waiting to make a left turn.  Another recognition was factor was coded as the impending problem was masked by the rush hour traffic.\n\nV2 was driven by a belted 26 year-old male in good health and traveling home after running a few errands.  This driver stated he was looking first at the driver who \'waived\' him out and then looked to his right for on-coming traffic. He stated he did not see V1 until \xe2\x80\x9cthat car hit me\xe2\x80\x9d.  This vehicle was not towed, however, it was pushed back into the parking lot when its battery went dead.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for Critical Precrash Event was coded as an other recognition error, impending problem masked by traffic flow pattern, as the driver of V2 could not see around the traffic in lane to view the traffic in lane two.  The associated factors for this crash include inattention as the driver was focused on approaching traffic as well dealing with the same rush hour traffic V1 was dealing with.
