preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound lanes of a straight, level three-lane divided interstate (6 lanes total) with a posted speed limit of 105 KPH (65 MPH).  There were two southbound lanes and an acceleration lane at the crash site.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early morning weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1997 Honda Civic, was traveling south in the passing lane (lane 3) of the interstate.  A non-contact vehicle moved into the path of V1 from the right.  The operator of V1 attempted to avoid the non-contact vehicle by steering to the right.  V1 began to rotate clockwise and across the driving and acceleration lanes.  V1 continued off the right side of the roadway striking a delineator with its left side and then striking a rock embankment with its front.  V1 continued to rotate clockwise, came back on the roadway and came to rest facing in a northwesterly direction.\n\n     The Honda Civic (V1) was driven by a belted 34-year old female who was transported, treated and hospitalized for a complaint of pain.  No interview was obtained. She stated (in the medical) that she was driving in the daytime when another driver cut in front of her and in an attempt to avoid an accident she swerved.  There was no additional information available.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to her traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as overcompensation, a performance error.  This was chosen because the driver overreacted to the situation by steering too abruptly to the right.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of an unidentified allergy pill. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. \n\n     \n
../resources/summary/2005002585063.json
preprocessing
   \n The crash occurred on a two-lane undivided level roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KPH (55 MPH).  V1 was negotiating a curve to the right with a superelevation of 4%.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this early afternoon weekend crash.\n\nV1, a 1988 Nissan Maxima, was traveling north on the two-lane undivided roadway negotiating the curve to the right.  The operator of V1 observed a non-contact vehicle in her lane slowing or stopping.  Operator of V1 braked and steered to the left in an attempt to avoid the non-contact vehicle.  V1 began to rotate counterclockwise, corrected right and then began to rotate clockwise.  V1 continued across the southbound lane and off the left side of the roadway striking a 48 cm diameter tree with its left side.  V1 rotated counterclockwise and came to rest facing in a westerly direction.\n\nThe Nissan Maxima (V1) was driven by a belted 26-year-old female who was airlifted to a trauma center with severe bleeding to the head.  The belted 5-year-old front seat passenger was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for minor bleeding to the head. The PAR indicated unsafe speed as a contributing factor.  There was no additional information available.  V1 was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Pre Event Movement for V1 was negotiating a curve; the Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was a loss of control due to traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was the overcompensation in steering by the driver, a performance error.  This was chosen because the driver overreacted to the situation steering abruptly to the left.   Excess speed and aggressive driving were coded as associated factors. No interview was obtained; therefore no additional associative factors could be determined.\n
../resources/summary/2005002585103.json
preprocessing
\n     The crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway curving to the right, with a posted speed limit of 89KPH (55MPH) and a -8.9% grade. There was a four-leg intersection at the bottom of the hill. The intersecting roadway was a two lane undivided roadway controlled by stop signs for both east and west directions.  The weather was clear, the roadway was dry and it was dark, but lighted at the time of this early evening weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1997 Jeep Grand Cherokee, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway, negotiating a curve to the right on a downgrade and approaching the intersection. It should be noted that there was a black on yellow intersection warning sign with flashing yellow beacons and a 56KPH (35MPH) suggested speed limit sign 177.7 meters before the intersection. An uninvolved passenger van entered the intersection from the west and pulled into the path of V1.  V1 braked and steered to the left, going through the intersection and struck a box beam guardrail on the southeast corner, with its front. V1 dislodged the guardrail from its posts and rotated counterclockwise one-quarter turn to the left, continued off the road and was stopped from rolling down a 50ft steep embankment by the guardrail. V1 came to rest facing in an easterly direction.\n\n     The Jeep Cherokee (V1) was driven by a belted 32 year old male who was not injured.  An unsecured 90 lb black Labrador retriever was also in the vehicle and uninjured. This driver had been driving for one and a half hours (1 \xc2\xbd) since the beginning of this trip. He had driven 90 miles prior to the crash. The driver indicated that he was familiar with the vehicle and denied any inattention or distractions.   No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Jeep.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when V1 traveled off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as traveling too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users.  This was coded because the driver failed use caution when approaching the intersection and was traveling too fast, by failing to heed the warning sign. No other associated factors were coded to the driver of this vehicle.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The uninvolved vehicle was driven by a male in his 30\'s, who stated he had just awaken from a nap as he had only 4 \xc2\xbd hours sleep the previous evening. He was a client in an alcohol rehabilitation center and was driving that agency\'s van to pick up another client.  He also indicated that he was not very familiar with the area.  He stated he had stopped at the stop sign, and then continued into the intersection. He had not observed the approaching Jeep Cherokee and was only made aware of it when a passenger in the van called to him to \'look out\'.  It should be noted that V1 was black.\n\n\n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005002585142.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway curving to the right, with a posted speed limit of  89KPH (55MPH) and a -2.5% grade.  Many driveways for retail establishments intersect the roadway.  It should be noted that there was a black on yellow curve warning sign with a suggested speed limit of 72 KPH (45 MPH) prior to the curve. The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekday morning.  \n\n     V1, a 2003 Honda Element, was traveling south on the two lane undivided roadway when it stopped to allow northbound traffic to pass before making a left turn into a driveway.  V2, a 1997 Ford Thunderbird XL, was traveling on the same two lane undivided roadway, in the same direction behind V1. V2 impacted the rear of V1 with its front. Both vehicles came to rest in the roadway facing south.    \n\n     The Honda Element (V1) was driven by a belted 43 year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released for a complaint of pain to her neck. No interview was obtained, unable to contact driver of V1 and no further information is available.  V1 was driven from the scene.\n   \n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when another vehicle was in her lane traveling in the same direction at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. The driver of the Honda Element was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  There is no evidence of any drug use legal or illegal by this driver.\n\n     The Ford Thunderbird (V2) was driven by a belted 71-year-old male who reported no injuries. There was a belted 70-year-old female passenger in the right front seat who had a complaint of pain to her head, but refused medical transport.  Both the driver and passenger airbags were deployed.  It should be noted that there was a handicap card hanging from the rearview mirror.  The driver indicated that he was familiar with the road and denied any inattention or distractions.  He indicated that he never speeds and was going the suggested speed limit of 72 KPH (45 MPH).  The driver was wearing his glasses at the time, but does not know his corrected vision.  Driver refused to give any information regarding current medications.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other motor vehicle in lane stopped.\nThe Critical Reason for the Critical Event was too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users, a decision error.  This was chosen because this driver saw the stopped vehicle, braked and skidded approximately 22 meters before it struck V1.  Had V2 been traveling the suggested speed, anticipated other\'s actions (is familiar with road) there would have been ample time to slow or stop to avoid the collision.  No other reason was attributed to V2 as the driver refused to give further medical information (pre-existing conditions or medications).  The police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests for either driver.    \n
../resources/summary/2005002585183.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway, slightly curving to the right prior to the crash site, with no grade and a posted speed limit of  72 KMPH (45 MPH). The weather was clear and the roadway was dry. This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 1998 Honda Accord, was traveling north on the two lane undivided roadway when it stopped to allow several  southbound vehicles  to pass before proceeding to make an intended left turn onto a side road. V2, a 1994 Ford Escort LX, was traveling in the same direction behind V1. V2 impacted the rear of V1 with it\'s front. Both vehicles came to rest in the roadway facing north.\n\nThe Honda Accord (V1) was driven by a belted  37 year old female who was transported to an area hospital, treated and released, with a complaint of pain to her neck.  She stated that she was stopped, waiting for the on coming traffic to clear before she made her left turn.  Just as she glanced at her rear view mirror she saw V2 coming at her fast.  The driver of V2 was not slowing down and then she heard brakes and she gripped the steering wheel, and then she was hit from behind.  The driver of this vehicle was wearing prescription contacts at the time of the crash.  V1 was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle. The driver of the V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash. There is no evidence of any illegal drug use, however the driver stated she takes an antihistamine for allergies. \n\nThe Ford Escort LX, (V2) was driven by a belted 44 year old male who was uninjured. . The driver of V2 stated he was showing his girlfriend the trees in the area, as she was from out of town, and he was looking to the right at times. He stated he did see V1 stopped in the roadway too late, tried to stop but didn\'t have enough time to stop. A passenger in the vehicle, an unbelted female, was transported to an area hospital, treated and released, for a minor head injury from impacting with the dashboard as stated by the driver. V2 was towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was other motor vehicle in lane other vehicle stopped. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as external distraction.  It should be noted here that this driver is taking multiple medications for an immune deficiency disease. The police did not consider illegal drugs to be involved and ordered not tests for either driver.
../resources/summary/2005002585184.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound center lane of a three lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KMPH (55 MPH).  There were two lanes southbound with a right turn only lane into a side road.  The roadway curved to the left with a radius of 225 meters and a superelevation of 3.2%. The roadway had a -2.3% grade. There were numerous highway signs advising that the roadway ahead was closed.  There was also a large illuminated sign at the road closure itself.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 1993 Chevrolet Blazer, was traveling south in the center (straight) lane approaching the intersection.  A large box truck pulled out from the intersecting street to turn left and in doing so blocked the \xe2\x80\x9cRoad Closed\xe2\x80\x9d sign from the driver of V1\'s view.  As the box truck completed the turn, the driver of V1 observed the sign, braked and steered right.  V1 went off the right side of the roadway rotating clockwise and struck a w-beam guardrail with its front.  V1 continued through the guardrail, struck a highway sign post and rolled over to the left 3-quarter turns down an embankment. V1 came to rest on its right side facing west.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Chevrolet Blazer (V1) was driven by a belted 43 year old female who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital.  She stated that she had just left work and was on her way to a weekly appointment.  She was traveling at the posted speed limit of 89 KMPH (55 MPH) and was not in a hurry.  She had not driven the road since the flood and had missed her last four scheduled appointments.  She recalled that she had heard that the road was closed, but did not see any signs before the crash, only at the last second. The driver stated that a large box truck blocked the large \xe2\x80\x9croad closed\xe2\x80\x9d sign and it was only after it completed its turn that she saw it. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was inadequate surveillance, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver stated she did not see any \xe2\x80\x9croad closed\xe2\x80\x9d signs, yet there were several prior to the detour.  It is also possible that this driver may have been thinking about her scheduled appointment and inattentive to the driving task.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription and non-prescription medications.  She was taking four medications: (a) female replacement hormones, (b) vitamins, (c) aspirin and (d) a natural herbal supplement.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.
../resources/summary/2005002585224.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the northbound lane of a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 40 MPH (64KPH).  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 2002 Acura MDX, was parked off the right side of the roadway in an unimproved area used by a business for parking.  V2, a 1992 GMC Vandura designated as a school bus, was traveling north on the two lane undivided roadway.  V1 entered the roadway from the right into path of V2 to execute an illegal U-turn.  V2 braked and steered left to avoid a collision.  V2 struck V1 in left side with its front.  V2 came to rest facing in a northwesterly direction.  V1 was rotated slightly clockwise and came to rest facing in a northerly direction.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Acura MDX (V1) was driven by a belted 51 year old male who was treated at the scene for a laceration to his arm.  He stated that he had stopped to pick up lunch for his co-workers and was going to make a U-turn to return to work.  He stated that he had glanced at the traffic light (behind him) and thought it was red.  He also stated that he had looked, but didn\'t see the bus.  He estimated that he was traveling less than 10 MPH at the time of impact and made no avoidance maneuvers.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was inadequate surveillance, failed to look, looked but did not see, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver stated that he had looked all around prior to the crash, but didn\'t look hard enough.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of three prescription medications: (a) a blood pressure medication, (b) a stomach acid medication and (c) an unknown medication.  He was wearing contact lenses and over the counter sunglasses at the time of the crash.  \n\n     The GMC Vandura school bus (V2) was driven by a belted 41-year-old female who sustained no injuries.  She stated that she had slowed as she approached the traffic light, but it turned green so she did not come to a complete stop and continued. It should be noted that the traffic light is 30+ meters prior to the crash. She was aware of the vehicles that park on the side of the road by the deli and used caution when passing by.  She was traveling approximately 25-30 MPH. She observed V1 as it entered the roadway and braked, steered right and honked her horn to avoid the collision. V2 was towed due to damage. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the encroachment of the other vehicle from a parking lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of a prescription medication.  She was taking a heart medication for a previous heart attack in 2003.  She was wearing her prescription eyeglasses for both near and far sightedness.  The driver of the school bus was not thought to have contributed to the crash.

preprocessing
The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 55 MPH (89 KPH).  The road was curved left with a radius of curvature of 375 meters and a superelevation of 1.8% for V2. The road was curved right with a radius of curvature of 1875 meters and no superelevation for V1.  Both vehicles had black on yellow curve warning signs with a suggested speed of 50 MPH.  The weather was cloudy.\n\n     V1, a 2000 Chevrolet Cavalier, was traveling west on the two-lane roadway negotiating a curve to the right approaching a driveway.  V2, a 1995 Dodge Intrepid, was traveling east on the same roadway negotiating the curve to the left.  V1 attempted a left hand turn into the driveway and was struck in the front by V2\'s front.  V1 was rotated counterclockwise back across both lanes and came to rest in the westbound lane facing east.  V2 continued off the right side of the roadway, came back on the roadway crossed both lanes, off the north side of the road and struck a 25cm pole with its front.  V2 came to rest facing in a northerly direction.  Both vehicles were towed due to damage. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Chevrolet Cavalier (V1) was driven by a belted 80 year old male who was transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  The right front seat passenger was a belted 72-year-old female who was also transported, treated and released for minor injuries. Both driver and passenger airbags deployed. The interview was refused and no information obtained from the driver. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an unknown type of driver error.  This was coded because there was no further information available.  It is possible that the driver may have been inattentive because his wife was in the vehicle, misjudged the gap distance of the other vehicle or made a false assumption.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  He was taking two medications: (a)  a diuretic, with a possible side effect of drowsiness and (b) a beta-adrenergic blocking agent, with mild to no side effects known. It should also be noted that the medical indicated that the driver had consumed an alcoholic beverage 1-\xc2\xbd hours prior to the crash. \n\n     The Dodge Intrepid  (V2) was driven by a belted 29-year-old female who was transported, treated and released for minor injuries. There was no interview and no information obtained from the driver.  No other associated factors were coded to this driver.     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded Other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line. No Critical Reason was coded to the driver of the Intrepid and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

The crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 45 MPH (72 KPH).  The roadway curved to the right with a radius of 81.06 meters and a superelevation of 1.6%.  The roadway had a downgrade of  -6.7%.  There was a black-on-yellow curve warning sign with an advisory speed of 30 MPH more than one-quarter mile prior to the crash site.  It was cloudy, the roadway wet and it was daylight at the time of this early morning weekend crash.\n\n     V1, a 2004 Nissan X-terra, was traveling in a northerly direction on the two-lane roadway negotiating a curve to the right on a downgrade.  V1 went off the right side of the roadway rotating slightly clockwise and struck a rock embankment with its front.  V1 continued up the embankment a short distance and began to roll over to the left.  V1 came back onto the roadway, continued to roll over two more quarter turns and came to rest on its passenger side in the southbound lane facing in a northerly direction.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Nissan X-terra was driven by a belted 33-year old female who was transported, treated and released from a local hospital for minor injuries.  She reported that she had seen the black-on-yellow warning sign and was traveling between 31-40 MPH, although the advisory speed was 30 MPH.  She also stated that she had thought of her friend who always drove slowly down the mountain.  It should be noted that she rarely drove this road and was not used to its curvy nature.  Also, she reported that she had been driving this vehicle less than one year and may not have had sufficient experience.  Information obtained from emergency personnel indicated that the driver had been out all night with friends, slept little and was on her way home from a friend\'s house when the crash occurred.  \n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was traveling too fast for the curve, a decision error.  This was chosen because the driver stated she was traveling 31-40 MPH and the police indicated unsafe speed.  Associated factors coded to this driver were possible fatigue, alcohol presence and insufficient braking and steering inputs.  In addition, a roadway-related factor was coded because the measured radius of the curve did not meet AASHTO design standards. The posted speed limit should have been no more than 25 mph. Police indicated alcohol involvement and issued a citation to the driver of V1.  The results of the alcohol test were not made available.\n

The crash occurred on a two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 55 MPH (89 KPH).  The roadway was straight with a grade of -2.3%.  There was a black on yellow \xe2\x80\x9cY\xe2\x80\x9d intersection warning sign for both vehicles.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday afternoon crash.  \n\n     V1, a 1997 Plymouth Neon, was traveling north on the two lane roadway approaching the intersection.  V2, a 1987 Ford F-350 stake body, was stopped facing north waiting to make a left hand turn.  V1 struck V2 in rear with front.  Both vehicles came to rest facing north.  V1 was towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Plymouth Neon (V1) was driven by a belted 76 year old female who was transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  Both airbags deployed.  She stated to police that she did not realize that V2 was stopped.  She attempted to brake, but not in time to avoid the collision.  There was no interview obtained and no further information available.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was other motor vehicle in lane stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed, a decision error.  This was chosen because of the driver\'s statement that she did not realize the other vehicle was stopped.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  She was taking three medications: (a) a high blood pressure medication with possible side effects of dizziness, tiredness or headaches, (b) a calcium channel blocker with possible side effects of dizziness, light-headedness and headaches and (c) a beta-adrenergic blocking agent with relatively uncommon or mild side effects.  \n\n     The Ford F350 stake body (V2) was driven by a belted 40 year old male who was treated at a local hospital the following day for shoulder pain.  The belted 18 year old male passenger complained of pain, but declined medical attention.  The driver stated that he was stopped with his directional on for approximately 1 minute waiting for traffic to clear prior to making a left hand turn.  He advised that he caught the movement of V1 just prior to impact in his side mirror, but was unable to take any avoidance maneuvers.  He also stated that he was not in a hurry, had just finished lunch and was going to look at a vehicle with his passenger. He does not wear corrective lenses and does not take any type of medications.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no additional associated factors coded to this driver.\n\n\n

The road was curved slightly left with a radius of curvature of 2,812 meters and no superelevation.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekday afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 1996 Buick Skylark, was traveling south on the two-lane roadway negotiating the slight curve.  V1 drove off the right side of the roadway, down a slight slope and struck a telephone pole guide wire anchor with its front.  V1 rotated counterclockwise and came to rest facing east.  V1 was towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. \n\n     The Buick Skylark (V1) was driven by a belted 19 year old male who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for minor injuries.  The driver was unable to be contacted for additional information.  The medical indicated that the driver said "he realized that he was going to hit the telephone pole, swerved and hit side guard" and also stated during interview that "maybe he should have hit the pole."\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was unknown type of driver error.  This was chosen because there was no additional information available, however, from scene evidence there were no braking or avoidance maneuvers indicated.  It should be noted that the medical indicated that the driver had a history of seizures and asthma, but he denied taking any type of medications.  \n\n\n

The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 89 KMPH (55 MPH).  The roadway was curved with a radius of curvature of 563 meters and a superelevation of 2.8%.  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1992 Toyota 4-Runner, was traveling south on the two-lane roadway negotiating the curve to the right.  V2, a 2005 Freightliner School Bus, was traveling north on the same roadway negotiating the curve to the left.  V1 crossed the centerline into the northbound lane.  V2 attempted to steer right onto the paved shoulder to avoid the collision.  V1 continued across the northbound lane onto the paved shoulder and struck V2\'s front with its front.  V1 came to rest facing in a southeasterly direction on the east shoulder and V2 came to rest facing in a northerly direction.  Both vehicles were towed due to damage.\n\n     The Toyota 4-Runner (V1) was driven by a belted 27 year old male who received minor bruises, but refused medical treatment.  He stated that as he was negotiating the curve at approximately 64-72 KMPH (40-45 MPH), when his truck pulled to the left and he thought it might have been a wind gust.  He attempted to steer back into his lane, but the steering wheel would not turn.  He was unable to return to his lane and continued to drift into the opposing lane.  He observed the bus coming toward him, but was only able to brake in an attempt to avoid the collision.  The truck left approximately 17 meters of pre-impact skids.  The police issued him a citation for failure to keep right.  He stated that he took no medications and did not wear corrective lenses.  He indicated that he had gotten off work early and was not in a hurry. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane.  The Critcal Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was steering failure, a vehicle related factor.  This was chosen because the driver stated he was unable to straighten the vehicle to return to his proper lane.  No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\n     The 2005 Freightliner School Bus (V2) was driven by a belted 61-year-old male who received a minor injury to his knee, but refused medical treatment.  There were 5 additional unbelted occupants in the bus, none of which sustained any injuries.  The driver stated that he was on a work related trip, saw the other vehicle drift into his lane, moved as far right as possible, but was unable to avoid the collision.  There was no additional information obtained because the driver could not be re-contacted.  \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n\n     \n

\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 56 KPH (35 MPH).  The road was slightly curved to the left with a radius of curvature of 5,625 meters. There were no curve warning signs present. The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this late afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1992 Chrysler LeBaron, was traveling west negotiating the slight curve to the left and approaching a sharp curve to the left with a small hillcrest.  V1 entered the sharp curve, went off the right side of the roadway and struck a 40 cm diameter tree with its front.  V1 came to rest facing in a westerly direction.  V1 was towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Chrysler LeBaron (V1) was driven by a belted 17 year old male who was transported, treated and released for a minor head contusion.  The belted right front seat 15 year old passenger and belted right seat rear 17 year old passenger were also transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  The driver stated that he had been driving over the center of the roadway and another car was coming the other way.  He said the other driver started \xe2\x80\x9cscreaming and cursing\xe2\x80\x9d at him and he thought that he would \xe2\x80\x9ccome after me\xe2\x80\x9d so he sped up (indicating that he was traveling at 82-97 KMPH (51-60 MPH)) and the lost control.  He also stated that he was in good health, did not wear corrective lenses and took no medications.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was decision error - inadequate evasive action.  This was chosen because the driver stated he drove the road rarely and was in the center of the roadway when he initiated a braking maneuver, however drove straight off the roadway striking the tree. An associated factor coded to this driver was that he failed to look far enough ahead and did not realize that caution was required.  It should also be noted that the driver had only had his license for two weeks and had been driving less than one year.  He also had two friends in the car and they were going to a friend\'s house so there was the probability of inattention.  The police indicated that the driver was inexperienced and was traveling at an unsafe speed. \n

\n\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 30 MPH (48 KPH).  It was raining, the roadway was wet and it was dark, but lighted at the time of this weekday evening crash.\n\n     V1, a 1990 Buick Century, was traveling east on a one-way street with a posted speed limit of 25 MPH (40 KPH) going the wrong way.  V1 had failed to comply with police and attempted to elude them. V1 approached a \xe2\x80\x9cT\xe2\x80\x9d intersection with no controls for this direction.  V1 entered the intersection, crossed both north and southbound lanes and struck a parked vehicle in the left side with its front.  V1 came to rest facing east in the northbound lane.  The parked vehicle, a 1994 Chrysler LHS, which was legally parked in a designated parking lane, was rotated counterclockwise and struck the curb with its right side.  The parked vehicle continued to rotate, struck a light pole with its right side and came to rest facing in a northwesterly direction. Both vehicles were towed due to damage.  \n\n     The Buick Century (V1) was driven by an unbelted 47 year-old male, who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital for minor injuries. He stated that he  was traveling down a one way street and hit a parked car.  He stated that he was attempting to turn right at the intersection and braked in an attempt to avoid the crash.  He stated he did not wear corrective lenses.  No additional information was obtained due to driver being incarcerated.   \n\n     The Chrysler LHS was occupied by an unbelted 39-year-old male, who was transported, treated and released at a local hospital.  This person could not be located and no further information was obtained.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling, end departure.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was too fast for conditions.  This was chosen because the driver was eluding police, going down a one-way street the wrong way at a high rate of speed and it was raining.  Police considered alcohol to be a factor and issued a citation.  \n\n\n

\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a suggested speed limit of 25 MPH (40 KPH).  This suggested speed limit was for construction work on the roadway and indicated by black on orange warning signs, regulatory signs were covered.  There were also black on yellow warning signs at either end of the roadway indicating "no shoulder". The roadway curved to the left with a radius of curvature of 625 meters.  It should be noted that the roadway had been newly paved and had 8 cm to 15 cm lip edge. The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of the early morning weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1987 Volvo 740, was traveling north on the roadway negotiating the curve to the left.  V1 drove off the right side of the roadway and struck an unknown diameter pole, shearing same with its front.  V1 continued, crossed a driveway and came back on the roadway striking the 15 cm roadway lip.  V1 rotated counterclockwise across both lanes and came to rest facing west.  V1 was towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Volvo (V1) was driven by a belted 33 year old male who was treated at the scene for a minor injury.  The driver was taken into custody and no further information was obtained because the driver could not be contacted or located.   \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was unknown critical non-performance, a driver related factor.  This was chosen because there was no additional information available, but the police indicated "fatigued/drowsy". \n\n\n\n     \n

preprocessing
\n\n     The crash occurred on a level four lane undivided roadway at a four-leg intersection controlled by a traffic signal.  The posted speed limit was 35 MPH (56 KPH).  It was raining, the roadway was wet and it was daylight at the time of this weekday morning crash.\n\n     V1, a 1998 Ford Contour, was traveling west exiting a parking lot driveway controlled by a flashing red light.  V2, a 2000 Dodge Durango, was traveling north in the second lane of the main road approaching the intersection.  V1 entered the intersection to turn left and was struck in the left side by the front of V2.  V1 was rotated counterclockwise, across the southbound lanes and came to rest off the road facing in a southeasterly direction.  V2 drove off the road to the right and stopped in a parking lot.  Both vehicles were towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Ford Contour (V1) was driven by a belted 69 year old female who was transported, treated for fractured ribs and released from a local hospital.  She stated that she had just left the feed store and was waiting to pull out to make a left hand turn.  She indicated that she had been stopped for more than 10 seconds prior to proceeding and waited until other traffic had a red light as she always did.  She stated that other vehicles had stopped, but the vehicle that hit her didn\'t. She stated she wore glasses for myopic (near-sighted) and hyperopic (far-sighted) conditions. She had a hearing deficiency and was wearing a hearing aid at the time of the crash.  She considered herself in fair health.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was false assumption of other\'s actions.  This was chosen because her statement "all the other cars stopped" led her to believe he would stop also.  It should be noted that this driver had a flashing red light; while the main road had steady lights and it is possible the light had just changed for V2.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  She was taking twelve medications: (a) a calcium channel blocker with possible side effects of dizziness, (b) a beta blocker with mild or uncommon side effects, (c) 2 high blood pressure medications with possible side effects of drowsiness, dizziness or fatigue, (d) a allergy medication with possible side effects of drowsiness or fatigue, (e) a cholesterol medication, (f) 2 stomach medications, (g) a pain medication with the possible side effect of drowsiness, (h) an anti-depressant with possible side effects of sedation, blurred vision, confusion and sensitivity to bright light, (i) a glaucoma medication with a possible side effect of blurred vision and (j) an unknown medication.\n\n     The Dodge Durango (V2) was driven by a belted 61-year-old male who was not injured.  The right front seat belted 62-year-old male passenger also was not injured.  Since this driver did not speak English limited information was obtained through a friend.  He indicated that he had been traveling at a normal speed for the roadway and that "she came out of nowhere".  He attempted to brake, but it was too late.  He was in good health, wore corrective lenses for an unknown condition and took no medications.  \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroaching from a driveway turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  It is possible that since this vehicle was traveling in the second lane approaching the intersection that traffic had been stopped in the right lane masking this driver\'s view of V1 as he entered the intersection.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver of the Durango and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n     \n\n\n

Case Summary 02-2005-052\n\n     The crash occurred on a level four lane undivided roadway at a four-leg intersection controlled by a traffic signal.  The posted speed limit was 35 MPH (56 KPH). The roadway for V2 was slightly curved to the right with a radius of curvature of 1,125 meters. The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this afternoon weekday crash.\n\n     V1, a 1991 Dodge Dynasty, was traveling north in the second straight/left turn lane approaching the intersection.  V2, a 1992 Mazda 626, was traveling south in the right hand lane approaching the same intersection. Both vehicles had a green light. V1 stopped waiting for traffic to clear prior to making the left hand turn.  V1 proceeded to make the left turn and struck V2 in its front with front.  V1 drove off the road into a driveway.  V2 continued a short distance and came to rest facing in a southerly direction in its original lane.  V2 was towed due to damage.  Police did not consider either alcohol or drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The Dodge Dynasty (V1) was driven by a belted 71 year old female who had a bruise to her right forearm from the deployed airbag, but refused treatment.  She stated that she was on an errand for her grandson at her anticipated destination.  She stated that she had stopped waiting for traffic to clear before making the left, thought she had a green light at the time as she made the turn.  As she proceeded to make the turn, she indicated that she saw the other vehicle \xe2\x80\x9cout of the corner of her eye\xe2\x80\x9d at the last second, but the other vehicle was \xe2\x80\x9cright there\xe2\x80\x9d and she was unable to avoid the crash. She also stated that she had just accelerated from a stop and was traveling no more than 5-10 MPH.  She indicated that the other vehicle was traveling pretty fast and that she never saw her until she was right there.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that this vehicle was traveling, turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Even was inadequate surveillance, failed to look, looked but did not see, a recognition error.  This was chosen because the driver stated that she never saw V2 until she was right there.  An associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription and non-prescription medications:  (a) a blood pressure medication, (b) a diabetic medication, (c) an asthma medication, (d) a pain reliever and (e) 2 unknown additional medications.  The driver did not wear corrective lenses nor have a hearing impairment.\n\n     The Mazda 626 (V2) was driven by a belted 32-year-old female who was not injured.  She stated, \xe2\x80\x9cShe pulled in front of me\xe2\x80\x9d.  No additional information was obtained due to the driver being unable to be contacted or located.  \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005002585724.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a weekday afternoon in an intersection between two, two lane undivided, bituminous roadways.  The East/West roadway was dry and straight with a posted speed limit of 89kmph (55mph) and a -2% grade.  This roadway had a black on yellow intersection warning with flashing yellow beacon with a suggested speed of 72kmph (45mph) prior to the intersection.  The North/South roadway was a dry, level roadway with a posted speed limit of 72kmph (45mph) and was controlled by a stop sign.  There was also a flashing signal, yellow for the main roadway and red for the cross street.  \n\nV1, a 1993 Chevrolet Prizm, was stopped in the northbound lane for the stop sign and flashing red beacon.  V2, a 2001 Jeep Wrangler, was westbound approaching the same intersection.  V1 entered the intersection and was struck in the right side by the front of V2.  V1 rotated counterclockwise and the right side struck the left side of V2.  V2 continued forward a short distance, struck a light pole with its front and came to rest facing west.  V1 continued off the right side of the roadway and swiped an 80 cm diameter tree with its right side.  V1 than struck a 120 cm diameter tree with its front and came to final rest facing west. Both vehicles were towed due to damage. \n\n     V1 was driven by a belted 20year-old female who was transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  The driver could not be located or contacted for additional information.  She did state to the police that she did not see V2 coming when she proceeded into the intersection.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a recognition error, inadequate surveillance, looked but did not see.  This was chosen because the driver stated that she did not see V2 coming when she began to enter the intersection.  \n\n     V2 was driven by a belted 19-year-old male who was in good health and on his way to the dentist.  The driver stated that he was traveling between 66-80kmph (41-50mph) prior to the crash.  He also stated that his sight line to the other vehicle was clear, that she went through the stop sign and he attempted to avoid the collision by braking and steering right but it was too late.  The driver was uninjured but his passenger was transported to a treatment facility with non-incapacitating injuries. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no known associated factors coded to this driver and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n     \n
../resources/summary/2005002585743.json
preprocessing
Case Summary 2005-02-056\n\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 55 MPH (89 KPH).  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of this weekend afternoon crash.\n\n     V1, a 1998 Toyota Camry, was traveling north on the two lane undivided roadway.  V1 crossed into the southbound lane and off the left side of the roadway.  V1 continued striking a large boulder with its undercarriage and swiping a 10 cm tree with its left side.  V1 continued a short distance, struck a 25 cm tree with its front and came to rest facing in a northerly direction.\n\n     The Toyota Camry (V1) was driven by a belted 21-year-old male who was transported, treated and released for minor injuries.  No additional information was obtained as the driver could not be located or contacted.  The driver did state to the police that he had fallen asleep causing V1 to drift off the roadway.  There were no indications of any type of avoidance maneuvers.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was that the driver fell asleep, was actually asleep a critical non-performance error.  This was chosen because of the statement made by the driver to the police.  Information obtained at the scene from fire personnel indicated that this driver had had a similar crash a week or two before and may have had a seizure.  It should be noted that V1 had recently been registered and had a 10-day temporary inspection sticker.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n\n

Case 02-2005-057\n\n     The crash occurred on a level two lane undivided roadway with a posted speed limit of 55 MPH (89 KPH).  The weather was clear, the roadway dry and it was daylight at the time of the crash.\n\n     V1, a 1996 Honda Civic, was traveling east on the roadway behind V2, a 2002 GMC Envoy.  V2 observes a non-contact vehicle in front of it slowing to make a left into a driveway.  V2 decelerates and is struck in the rear by the front of V1.  V2 is pushed forward and drives off the road to the right coming to rest facing east off the south shoulder.  V1 came to rest facing east off the south shoulder.\nV1 was towed due to damage and V2 was driven from the scene.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n     The 1996 Honda (V1) was driven by a belted 16-year-old male who was transported, but received no injuries.  The belted 16-year-old male right front seat passenger was transported, treated and released for minor bruising.  The unbelted 12-year-old male in the right rear seat was transported, but received no injuries. Driver refused to provide any information regarding the crash.  He did state to the police \xe2\x80\x9che took his eyes off the road which caused the collision\xe2\x80\x9d.  Police also indicated driver inexperience and passenger distraction as contributing factors to the crash.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was other vehicle in lane traveling in same direction while decelerating.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a driver related factor: internal distraction  This was chosen because there were several associated factors: driver inexperience, passenger distraction, and his statement that he had taken his eyes off the road.  \n\n     The 2002 GMC (V2) was driven by a belted 48-year-old female who was not injured.  The belted 75-year-old female right front passenger was also not injured.  The driver stated that she was slowing down for a car ahead of her that was turning left.  She said she never saw him, only heard the squealing and felt the impact, which sent her a ways down the road.  She took no avoidance maneuvers.  She advised that she was on her way to an appointment in town, but was not in any hurry.  Additional information was not obtained because the driver could not be re-contacted.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle and this vehicle was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  No other associated factors were coded to this driver. \n

The crash occurred on the westbound lanes of an elevated one-way roadway with three-lanes.  On the left side of the roadway there is concrete wall and on the right side there is a guardrail.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 80kmph (50 mph).  The road was wet and it was daylight with a slight drizzle.  The roadway had no grade and it was straight and level.  The pre-crash of this roadway was curved left.\n\nV1 was a 1999 Nissan Quest which was traveling on the right lane when the right/front tire and wheel contacted the raised curb on the right side of the travel lane, and when the tire blew, the front contacted the guardrail.  The vehicle came to final rest on the right lane after impact.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event is a decision error - too fast for curve.  An Associated Factor was coded as slick roads.  The driver stated that he was in good health.  He said that he was on his way to visit friends.  The driver also stated that he works the night shift and has adequate sleep.

This crash occurred at the intersection of an east-west roadway with two lanes in each direction, and a one-way northbound roadway.  The roadway was straight and level, and it was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.\n\nV1 was a 1991 Mazda Navajo, which was traveling westbound on the left lane.  V2 was a 2003 Honda Accord, which was traveling northbound.  At the intersection, the front of V2 contacted the left side of V1.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a Forty-eight year old female.  She did not sustain any injuries.  The driver declined to participate in the study.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a Twenty-three year old male.  He did not sustain any injuries.  V2 had a Forty-two year old male passenger seated in the right front seat, did not sustain any injuries.  The driver declined to participate in the study.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection. This crash occurred in the right lane of the northbound lanes of an undivided roadway with two lanes in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level, and it was cloudy and raining.  The roadway was wet and had a posted speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph). The crash occurred at a 4-way signalized intersection.  \n\nV1 was a 1999 Toyota Camry that stopped for an emergency vehicle traveling westbound with the emergency lights on.  V2 was a 2000 Nissan Sentra that was behind V1 and could not stop in time.  V2 rear-ended V1.   The emergency vehicle was crossing over the intersection.\n\nA seventy-four year old male who did not sustain any injuries drove the Toyota Camry.  He stated that he saw the emergency vehicle trying to go through the intersection so he slowed down and came to a stop.  As he stopped, he was rear-ended by V2. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as: other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in the same direction at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  One associated factor coded to this driver was the use of prescription medications.  He stated that he was taking medication for pain in his chest, back and feet.  The medication was both over the counter and prescribed, and he did not reveal the names of the medications.  He was wearing prescription bifocal glasses for both hyperopic and myopic conditions. Two other associated factors that were coded (to both drivers) were the traffic flow interruption in the form of the approaching emergency vehicle and the weather (rain). V1 was driven away from the scene.\n\nA forty-seven year old male who did not sustain any injuries drove the Nissan Sentra.  He stated that V1 suddenly stopped and he could not stop due to the wet road.  A thirty-seven year old female who also did not sustain any injuries was the passenger in the front-right position.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as: other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a decision error: Too fast to be able to respond to unexpected actions of others.  Associated factors coded to this driver include traveling too fast, a false assumption in that the driver assumed that because his light was green, traffic in front of him would continue to proceed, the traffic flow interruption in the form of the approaching emergency vehicle, and the weather (rain). Other possible associated factors were unknown because the interview was not obtained.  V2 was towed due to damage.  \n\n
../resources/summary/2005003498121.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on an eastbound exit ramp of a three-lane parkway.   The pre-crash roadway had a posted speed limit of 80 kmph (50 mph), however no speed was posted for the exit ramp.  There were warning signs posted along the exit ramp of the sharp curve ahead.  The conditions were daylight and dry with sunny skies on a weekday morning.  The exit ramp had an uphill grade of 3 percent and was curved to the right.  The pre-crash roadway was straight and level.               \n\n     V1 was a 1995 Chevrolet G-Series Van, which was traveling in the right lane exiting the parkway. The driver of V1 took the curve too fast and skidded off the ramp into a guardrail, which V1 then partially mounted. The driver of V1 claimed that as he entered the exit ramp, an unknown vehicle came along the right side of his van and caused him to lose control and drive into the guardrail. The vehicle came to final rest with its front end partially over the guardrail.\n\n     A 22-year old male drove V1 and a 29-year old male was a passenger.  Neither was injured or transported to the hospital.  The driver stated that an unknown vehicle had driven up on his right side and cut him off on the exit lane, which caused to lose control and contact the right side guardrail.  The driver received a citation for operating a commercial vehicle on a parkway.  He stated in the interview that he travels on this roadway daily, which prohibits commercial vehicles. The van was towed due to damage.\n\n      The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was when it traveled off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was a decision error - too fast for curve. The driver\'s statement that a non-contact vehicle on his right forced him off the road was not deemed credible due to the narrow width of the road and the lack of tire tracks on the grass to the right. An associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was a distraction by a non-contact vehicle that may have caused him to fail to reduce his speed sufficiently in order to safely negotiate the curved ramp. The driver stated that he was in good health and was not fatigued at the time of the crash.   \n\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a two-way roadway with one-lane in each direction and a two-way roadway with two lanes in each direction.  It was daylight and the conditions were clear with no adverse conditions.  The roadway was level and had a posted speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).\n\nV1 was a 1999 Dodge Caravan, which was traveling northbound on the two-way roadway with one lane in each direction.  As he crossed the intersection he was contacted on the right side by the front of V2.\n\nThe Dodge Caravan (V1) was driven by a 66-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver declined to participate in the study, but a witness stated that he stopped for the light, and then proceeded through the intersection while he had the red light.  The minivan was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, crossing through intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as; Driver related error, Illegal maneuver.  The associated factors were coded unknown.  \n\nV2 was a 1988 Toyota Camry, which was traveling westbound on the left lane of the roadway.  As he proceeded through the intersection, he contacted the right side of V1.  \n\nThe Toyota Camry (Vehicle# 2) was driven by a 57-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The Camry was driven from the scene.  The driver declined to participate in the study.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as:  Other vehicle encroaching into lane, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the critical Event was not coded for this vehicle because the driver was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  No other associated factors were coded to the driver.\n

This crash occurred in the intersection of a north-south road and an east-west road.  The roadways were one-way with one lane of travel.  The intersection was controlled by a traffic light, which was working properly.  The conditions were daylight, and clear with no adverse conditions.  The level roadway had a speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  The grade for V1 pre-impact location was measured as -3 percent, and the grade for V2 pre-impact location was measured as 2 percent.\n\nV1 was a 1998 Jeep Cherokee, which was traveling northbound when the front struck V2, a 1992 Nissan Maxima on the left side.  V2 then rotated counter-clockwise and the right side struck the back of V3.  V3 was legally parked in the northwest corner of the intersection and pushed forward upon impact.  \n\nThe Jeep Cherokee was driven by a 21-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that the driver of V2 disregarded the traffic control signal at the intersection.  There were also three other occupants in his vehicle that did not sustain any injuries.  He also stated that he could not avoid the crash once he saw V2.  The driver was issued a citation for failure to produce proof of registration.  The Jeep was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: Other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  No associated factors were coded to this driver. \n\nV2 was driven by a 44-year old male who sustained unknown injuries and was transported to a local medical facility.  The driver stated on the Police Report that he was speeding and trying to catch the light at the next intersection.  The driver was also issued a citation for operation of a vehicle when privilege is suspended or revoked.  The Nissan was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, passing through intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an illegal maneuver because he failed to stop for a traffic control signal. An associated factor coded to this driver was aggressive driving.\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a one-way North-South road and a two-way East-West road.  The roadway was straight and level and had a posted speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).  The conditions were daylight and the roadway was dry.  \n\nV1 was a Chevrolet Malibu, which was traveling northbound on a one-way roadway with one lane.  V2 was a Chevrolet G-Series Van that was traveling eastbound on a two-way roadway with one-lane in each direction and stopped for the stop sign.  At the intersection, V1 proceeded through and the front of V2 contacted the left side of V1.\n\nV1 was driven by a 37-year old male, who had two occupants, an 11 year-old female in the front-right position and a 10-year old female in the back-right seat.  The 11-year old female and the 10-year old female both sustained minor injuries and were transported to a medical facility.  The Chevrolet Malibu was towed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as: Other Vehicle Encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The associated factors were coded as unknown. The driver of V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n\nV2 was driven by a 41-year old male who stated that he thought the other driver also had a stop sign, and thought the driver of V1 was going to stop when he proceeded through the intersection.  The driver sustained no injuries and was not transported.  The Van was not towed. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as: This Vehicle Traveling, crossing over intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a Driver Related Error, false assumption of other\'s actions.  Two emotional factors were coded to the driver, he was visiting his grandmother who just came back from the hospital and he was also concerned about his financial situation.  He has no employer stress factors because he is the owner of the business.

It was the mid-evening hours and it was dark out but the roadway was lighted. It was dry with no adverse weather conditions.\n\nV2 was a 1995 Ford Taurus that was traveling eastbound and veered into the westbound lane.  V1 was a 2001 Ford F-150 pick-up truck traveling westbound on the same roadway.  The front of V2 contacted the front of V1.\n\nA 39-year old male drove the Ford F-150 (V1) and he did not sustain any injuries.  The passenger seated in the front-right position sustained minor injuries and was transported to a medical facility.  The driver stated that the driver of V2 had an alcohol odor about him and that he was driving eastbound in the westbound lane.  V1 was towed due to damage.  The driver of this vehicle declined to participate in the study.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was the other vehicle encroaching into lane, over the left-lane line. The associated factors were coded as unknown.  \n

This crash occurred on the eastbound lanes of an undivided four-lane roadway with two lanes in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level, and it was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.  The speed limit for the roadway was 48 kmph (30 mph).\n\nV1 was a 1996 Lincoln Town Car that was in the eastbound parking lane and attempting to make a U-turn to go westbound on the roadway.  V2 was a Dodge Grand Caravan that was traveling eastbound in the second lane of travel.  V1 attempted to make a U-turn and the front impacted the right side of V2.\n\nThe Lincoln Town Car (V1) was driven by a 37-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that he was coming out of a parking spot and attempting to make a U-Turn.  V1 was used and registered as a livery cab and was driven away from the scene. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, over the line on the left side of travel lane. An associated factor that was coded to the driver was a Driver Recognition Error, Inadequate surveillance, (looked but did not see). V2 was used and registered as a livery cab and was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as: Other Vehicle Encroachment, from adjacent lane over the right lane line.  No Critical Reason was coded to the driver of V2.  No associated factors were coded to the driver.  The driver wore eyeglasses that corrected a myopic condition. \n\n

The crash occurred at the signalized intersection of a northbound one-way roadway with two lanes of travel, and an eastbound one-way roadway with two lanes of travel.  The roadways were straight and level, and had a posted speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.  \n\nV1 was a 2005 Honda Civic traveling on the northbound roadway and V2 was a 1999 Mercury Grand Marquis traveling on the eastbound roadway attempting to make a left hand turn heading northbound.  V3, a Chevrolet Express G-Series cargo van was legally parked approximately 20 feet north of the intersection on the northbound roadway.  At the intersection, the left front of V1 impacted the right side of V2.  This caused V1 to roll right - primarily about the longitudinal axis 3 quarter turns.  The undercarriage of V1 contacted the rear plane of V3 and came to final rest on its left side plane.  This event pushed V3 approximately 20 feet north. \n\nThe Honda Civic (V1) was driven by a 43-year old female who was transported to the hospital for minor injuries.  The Honda Civic was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: Other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, turning into the same direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was not coded for this vehicle because a witness stated that she did have the green light.  The associated factors were all coded unknown because no interview was obtained.  \n\nThe Mercury Grand Marquis (V2) was driven by a 71-year old male who sustained minor injuries, and a 70-year old female in the front-right seating position also sustained minor injuries. Both were transported to a medical facility.  The Mercury Grand Marquis was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, turning left at the intersection.   The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as an illegal maneuver. Because there was no interview, it was unclear if the driver of V2 had intentionally disregarded the traffic control device or if he did not recognize that there was a control device present.  The associated factors were all coded unknown because no interviews were obtained.\n\nThe Chevrolet Express G-Series Van (V3) was legally parked and occupied by an 18-year old male, who was in the front-right seat. He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a medical facility.\n\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a two-way north/south road with two lanes in each direction and an east/west road with one lane in each direction.  The roadways were straight and level and each had a speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.  The crash occurred in the morning hours on a weekday.\n\nV1 was a 2004 Acura MDX that was traveling southbound in the right lane.  V2 was 1995 Dodge Neon that was traveling westbound. At the intersection, the front of V1 impacted the right side of V2.    \n\nThe Acura MDX (V1) was driven by a 29-year old female who did not sustain any injuries.  She stated that she had come to a rolling stop at a red light and then when her light turned green, she accelerated into the intersection. She stated that V2 came from nowhere.  The Acura was not towed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as: Other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason for the critical event was not coded to the driver of V1.  An associated factor coded to the driver was that she does experience work related stress and pressure relating to her occupation.  The driver stated that she does work many hours but did not appear to be fatigued.\n\nThe Dodge Neon (V2) was driven by a 31-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that he was going straight and had the green light at the intersection when the driver of V1 went through the red light.  The Dodge Neon was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, a decision error.  Based on vehicle damage, it is believed that the driver of V2 entered the intersection when the lights on the traffic control devices were changing to red. No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.  \n

It was dark but lighted and had a speed limit of 48 kmph (30mph).  The crash occurred in the evening hours of a weekday.\n\nV1 was a 2000 Jeep Grand Cherokee that was traveling eastbound in the right lane and attempting to make a U-turn.  V2 was a 2001 Nissan X-Terra that was traveling eastbound in the left lane.  The front of V2 impacted the left side of V1 as V1 turned in front of it.  This impact spun V1 counter-clockwise and its right side impacted V3, a parked and unoccupied BMW 325xi (V3) on the left side.\n\nThe Jeep Grand Cherokee (V1) was driven by an 82-year old male who sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local medical facility.  The Grand Cherokee was not towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded: This vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as an illegal maneuver, a decision error.  An associated factor coded to the driver was inadequate surveillance, as it was believed that he looked but did not see. All other associated factors for the driver of V1 were all coded as unknown due to a lack of an interview.  \n\nThe Nissan X-Terra (V2) was driven by a 29-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that he was going straight when V1 darted out in front of him while attempting to make a U-turn.  The driver of V2 attempted to brake and steer right but could not avoid V1.  The X-Terra was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event was coded: Other vehicle encroaching into lane, from adjacent lane over the right lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. He wore prescription eyeglasses that corrected a myopic condition. No other associated factors were coded to him.  The driver of the X-Terra was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nThe BMW 325xi (V3) was legally parked and unoccupied on the westbound parking lane of the roadway.  The BMW was not towed.\n

It was dark but lighted, and it was clear with no adverse conditions.  The crash occurred in the early morning hours on a weekend.\n\nV1 was a 2000 Mack Dump Truck that was traveling westbound on the roadway.  V2 was a 2003 Chevrolet Trailblazer that was traveling eastbound, when it swerved into the westbound lanes.  The front of V2 impacted the left side of V1.  V2 came to a final rest back on the eastbound lane.\n\nThe 2000 Mack Truck (V1) was driven by a 28-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The Mack Truck was not towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: Other vehicle encroaching into lane, from opposite direction over the left lane line. preprocessing
The crash occurred in the intersection of a two-way roadway with one lane in both the north and south direction and an eastbound one-way roadway.  The roadway was straight and level and had a speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  The road was wet and it was cloudy and raining.\n\nV1 was a 2002 Mitsubishi Montero that was traveling eastbound on the one-way roadway and stopped at the stop sign and proceeded through.  V2 was a 1998 Ford E-Series Van that was traveling southbound.  At the intersection, the front of V2 impacted the left side of V1.  \n\nA 25 year-old female drove the Mitsubishi Montero (V1) and she did not sustain any injuries.  The 15-month old passenger seated in the second-row center position also did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that she was stopped at the stop sign when the driver of V2 was speeding and impacted her vehicle on the left side.  V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was a Driver related error, inadequate surveillance.  The associated factors were the wet roadway and the rain.   \n\nA 50 year-old male drove the Ford E-Series Van (V2) and he did not sustain any injuries.  There were four male occupants who did not sustain any injuries but were transported due to being minors, and one male occupant who was not transported because a parent was on-scene.  He stated that the driver of V1 did not stop at the stop sign, but she stopped in the middle of the intersection.  V2 was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was other vehicle encroaching into lane, from crossing the street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to the driver of V2.  The associated factors coded to the vehicle were that he was traveling too fast for conditions, and did not realize that caution was necessary.  The atmospheric conditions were cloudy and raining, and the roads were wet.  \n\n\n

The crash occurred on the eastbound lane of a two-way road with one lane in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level, and it was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions. There were no traffic control devices and the speed limit was 48kmph (30mph).\n\nV1 was a 2004 Mercury Sable that was traveling westbound.  The driver veered into the eastbound lanes and the front of V1 impacted the left side of a legally parked and unoccupied Ford E-Series Van. V1 came to a final rest when it impacted a fence on the sidewalk. \n\nThe Mercury Sable (V1) was driven by a 55 year-old female who sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  The occupant in the front-center seating position did not sustain any injuries but was also transported to a local hospital.  The driver stated that she attempted to stop when she stepped on the accelerator instead of the brake pedal.  The Mercury Sable was towed due to damage and the driver declined to participate in the study.  \n\nThe Critical pre-crash event for V1 was coded as: This vehicle traveling, over the left side travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as a Driver related factor, poor directional control (Failing to control vehicle with the skill ordinarily expected).  The associated factors were all coded unknown.  The driver was issued a citation for unlicensed operator.
