This crash occurred at the intersection of a two-way roadway with one lane in each direction and a one-lane, one-way roadway.  It was daylight and the roadway was straight and level and it was clear with patches of ice that formed from the night before.  The speed limit was 48kph (30mph).  \n\nV1, a 1999 Ford Crown Victoria, was traveling westbound on the two-way roadway.  V2, a 1993 Ford Crown Victoria, was traveling northbound on the one-way roadway.  At the intersection, the front of V2 contacted the left side of V1.  V1 then struck a pedestrian standing on the northwest corner of the intersection.  The pedestrian sustained no injuries.\n\nThe 1999 Ford Crown Victoria was driven by a 48-year old male who sustained no injuries and was not transported to the hospital.  The vehicle was used as a livery taxicab, and he was transporting one passenger.  He stated that he had the green light and was trying to avoid V2 by steering right.  The driver also stated that V2 was traveling at a high rate of speed and disregarded the traffic control signal.  This vehicle was driven from the scene.  The driver of V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded, other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street; turning into same direction.  The Critical Event was not coded for this vehicle.\n\nThe 1993 Ford Crown Victoria was driven by a 33-year old who sustained no injuries and was not transported to the hospital.  He stated that he was attempting to make a left turn at the intersection and slid on ice patches and lost control.  He wears glasses to correct his myopic (near sighted) condition, and does not have any health problems.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle control loss due to; poor road conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as decision errors too fast for conditions.  An associated factor was coded as environment related factor; slick roads.

The crash occurred on a one-way roadway with one lane of travel.  The roadway was straight and level and had a speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.  The roadway was asphalt and was dry for the most part but had an ice condition caused by freezing temperatures and a flooded drain approximately 55 meters south of the point of impact.\n\nV1 was a 2005 Ford Crown Victoria that was traveling northbound on the roadway when it lost control on the ice patch.  V1 departed the roadway on the right side and impacted a small metal pole and then impacted the building located to the west of the roadway.  V1 came to a final rest contacting the building.  \n\nThe Ford Crown Victoria (V1) was driven by a 44 year-old male who sustained non-incapacitating injuries and was transported to a local medical facility.  The driver stated that the ice patch caused him to loose control and impact the building.   The Ford Crown Victoria was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as going straight.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as an Environment related factor, slick roads.  An associated factor coded to the driver was a decision error, traveling too fast for conditions, did not realize that caution was required.

The crash occurred in the intersection of two one-way roadways.  Both roadways had one lane of travel and were straight and level.  The speed limit was 48kmph (30mph) and it was clear with no adverse conditions.\n\nV1 was a 2005 Infiniti FX35 that was traveling southbound on a one-way roadway.  V2 was a 1993 Ford F-250 Pick-up truck that was traveling westbound on a one-way roadway, which was controlled by a stop sign.  At the intersection, the front of V1 impacted the right side of V2, and then the left side of V2 impacted the right side of V1.  V1 then departed the roadway on the left side and then impacted a fence and came to a final rest after impacting the side of the building.\n\nThe Infiniti FX35 (V1) was driven by a 45 year-old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver of this vehicle declined to participate in the study.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as:  Other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street across path. The associated factors were coded as unknown.\n\nThe Ford F-250 (V2) was driven by a 50 year-old male who did not sustain any injuries. The Ford was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as:  This vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection. The associated factors coded to the driver were both recognition factors, he was conversing with the passenger and inadequate surveillance, looked, but did not see.  The driver wore eyeglasses that corrected an unknown condition, and he was issued a citation for uninsured vehicle.

The crash occurred in the early afternoon of a weekday in the westbound lanes of a divided two-way roadway with three lanes in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level and had a posted speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.\n\nV1, a 1997 Infiniti QX4, was traveling westbound in the right lane (lane one).  V2, a 1990 Ford Crown Victoria, was traveling westbound on the middle lane (lane two).  V2 attempted to make a right turn at the intersection the right side of his vehicle collided with the left front of V1.  V1 then went off the roadway to the right and then the front impacted a breakaway light pole.\n\nV1 was driven by a 34 year-old female who sustained minor injuries and was transported to a medical facility.  She was unable to be located for an interview, but she told the police on scene that she was going straight when V2 attempted to make a right turn at the intersection.  The Infiniti was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroaching from adjacent lane (same direction), over the left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to the driver.  There were no known associated factors coded to V1 and the driver was not believed to have contributed to the crash.\n\nV2 was driven by a 58 year-old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that V1 was driving behind him and attempted to pass him from the right lane.  The driver declined to participate in the study.  The Ford was not towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as:  This vehicle traveling, turning right at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor, illegal maneuver, as V2 attempted to turn from the wrong lane.  There were no known associated factors coded to V2.

This crash occurred in the early afternoon of a weekend in the intersection of a northbound one-way roadway and a two-way east and west roadway.  All roadways were straight and level and had a speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).  The northbound entrance into the intersection was controlled by a stop sign.  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.\n\nV1, a 1998 Mercedes-Benz ML320, was traveling westbound approaching the intersection.  V2, a 1999 Chevrolet Lumina, was traveling northbound and stopped at the stop sign.  As V2 proceeded into the intersection, its front impacted the left side of V1.  V1 than yawed counterclockwise and the right-rear wheel impacted the curb.  The right side of V1 then impacted a breakaway light-pole and rolled over one quarter turn before coming to final rest on its right side.\n\nV1 was driven by a 35 year-old male who sustained minor injuries and was transported to a medical facility.   A complete interview could not be obtained, but the driver stated that he was going straight when he was impacted by V2, who did not stop at the stop sign.  The Mercedes-Benz was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: Other vehicle encroaching into lane, from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was not coded to the driver.  An associated factor coded to the driver was a decision error, traveling too fast for conditions, too fast reason unknown.  \n\nThe Chevrolet Lumina (V2) was driven by a 39 year-old female who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that she stopped at the stop sign before proceeding through the intersection.   The driver declined to participate in the study.  The Chevrolet was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as:  This vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor, a decision error, driver crossed with obstructed view.  The associated factors coded to the driver were, other decision factor, that she crossed with obstructed view and a sightline restriction caused by legally parked vehicles.

It was dark but lighted and the roadway had a speed limit of 48kmph (30mph).\n\nV2 was a 2001 Suzuki Grand Vitara that was traveling northbound approaching the intersection and slowed down for an emergency fire truck with the emergency lights and sirens attempting to go eastbound on a two-way roadway.  V1 was a Lincoln Navigator that was traveling northbound behind V2.  The front of V1 impacted the rear of V2.  V2 then continued forward and impacted a fence that was located on the northwest corner.  \n\nThe Lincoln Navigator (V1) was driven by a 27-year old male who sustained incapacitating injuries and was transported to a medical facility.  The Lincoln was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as: Other Motor Vehicle in Lane, traveling in same direction while decelerating.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded unknown because no driver interview was obtained.  The associated factors coded to the driver were inadequate surveillance, failed to look far enough ahead and a driver decision factor, that he did not realize that caution was required. The crash occurred in the northbound lanes of a two-way roadway with two-lanes in each direction.  The roadway had a speed limit of 48kmph (30mph) and was straight and level.  The conditions were raining and wet.  The crash happened in the early morning hours of a weekday.\n\nV1 was a 1990 Honda Accord, which rear-ended V2, which was a Toyota Camry.  V2 then rear-ended V3, a 2001 Toyota Rav-4.  All crash events happened in the right lane of the roadway.  \n\nThe Honda Accord (V1) was driven by a 25-year old male who sustained no injuries and was not transported.  He stated that he was looking to the left at an unknown exterior distraction prior to recognizing that the crash was imminent.  Due to weather conditions, the driver also locked up his wheels in an attempt to stop.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded Other Motor Vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason was coded as Recognition Error, External Distraction.  Two Associated factors coded to the driver were Driver Decision Factor, Did not realize that caution was required and use of prescription drugs, pain-killers due to his employment in the construction business.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 55-year old male who sustained no injuries and was not transported.  No interview was obtained but stated that he was stopped at the traffic control signal at the intersection.  V2 was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Pre-crash Event was coded as other Motor Vehicle in lane, Traveling in the same direction with higher speed.  No Critical Reason was coded to the driver of V2 because he was also stopped.\n\nThe driver of V3 was a 34-year old female, who sustained no injuries at time of crash.  The driver and occupant of V3 complained of neck, back and knee pains sometime later.   She stated that she was stopped at the traffic control signal, where she was rear-ended.  No interview was obtained for the driver.  V3 was also driven from the scene.\n\nNo Critical Pre-crash Event or Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because she was not involved in the first harmful event.  V3 was in front of V2 when the crash occurred.

This crash occurred in the southbound lanes of a two-way roadway with two lanes in each direction.  The roadway was straight with a downhill grade of -2/61.  It was daylight and clear with no adverse conditions.  The speed limit for the roadway was 48kmph (30mph).  On the right of the southbound lanes was a gas station and a carwash. \n\nV1 was a 1996 Mitsubishi 3000GT, that was traveling southbound on the right lane.  V2 was a 1996 Ford Windstar that was traveling northbound on the left lane and attempting to turn left into the Gas Station.  Due to a sightline restriction from a non-contact vehicle, the front of V1 contacted the right-front wheel of V2.  \n\nThe Mitsubishi 3000GT was driven by a 40-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that he was traveling approximately 25 mph when a mini-van traveling northbound attempted to make a left-turn.  The driver stated that he tried to brake but it was too late because his sightline was restricted by another vehicle on the left-lane.  The Mitsubishi 3000GT was not towed due to damage. \n\nThe Ford Winstar was driven by a 66-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that the driver of a non-contact vehicle allowed him to enter the gas station and that once he began turning, he was struck on the right-front wheel by Vehicle. # 1.  The Windstar was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as, other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  No Critical reason was coded to the driver of V1 because he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  The driver of the 3000GT had engaged in strenuous workout at the gym, four times a week, however he was not thought to be fatigued at the time of the crash.  An associated factor was coded as a Roadway related factors, Slick surface due to soap and tire treatment residue from the carwash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as, this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason was coded as; a decision error, turned with obstructed view.  \n\n

The crash occurred in the southbound lanes of an undivided two-way roadway, with two lanes of travel in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level and had a posted speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  It was dark out but the roadway was lighted and it was dry.  \n\nV1 was a 2002 Dodge Stratus, which was traveling southbound on the two-way roadway in the right lane.  V2 was a 1993 Nissan Altima that was traveling southbound on the two-way roadway in the left lane.  On this roadway, V1 was attempting to make a U-turn to travel northbound when it was contacted on its left plane by V2\'s frontal plane. The crash occurred on a non-junction roadway with no traffic signs or signals. Both vehicles came to final rest on the sidewalk of the northbound lanes.\n \nA 27-year old male drove V1, with no other occupants present.  He sustained minor injuries but was not transported to a medical facility.  The Dodge Stratus was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, a decision error.  The illegal maneuver was the attempted U-turn. An associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was inadequate surveillance.\n\nV2 was driven by a 22-year old male who had two occupants with him, a 15-year old female in the front-right position and a 16-year old female in the back-right seat.  All three occupants sustained minor injuries and were transported to a medical facility. The Nissan Altima was also towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as: other vehicle encroachment, from adjacent lane (same direction)-over right lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver. The driver of V2 could not be located for an interview. He was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n  \n\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a two-way roadway with one lane in each direction and a one-way roadway with one lane of travel.  The roadway was straight and level, and had a posted speed limit of 30mph (48kmph). The east/west roadway had no traffic control device; the southbound roadway was controlled by a stop sign. It was dark but lighted, and clear with no adverse conditions.    \n\nV1 was a 2002 Lexus SC430 traveling eastbound on the two-way roadway and V2 was a 1993 Lexus LS400 traveling south on the one-way roadway.  At the intersection, the front of V1 impacted the right side of V2.  The front of V1 then impacted a light-pole on the southeast corner of the intersection.  \n\nThe Lexus SC430 (V1) was driven by a 45-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that he was going straight through the intersection when V2 ran the stop sign and caused him to impact V2 and then into the light-pole.  He stated that he did not perform any avoidance maneuvers.  The Lexus SC430 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was when the other vehicle encroached from a crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of the Lexus SC430 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nThe Lexus LS400 (V2) was driven by a 76-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The 38-year old female seated in the front-right position sustained minor injuries and was treated on-scene and a 32-year old female seated in the second-row right position did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that he stopped for the stop sign for approximately five seconds and looked both directions before proceeding through the intersection.  The Lexus LS400 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was when it began to pass through the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  An associated factor coded to the driver was that he was taking an unidentified prescription medication for high blood pressure.  The driver wore prescription eyeglasses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.\n

This crash occurred in the intersection of a north/south road with one lane in each direction and an east/west road with one lane in each direction.  The roadways were straight and level and each had a speed limit of 48 kmph (30 mph).  It was raining and the roadways were wet.  The crash occurred in the morning hours on a weekend.\n\nV1 was a 2001 Chevrolet Lumina that was traveling southbound. V2 was a 2003 Lexus LS430 that was traveling westbound.  At the intersection, the front of V2 impacted the left side of V1.  The impact spun V1 counter-clockwise and the right side impacted a train support pillar.  V1 then spun clockwise to its final rest, facing northbound.\n\nThe Chevrolet Lumina (V1) was driven by a 52-year old male who did not sustain any injuries. A 52-year old female occupant in the front-right seat sustained incapacitating injuries and was transported to a local medical facility.  The driver stated that he was going straight and had the green light when V2 ran the red light, which caused him to impact the train support pillar.  The Chevrolet Lumina was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as: This vehicle crossing over (passing through) the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as an illegal maneuver. The Critical Reason was coded to the driver of V1 due to vehicle damage and the trajectory of the vehicle following the first impact. It was believed that the driver of V1 ran the red light shortly after his light changed to red and was struck in the left rear side by V2.  The traffic control device was working properly.  The associated factors coded to this driver were wet roadways (a highway-related factor), and rain, a weather-related factor.\n\nThe Lexus LS430 (V2) was driven by a 57-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  He stated that he was going straight and had the green light when V2 ran the red light at the intersection.  The Lexus LS430 was not towed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as: Other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was not coded to this driver.  The driver wore prescription glasses that corrected a myopic condition.  The associated factors coded to this driver were wet roadways (a highway-related factor), and rain, a weather-related factor.\n\n

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound lanes of a two-way roadway that was divided by a raised curb median with two lanes in each direction.  The roadway was straight and level and had a posted speed of 48 kmph (30 mph).  The weather was clear with no adverse conditions.  It was the evening hours of a weekday and it was dark out but the roadway was lighted. The crash occurred at a signalized intersection with an east/west roadway.\n\nV1 was a 2001 Mitsubishi Mirage that was traveling southbound in the right lane.  V2 was a 1995 Ford Probe that was traveling northbound in the left lane and attempting to make a left turn.  At the intersection, the front of V1 impacted the right front side of V2, and then V2 impacted a chain-link fence that was located on the southwest corner of the intersection.\n\nThe Mitsubishi Mirage (V1) was driven by a 40-year old female who was transported to a local medical facility with incapacitating injuries.  A 21-year old female sustained minor injuries and a 12-year old male in her vehicle sustained non-incapacitating injuries and were both transported to a local medical facility.  V1 was going straight through the intersection when V2 turned in front of it.  The Mirage was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V1 was coded as:  Other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction over the left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was not coded to this driver because she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  A sightline restriction was coded because it was believed that a non-contact vehicle obstructed the driver\'s view of V2. All other associated factors for the driver were coded as unknown due to a lack of an interview.\n\nThe Ford Probe (V2) was driven by a 20-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that he was making a left turn at the intersection and that his sightline was restricted by an on-coming vehicle (sport utility vehicle) when he was impacted on the right front side by V1.  The Probe was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event for V2 was coded as:  This vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as a Driver Related Factor: inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  The associated factors coded were a decision error: crossed with obstructed view, and work stress, as he had an adversarial work relationship with his manager.  A sightline restriction was also coded due to a larger vehicle attempting to make a left turn from the opposite direction, obstructing his view of V1.  The driver was not coded to be fatigued even though he had only slept five hours in the last 24 hours because that was his normal sleep pattern and his sleep and work patterns did not rotate or change.\n\n

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a two-way roadway that is divided by a center median with three lanes in each direction.  It was daylight and clear and the ground was wet from a previous rainstorm.  The roadway was straight and level and had a posted speed limit of 48kmph (30mph). \n\nV1 was a 2000 Mercedes-Benz ML320 that was stopped for the Traffic control device when it was rear-ended by V2, a 1996 Toyota Corolla.  Both vehicles came to final rest in the roadway.\n\nV1 was driven by a 42 year-old male who did not sustain any injuries and was unable to be located for an interview.  V1 was driven away before it could be inspected.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in the same direction with higher speed.  The Critical reason for the Critical event was not coded to the vehicle.  Although the roads were wet the driver of V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nV2 was driven by a 41 year-old male in good health despite a history of high blood pressure (for which he took an unknown medication).  The driver stated that the intersection had two sets of traffic control devices and he thought that the driver of V1 would go through the second set after he went through the first set.  The driver attempted to avoid the crash by braking (with lock-up) and steering right, but impacted the rear of V1 regardless.  The driver of V2 suffered no injuries but V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor, false assumption of other\'s actions.  The driver assumed that V1 was going to go through second set of traffic lights.  An associated factor was a highway related factor, wet roads.  The driver was also taking two unidentified prescription medication for high blood pressure and high cholesterol.

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane roadway with an adjacent private driveway.  Conditions were dusk and dry with cloudy skies at 4:38 pm on a weekday late afternoon.  The roadway had a posted speed of 35 MPH and the eastbound lane had a negative 2% grade.  The private driveway was dry and did not have a posted speed limit but had a negative 3% grade.\n\nV1 was a 1995 Plymouth Neon Sedan decelerating for the vehicle in front of him, which was making a left turn into a plaza.  V2, a 1996 Kia Sephia, was exiting a private drive to the right of V1.  The front of V1 struck the right side of V2; V2 rotated 90 degrees right.  V1 swerved right then left then both vehicles came to final rest in the right lane facing east.\n\nThe 45-year-old driver of the Plymouth Neon (V1) stated that he was struck on the right side and swerved to final rest in the eastbound lane.  The driver of V1 sustained a laceration to his forehead and was transported to the emergency room.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1 has pre-existing health conditions such as high blood pressure and a mild case of sleep apnea.  The driver also has engaged in strenuous activities however none of these factors were thought to have contributed to the crash.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was other vehicle encroachment - from driveway turning into opposite direction; no Critical Reason was coded to this vehicle.\n\nA 30-year-old female who did not sustain any injuries drove the Kia Sephia (V2).  She stated she had come to a complete stop, looked both ways, and then entered the roadway intending on turning left.  She stated she was traveling less than 5 MPH and the sun obscured her vision of V1.  Her vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was turning left, exiting a parking lot; the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was looked but did not see.  An associative factor was sun glare.  \n

The crash occurred in the northbound lane of a T-intersection with a grass median.  There was one northbound left-turn only lane with a traffic control and two eastbound lanes with the same traffic control signal.  Conditions were overcast with rain with light fog in the early afternoon of a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed of 45 MPH.\n\n     V1 was a 1988 Mercedes Benz 300SL stopped for the traffic control intending on turning left.  V2 was a 2002 Mercury Mountaineer driving eastbound in the right lane approaching the traffic control.  The light for the Mercedes turned green and the vehicle started turning left when the front of the Mercury struck the left-front corner of the Mercedes.  The Mercedes rotated CCW 90 degrees and the vehicle\'s final rest was facing east in the eastbound lane.  Final rest for the Mercury was facing east in the eastbound lane as well. \n\n     The driver of V1, a 54-year-old female drove V1 to a local hospital with minor injuries.  She stated she had come to a complete stop at the traffic signal for a few minutes and then began to turn left with the green light.  The crash occurred seconds after she proceeded to turn left and stated that she was only going about 5 MPH at impact.  V1 was towed due to damage and had a CDC of 11FLEN1.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when the other vehicle was coming from the crossing street across her path.  The Critical reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. \n\n     A 66-year-old male who was not injured drove the Mercury Mountaineer (V2).  Occupant two was a 6-year-old female who was seated in the second row, center seat.  She was not restrained in a child safety seat.  The driver said that he was approaching the intersection and did not see the traffic control.  The driver denied any inattention or distractions and he was familiar with his vehicle and the roadway.  Police charged him with disregard of traffic signal.  The vehicle was driven from the scene and had a CDC of 12FDEW1.  The driver and the occupant were belted.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event was when this vehicle was crossing over the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event for this vehicle was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  This was chosen because the driver reported that he was looking straight ahead but did not see the traffic control.  The driver also reported that he takes 10mg of Lipitor for high blood pressure once each evening.
../resources/summary/2005004112061.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound lane of a two-lane highway with a T-intersection.  Conditions were daylight and dry with cloudy skies in the mid-afternoon on a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed of 45 MPH and the southbound lane had a negative 2% grade.\n\nV1 was a 2003 Ford F350 super duty extended cab pick-up traveling south.  V2 was a 2004 Honda Civic coupe EX traveling south in front of V1.  V2 was braking and drifting to the right side of the road then tried to make an illegal left-handed U-turn.  V1 steered left but the front right corner of V1 struck the left side of V2.  V1 pushed V2 across the road coming to final rest just south of the impact.  V1 was facing south and V2 was facing north.  After coming to final rest, V2 drove up and over a median to get out of the way of oncoming traffic.\n\nV1 was driven by a 34-year-old male who sustained minor injuries and did not receive any medical attention.  He had stated that he was traveling south when he saw the other vehicle (V2) in front of him braking and drifting towards the right shoulder.  V2 then attempted to make a U-turn and the driver of V1 swerved left.  The driver of V1 was traveling less than 40 MPH.  V1 was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from an adjacent lane over the right lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  An associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was a false assumption of the road user\'s actions.  The driver of V1 assumed that the driver of V2 was pulling off the road to the right and that he would stay there until he (V1) passed.  V2 had been braking on and off for some distance, and it is possible that the driver of V1 was getting \xe2\x80\x9cfed up\xe2\x80\x9d with V2\'s erratic behavior and wanted to believe that V2 was pulling off to the side of the road so that V1 could pass him.  The driver of V1 was wearing his prescription glasses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  The driver of V1 was taking an allergy medication that had the possible side effect of drowsiness but this was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  He was familiar with the roadway and his vehicle.\n\nV2 was driven by a 17-year-old male who was treated by EMS at the scene for minor injuries but was not transported.  The driver of V2 stated that he was lost so he decided to move to the shoulder then make a U-turn.  He did not see the white truck behind him and was struck on the left side then pushed to final rest across the roadway.  He stated that he was traveling less than 5 MPH at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was when V2 went over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was when V2 attempted to negotiate an illegal maneuver (U-turn) in front of V1.  Inattention was coded as an associated factor because the driver of V2 admitted that he was lost.  Consequently, he was thinking about this fact rather than focusing on the driving task.  Similarly, an exterior distraction was coded as an associated factor - he was busy looking around for his intended destination.  Inadequate surveillance was also coded as an associated factor - had the driver of V2 checked all his mirrors, he would have seen V1 approaching.  Finally, while the driver of V2 was familiar with his vehicle, this was the first time he had driven on this roadway.  This helps explain the fact that he was lost, looking around for his intended destination, and inattentive to the driving task.\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a five-lane roadway with a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight with snow and slush on the roadway at 1:06 pm on a Monday afternoon.  The roadway had a posted speed of 50 MPH and the northbound lane had a positive 3% grade. \n\n     V1 was a 1998 Toyota Camry sedan intending on going straight thru the intersection with a green light in the southbound lane.  V2 was a 1994 Dodge Intrepid sedan intending on turning left at the same intersection with a green light.  V2 was in the northbound lane.  As V2 was turning left, the front of V2 struck the left side of V1.  V1 continued on and the front right corner struck a guardrail, coming to final rest.  V2 came to final rest in the center of the intersection-heading north. \n\n     A 34-year-old male who was transported drove V1 and was transported to a local hospital with minor injuries.  He stated that he was going straight in the southbound lane and he saw the other vehicle turning in front of him.  He was unable to take any avoidance actions.  V1 continued straight and the front of V1 rested against a guardrail.  The driver of V1 was traveling at 50 MPH at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage and had a CDC of 10LYEW1.\n\n     No critical precrash event and no critical reason were coded to the driver of V1.  The driver of V1 wears prescription glasses and is near sighted.  He felt rested before the crash sequence.\n    \n      A 34-year-old male drove V2 and sustained minor injuries but was not transported.  He did not have a license and spoke very little English.  His primary language was Spanish.  Thru translation he stated that the light was green so he turned left.  He saw V1 but thought he was stopped. V2 was traveling less than 5 MPH at the time of impact and final rest was facing in a northwest direction.  V2 was towed due to damage and had a CDC of 11FLEN1.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V2 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The critical reason for the critical event was weather related, primarily snow restricting his view.  The driver of V2 stated that he was also fatigued from his busy work schedule.  He works six days a week, ten hours each day and only gets seven hours of sleep each night.  The driver of V2 was thought not to have contributed to the crash.

The crash occurred in the intersection of a five-lane roadway with a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight, dry in the early afternoon on a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed of 81 KPH (50 MPH) and the northbound lane had a positive 3% grade. \n\nV2 was a 1992 Ford Escort coupe intending on going straight through the intersection with a green light in the southbound lane. V2 came to final rest in the center of the intersection-heading southwest. \n\nA 33-year-old male drove V1 and sustained minor injuries but was not transported. V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 is other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  There was no Critical Reason coded to the driver of V2.  He felt rested before the crash sequence and was familiar with the area.\n

The roadway was wet and level.\n\nV1 was a 1996 Chevy Cavalier coupe that was traveling south in the right lane. The occupant of V1 claimed not to be the driver and did not recall what had happened.  Upon police investigation, they concluded that the occupant of V1 was actually the driver and that no other person was present in the vehicle.  The driver needed to be extricated from the vehicle.  Information provided by local authorities show that the occupant while involved in illegal activity had been robbed and then stole a neighbor\'s vehicle (V1) in order to give chase. Driver of V1 was unavailable for interview due to incarceration and a false address on PAR.\n\nThe critical precrash event was V1 traveling too fast for conditions. V2 was a 1994 Ford Taurus sedan directly in back of V2 intending on going straight.  The driver of V2 was looking to the left then looked straight ahead.  V2 tried to steer left and brake to avoid V1.  The front of V2 struck the back of V1 in the westbound lane.  Both vehicles came to final rest facing west.\n\nThe driver of V1 was 68 years old and was transported to a local hospital with minor injuries. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V1 was other motor vehicle was in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to V1. Associated factors coded was fatigue due to a busy work schedule, driver recognition factor - looking at approaching traffic from the left side, and driver experience factors - had driven this vehicle only 4 times. The roadway had a posted speed of 40 MPH and was level.  There was a road department truck in the center of the double-yellow line approximately 100-150 feet north from point of impact.\n\n     V1 was a 1994 Dodge 350 Ram Van going straight in the northbound lane.  V2 was a 1992 Toyota Camry sedan traveling south in the southbound lane.  V2 made a left turn in front of V1 and the front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in the northbound lane.  The impact rotated V2 180 degrees and came to final rest in the northbound lane.  V1 came to final rest against the apex of the northeast curb.  \n\n     V1 was driven by a 55-year-old female who was transported to a local hospital with minor injuries.  She had stated that she was going straight, about 40 MPH, and saw V2 turn into her direction.  She immediately braked.  V1 was towed due to damage and had a CDC of 10LYEW1. \n\n     The critical pre-crash event for V1 was when V2 encroached into her lane from the opposite direction, over the left lane line.  The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  The van also had two other occupants, both refusing medical attention.\n\n     V1 was driven by an 89-year-old male who was not injured.  He had stated that he was going straight and saw the road department truck and was distracted by them.  Soon after, he made a left turn and struck V1.  He was traveling less than 5 MPH at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage and had a CDC of 12FDEW1.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V2 was when V2 was turning left.  The critical reason for the critical event was when V2 had inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).   The driver of V2 is currently taking four medications (Coamadin, Procardia, Rynotan & Phyllocontin) each day for high blood pressure and chest decongestion.  He was wearing his prescription glasses that corrected a farsighted condition.  He was also wearing his hearing aid in his right ear.  The driver of V2 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane roadway.  Conditions were daylight in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 40 MPH (64 KMPH).\n\nV1 was a 1999 Toyota Camry sedan traveling westbound in the right lane.  V2, a 2002 Ford F150 pickup truck, was traveling eastbound in the right lane.  As V1 was traveling westbound, a dead animal was in the roadway and V1 swerved right to try and avoid it but lost control of the vehicle.  V1 fishtailed for several meters and V1 entered oncoming traffic and the front of V1 struck the left side of V2 in the eastbound lane.  Both vehicles then spun counter clockwise.  V1 came to final rest off the roadway in a field facing northeast.  V2 struck a curb, went down a -45% embankment, and came to final rest against a tree facing south.\n\nV1 was driven by a 21-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he saw the dead animal, swerved right, then lost control of his vehicle and struck V2.  V1 was traveling between 41 and 50 MPH (66 and 80 KMPH) and did not take any avoidance actions before striking V2.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle control loss due to - traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a performance errors - poor directional control e.g.. Failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected.  The driver of V1 is familiar with the roadway and was wearing glasses at the time of the collision for his myopic condition.  An associated factor coded to this vehicle was a driver recognition factor/exterior factor, the dead animal in the roadway.\n\nV2 was driven by a 29-year-old male who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  He stated he was driving eastbound when V1 swerved into his lane.  He had no time to take any avoidance actions.  V2 was traveling between 31 and 40 MPH (50 and 64 KMPH) at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors coded to this vehicle was driver recognition, the driver was conversing with his wife.  The driver of V2 travels this road daily and is comfortable driving his vehicle.\n

The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a five-lane divided roadway at an intersection with another five-lane divided roadway. There were three lanes westbound and two lanes eastbound. The intersection was controlled by a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight with rain in the morning on a weekend.  The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 MPH).\n\n     V1 was a 2001 Hyundai Tiburon coupe traveling westbound in the third westbound lane approaching the intersection with a red traffic control signal.  V2, a 2000 Ford F150 pickup, was traveling southbound in the left turn lane intending on turning left at the intersection.  V3, a 1995 Peterbilt dump truck, was traveling southbound in the second lane intending on turning left at the intersection.  V1 ran the red signal and struck the left side bumper of V2.  V1 continued on and struck the left side of V3 in the westbound lane.  V1 came to final rest facing westbound.  V2 and V3 came to final rest facing eastbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 21-year-old male who sustained minor injuries but was not treated or transported.  The driver refused to be interviewed at the scene.  The critical precrash event for the driver of V1 was when he began to cross over the intersection. The critical reason for the critical precrash event was a decision error - an illegal maneuver (running a red TCD).  One associated factor coded to V1 was the weather - it was raining at the time of the crash. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 41-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he had a green signal, entered the intersection but saw V1 on his left.  V2 then accelerated but was struck on the left bumper by V1.  V2 was traveling between 11 and 20 MPH at the time of impact.  V2 was driven away from the scene.  The driver of V2 did not want the EDR information to be downloaded from his vehicle.  \n\n     The critical precrash event for the driver of V2 was when V1 encroached into V2\'s lane from the crossing street, across path.  No critical reason for the critical precrash event was coded to this vehicle.  The only associated factor coded to this vehicle was the weather - it was raining at the time of the crash.\n\n     V3 was driven by a 44-year old male who was not injured.  He stated that he had a green signal, entered the intersection and was struck by V1 on his left side.  V3 was traveling between 1 and 10 MPH at the time of impact.  No avoidance actions were taken and V3 was driven away from the scene.  \n\n     No critical precrash event and no critical reason were coded to the driver of V3 because he was not involved in the first harmful event (the impact between V1 and V2).  Two associated factors were coded to the driver of V3. The first associated factor was the same as the other two drivers - the weather (rain). Also, the driver of V3 participated in a recreational activity during the last 7 days that involved periods of strenuous activity; however, he was not thought to have been fatigued at the time of the crash.

The crash occurred off the right side of the roadway of a two-lane roadway.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the morning on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 56 KMPH (35 MPH).\n\n     V1 was a 1993 Chevy S10 Blazer SUV traveling eastbound in the right lane.  V1 departed the right side of the travel lane and struck the right curb.  He then continued on and the front of V1 struck a utility pole.  V1 came to final rest against the pole facing east.\n\n     V1 was driven by an 80-year-old male who was unconscious minutes before the crash occurred.  V1 was towed due to damage.   The Critical Precrash Event was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a critical non-performance error; when the driver of V1 was unconscious with the inability to act.  \n\n     Numerous attempts were made in order to obtain an interview from the driver of V1 but the outcome was unsuccessful.\n

The crash occurred in the middle of an intersection of a four-lane roadway controlled by a traffic control signal.  Conditions were dark with lights and dry in the evening on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 64 kpmh (40 mph) for the southbound lane and 40 kmph (25 mph) for the westbound lane.\n\n     V1 was a 1993 Plymouth Grand Voyager minivan traveling southbound in the right lane approaching the intersection with a green traffic control signal intending on continuing straight.  V2, a 2000 Chevy Malibu sedan, was traveling northbound in travel lane #2 intending on turning left at the intersection.  As V1 was going straight, an unknown vehicle stopped to let V2 turn.  V1 was to the right of the unknown vehicle and the driver of V2 did not see V1.  The front right of V2 struck the front of V1 in the southbound lane.  V1 then struck a utility pole.  V1 came to final rest facing southwest against the pole.  V2 came to final rest facing west.\n\n     A 29-year-old female drove V1 and was not injured.  She stated that the light was green and she didn\'t see V2 until the last second.  The driver of V1 braked and swerved right and hit the pole.  V1 was traveling between 34 and 48 kmph (21 and 30 mph) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was the other vehicle encroachment from the opposite direction-over the left lane line.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to V1.  The driver felt rested and was familiar with the area.\n\n     A 30-year-old female drove V2 and was not injured.  She stated that the light was green and an unknown vehicle opposing her stopped to let her turn left.  The driver of V2 did not see V1.  V2 was traveling between 18 and 32 kmph (11 and 20 mph) at the time of impact.  V2 did not take any avoidance actions.  V2 remained at the scene.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error; inadequate surveillance; looked but did not see.  Associated factors coded to V2 a include a driver recognition factor; driver inattention regarding an undisclosed personal problem, other recognition factor; impending problem masked by traffic flow pattern, inexperienced driver; first time driving this vehicle and only having license for one year.

The crash occurred in the right lane of a four-lane roadway.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the early evening on a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed of 64 KMPH (40 MPH) with a curve left.\n\n     V1 was a 2003 Jeep Wrangler Sport intending on negotiating a curve in the southbound lane.  As V1 was negotiating the curve, an unknown vehicle passed this vehicle on the left and cut in front of V1.  V1 then swerved right and struck the curb.  V1 then drifted left across three travel lanes and the right side of V1 struck a curb then a tree.  V1 then rolled left two-quarter turns coming to final rest onto its roof facing southwest.\n\n     A 26-year-old female drove V1 and sustained minor injuries but was not transported.  She stated that an unknown vehicle cut her off and she swerved right and that is when she lost control of V1.  After striking the tree, the driver of V1 does not recall what had happened.  V1 was traveling between 50 and 64 KMPH (31 and 40 MPH) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a decision error; too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users; unknown vehicle cut off V1.  The driver felt rested before the crash sequence and was familiar with the area.  The police officer in charge on the investigation conducted a field sobriety test, which the driver passed.

The crash occurred off the right side of a two-lane undivided roadway.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 40 KMPH (25 MPH).\n\n     V1, a 1987 Toyota 4-Runner pickup truck, was traveling northbound when the front right tire blew out. The driver tried to pull over and bring the vehicle to a stop; however, the vehicle veered right, jumped the curb, and then the front right of the vehicle struck a utility pole.  V1 came to final rest facing eastbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 37-year old male who was transported with moderate injuries prior to the researcher\'s arrival.  The driver spoke little English and a police officer translated the interview.  He stated that his steering wheel was shaking and he braked and tried to pull over to the right but his vehicle jumped the curb and struck the pole.  He estimated his speed at impact to be between 21 and 30 MPH.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when the vehicle lost control due to a blow out to the right front tire.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a vehicle related factor - tire failed.   The driver was familiar with the roadway and felt rested prior to the crash. No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\n

The crash occurred in the southbound lane of a three-lane roadway with a median controlled by a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight with rain in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 80 KMPH (50 MPH) with a -2% downhill grade.\n\n     V1 was a 1990 Honda Civic sedan traveling southbound in the second travel lane approaching an intersection controlled by a traffic control signal.  V2, a 1999 Chevy Silverado pick-up, was stopped in traffic in the southbound lane in front of V1.  The front of V1 struck the back of V2 in the southbound lane.  Both vehicles came to final rest facing southbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 18-year-old female who was not injured.  She stated that she was talking to her friend and did not realize how close she was to V2.  She then braked and swerved right but struck V2 in the rear.  V1 was traveling between 50 and 64 KMPH (31 and 40 MPH) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when this vehicle was decelerating in the traffic lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error; internal distraction.  Associated factors coded to this driver were the driver not being familiar with the roadway and driving.  The driver had her license for one year prior to the crash.\n\n      V2 was driven by a 70-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he was stopped in traffic and was struck in the rear by V1.  V2 did not take any avoidance actions.  V2 was driven away from the scene. \n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle in the travel lane; traveling in same direction while decelerating.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.  The driver was taking medication for diabetes and high blood pressure.

The crash occurred off the right side of a two-lane roadway at a T-intersection.  Conditions were dry with daylight in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit on the initial roadway of travel was 80 kmph (50 MPH) and 32 kmph (20 MPH) on the intersecting roadway.\n\n     V1 was 1988 Plymouth Reliant sedan traveling eastbound.  V1 was driven by a 94-year old female who was traveling approximately 20 MPH on the 50 MPH roadway. Consequently, vehicles behind her were honking their horns in an attempt to make her speed up or get out of the way. The driver of V1 tried to accelerate but did not feel her vehicle respond. She decided to turn left at a T-intersection to let the other vehicles pass her. While making the left turn, the vehicle suddenly accelerated and the driver took the turn at too wide of an angle. It departed the right side of the roadway and struck a curb, a sign, and then a tree.  V1 came to final rest on the roadway facing northwest.\n\n     The driver of V1 sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  She stated that as she was turning left, her vehicle accelerated out of control.  It is believed that the driver of V1 was not pressing down hard enough on the accelerator prior to the left turn, but then did not ease up on the accelerator as she began the turn. This caused her to take the turn at a speed that was not comfortable to her. There was no substantiation to her claim that the vehicle suddenly accelerated on its own as its driver was making a left turn. The crash was believed to be due to confusion on the part of the driver, which caused a performance error. The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as "This vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side" and the Critical Reason was coded as "Poor directional control, e.g. failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected." Associated factors coded to this driver were several physical ailments including high blood pressure, cataracts, myopic vision, hearing deficit and a pacemaker. The driver also takes several medications for her ailments. The driver was wearing corrective lenses and a hearing aid at the time of the crash. Other associated factors coded to this driver were her being upset by the vehicles behind her honking their horns and the perceived vehicle malfunction.

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane roadway with a T-intersection.  Conditions were dusk and dry in the evening on a weekend.  The northbound lane had a posted speed limit of 40 kmph (25 mph) and the eastbound lane had a posted speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 2003 Hyundai Elantra sedan traveling eastbound in the right lane approaching a T-intersection.  V2, a 1998 Ford Taurus sedan, was traveling northbound in the right lane approaching a stop sign intending on turning left.  V2 stopped at the stop sign, looked in both directions but there was landscaping and a fence obstructing V2\'s view.  V2 then proceeded to turn left and the front of V1 struck the left side of V2 in the intersection., as V1 passed by V2, V2\'s right front contacted the back of V1.  V1 continued on and struck a curb and a tree.  V1 came to final rest facing eastbound.  V2 continued on and struck a curb and came to final rest facing northwest.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 61-year-old female who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  She stated that she was traveling eastbound and saw V2 turn in front of her.  The driver of V1 braked and swerved left but struck the left side of V2.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was other vehicle encroachment from crossing street turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors coded to this driver include several physical ailments such as high blood pressure, diabetes and asthma.  The driver of V1 also takes several medications for these ailments.  The driver is familiar with the roadway.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 26-year-old female who was not injured.  She stated that she stopped at the stop sign, looked in both directions but was unable to see V1 because of a fence and landscaping obstruction.  V2 intending on turning left but was struck by V1.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was an environmental related factor; view obstructed by a fence and landscaping.  Associated factors coded to this driver was a recognition factor; driver was conversing with the passenger, inadequate surveillance; looked but did not see, the driver being unlicensed.  The driver was familiar with the roadway.\n

The crash occurred off the left side of the road on a two-lane roadway with a curve-right.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 48 KMPH (30 MPH).\n\nV1 was a 2002 GMC Envoy Sport Utility Vehicle that was traveling eastbound negotiating the right curve in the road.  As V1 was negotiating the curve, a small animal ran across the roadway and the driver swerved left to avoid it.  V1 then struck the curb, a tree, and support wires.  V1 came to final rest facing eastbound.\n\nV1 was driven by an 81-year old male who was transported due to moderate injuries.  He stated that a small animal ran across the roadway and he swerved left to try and avoid it but lost control of his vehicle.  V1 was traveling between 31 and 40 MPH at the time of impact and was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was an animal in the roadway.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was overcompensation, a performance error.  The driver claimed that he felt rested before the crash and that he takes several vitamins and medications for high blood pressure.  He was familiar with the roadway and the vehicle.  Medical records indicated that the driver had a BAC of .18 less than an hour after the crash. This was coded as an associated factor, along with the use of prescription medications. It was learned that this driver was operating his vehicle with an expired driver\'s license.\n

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane roadway with a curve right.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 1999 Toyota Rav 4 SUV traveling westbound in the right lane negotiating a curve-right.  V2, a 2000 Jeep Cherokee SUV, was traveling eastbound in the right lane negotiating the same curve.  V1 drifted across the centerline and the front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the eastbound lane.  Both vehicles came to final rest facing northbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 50-year-old female who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  She stated that she was very upset due to recent news about her mother who was ill.  The driver drank two beers and continued to drive when her vehicle drifted across the centerline and struck V2.   V1 was traveling between 50 and 64 kmph (31 and 40 mph) at the time of impact.  The driver of V1 did not take any avoidance actions.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V1 was when this vehicle drifted over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The critical reason for the critical precrash event was a recognition error; driver inattention.  The driver stated that she wasn\'t thinking straight and was very upset over her mother\'s illness prior to the crash. (NOTE: In addition to this inattention factor, the driver had a BAC reading of 0.307. She was, therefore grossly intoxicated). There were no other associated factors coded to this driver, however, the driver does work close to 60 hours per week.  The driver feels rested when she wakes up in the morning and does not have any pre-existing medical ailments.  The driver is familiar with the area.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 32-year-old male who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  He stated that he was traveling eastbound when he saw a white vehicle drift into his lane.  The driver of V2 then braked and swerved right to try and avoid the vehicle but was unsuccessful.  The driver of V2 was traveling between 66 and 80 kmph (41 and 50 mph) at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V2 was the other motor vehicle in his lane, traveling in opposite direction.  The critical reason for the critical precrash event was not coded to this vehicle.   The driver of V2 is on a rotating work schedule but this was not thought to have contributed to the crash.

The driver of V1 is not the owner and both the inspection and interview were refused.\n\n     The crash occurred in the northbound lane of a four-lane undivided roadway.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the afternoon on a weekday.  The roadway was dry, straight, and level. The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 MPH).\n\n     V1 was a 1993 Cadillac DeVille traveling northbound in the right lane. V2 was a 1999 Honda Odyssey minivan traveling directly behind V1.  V3 was a 2002 Hyundai XG350 sedan traveling directly in back of V2 and V4 was a 1988 Cadillac sedan traveling directly in back of V3.  For reasons unknown, V1 braked several times and the front of V2 struck the back of V1 in the northbound lane.  The front of V3 then struck the rear of V2 in the northbound lane.  The front of V4 then struck the back of V3 in the northbound lane.  All vehicles came to final rest facing northbound. \n\n     V1 was driven by a 63-year old male who was not injured.  V1 was driven away from the scene. The Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when there was another vehicle in his lane, traveling in the same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1. Associated factors coded to this driver were following too closely and the traffic flow interruption in the form of heavy traffic.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 28-year old female who was not injured.  She stated that the vehicle in front of her kept braking then slammed on its brakes and the front of V2 struck the back of V1 in the northbound lane.  V2 was traveling between 1 and 10 MPH at the time of impact.  V2 braked prior to impact but was unsuccessful.  V2 was driven away from the scene.\n\n     The critical precrash event for the driver of V2 was when there was another vehicle stopped in her lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cFollowing too closely to respond to unexpected actions of other road users.\xe2\x80\x9d  Associated factors coded to this driver were following too closely and the traffic flow interruption in the form of heavy traffic.  The driver of V2 also had her three children in the vehicle and this may have served as a distraction.  The driver is familiar with the area and drives on this road daily.  The driver does not work and does not have any pre-existing medical ailments.\n\n     V3 was driven by a 62-year old male who was not injured.  He stated that he saw V2 slam on its brakes so he did the same but was unsuccessful.  The front of V3 struck the back of V2 in the northbound lane.  The driver of V3 reported that he was traveling between 41 and 50 MPH at the time of impact.  V3 was towed due to damage. No Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because he was not involved in the first harmful event. One associated factor coded to this driver was excess speed, because by his own admission he was exceeding the posted speed limit. Another associated factor coded to this driver was the traffic flow interruption in the form of heavy traffic. The driver of V3 drives this road several times a month and is comfortable with the roadway.  The driver is retired and does not have any pre-existing medical ailments.\n\n

The crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection.  Conditions were daylight with rain in the morning on a weekday.  Both lanes had a posted speed limit of 72 kmph (45 mph).  \n\n     V1 was a 2003 Kia Rio sedan traveling southbound in the right lane approaching the intersection with a blinking beacon light.  V2, a 2002 Honda Civic sedan, was traveling northbound in the right lane approaching the same intersection.  V1 made a left turn in front of V2 and the front of V2 struck the right side of V1 in the middle of the intersection.  The two vehicles then side-slapped the front right bumper of V1 hit the right rear wheel rim of V2.  V1 came to final rest facing west.  V2 came to final rest facing northeast. \n\n     V1 was driven by a 44-year-old female who was not injured.  She stated that she thought that V2 was turning so she made a left turn in front of V2.  The front of V2 struck the right side of V1.  V1 was traveling between 50 and 64 kmph (31 and 40 mph) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling and turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a false assumption of other road user\'s actions.  \n\n     V2 was driven by a 19-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he was going straight when he saw V1 make a left turn in front of him.  He swerved left and braked but was unsuccessful.  V2 was traveling between (21 and 30 mph) at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle encroachment from the opposite direction over the left lane line. The crash occurred in the southbound lane of a two-lane roadway with a T-intersection.  Conditions were daylight with cloudy skies and rain in the morning on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 72 kmph (45 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 2003 Acura 3.2 TL sedan traveling eastbound in the right lane approaching a T-intersection with a stop sign.  V2, a 1993 Ford Aerostar minivan, was traveling southbound in the right lane approaching the T-intersection.  V1 made a left turn at the stop sign and the front of V2 struck the left front corner of V1 in the southbound lane.  V1 spun clockwise and came to final rest facing westbound.  V2 came to final rest facing southbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 26-year-old male who was injured but refused medical treatment.  He stated that he was stopped at the stop sign for several seconds, looked both ways then proceeded to turn left and did not see V2 at all.  He stated that his windshield and windows were foggy and this may have contributed to the crash.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error; inadequate surveillance; looked but did not see.  Associated factors coded to this driver include a vehicle condition related factor; view obstruction related to condensation build-up on the interior glazing and a weather related factor; rain.  The driver is familiar with the roadway and is comfortable with his vehicle.  He was wearing glasses for this myopic vision.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 25-year old male who was transported to a local hospital with moderate injuries.  He stated that he was traveling southbound in the right lane and saw the other vehicle sticking out of the intersection then seconds later the vehicle pulled out in front of him.  The driver of V2 locked up the brakes but was unable to avoid V1.  The front of V2 struck the left front corner of V1 in the southbound lane.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle encroachment from the crossing street, turning into the same direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this driver. The crash occurred in the westbound lanes of a four-lane roadway separated by a raised curb median (two lanes each direction) at an intersection controlled by a traffic signal.  Conditions were daylight with clouds in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 MPH).  The westbound lanes had a negative 2 percent slope.\n\n     V1 was a 2004 Chevy Cavalier sedan traveling around a jug-handle intending to turn left at the intersection with the east/west roadway.  V2, a 2002 Buick Century sedan, was traveling westbound in the left lane intending on continuing straight through the intersection with a green traffic control signal.  The driver of V1 stated that she stopped for a red traffic signal, and when she thought that her light had changed to green, she entered the intersection. The front of V1 struck the right front side of V2.  V2 was deflected to the left and onto the grass median where the front of V2 struck a traffic control signal post.  V1 came to final rest facing southeast and V2 came to final rest facing southwest.  A witness that was identified on the police report as traveling to the right of and behind V2 indicated that the traffic signal for westbound traffic had been green. The county\'s highway department reviewed the tripped curcuit and verified that traffic on the jug-handle (V1) had a red light.\n\n     A 41-year old female drove V1 and was not injured.  She stated that she was traveling around the jug-handle intending on turning left at the intersection with a possible green traffic control signal when V2 struck the front of her vehicle.  The driver of V1 did not have time to take any avoidance actions.  V1 was traveling between 11-20 MPH at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical pre-crash event for V1 was when it began to turn left at the intersection.  The critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was coded as an Iinadequate surveillance because she did not look at the signal again - she thought her light had turned green. Associated factors coded to the driver of V1 include an illegal maneuver (entering an intersection with a red light) and a false assumption of other road user\'s actions - when interviewed, the driver of V1 stated that she saw V2 approaching from her left but thought that V2 would stop.\n\n           A 69-year old female drove V2 and sustained minor injuries.  She stated that she was traveling westbound in the left lane with a green traffic control signal when she saw V1 run the red traffic light.  The driver of V2 did not have time to take any avoidance actions.  The front of V1 struck the right front side of V2 in the westbound lane.  V2 then continued on and struck a traffic control signal post.  V2 was traveling between 31- 40 MPH at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical pre-crash event for V2 was the other vehicle encroachment from the crossing street, turning into opposite direction.   The critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 drove this road daily and was familiar with the roadway.  The driver was wearing glasses for her hyperopic condition.  The driver of V2 was also taking a prescribed cancer medication. It was not thought that the driver of V2 took any actions that contributed to the crash.

The crash occurred in the middle of an intersection of a four-lane roadway controlled by a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the early evening on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 mph) for V1 and 72 kmph (45 mph) for V2.\n\n     V1 was a 2003 Buick Century sedan traveling northbound in the 3rd travel lane approaching a green traffic control signal intending on turning left at the intersection.  V2, a 2004 Toyota Corolla sedan, was traveling southbound in the second travel lane approaching the same green traffic control signal intending on continuing straight.  V1 looked but did not see V2 approaching and proceeded to make a left turn at the intersection.  The front right of V1 struck the front of V2 in the middle of the intersection.  V1 then spun 45 degrees and both vehicles came to final rest facing southwest.\n\n     A 74-year old male drove V1 and sustained minor injuries but refused any medical attention.  He stated that he was traveling between 1 and 10 MPH when he approached the intersection, looked ahead, then turned left.  The driver of V1 did not see V2 at all.  The driver of V1 did not take any avoidance actions.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V1 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The critical reason for the critical precrash event was a driver related factor - inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  The driver felt rested prior to the crash and was somewhat familiar with the roadway.  He reported that he drove on it several times a month.  The driver had two passengers in the vehicle. No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\n     A 22-year old female drove V2 and sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital. V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line.  No reason for the critical precrash event was coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\n\n\n     \n
../resources/summary/2005004112641.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the right lane of a three-lane roadway near a T-intersection controlled by a traffic control signal.  Conditions were daylight and clear in the afternoon on a weekday.  The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 1990 Chevy C25 Cheyenne pickup truck traveling eastbound in the right lane approaching a T-intersection with a traffic control signal.  V2, a 2005 Cadillac STS sedan, was traveling eastbound in the right lane directly in front of V1 and decelerating in traffic.  V3, a 1996 Ford Explorer SUV, was traveling eastbound in the right lane directly 3-4 car lengths in front of V2.  The driver of V1 was traveling between 21-30 MPH when he looked down for a second then looked back up and struck the back of V2.  The driver of V1 braked and swerved right prior to the first impact. The front of V2 was pushed into the rear of V3.  All three vehicles came to final rest facing eastbound in the right lane.  \n\n     A 39-year old male drove V1 and was not injured.  He stated that he was traveling eastbound in the right lane at about 21-30 MPH when he looked down at his lap for a second. When he looked up, he saw that V2 was decelerating abruptly and he slammed on his brakes and swerved right in response but could not avoid contacting V2.  He stated that there was stop and go traffic but thought he had enough room in between both vehicles.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when V2 was decelerating while in the same lane in front of V1.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error - an internal distraction when the driver looked down while driving.  The driver had about 100 lbs. of cargo in the bed of his pickup but there was no cargo shift or cargo spillage.  The driver was familiar with the area and the surrounding traffic.  The driver was keeping up with traffic but did not think he was traveling too closely.  \n\n     A 57-year old male drove V2 and was transported due to moderate injuries.  He stated that he was decelerating in traffic when he was struck in the back by V1.  The driver of V2 did not take any avoidance actions.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle in his lane, traveling in the same direction but at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 had three pre-existing medical conditions including sleep apnea, but he does not receive any treatment for his sleep apnea.  The driver reported being drowsy prior to the crash.  \n\n     A 23-year old male drove V3 and was not injured.  He stated that he was stopped in traffic when he saw V1 in his rearview mirror driving very fast towards the vehicle in back of him.  The driver of V3 turned his wheel to the right but was struck in the back by V2.  V3 was driven away from the scene.\n\n     No Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to V3 because it was not involved in the first harmful event.  The driver of V3 was talking with his passenger at the time of the crash but had watched the crash unfold in his rear view mirror. It was not thought that the driver of V3 contributed to the crash. \n\n
