The crash occurred in the westbound lanes of a three-lane roadway with a T-intersection.  Conditions were dark with lights, dry with cloudy skies in the evening on a weekday.  The westbound lanes had a posted speed of 80 kmph (50 mph), the southbound lane had a speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 1998 Ford Escort sedan traveling southbound in the right lane approaching a T-intersection with a stop sign.  V2, a 1993 Subaru Legacy sedan, was traveling westbound in the right lane approaching the T-intersection.  V1 made a left turn at the stop sign and the front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in the westbound lane.  Both vehicles came to final rest facing westbound.  \n\n     V1 was driven by a 19-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he was lost and trying to find a church that was close by.  He approached the stop sign and did not see V2 until it was too late.  He turned left directly into V2 traveling between 21-30 MPH.    V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when this vehicle was turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was inadequate surveillance; he looked but did not see.  Associated factors coded to this driver was the driver being fatigued due to a busy work and exercise schedule, the driver not familiar with the area (he was lost), and traveling too fast (he was in a hurry).  The driver has myopic (near-sighted) vision but does not need to wear glasses to drive, this was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 63-year-old female who was transported to a local hospital with minor injuries.  The driver refused to be interviewed at the hospital and refused us when we visited her home.  V2 remained at the scene.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was when V1 encroached from the crossing street, turning into the opposite direction.  No Critical Reason was coded to the driver of V2.

The southbound lane had a posted speed limit of 80 KMPH (50 MPH) with a -2% downhill grade.  \n\n     V1 was a 2003 Honda Civic sedan traveling southbound in the right lane when a wild turkey encroached from the driver\'s right side.  The driver of V1 swerved left to avoid the bird but lost control of the vehicle.  V1 departed the right side of the roadway and the front of V1 struck a utility pole.  V1 came to final rest facing south.  \n\n     V1 was driven by a 21-year-old female who sustained minor injuries and was transported to the hospital by her mother.  The driver of V1 was on her way to school and is familiar with the roadway.  V1 was traveling between 50 and 64 KMPH (31 and 40 MPH) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event was an animal in the roadway and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was a performance error; overcompensation.  The driver of V1 performed household chores that involved strenuous labor within the last seven days but this was thought not to have contributed to the crash. There were no associated factors coded to V1.

The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a three-lane intersection.  Conditions were daylight on a weekend.  The westbound lane had a posted speed limit of 56 KMPH (35 MPH) and the northbound lane had a posted speed limit of 64 KMPH (40 MPH).\n\n     V1 was a 2002 Honda CRV traveling westbound in the right lane approaching the intersection with a green traffic control signal.  V2, a 2003 Dodge Durango, was traveling northbound in the left lane approaching the same intersection.  V2 went thru the red traffic control and the front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in the westbound lane.  V2 came to final rest facing northwest.  V1 continued on and struck a curb then rolled \xc2\xbc turn onto its left side.  V1 came to final rest on its left side facing north.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 65-year-old male who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  The driver of V1 stated that he was on a \xe2\x80\x9cSunday drive\xe2\x80\x9d with his wife, proceeded thru the intersection with a green traffic control signal, and was struck on the left side.  No avoidance actions were taken and the driver of V1 was traveling between 66 and 80 KMPH (41 and 50 MPH) at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was the other vehicle encroaching into his lane from the crossing street, across path.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.  The driver felt fatigued, wears glasses for reading and takes medication for high blood pressure but none of these factors was thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 31-year-old female who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  The driver of V2 stated that she looked down to reach for a lighter and when she looked back up it was too late and the collision occurred.  No avoidance actions were taken.  V2 was traveling between 50 and 64 KMPH (31 and 40 MPH) at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was this vehicle crossing over (passing through) the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error; internal distraction.  Associated factors coded to this driver were driver inattention and emotional factors.  The driver stated that she was very upset over family problems and was thinking about them when the crash occurred.  The driver also takes medication for high blood pressure but this was thought not to have contributed to the crash.  The driver also feels fatigued when she wakes up in the morning.  The driver travels on this roadway daily and gets an average of 6 hours of sleep.  The driver was wearing non-prescription sunglasses at the time of impact.  After the impact the driver blacked out.

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane intersection controlled by a stop sign.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the morning on a weekday.  The eastbound lane had a posted speed limit of 40 kmph (25 mph) with a stop sign; the southbound lane had a speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\nV1 was 1999 Pontiac Montana Minivan, which was traveling southbound in the right lane approaching an intersection.  V2, a 1991 Ford Tempo sedan, was traveling eastbound in the right lane approaching the intersection with a stop sign.  V2 stopped at the stop sign and then proceeded through the intersection.  V1\'s front struck the left side of V2 in the eastbound lane.  V1 came to final rest facing eastbound and V2 came to final rest facing northbound.\n\nV1 was driven by a 40-year-old female who was not injured.  She stated that she was going straight, saw V2 stopped at the sign, and then saw V2 accelerate into her path.  The driver of V1 didn\'t understand why V2 decided to accelerate.  The driver of V1 braked but could not successfully avoid V2.  V1 was traveling between 17-32 kmph (11-20 mph) at the time of impact.  V1 was driven from the scene.  The driver of V1 did not want me to take any pictures of the vehicle.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was when the V2 encroached into V1\'s lane from the crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to V1.  The driver of V1 was conversing with the occupants but denied that this contributed to the crash.\n\nV2 was driven by a 62-year-old male who was not injured.  She stated that she stopped at the stop sign, looked in both directions, and then proceeded through the intersection and was struck on the left side by V1.  The driver of V2 did not see V1.  V2 was traveling less than 16 kmph (10 mph) at the time of impact.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was This Vehicle Traveling - Passing through the Intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was Inadequate Surveillance - looked but did not see.  An associative factor was environment related - the driver\'s view was obstructed by other parked vehicles.  Contributory factors coded to this driver were the driver being fatigued, the driver taking medication for a pre-existing health condition, and sight line restrictions - roadside parking obstructed the view.  V2 also failed to stop for a traffic control device.\n

This single-vehicle crash occurred off the left side of a two-lane undivided roadway in a wooded area.  The crash occurred on a weekend in the late afternoon hours while still daylight. The roadway was dry, straight and level with a posted speed limit of 80 kmph (50 mph). \n\n     V1 was a 1999 Buick Park Avenue sedan that was traveling westbound. The driver of V1, a 60-year old male, told police that a deer ran out into the roadway from his right.  The driver of V1 swerved right and drove over a curb. He then steered to the left and departed the roadway to the left before striking a tree and coming to final rest.  \n\n     The driver of V1 sustained moderate injuries and was transported prior to the researcher\'s arrival.  Police stated that he was traveling westbound when a deer ran across his path.  He swerved right, drove over a curb, and then veered left.  V1 was towed due to damage.  The driver of V1 refused to be interviewed.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when an animal was in the roadway.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a performance error - overcompensation. One important associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was alcohol intoxication. Although the police report did not indicate that alcohol was involved, medical records indicated that the driver of V1 had a BAC of .21 an hour and a half after the crash. Another associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was inadequate evasive action. The police report indicated that there was no evidence of heavy braking on the part of the driver. This lack of braking pressure combined with over-steering may have been the result of alcohol use.\n\n

The posted speed limit for both roads was 40 kmph (25 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 2005 Toyota Matrix hatchback traveling westbound in the right lane approaching an intersection. V2 came to final rest facing northwest.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 31-year-old male who was transported with moderate injuries to a local hospital prior to our arrival.  V1 was towed due to damage. Conditions were daylight and dry in the afternoon on a weekday. There was a flatbed tractor-trailer in the left lane intending on making a wide right-hand turn at the intersection.  V1 then accelerated to try and pass the truck but ended up steering hard to the right and departed the right side of the roadway and struck a traffic pole and several shrubs.  The traffic pole then fell and took down a utility pole, which then struck a pedestrian.  V1 did not make any contact with the truck or the pedestrian.  V1 came to final rest facing westbound against the bushes.\n\n     A 19-year old male drove V1 and was not injured.  He had an 18-year old passenger who also was not injured. The driver of V1 stated that he saw the truck try and make a wide right turn but accelerated to try and pass the truck. The driver stated that he didn\'t know what he was thinking and did not intend on causing a collision.  V1 was traveling between 41 and 50 MPH prior to the first impact. The driver felt rested and was familiar with the roadway and surrounding traffic.\n\n

\n\n     The crash occurred in the northbound lane of a two-lane roadway with a driveway related intersection.  Conditions were daylight in the morning on a weekend.  The posted speed limit for the northbound lane was 35 MPH.  There was no posted speed limit for the driveway.\n\n     V1 was a 2001 Buick Century sedan turning left out of the driveway facing westbound.  V2, a 2005 Toyota Tundra pick-up, was traveling northbound in the 1st travel lane approaching the driveway intending on going straight.  V1 made a left turn and the front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in the northbound lane.  Both vehicles came to final rest facing northbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 76-year-old female who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  She stated that prior to exiting the driveway, she looked both ways and couldn\'t see to her left because of a big sign.  She proceeded to turn left and struck V2.  V1 did not take any avoidance actions and was traveling less than 10 MPH at the time of impact.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V1 was when this vehicle was turning left at the intersection.  The critical reason for the critical precrash event was a highway related factor (view obstructed by a large sign).  Associated factors coded to this driver were  a sightline restriction (sign), inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see), and the driver turned with an obstructed view.  The driver takes several medications due to her pre-existing medical conditions but this was thought not to have contributed to the crash.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 46-year-old male who was not injured.  He stated that he was traveling northbound in the 1st travel lane when he saw V1 turn in front of him.  V1 did not have time to take any avoidance actions.  The driver of V2 did state that he is uncomfortable with the congestion on this roadway and rarely drives on it.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The critical precrash event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from the driveway turning into opposite direction.  No critical reason for the critical precrash event was coded to this driver.\n\n\n

The posted speed limit was 35 MPH.\n\n     V1 was a 1995 Volkswagen Passat sedan which was turning right and intending on going straight.  The driver of V1 lost control of his vehicle and departed the right side of the roadway and the front of V1 struck a tree.  V1 came to final rest up against the tree facing southwest.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 17-year-old male who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital. The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a two-lane intersection controlled by a stop sign.  Conditions were cloudy with rain in the morning on a weekday.  The posted speed limit for the eastbound lane was 40 kmph (25 mph) and the posted speed limit for the northbound lane was 64 kmph (40 mph).\n\n     V1 was a 2004 Volkswagen Jetta sedan traveling eastbound in the 1st travel lane approaching an intersection controlled by a stop sign intending on turning left.  V2, a 1991 Dodge minivan, was traveling southbound in the 1st travel lane approaching the intersection intending on going straight.  V3, a 1992 Buick Regal coupe, was traveling northbound in the 1st travel lane intending on going straight.  V1 looked but did not see V2 as she was making the left turn.  The front of V1 struck the right side of V2.  As a result of the impact, V2 then swerved into oncoming traffic and the front of V2 struck the front of V3 in the northbound lane.  V1 came to final rest facing eastbound, V2 came to final rest facing southbound and V3 came to final rest facing northbound.\n\n     V1 was driven by a 17-year-old female who was not injured.  Her parents refused to be interviewed.  The investigating officer stated that the driver of V1 stopped at the stop sign, looked in both directions and entered the intersection intending on turning left. V1 was driven away from the scene.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was inadequate surveillance, looked but did not see.  Associated factors coded to this driver were wet roads and the driver being inexperienced.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 44-year-old male who sustained moderate injuries and was transported to a local hospital.  He stated that he was traveling southbound in the 1st travel lane when he saw V1 pull out into the intersection and strike the right side of his vehicle.  He then stated that his vehicle was pushed into on coming traffic and struck V3.  V2 was traveling between 34 and 48 kmph (21 and 30 mph) at the time of impact and did not take any avoidance actions.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle encroachment from the crossing street, turning into opposite direction.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this driver.  \n\n     V3 was driven by a 17-year-old male who was not injured but was transported to a local hospital for observation.  He stated that he was traveling northbound in the 1st travel lane when he saw an unknown vehicle on his right in the shoulder.  He did not see V2 come into his lane until the last second.  The driver of V3 was traveling between 50 and 64 kmph (31 and 40 mph) at the time of impact.  The driver of V3 braked with out lock up but could not avoid V2.  V3 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V3 was not part of the first harmful event.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this driver.\n\n     \n\n\n

Conditions were cloudy and dry in the afternoon on a weekend.  The posted speed limit was 80 KMPH (50MPH).\n\n     V1 was a 2000 Chevy Malibu sedan traveling westbound in the 2nd travel lane intending on changing lanes to the 1st travel lane. As a result of the impact, V2 swerved left and the front of V3 struck the left side of V2 in the 3rd travel lane.  V2 continued on and struck a curb, drove onto the center median and struck a fence. This accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided, stop sign -controlled intersection.  The conditions were as follows: late afternoon, clear skies, the roadway was dry and no adverse atmospheric conditions were present.  The gradient for both roadways of V1 and V2 travel were level.  The posted speed limit for V1 was 56 kph (35 mph), whereas the posted speed limit for V2 was 40 kph (25 mph).\n\nV1 was a 2001 Ford Escort, traveling north, and did not have any traffic control devices, for its travel lane, giving V1 the right of way.  V1 was struck by V2 in the left front.  The impact caused V1 to be pushed off the side of the road, coming to final rest on the northbound side.  This vehicle needed to be towed from the scene.  V2 came to final rest after hitting the street sign on the northbound side of the road that V1 was traveling, which was near V1\'s final rest.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 19-year-old female who was treated by EMS on scene, with an ice bag for her arm.  The driver stated that she had the right of way, the side road had a stop sign.  The driver of V2 went across the street, he used poor judgment.  V1 was towed due to damage from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  After obtaining the interview from the driver of V1, there were no factors that contributed to this crash.  She was wearing her contacts that corrected her myopic (near-sighted) condition.  The driver stated that no medications were taken prior to the accident.  Furthermore, her emotional and fatigue levels at the time of the crash, as well as the days preceding, were normal.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 67-year-old male who did not need medical attention.  V2 was a 2002 Toyota Highlander, traveling east, that was stopped at a stop sign at the intersection.  The driver of V2 was supposed to cross over the perpendicular roadway that V1 was traveling.  Upon realization of the impending crash, the driver of V2 attempted to avoid the collision by steering his vehicle to the left.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  This vehicle also needed to be towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle traveling over, passing through the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is a decision error, misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.  He claimed to be in good health, but was taking a prescribed medication to lower blood pressure that was thought not to contribute to the crash.  Furthermore, his emotional and fatigue levels at the time of the crash, as well as the days preceding, were normal.

preprocessing
This one-vehicle crash occurred off of the roadway at a "T" intersection in an end departure configuration.  Both roadways of the intersection consisted of two, non-divided lanes of travel, each in opposite directions.  The northbound lane, upon which V1 (V1) was traveling, was controlled by a stop sign with no visual obstructions.  The posted speed limit for V1 was 40kph (25mph), while the crossing lane had a posted speed limit of 56kph (35mph).  There were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash, and the roadway was dry.  The gradient for the north/south lane was measured to be 6%; the crossroad was level.\n\nV1, a 1992 Oldsmobile 88 Royale, was traveling north approaching a stop sign at the intersection.  The vehicle crossed through the intersection, departed the roadway, and traveled down a fairly steep embankment of nearly 3 meters (10 feet).   V1 then traveled approximately 20-25 meters (66-82 feet) off of the roadway where it came to final rest, slightly hanging over another embankment leading down towards abandoned railroad tracks.  The vehicle had to be lifted back onto the roadway with the assistance of a bulldozer before being towed from the scene due to damage.   \n\nAll attempts to obtain the interview from the driver, a 24-year old male, were unsuccessful.  The PAR contained a narrative detailing the cause of this crash.  Initially the driver stated he lost control of the vehicle after swerving from the path of another vehicle.  When the officer followed up with the driver, the driver believed that he lost consciousness, which led him to drive off of the roadway and down the embankment.  The driver was trapped in the vehicle for approximately 90 minutes before being found.  He was transported to the hospital due to injuries.  According to the medical report, the driver suffered a broken right femur.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was end departure.  The Critical Reason for the Pre-crash Event was driver related - heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act. Few contributory factors could be determined - the driver did cite fatigue as a factor to police investigators.

preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided roadway.  There was an intersecting road, although the intersection did not play a part in this crash, and there were no traffic signals controlling the intersection. The posted speed limit upon which both vehicles were traveling was 40 kmph (25 mph).  There were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident, and the roadway was dry.  The gradient for this roadway was measured to be level.\n\nV1 (V1) was a large truck and was heading north on the roadway.  V2 (V2) was a light vehicle and was also heading in the same direction, traveling behind V1.  There was a green traffic light up a few blocks.  The driver of V2 noticed this and was wondering why traffic was not moving.  V2 decided to go around the truck using the shoulder to achieve this.  After overtaking the truck, V2 attempted to return back to the original lane of travel at which point V2 was struck by the large truck.   The front of the large truck made contact with the driver side of V2.  The impact caused the light vehicle to spin counter clockwise approximately 30 degrees before coming to final rest in the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of the large truck did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  The truck itself had minimal damage and was driven from the scene.  Numerous attempts at obtaining the interview from the driver of V1 were unsuccessful.  The Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction - over right lane line).  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded for this vehicle.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was transported to the hospital due to possible injuries.  The vehicle suffered moderate to major damage and had to be removed from the scene.  The interview was obtained on a follow up telephone call to the driver.  Through the interview, it was revealed that they were indeed in a hurry because of an appointment with the local DMV.  The driver also stated that they were not familiar with the surrounding area, and in addition, they had never driven on this particular roadway before.  As previously stated, the driver of V2 thought the green light ahead of them was for the intersection they were approaching.  That was not the case, as the signal was designated for an intersection a few blocks up.  Since the traffic was not moving the driver of V2 took it upon themselves to move around the truck in front of their vehicle.  When they attempted to return to the original travel lane, that is when the large truck (V1) struck V2.  The driver stated that no fatigue related issues played a part in this crash, and that no drugs were taken on the day of, or in the days prior to this incident.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as illegal maneuver, in that they passed another vehicle using a non-passing lane.
../resources/summary/2005005289102.json
preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a 4-way intersection, controlled by traffic signals in all directions.  The east/west roadway consisted of 4 lanes.  The north/south roadway had only 2 lanes.  The posted speed limit was 56kph  (35mph).  There were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident and the roadway was dry.  The gradient for both vehicles involved was determined to be level.\n\nV1 (V1) was traveling west attempting to make a left at the intersection.  V2 (V2) was heading east, intending to continue straight through the intersection.  Both vehicles had a green light at the intersection, however V1 did not have a green arrow, as none was available.  Therefore V1 was required to yield to oncoming traffic.  V1 was traveling at approximately 18-32kph  (11-20mph) when the front of the vehicle struck the left front of the opposing vehicle (V2).  V2 was traveling at the speed of 56kph  (35mph) and spun clockwise, and then continued forward while V1 hit V2 again in the left side before coming to final rest on the property of the north/east corner of the intersection.  The impact also caused V1 to spin counter-clockwise and continued forward.  V1 was driven to a safer place after impact off to the side of the road.  Only V2 had to be removed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1 did not suffer any injuries as a result of the impact.  The interview with driver of V1 on scene revealed that he did not see the oncoming vehicle as he was making the left turn.  He knew that he had a green light and thought the "coast was clear."  Since the driver did not see the other vehicle until the very last second, no avoidance actions were taken.  The driver did not make a note of any internal or external distractions.  Further, no inattentive factors for V1 were attributed to this crash.  The driver did mention that he had a minor heart condition, but that it did not hinder his ability to operate the vehicle.  He was not currently taking any medication, prescription or otherwise, at the time of the crash.  The fatigue level of the driver could have been described as normal.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as turning left at intersection.   The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).\n\nV2 was traveling at approximately 56kph (35mph) through the intersection before it was struck by V1.  After realizing a crash was about to occur, the driver of V2 hit the brakes and steered to the right in an attempt to avoid the collision.  Unfortunately, this action was not sufficient enough to prevent this crash from taking place.  \n\nAll three occupants of V2 were transported to the hospital for possible injuries.  The interview was obtained from the front seat passenger, who claimed that the driver of V2 was in good physical health.  The driver also was not taking any type of medication on the day of, or days leading up to the crash.  V2 was making a trip of quite some distance, but the two front seat occupants would take turns driving.  They would switch about every five or six hours, with short breaks in between.  The interviewee claimed they were only driving no more than one half hour from the last break, before the impact occurred.  No emotional or fatigue related issues were mentioned as a factor of this crash.  In addition, no internal or external distractions could be attributed to this crash.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this incident was coded as other motor vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle.  \n\n

preprocessing
This accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway is not physically divided, and has a traffic-control device at the intersection.  The conditions were as follows: early evening, dark, clear skies, the roadway was wet and there was no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for the three vehicles involved were all level.  The posted speed limit for V1 was 35 mph (56 kmph) and V2 was 40 mph (72 kmph). \n\nV1 was a 2003 Chevrolet Impala, traveling northbound, and had a red light at the intersection.  V1 reported to the Police and related to me to have driven through the red light, just prior to the crash.  V2 a 2000 Ford Focus was traveling westbound through a green light at the intersection.  \nV2 struck V1 on the right rear door and down the side toward the right front door.  V2 came to final rest in the middle of the intersection and in front of the opposing traffic.  The impact caused V1 to be pushed up and spun counter clockwise by almost 180 degrees, in the intersection.  When V1 spun around, it was reported that it struck V3.  V3 was stopped waiting to proceed straight, in the opposite direction of V1.  Shortly after the initial impact, V2 caught fire, probably starting at or near the battery, because of the angle of the crash for V2.  Just V1 and V2 were towed due to damage.  V3 was able to be driven from the scene.\n\nThe drivers of the three vehicles and the one passenger did not need treatment, because they did not suffer any injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle crossing over or passing through the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is unknown, because the researcher was not able to obtain an interview.  The driver of V1 would not return the researchers phone calls.   \n\nV2 was a 2000 Ford Focus was traveling westbound and had a green light at the intersection.  Upon realization of the impending crash, the driver of V2 attempted to avoid the crash by braking and steering her vehicle at the last moment to the right.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  Shortly after the impact, this vehicle caught fire, which was believed to have started at the battery.  This vehicle also needed to be towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2, refused to give the researcher an interview.\n\nV3 was a 2003 Honda Accord was traveling southbound and had a red light at the intersection.  This vehicle was stopped at the intersection, awaiting the light to turn.  After V1 was hit it spun around and hit V3.  This vehicle did not need to be towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V3 was coded as not involved in first harmful event.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.

preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred on a two-lane, two-way, undivided roadway.  There were no vehicle traffic control signals present for this particular stretch of roadway.   The road had a posted speed limit of 72 kmph (45 mph).  It had just started to rain slightly but the road was still considered dry at the time of the incident.  The gradient for this trafficway was measured to be level.  \n\nV1 (V1) and V2 (V2) were both light vehicles.  V1, a 2002 Honda Civic, was approaching V2, a 1980 Dodge Aspen, at approximately 34-48 kmph (21-30 mph), heading in the same direction.  V2 was stopped on the roadway waiting to make a left turn into a private driveway.  The left front of V1 made contact with the rear right of V2.  The impact caused V2 to rotate counter-clockwise approximately 90 degrees before coming to final rest in the entranceway of a daycare center.  V1 continued forward before coming to final rest in its original lane of travel.  Both vehicles had to be towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 69-year old female, did not suffer any injuries as a result of the impact.  The interview with the driver of V1 did not yield much information.  She was not really sure what the reason for this crash was.  She claimed that there was another car directly in front of her vehicle and behind V2.  She stated that the car in front of hers went around V2, which was waiting to make a left hand turn into a daycare center.  As soon as she realized the impending danger she hit the brakes.  This action was unfortunately not enough to prevent the crash from occurring.  The driver of V1 claimed to be in good health; however, she was taking some prescription medication.  One prescription was a hormone-replacement medication and the other medication was a thyroid-replacement medication.  No deviance from the driver\'s normal sleep pattern was noted, and she claimed to be well rested at the time of the incident.  Further, no emotional stresses were believed to be a factor in this crash.  She was wearing her prescription lenses that corrected both hyperopic and myopic vision conditions. The Critical Precrash Event for this driver was when another motor vehicle was stopped in her lane.  The Critical Reason was coded as an "other" recognition error - driver focused on extraneous vehicle. The driver kept watching the vehicle she had been following as it swerved around V2. The weather was also coded as an associated factor - it was drizzling at the time of the crash.\n\nThe driver of V2, a 31-year old female, was not seriously hurt; however, she was taken to the hospital for evaluation.  V2 was stopped in the traffic lane waiting to make a left turn into a daycare center.  The interview could not be obtained from this person because no phone number was provided on the Police Accident Report.  There was a phone number on the medical report but no one could be reached at that number. The Critical Precrash Event for this driver was when another motor vehicle was in her lane traveling in the same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. One associated factor coded to this vehicle was the weather, because it was drizzling out at the time of the crash. No other information about the driver of V2 was known because there was no interview.\n

preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred on a two-way, three-lane, not physically divided roadway.  The posted speed limit was 72kph (45mph).  There were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident and the roadway was dry.  \n\nV1 (V1) was exiting a parking lot, which had a gradient of +2.  V2 (V2) was going straight on a level roadway, passing the parking lot from where V1 was exiting.  There were no traffic control devices present at the location of this crash.    \n\nV1 a 1996 Jeep Grand Cherokee was attempting to make a left onto the westbound roadway from a parking lot from a convenience store.  V2 a 1992 Chevy Cavalier was traveling east on the main roadway at approximately 64kph (40mph).  The front left of V2 made contact with the left rear of V1.  The impact caused V1 to spin counter clockwise before coming to final rest in the westbound lane.  V2 continued further ahead before coming to rest in between lanes one and two of the roadway.   V2 was removed from the scene due to moderate damage, whereas V1 suffered minor damage and was removed by the owner.  \n\nNumerous attempts and messages could not generate an interview with the driver of V1 who had already departed the scene upon my arrival.  However, through information collected by the police officer, it appears that the driver failed to look both ways before entering the roadway.  Based on this information, the Critical Precrash Event was coded this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection (from parking lot).  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as recognition error, inadequate surveillance, in that the driver failed to look both ways.  As far as the details of fatigue, medication, or possible distractions are concerned, this information remains unknown.  The driver of V1 did not suffer any injuries as a result of this crash.\n\nThe passenger of V2 was taken to the hospital for possible injuries, and the driver accompanied them before my arrival.  An attempt was made to contact the driver of V2 using the number provided on the Police Accident Report.  Unfortunately the person who answered claimed that it was not the residence of the driver in question.  A match could not be found using sources such as the phone book or the Internet.  Because no interview could be obtained, any other factors that may have contributed to this crash are unknown at this time.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was other vehicle encroachment (from driveway, turning in opposite direction).  There was no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.  \n\n  \n
../resources/summary/2005005289182.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided roadway.  The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph) and there were no traffic signals associated with this stretch of roadway.  The roadway was dry and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident.  The roadway is considered to be level where the crash occurred.  \n\nV1 (V1) was a white minivan traveling west and intending to continue straight on the roadway.  V2 (V2) was a red pick-up truck, legally parked on the eastbound shoulder of the roadway.  There was an occupant in the driver\'s side of the vehicle, however V2 should be considered not in transport.  V1 crossed the double yellow lines and struck a wall first before continuing forward, and making contact with the parked pick-up.  The impact between vehicles caused V2 to be pushed up over the curb before coming to final rest.  V1 had considerable damage to the front and driver side of the vehicle and had to be removed from the scene.  V2 had minor damage and did not have to be removed from the scene.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was taken to the hospital as a precautionary measure, although injuries were thought to be minor.  The follow up interview with the driver revealed that he might have been talking on the CB radio right before the crash occurred, but he wasn\'t entirely certain.  He stated that he was traveling approximately 50-64 kmph (31-40 mph) when all of a sudden, he veered left and side swiped a brick wall.  He then applied the foot brakes but could not bring the vehicle to a stop before contacting the pick-up truck that was parked on the shoulder.  No fatigue or health related issues were thought to have contributed to this crash.  The driver did say that he had diabetes and was taking medication to help control that condition.  In addition, he was taking a cholesterol-lowering medication as well.  The Critical Precrash Event was coded as: this vehicle traveling, over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as an internal distraction.  \n\nAs previously stated, V2 was traveling east on the roadway before pulling off to the shoulder where he used his cell phone.  While parked on the shoulder, he observed V1 cross the double yellow lane line and make impact with a stone wall.  After the initial impact, V1 continue forward before making contact with V2.  The occupant complained of neck pain and was taken to the hospital for evaluation.  A brief interview was conducted with the occupant of V2.  He claimed that he thought the driver of V1 had passed out and that is what caused him to cross into the opposite lane.  The was no Critical Precrash Event or Critical Reason coded to this vehicle because he was not involved in the first harmful event.
../resources/summary/2005005289222.json
preprocessing
This late-night, V2 crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided roadway.  The posted speed limit was 56kph (35mph) and there were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident.  The gradient for both vehicles involved was level.  No traffic control devices were associated with this crash.  \n\nV1 (V1) was traveling eastbound and had just negotiated a right curve.  For unknown reasons, V1 partially left the right side of the roadway and overcompensated the vehicle when trying to return.  This caused V1 to spin laterally in a counterclockwise direction.  After loosing control of the vehicle, the passenger side of V1 made contact with the front of V2 (V2), which was traveling in the opposite direction.  The impact caused V1 to spin in a clockwise direction, approximately 180 degrees, before coming to final rest entirely off of the roadway on the property of a nearby house.  After colliding with V1, V2 spun clockwise, also approximately 180 degrees, before coming to rest partially off of the roadway on the same property as V1.  The travel speeds of both vehicles could not be determined.  \n\nAll three occupants involved were airlifted to nearby hospitals due to injuries.  Unfortunately, the interviews of the drivers could not be obtained.  Therefore, some pertinent information could not be acquired, thus giving an incomplete synopsis of events.  There was however, some witness information given to the officers that help complete the scenario.  \n\nAccording to a witness that was traveling ahead of and in the same direction as V1, V1 had been tailgating the witness before the crash took place.   V1 then attempted to pass the witness in a no-passing zone on the left side of the witness\'s vehicle, preceding the right curve in the roadway.  After passing the witness, V1 tried to get back into the eastbound lane, but apparently had taken the turn too hard and at a rate of speed that was considered unsafe.  Subsequently, V1 slightly left the right side of the roadway and overcompensated his vehicle to the left, causing him to spin laterally in a counterclockwise motion.  With no control of the vehicle, V1 could not avoid colliding with V2, which was traveling in the westbound lane, approaching the left curve.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle traveling, over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded decision error, too fast for curve.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as: other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction, over left lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.

This three-vehicle crash occurred in a 4-way intersection controlled by traffic signals in all directions. Both roadways were undivided with two lanes and a posted speed limit of 40 kmph (25 mph).  It was slightly overcast at the time of the incident, and the roadway was wet from a previous rainfall.  The gradient at this particular location was determined to be level.  \n\nV1 (V1), a gold 2000 Nissan Altima, was traveling east at approximately 35 mph (56 kmph) intending to continue through the intersection.  V2 (V2), a white 2001 Sterling street sweeper, was traveling north at approximately 10 mph (16 kph) also intending to continue straight through the intersection.  V3 (V3) was a red 2001 Dodge Durango legally parked on the side of the eastbound roadway.  As V1 passed through the intersection, the front side of the vehicle made contact with the left rear of the street sweeper.  After the initial impact, V1 continued forward and made contact with the back of V3 before coming to final rest.  The only vehicle that had to be towed from the scene as a result of damage was V1.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 26-year old female, was taken to the hospital for possible injuries.  After numerous attempts, the interview with the driver could not be obtained. As described on the Police Accident Report (PAR), V1 attempted to avoid the collision by slamming the brakes.  This unfortunately was not enough to prevent the crash.  It was also revealed on the PAR that there were witnesses present at the time of the incident.  They claimed that the light had turned green for north/south traffic.  With this information, the Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, because V1 apparently went through a red light.  Associated factors coded to this driver include speeding and aggressive driving. \n\nSome unfortunate information about the driver of V2, a 56-year old male, was disclosed to the researcher of this case.  He unexpectedly passed away approximately one month after the incident.  He was not taken to the hospital after the crash, so no medical reports were available.  No official reason was given as to the cause of death.  It is the opinion of the researcher that his death was in no way related to the crash.  The Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V2 was other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  No associated factors could be coded to the driver of V2 due to the lack of an interview.\n\nSince V3 was legally parked on the side of the road, no pre-crash information was required.  There was only minor damage to the rear bumper of the vehicle.\n

This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection, controlled by light signals in all directions.  The two-way roadway was not physically divided.  The east/west roadway consisted of four lanes, while the north/south roadway, only had two lanes.  The posted speed limit for the road upon which both vehicles were traveling was 56 kph (35 mph).  There was consistent rainfall at the time of the incident, thus making the roadway wet.  There was an uphill grade for both vehicles, as the intersection formed the peak of the two hills.  \n\nV1 (V1), a 2002 Honda Civic, was traveling westbound intending to pass through the intersection.  V2 (V2), a 1994 Jeep Cherokee was traveling eastbound, intending to make a left at the intersection.  As V1 was crossing over the intersection, V2 turned in front of V1.  The front of V1 made contact with the right front of V2.  Both vehicles were removed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe driver of V1 suffered minor injuries, but did not require transportation to a hospital.  The driver was still on scene upon my arrival, but did not feel comfortable participating in the interview.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V2 did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  The driver had already left the scene when I arrived.  Numerous phone calls were made to the driver, however, an interview could not be obtained.  Through information contained in the Police Accident Report, the view of V2 may have been hindered by another vehicle.  As traffic was backing up in the westbound lane, a vehicle in lane two westbound was going to allow V2 to make the left turn.  The driver of V2 did not see V1 coming into his lane while trying to cross the intersection.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle as view obstructed by other vehicle.  It should also be noted that the view could have been further obstructed by the fact that the intersection was at the top of a slight hill.   \n

This V4 chain reaction crash occurred on a two-way, three-lane roadway.  The middle lane acts as a common turning lane for both directions.  The posted speed limit on the roadway was 64kph (40mph).  There were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident, although it was slightly cloudy.  The gradient for all vehicles involved was determined to be level. \n\nV1 (V1), a 2000 Mercury Grand Marquis, was traveling in the south bound lane, at approximately 48kph (30mph), intending to continue straight on the roadway.  V2 (V2) was a 1990 Honda Civic, which was stopped in the roadway for a traffic light at the intersection ahead.  V3 (V3) was a 2003 Acura TL, which was also stopped in the roadway in front of V2.  V4 (V4), a 2000 Chevy Cavalier was stopped in front of V3 on the roadway.  The front of V1 made contact with the back of V2 which then in turn, contacted the back of V3 which ultimately contacted the back of V4.  V1 continued forward a bit before coming to final rest.  All the other vehicles also continued forward as a result of the crash before coming to final rest.  \n\nThe driver of V1 did not suffer any injuries from the crash.  Although he was on scene, he did not want to answer any questions at that time.  He said I could call later, however he never returned any of my calls.  For this reason, an interview could not be obtained.  Through information contained in the Police Accident Report (PAR), as well as conversation I overheard while on scene, the driver of V1 apparently looked away from the roadway at a piece of paper he had in the vehicle.  By the time he focused his attention back on the roadway, he realized the crash was imminent.  He applied the brakes, unfortunately this was not enough to prevent the crash from occurring.   The vehicle was towed from the scene as a result of damage.  The Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other motor vehicle stopped in lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as internal distraction.  \n\nThe driver of V2 had minor injuries, but did not require transportation to a hospital.  Through the interview obtained from this driver, no other additional factors seemed to have played a role in this crash.  Both fatigue and emotional levels appeared to be normal.  He was not taking any medication, prescription or otherwise, on the day of or in the days preceding the incident.  The driver stated that he was talking to a passenger, however this was not considered a cause, as the driver was already stopped in the roadway.  It is the opinion of the researcher, that there was nothing this driver could have done to prevent the crash.  The vehicle itself was towed from the scene as a result of damage. The Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same lane while deceleration.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V3 did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  Seeing as this vehicle did not have to be towed from the scene, the driver of V3 left shortly after my arrival.  Numerous attempts to contact the driver were unsuccessful.   This vehicle, which was also stopped, had no chance of avoiding the collision.  The Critical Precrash Event coded not involved in first harmful event.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\nThe driver of V4 also came away unscathed from the crash.   A vehicle inspection as well as an interview was not required for this vehicle.  Even so, no critical conditions were attributed to this vehicle.  There was nothing that could have been done to prevent this vehicle from being hit.  \n

This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a two-way, five-lane roadway.  Traffic signals controlled all directions of the intersection.  The roadway was not physically divided for V1 (V1); however, there was a divider for V2 (V2).  V1 had a slight downhill grade, but the gradient for V2 was level. The roadway was dry, and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident. The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 mph).\n\nV1, a 2000 Ford Windstar, was traveling north at approximately 24 kmph (15 mph). V1 then attempted to make a left turn at the intersection, but contacted the left front corner of V2.  V2 was traveling south, at approximately 56 kmph (35 mph) intending to continue straight through the intersection.  At impact, V1 spun counterclockwise approximately 90 degrees before coming to rest in the southbound travel lane.  V2 continued forward before coming to final rest, also in the southbound travel lane.  Both vehicles had to be towed from the scene due to damage. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 50-year old female, did not suffer any injuries, nor did the passenger in the vehicle.  Neither of the individuals from V1 was present at the scene upon researcher arrival.  An interview with the driver could not be obtained, even after numerous attempts to contact her.  The Police Accident Report (PAR) indicated that the driver of V1 was in the left turn lane, although she claimed that her intention was to continue straight through the intersection under the overpass.  When traffic prevented her from accomplishing this, she decided to make the left turn.  It is unclear whether fatigue, medications, or distractions played any role in this crash due to the lack of an interview.  The Critical Pre-crash Event for this vehicle was coded as turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an unknown recognition error. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 26-year old female, was on-scene upon researcher arrival.  She suffered from a bruise on her head and received an ice pack from EMS to reduce the swelling.  The researcher attempted to conduct an interview while on-scene, however she was not "in the mood" to answer any questions.  She was obviously still a bit shaken up.  The researcher tried to reach her by phone, but could not get in touch with her.  The Critical Pre-crash Event for this vehicle was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors could be coded to this driver due to a lack of an interview.\n\n

This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a 4-way intersection controlled by traffic signals in all directions.  Both roadways were two-way, two-lane roadways that were not physically divided. The crash occurred in the mid-evening hours. Streetlamps were present and illuminated at the time of the incident.  The roadway upon which V1 (V1) was traveling had a slightly positive grade, while the roadway upon which V2 (V2) was traveling was considered to be level.  The posted speed limit for V1 was 80 kmph (50 mph) and the posted speed limit for V2 was 72 kmph (45 mph).   \n\nV1, a 2004 Toyota Highlander, was traveling west approaching the intersection.  V2, a 1997 Acura CL, was stopped at a red light in the southbound lane waiting to pass through the intersection.  When V2\'s light turned green, it entered the intersection, at which time the front of V1 contacted the left side of V2.  The impact sent V2 up a nearby driveway before coming to final rest.  V1 spun counterclockwise approximately 90 degrees after the first impact and then made contact with a stone wall at the entrance of the driveway.  After hitting the wall, V1 then proceeded to roll backward, coming to final rest in the middle of the intersection.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 39-year old female, was not injured and did not require EMS transport to a hospital.  There were two other occupants in V1 in addition to the driver.  One of the other occupants received minor injuries and was transported to the hospital to be observed.  After numerous attempts, the interview could not be obtained from the driver of V1.  The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an illegal maneuver. One associated factor coded to this driver was a sightline restriction due to shrubbery on the side of the road. This probably blocked V1\'s view of V2 until V2 entered the intersection.\n\nThe driver of V2, a 47-year old male, received major injuries as a result of the crash, including but not limited to a collapsed lung, and was transported to the hospital.  An interview was obtained from the driver of V2.  He stated that he was stopped at a red light and when the light turned green, he proceeded to travel into the intersection.  At that moment he noticed something in his peripheral vision.  There was nothing he could do to avoid the accident. A witness who was stopped facing eastbound for the red light corroborated the driver of V2\'s version of events. The Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from a crossing street, across his path. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. One associated factor coded to this driver was a sightline restriction due to shrubbery on the side of the road. This probably blocked V2\'s view of V1 until V2 entered the intersection.\n

This three-vehicle accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway, which was not physically divided.  There were no permanent traffic signals present at the scene of the incident, however, there were warnings signs as well as a flagman, indicating a construction zone in the area.  The grades for both V1 (V1) and V3 (V3) were level, whereas the gradient for V2 (V2) was slightly negative.  There were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash.  The posted speed limit for the roadway was 72 kmph (45 mph). \n\nV1, a 2000 Ford F-150, was traveling north at an undetermined rate of speed.  V2, a 2003 Kenworth dump truck, was traveling south on the same roadway in the opposite direction, at an unknown rate of speed.  V3, a 2002 Pontiac Grand Am, was stopped in the northbound lane ahead of V1, due to construction.  For reasons that are unclear, V1 crossed over the center double yellow lines, and the front of the vehicle contacted the front of V2.  After the initial impact, V1 continued forward and the left front of the vehicle made contact with the right rear of V3, where both vehicles came to final rest.  The front axle of the heavy truck (V2) separated from the vehicle causing it to continue approximately 150 feet before coming to final rest.   \n\nThe driver of V1, a 24 year-old male, had a laceration to his arm and was taken to the hospital for observation.  The driver could not be reached for an interview, so it is unclear whether or not any fatigue or health related issues contributed to this crash.  The Police Accident Report (PAR) mentioned that the driver claimed that he swerved into oncoming traffic because he thought a car was pulling out from a parking lot into his lane of travel.  Further, he did not realize that the traffic ahead was stopped due to ongoing construction.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was that this vehicle traveled over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event  was coded as too fast for conditions (i.e. construction).\n\nThe driver of V2, a 44 year-old male, did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash, and therefore did not require any medical attention.  Numerous messages during various times of the day could not provide the researcher with an interview.  Through information contained in the PAR and evidence at the scene, it seems there was nothing the driver could have done to avoid the collision.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded to this vehicle was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction, over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event  was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V3 was a 35 year-old male who complained of neck and back pain and was air lifted to a hospital for treatment.  Information received via an interview did not reveal many Precrash facts, being as the driver was the victim of circumstances, which occurred as a result of the second event of the crash.  There were no health or fatigue related issues that contributed to this crash for the driver of V3.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded not involved in first harmful event.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event  was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n  \n

This crash occurred at a T-intersection of two undivided roadways. The east/west roadway had four lanes of travel (two in each direction) and the north/south roadway had two lanes of travel (one in each direction). The southbound roadway ended at the T-intersection and was controlled by a stop sign. The east/west roadway had no traffic control device. The conditions were as follows: early evening, partly cloudy skies, the roadway was dry and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for southbound traffic was +4 percent. The westbound roadway at the intersection was level. The posted speed limit on the north/south roadway was 40 kmph (25 mph).  The posted speed limit on the east/west roadway was 72 kmph (45 mph).\n\nV1, a 2005 Chevrolet Malibu, was driven by a 38-year old male. V1 was initially traveling southbound, and was intending to turn left at the T-intersection to head eastbound.  V2, a 2004 Chrysler Pacifica, was driven by a 39-year old female who was traveling westbound. Traffic was backed-up in the first westbound lane and had come to a stop. Traffic in the second westbound lane was still moving. V2 was traveling in lane two. A non-contact box truck that was stopped in the first westbound lane waved out V1 from its stop sign. As V1 pulled across the second westbound lane, the left front of V1 struck the left front of V2.  \n\nThere was no driver interview obtained for V1 after numerous times of trying to contact the driver.  V1 needed to be towed due to damage.  The police report did not indicate any injuries or the involvement of drugs or alcohol.   The police reported V1 traveling at an unknown speed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an "other" decision error - turned with obstructed view. The non-contact vehicle was coded as a sightline restriction. Other associated factors coded to this driver include inadequate surveillance and a traffic flow interruption caused by rush hour congestion.\n\nThere was no driver interview obtained for V2 after numerous times of trying to contact the driver.  V2 needed to be towed due to damage.  The police report did not indicate any injuries or the involvement of drugs or alcohol.   The police reported V2 traveling at an unknown speed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver include an "other" recognition error in that the impending problem was masked by the traffic flow pattern, a sightline restriction caused by the non-contact truck in the right lane, and the traffic flow interruption caused by rush hour congestion.\n

A stop sign was present for the one-way traffic, however there were no signs or signals present for the east/west roadway.  The incident occurred in the early morning hours, and it was raining at the time of the crash.  Both roadways were considered to be level, and both roadways had a posted speed limit of 40kph (25mph).  \n\nV1 (V1), a 2003 Suzuki XL-7, was traveling north on the one-way roadway approaching the intersection.  V2 (V2), a 1989 Nissan Maxima, was traveling west on the two-way roadway also approaching the intersection.  The front of V2 made contact with the left front of V1.  Both vehicles came to final rest shortly after the impact.  V1 was driven from the scene, however, V2 had to be towed due to vehicle damage.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 40-year old male, did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash and did not require any medical attention.   An interview could not be obtained from the driver because the telephone number on the Police Accident Report (PAR) was for a fax machine.  No record of the driver could be found in the phone book or on the Internet.  Through information contained in the PAR, it was revealed that the driver of V1 was not familiar with the area.  Further, he believed that the crossing roadway was also a one-way roadway and that V2 had a stop sign as well.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded as unknown travel direction because the driver\'s intentions were unclear.  The Critcal Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as false assumption of other\'s actions, because he thought V2 had to stop at the intersection.  \n\nThe driver of V2, a 46 year-old female, did receive injuries, however, the severity of which are unknown.  The driver was taken to the hospital for treatment.  After numerous attempts, an interview could not be obtained from the driver.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, intended path not known. This V2 crash occurred on a two-lane undivided level roadway.  The posted speed limit on the roadway was 48 kmph (30 mph). There were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident, although it was slightly cloudy.    \n\nV1 (V1), a 1995 Chevrolet Camaro, was driven by a 20-year old male. V2 (V2), a 2002 Ford Windstar, was driven by a 26-year old female. V1 and V2 were both traveling south on the same roadway, with V1 coming up behind V2 at approximately 80 kmph (50 mph).  The driver of V2 had decelerated and then stopped in her lane while waiting for an oncoming vehicle to pass so that she could turn left into a driveway.  For unknown reasons, V1 attempted to pass V2 on the left, ignoring the double yellow line.  As V1 was passing V2, V2 started to make a left into the driveway.  The right side of V1 contacted the left front of V2.  V1 then continued forward and made contact with the northbound curb before crossing the southbound lane again, and running into an embankment.  Finally, before coming to final rest, the front of V1 made contact with a mailbox on the property of the southbound side of the roadway.   After the initial impact, V2 continued forward approximately 20 feet before coming to final rest.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was taken to the hospital for possible injuries.  A phone interview could not be obtained from the driver of V1.  According to the police officer, the driver did not have a license to operate a motor vehicle and spoke very little English.  V1 had to be towed from the scene as a result of damage to the undercarriage.  Through information obtained from the police accident report, the Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling over the left side of travel lane.  The reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, in that the driver ignored the double yellow lines.  Associated factors coded to this driver include excess speed, aggressive driving, and a false assumption of other road user\'s actions in that the driver of V1 assumed that V2 would stay in her lane.\n\nThe driver of V2 was also taken to the hospital as a precautionary measure.  Numerous attempts at obtaining the interview were unsuccessful.  According to information relayed to the researcher by the police officer, the driver of V2 was waiting for an oncoming vehicle to pass before making a left into a driveway.  As the driver was making the left, V1 attempted to pass V2 illegally.  The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle turning left at intersection.  The reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  No associated factors could be coded due to the lack of an interview.\n\n

preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred on a one-way, two-lane roadway.  The crash ultimately ended at an intersection, however, the first harmful event occurred before the intersection.  There were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident and the roadway was found to be dry, straight, and level.  There were no traffic signals present where the crash took place and the posted speed limit for both vehicles involved was 40kmph (25mph).\n\nV1, a 1995 Chevrolet Blazer, was traveling north at an unknown rate of speed in lane one of the one-way roadway.  V2, a 1992 Nissan Sentra, was also traveling north in lane two at an unknown rate of speed.  V1 attempted to change from lane one to lane two.  The left side of V1 contacted the right side of V2.  After the initial impact, V2 continued forward, through an intersection and made contact with a utility pole on the left side of the roadway.  V1 came to final rest approximately 10 meters ahead of V2.  V1 did not sustain enough damage to warrant a tow, however, V2 sustained major damage from contact with the pole and had to be towed from the scene.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 22 year-old male, did not suffer any injuries as a result of the collision and did not require any medical attention.  Because V1 did not sustain disabling damage, the vehicle was driven from the scene shortly after the researcher\'s arrival.  There was no telephone number provided on the Police Accident Report, and no number could be acquired through investigation.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was this vehicle traveling, over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.  It is the researcher\'s opinion that V2 could not be seen by V1 when he attempted to switch lanes.  Because of this, the reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as inadequate surveillance.  No other factors could be attributed as a cause of this crash for V1.  \n\nThe driver of V2, a male whose age was unknown, suffered moderate to major injuries and was flown to a nearby hospital for treatment.  As was the case with the driver of V1, there was no telephone number provided for the driver of V2.  No numbers could be acquired for the driver and therefore, no interview could be obtained.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was other vehicle encroachment, from adjacent lane over right lane line.  The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There are no known associated factors coded to this vehicle and V2 was thought not to have contributed to the crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005005289682.json
preprocessing
This single vehicle crash occurred at a T-intersection of two two-lane undivided roadways. The crash occurred in the late afternoon hours while still daylight. There were no adverse atmospheric conditions, and both roadways were dry, straight, and level. Both roadways had a posted speed limit of 40 kmph (25 mph). The intersection was controlled by stop signs for all directions. \n\nV1 (V1) was a 1997 Ford Explorer driven by a 17-year old male. V1 was traveling south on the roadway that ended at the T-intersection. V1 proceeded into the intersection without stopping at the stop sign and skidded across the east/west roadway, departing the roadway on the south edge of the road. The front left of V1 impacted a utility pole on the roadside. The front of V1 sustained moderate damage and had to be towed from the scene. \n\nThe driver of V1 complained of pain but refused medical treatment. There were two other teen-aged occupants in the vehicle at the time of the crash, and each of them complained of pain, but both also refused medical treatment. The driver did not want to provide an interview and told police that his wheels locked up and he lost control of his vehicle. Based on scene evidence and information from police, the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as this vehicle traveling through end departure. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as too fast for conditions. It was believed that the driver was traveling at an excessive rate of speed as he neared the intersection, began braking too late, and skidded into and through the intersection and off the south edge of the intersecting roadway. Associated factors coded to the driver include an illegal maneuver, aggressive driving, and inexperience.\n

\nThis V2 crash occurred in the middle of a 4-way intersection controlled by traffic signals in all directions.  The southbound roadway upon which V1 (V1) was traveling, consisted of three lanes.  The northbound roadway, upon which V2 (V2) was traveling, consisted of four lanes.  The crash occurred during daylight hours, and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash.  The northbound roadway had a slight right curve as well as an incline.  The southbound lanes were straight and level.  The posted speed limit for both vehicles was 40kph (25mph).\n\nV1, a 1998 Jeep Cherokee, was traveling in lane two heading south, intending to make a left at the intersection.  V2, a 1996 Plymouth Voyager, was heading north in lane two intending to continue through the intersection.  Both vehicles did have a green light, however, V2 had a steady green, and therefore the right of way. As both vehicles entered the intersection the front of V2 struck the left front of V1.  The impact caused V2 to spin clockwise almost 360 degrees before coming to final rest againt the guardrail.  V1 spun counter clockwise almost 90 degrees before coming to rest in the eastbound roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 37 year-old male, was not injured and did not require any medical attention.  No other occupants were present in V1 at the time of the crash.  A complete interview was obtained from the driver of V1.  No fatigue or medical related factors were thought to play a role in this crash.  According to the driver, whose license was suspended, he did not see the approaching vehicle.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V1 was: this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as inadequate surveillance.  One associated factor coded to this driver was a sightline restriction due to an uphill grade for opposing traffic.  \n\nThe driver of V2, a 51 year-old male, received non-incapacitating injuries as a result of the crash, and was transported to a hospital for treatment.  The right front passenger of V2, a 47 year-old female, sustained severe injuries and was transported via helicopter to an emergency facility for treatment.  No interview could be obtained for V2, therefore it is uncertain if any fatigue or medical related issues had a role in this crash.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n

This one-vehicle crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided roadway.  The crash took place during daylight hours and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the incident.  The roadway upon which V1 was traveling was straight and level with a posted speed limit of 72kmph (45mph).  \n\nV1, a 1995 Dodge Dakota, was traveling east in lane one of the roadway.  The vehicle left its original lane of travel to the left into the opposing traffic lane.  V1 then continued off to the left leaving the roadway striking a tree stump, and continued down an embankment before coming to final rest in a drainage basin.  The vehicle sustained severe undercarriage damage. \n\nV1 was driven by a 46 year-old male in good health who was headed to his friend\'s home.  According to the driver, he was looking at a map, which was being held by the passenger.  The next thing he knew, he was headed off of the roadway and up the embankment.  However, the driver was suspected of consuming alcohol and was given a field sobriety test as well as a Breathalyzer test.  The police determined that he was not over the legal limit and was able to operate a motor vehicle.  The driver did not suffer from any injuries as a result of the crash and did not require any medical attention.  The passenger of V1, a 34 year-old female sustained minor injuries but did not require transport to a medical facility.  V1 was towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event that was coded as this vehicle traveling, off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an internal distraction; he was trying to read a map instead paying attention to the roadway, which caused his vehicle to drift off of the road.  The associated factors include a slight physical impairment due to alcohol and the driver\'s unfamiliarity with the road as he rarely drove it. \n

This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection that was controlled by traffic signals in all directions.  The two-way roadway, upon which V1 and V2 were traveling, consisted of four lanes.  The crash occurred during daylight hours, and there were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash.  The roadway was straight and level with a posted speed limit of 72kmph (45mph).\n\nV1, a 1991 Mazda MX-6, was traveling west in lane two, which was designated for traffic proceeding straight through the intersection.  V2, a 2003 Honda Accord, was facing east and was stopped in lane three, the designated left-turn lane.  As V1 proceeded through the intersection it drifted over the left lane line and the front of V1 contacted the front of V2.  The impact caused V2 to be pushed back slightly before coming to final rest, while V1 continued forward before coming to final rest. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 36 year-old female, adamantly refused an interview and would not take part in the study.  The driver did complain of some pain as a result of the crash, however she did not require transport to a medical facility. V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded as this vehicle traveling, over the lane line left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as an unknown decision error.  There are no known associated factors coded to this vehicle.  \n\nV2 was driven by a 72 year-old male, in good health and wearing prescription lenses that corrected a Myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He stated that he was stopped at the traffic light when V1 crashed into him.  Neither the driver nor the passenger of V2 suffered any injuries and V2 driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  An associated factor was the driver stated to have been talking to his passenger, however this was not thought to have contributed to this crash.
