preprocessing
\n\nThis three-vehicle crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection, which was controlled by traffic signals in all directions.  The east/west roadway consisted of 5 lanes at the intersection, whereas the north/south roadway consisted of six lanes at the southern end and five lanes at the northern end.  The grade for all vehicles involved was level except for V1 which was slightly downhill.  The posted speed limit for the east/west roadway was 64kph (40mph) and the posted speed limit for the north/south roadway was 72kph (45mph).  The incident occurred during daylight hours during a moderate rainfall.  \n\nV1 (V1), a 2004 black Chevrolet Malibu, was traveling east at approximately 16kph (10mph) intending to make a left at an intersection.  V2 (V2), a 1998 black Acura 3.5RL, was traveling west at approximately 64kph (40mph), intending to continue through the intersection.  V3 (V3), a 2005 red Honda Civic, was stopped at a traffic light in the southbound lanes.  As V1 attempted to make the left at the intersection, the front of V2 struck the right front of V1.  The impact caused V1 to spin counter-clockwise in a backwards motion approximately 270 degrees.  V2 continued forward and to the right, and ultimately struck the left front of V3 before coming to final rest.  V3 was pushed slightly to the right before coming to final rest.  All three vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1 was taken to the hospital for injuries including, but not limited to closed head injuries, and abrasions.  A complete interview was obtained from the driver.  The driver claimed that he was stopped in the middle of the intersection waiting to make a left turn.  At first he did not see the approaching vehicle (V2) because of a hill.  When the vehicle came into view, the driver stated that V2 was at least 150 yards away.  This occurred when the light, a steady green at the time, changed to yellow.  The driver of V1 then stated that he thought the light would change to red, and that the other vehicle would stop.  He offered that after the light turned to yellow, V2 must have slammed on the accelerator, because there was nothing he could do to avoid the collision.  The driver of V1 told the researcher that he was on prescription medication at the time of the incident.  The medication prescribed to the driver was to help an irregular heartbeat as well as high cholesterol among other ailments.  No fatigue related factors were thought to have played a role in this crash.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was: this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.\n\nThe driver of V2 had unknown injuries, but did not require transport to a medical facility.  A partial interview was obtained from the father of the driver for legal reasons.  According to the surrogate, V2 was intending to continue through the intersection.  V1 had all of the sudden made a left directly in from of V2, and there was nothing that could have been done to avoid the collision.  No fatigue or medical related factors were thought to have contributed to this crash.  The fact that the driver was inexperienced may have played a role.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was: other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction, over left lane line. The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\nThe driver of V3 did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  An interview could not be obtained from this driver, however the role of this driver was that of an innocent bystander.  No Critical Precrash Event, nor a reason for such, was coded to this vehicle since it was not involved in the first harmful event.  \n\nNOTE:\nIt should be noted that although the driver of V1 claimed a roadway grade that prevented him from seeing the other vehicle in time, it is the opinion of the researcher that there was not a significant grade for V2, which would have caused this.\n

This crash occurred as V1, 1995 Pontiac Transport, was turning right from a curved road to a driveway at a \xe2\x80\x9cT\xe2\x80\x9d intersection.  The crash occurred during daylight hours, and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions when the crash took place.  The east/west lanes of the roadway consisted of four lanes, two in each direction.  The north/south driveway that V1 was turning in to consisted of three lanes.  Two of the lanes were designated for the northbound traffic, and one was for southbound traffic.  There was an island dividing the two directions of travel.  The posted speed limit for the east/west lanes was 64kph (40mph).\n\nV1 was heading east in the first lane of travel.  As the vehicle turned into the driveway, it failed to slow down and veered off of the roadway striking the center median.  V1 was than redirected across the roadway over the curb on the right side and through a fence.  After contacting the fence, which crossed a bridge, the vehicle proceeded to fall approximately 10-15 feet before coming to final rest in a shallow stream.  Both airbags were deployed as a result of the collision. The vehicle had to be towed from the scene due to frontal damage, as well as damage to the undercarriage.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was airlifted to a nearby hospital for evaluation.  According to the police, the driver spoke very poor English and did not recollect exactly what happened.  Attempts at contacting the driver were not successful.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason was coded as a driver related factor, a decision error, traveling too fast for curve/turn.  It is believed that the driver was attempting to make the turn while driving too fast, and lost control the vehicle. It is unknown if any associated factors were involved in this crash as the driver could not be interviewed.\n\n\n

The posted speed limit for the roadway was 56kph (35mph).  \n\nV1, a 1999 Nissan Altima, was traveling west on the roadway approaching an intersection.  V2, a 2005 Ford F-250, was also in the westbound lane stopped at the intersection in front of V1.  V1 failed to stop and the front of V1 made contact with the rear of V2.  Both vehicles came to final rest shortly after the impact.  \n\nV1 was driven by a 17 year-old male who refused to be interviewed and participate in the study. There was another occupant present in the vehicle that may have suffered from possible injuries.  According to statements given to the police, the driver apparently was focusing on other police activity in the area.  Local police were conducting a traffic stop in the opposite lane.  As the driver was looking to the left, he did not notice the vehicle in front of him had stopped.  Neither the driver nor passenger of V1 suffered any injuries as a result of the crash, but V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was an external distraction, as the driver was focused on a traffic stop and not paying attention when this incident occurred.  Another associated factor for this crash was driver inexperience as he was only 17 years old.  \n\nV2 was driven by a 54 year-old male who did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  V2 had already departed from the scene upon the researcher\'s arrival. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There are no known associated factors for V2 and the driver of V2 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n

This V2 crash occurred in the early evening hours in the middle of a four-way intersection, controlled by signals in all directions.  It was dark at the time of the incident, but streetlights were present.  The divided roadway was dry, straight, and level with a posted speed limit of 64kmph (40mph).  There were no adverse atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash.     \n\nV1, a 1993 Ford F-150 with several post manufacturing modifications, was stopped facing north in lane four (the designated left turn lane) intending to make a left at the intersection.  V2, a 1998 Jeep Cherokee, was traveling south intending to continue straight through the intersection.  As V1 turned into the path of V2 the front of V2 struck the right side of V1.  The impact caused V1 to spin clockwise approximately 180 degrees before coming to final rest.  V2 spun clockwise about 45 degrees before coming to final rest.  Both vehicles had to be towed from the scene due to vehicle damage.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 41 year-old male, did not suffer any injuries as a result of the impact.  Communication with the driver was difficult as he was both deaf and mute.  The officer on scene smelled alcohol on the driver and performed a field sobriety test on him, which he subsequently failed.  An interview could not be obtained from the driver on-scene because he was taken into police custody.  A follow-up interview couldn\'t be obtained due to complications in his ability to communicate that are listed above.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as misjudgment of other\'s gap or speed.  The only known associated factor for this crash was the presence of alcohol in the driver as he was intoxicated.  \n\nThe driver of V2, a 30 year-old male, was not injured as a result of the collision. The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There are known associated factors for this crash, as the driver was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n

The vehicle then proceeded to cross over the opposite lane of travel, over the curb, and the front of V1 struck a tree where it came to final rest. \n\nV1 was driven by a 17 year-old male who did not suffer any injuries as a result of the collision. Conditions were as follows: it was early in the morning, with clear skies, and on an almost completely dry roadway.  The roadway was wet from the melting snow.  Just prior to the crash location, a posted speed limit sign stated 72kph (45mph), and the roadway had a negative 8% grade.\n\nV1 was 1997 Purple Dodge Neon that was traveling down a hill.  V1 traveled off the roadway to the right side.  The car went for 47.7m, after departing the roadway.  Over this distance, V1 struck a concrete water drainage system, and then came to rest after striking a utility pole.\n\nA 19-year old female drove V1, with 2 passengers.  The front seat passenger was taken to a local hospital via an ambulance.  The driver and back seat passenger were taken via their father to a local hospital for evaluation.  The driver stated that the front passenger distracted her because he was playing with a balloon.  She estimated her speed to be 50mph.  The car was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side. Driver of V1 stated that she did not have any other problems or other occurrences that contributed to the crash.  She has no vision or hearing problems.

This accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided, traffic signal-controlled intersection.  The conditions of the road at the time of the crash were dry and no adverse atmospheric conditions were present.  The gradient for both lanes of vehicle travel were level.  The posted speed limit for V1 (V1) was 72kph (45mph), whereas the posted speed limit for V2 (V2) was 40mph.\n\nV1 was a 1990 brown Honda Accord, which ran a steady red light at approximately 34-48kph (21-30mph) before impacting the left front side of V2.  The impact caused V2 to be pushed to its right nearly 12-15 meters.  V1 and V2 contacted again right rear with left rear respectively, and spun V2 almost 90 degrees clockwise before coming to final rest in the southbound lane.  V1 continued forward and to the left as well as spun counter-clockwise almost 45 degrees before coming to final rest.  The final resting position for V1 was partially off the road at the corner of the southbound and westbound lanes.  This vehicle was towed from the scene.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 46-year-old female who was taken to the hospital via ambulance due to injuries.  She claimed that the traffic signal seemed to go from green directly to red, without turning yellow.  After observing the traffic signal for some time, no atypical patterns were noted.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event  for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) an intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event  was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  After obtaining the interview from the driver of V1, it was revealed that she suffers from muscular dystrophy.  This condition however, according to the driver, has not hindered her ability to drive the vehicle.  No postproduction modifications on V1 were present at the time of inspection.  The driver stated that no medications other than vitamins were taken prior to the accident.  Furthermore, her emotional and fatigue levels at the time of the crash, as well as the days preceding, were normal.  He medical records revealed that she was taking an allergy medication and the possible side effects are drowsiness and fatigue.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 58-year-old female who was also taken to the hospital via ambulance, due to injuries.  V2 was a 2000 tan Mercury Sable, passing through an intersection between 50-64kph (31-40mph) with the right of way, as per a green traffic signal.  Upon realization of the impending crash, the driver of V2 attempted to avoid the collision by steering her vehicle to the right.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  This vehicle was towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was that the other vehicle encroached from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  She claimed to be in good health and was not taking any medications, prescription or otherwise, on the day of or prior to the crash.   She was wearing glasses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.\n\n\nOTHER POSSIBLE FACTORS:\n\nDuring the interview with the driver of V1, she mentioned that because of her muscular dystrophy, she had trouble walking for a long period of time because her legs weren\'t strong enough to support her weight.  She stated that she would take therapy exercises at her local health club.  During these exercises she would exercise her legs in a pool, which would allow her more freedom because her weight would be reduced.  She never mentioned that she required a wheel chair or walker.     \n

The crash occurred while (V1) V1 was heading East on a 2 lane not divided roadway.  Conditions were early in the afternoon, partly cloudy skies, and almost completely dry roadway, slightly wet from the melting snow in the middle of the week.  Just prior to the crash location, the investigator noticed a posted school speed limit sign that stated 24 kph (15mph).  The roadway grade was level at the critical event and at the crash.\n\nV1 was a 1998 Oldsmobile Silhouette minivan that just finished negotiating a slight curve past a school.  After the curve V1 hit an ice patch and a bush on the right side of V1.  Then started to lose control and departed the roadway to the left side.  She left the road and hit the mailbox on the north side of the driveway.  She continued across the driveway running over large bolders and hitting the large cement light post on the south side of the driveway coming to rest up an embackment in the bushes.  The minivan went for approximately 20m, after departing the roadway, up a slight embankment.\n\nV1 was driven by a 51-year old female, who was transported to a local hospital for bruises on the left side of her face and pain in her back.  The driver stated that she hit an ice patch on the right side of the road, hit some bushes, and lost control of the vehicle and went off the roadway to the left.  She estimated her speed was under the 40 kph (25mph).  The minivan was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was that the vehicle lost control due to traveling too fast for conditions.  Critical Reason for the Critical Event was too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users.  Driver of V1 stated that she had cold symptoms and was taking an over the counter cough medicine.  She stated that she did not take the medicine on the day of the crash, because she had to drive this was thought not to contribute to the crash.  She does not have vision or hearing problems.

This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided, traffic signal- controlled intersection.   The roads were dry in the evening on a weekday and there were no atmospheric conditions at the time of the crash.  The southbound lane upon which V1 was driving had a negative slope and the posted speed limit was 72kph (45mph).   The eastbound lane for V2 was level and had a posted speed limit of 56kph (35mph). \n\nV1 was a 1990 Chevrolet Cavalier; traveling south at 72kph (45mph) went through the red light at the intersection and contacted the front left side of V2.  V2 was a 1998 Ford Taurus, which was traveling east and was crossing the intersection with a green light.  V2 was stopped at a red light, and then proceeded to enter the intersection after the light had changed to green.  V2 was traveling at about 20 mph when it was struck by V1.  The impact sent V2 spinning clock-wise approximately 6 times before coming to final rest in the eastbound lane.   V1 continued forward through the intersection before coming to final rest on the side of the southbound lane.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 48-year old female who was air lifted to the hospital due to injuries.  It appeared that her head had made contact with the windshield.  When trying to obtain the interview, the driver of V1 refused to cooperate with us.  It is suspected however, from talking to the police on scene, that she was on prescription medication for depression.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection.   The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was unknown recognition error.  She was apparently on medication for depression and it is unknown if that contributed to the crash.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 63-year old man who did not suffer any injuries.  There were two other occupants in the vehicle, one in the front passenger seat and another in the left rear seat.   Both passengers also did not suffer any injuries.   The passenger of V2 acted as the surrogate interviewee and stated that there were no distractions, inside or outside of the vehicle.  She even stated that the radio was off and it was very quiet inside the vehicle.  She claimed that neither she nor the driver ever saw V1 coming.   As they entered the intersection, they were all of the sudden struck by V1.   The Taurus was towed do to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded for V2.   The wife noted that the driver of V2 did take medication every day.  He was on a cholesterol-lowering prescription. In addition he would take an aspirin and a daily vitamin each morning.   She claimed that the driver was in good health and did not have any emotional stress before or on the day of the crash.

The crash occurred while V1 was heading south on a one-way traffic way, leading to a traffic way that passes through a parking lot.  Conditions were as follows: early afternoon, with clear skies, and there was an almost dry roadway, wet due to snow melting from the snowfall the day before.  No speed limit was posted and the traffic way had a 0% grade.\n\nV1 was 1992 Tan Nissan Maxima that was initiating a left turn.  V1 went off the traffic way, over the curb, struck a fence, then struck a 30cm tree on the right front side.  From the traffic way to the tree was 5m.\n\nAn 81-year old male drove V1.  He refused to be seen by EMS or by a hospital.  He stated that his foot became stuck between the gas and brake pedals.  He estimated his speed at 20mph, and then stated he was unsure.  The car was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle off the edge of the road on the right side.  Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was due to performance error, because he stated that his shoe was stuck between the gas and brake pedal.  Driver of V1 stated that he had heart problems, but they did not contribute to the crash.  He does have vision and hearing problems, but was unsure of his corrected vision and hearing.  At the time of the crash, he was wearing his glasses and had his hearing aid on.  He was taking an unknown medication for his heart condition.

This accident occurred on a two-way, four-lane roadway. It is physically divided with a median strip, and has a traffic-control device at this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: late evening, cloudy skies, the roadway was wet and was experiencing snowfall for the atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for V1 was -2 percent and V2 was +2 percent.  The posted speed limit for V1 (V1) and V2 (V2) was (72 kph) 45 mph, V1 was stopped in the left hand turn lane prior to the crash.\n\nV1 was a 1993 Black Ford Thunderbird, which had a green round light, and did not have a left turn arrow, in the traffic control device.  V1 struck V2 in the left front, near the front door and down the side until it reached the left rear tire and started to push V2.  The impact caused V2 to be pushed off the right side of the road, coming to final rest on the curb on the southbound side.  V2 needed to be towed from the scene.  V1 drove to a nearby parking lot and parked.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was not treated, because he did not suffer any injuries.  After obtaining the interview from the driver of V1, he thought he had enough space to proceed.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle turning left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is decision error, misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.  The driver stated that he does not take any medications.  Furthermore, his emotional and fatigue levels at the time of the crash, as well as the days preceding, were normal.  \n\nV2 was a 2005 Black Subaru Legacy was traveling southbound and had a green light at the intersection.  Upon realization of the impending crash, the driver of V2 attempted to avoid the collision by steering his vehicle to the right.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  This vehicle also needed to be towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 did not need any medical attention.  He was wearing glasses to correct his myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He claimed to be in good health, but was taking a prescribed medication to lower blood pressure, on a constant basis.  He has been diagnosed with sleep apnea but was currently under no treatment.  Furthermore, his emotional and fatigue levels at the time of the crash, as well as the days preceding, were normal.

preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, four-lane, not physically divided intersection controlled by a stop sign.  The following conditions were present at the time of the crash: it was early morning, it was partly cloudy, the roadway was wet and there were no adverse atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for V1 had a grade of -2%.  The posted speed limit for V1 (V1) was 64 Kph (40 mph).\n\nA non-contact vehicle (NCV) and was northbound approaching an intersection controlled by a stop sign and was intending to turn left to head westbound. V1 was traveling west in lane one of a four-lane roadway and was passing through the same intersection. As the NCV turned left it entered V1\'s path of travel.  V1 traveled off the right side of the road and struck a brick light post, coming to final rest on the right roadside.  V1 was towed from the scene.  The NCV was never contacted but did stop following the crash.\n\nThe driver of V1 refused EMS on scene, but was taken to a hospital by a relative shortly after the crash.  The interview from the driver of V1 was not obtained.  Although the interview was attempted numerous times, all attempts through the driver\'s attorney were unsuccessful.  The Pre-event Movement was a successful avoidance maneuver; the Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as off the road on right side; the Critical Reason for Pre-crash Event was coded as overcompensation.  No associative factors could be determined.\n

preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane, not physically divided roadway.  It was mid-morning and heavy rain was present.  The gradient for both roadways of V1 and V2 travel were level.  The posted speed limit on the roadway was 64 kmph (40mph).\n\nV1, a 1999 Pontiac Sunfire operated by a 18-year-old male, was traveling westbound.  V2, a 2003 Hyundai Elantra operated by a 24-year-old male, was traveling eastbound.  V1 crossed the centerline, entered the eastbound lane, and impacted V2 head-on.  The impact caused V1 to rotate counterclockwise; V1 came to final rest in the westbound lane facing south.  The driver of V2 was initially traveling straight and then attempted to avoid the collision by steering the vehicle to the right.  V2 rotated clockwise before coming to final rest between a mailbox and telephone pole.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene. \n\nThe driver of V1 was transported by EMS to a local hospital.  After obtaining the interview from the driver of V1, it is likely that work and sleep patterns contributed to this crash. The driver was traveling home after working the graveyard shift.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was sleeping, that is actually asleep.  Associative factors for V1 include work and sleep schedule as well as weather conditions. The driver of V1 did not recall many details from the crash due to fatigue and injuries.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over the left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005005447142.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a parking lot drive-through roadway. The roadway was an unmarked undivided 2-lane roadway with designated parking spaces on either side of the roadway. At the time of the crash, it was early afternoon and the roadway was dry. At the point of the first impact, the roadway was level. There was no posted speed limit sign.\n\nV1 was a 2005 Chevrolet Malibu that was traveling westbound on the roadway. V2, a 2002 Nissan Pathfinder, pulled out of a parking space to the left of V1, attempting to turn left to travel in the same direction as V1. The front left of V1 struck the right side front of V2. This impact rotated V2 in a counterclockwise direction, causing the left front of V2 to strike a parked vehicle to its left, a 2004 Ford Focus. After striking V2, V1 struck two other parked vehicles on the right and then continued westbound on the roadway. V1 then departed the roadway to the right and struck some bushes and trees. The police incident report narrative stated that the driver of V1 claimed that her brakes had failed; however, an inspection of V1 revealed no such defect. The police speculated that after the initial impact, the driver of V1 kept her foot on the accelerator, thinking it was the brake. The driver of V1 also told police that after the first impact, the air bag deployed and the car went out of control. It is likely that the air bag deployment confused the driver of V1 and also blocked her field of vision.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 29-year old female, along with her 5-year old daughter who was a passenger in the back seat, were transported to a local hospital with minor injuries. The driver of V2, a 43-year old male, went later for treatment. There was a passenger in the parked Ford Focus who was sitting in the passenger seat doing paperwork as she waited for a relative inside one of the buildings. She reported that she looked up and saw V1 going very fast prior to the crash, and then saw V2 coming toward the vehicle that she was in. The passenger in the parked vehicle was not injured.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle encroached into her lane from a driveway, turning into the same direction. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to the driver of V1, although some associated factors were coded to her. First of all, the driver of V1 was traveling too fast for a parking lot. The passenger in the parked vehicle reported this, and the hard impact to V2 verified this. For this reason, the driver of V1 was also coded as driving aggressively. The driver of V1 was also unfamiliar with her vehicle - she told police that she had just rented the car from a rental agency. The driver of V1 had just left a doctor\'s office, and it was possible that she had received upsetting news or that she was late for another appointment. The driver of V1 cut her interview short, and so much information was unknown.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when he began to turn left onto the roadway. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance, a recognition error. He told police that he never saw V1 approaching because it was going too fast. Although it was believed that the driver of V1 was traveling too fast, it was not believed that this was the reason that the driver of V2 did not see V1. It was believed that the driver of V2 failed to look to his right immediately before pulling out from his parking space. The driver of V2 reported that he took a prescription medication to lower his cholesterol, but had no other health issues. \n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when V2 pulled from a parking space and attempted to turn left onto a drive-through roadway. The driver of V2 reported that he did not see V1 prior to the crash. The driver of V1 contributed to the crash by traveling too fast for the roadway/parking lot. \n
../resources/summary/2005005447163.json
preprocessing
This accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway is not physically divided, and there was no traffic-control device involved in this crash.  The conditions were as follows: late morning, rain, cloudy skies, and the roadway was wet.  The gradient for the three vehicles involved was level.  The posted speed limit for the three vehicles was 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\nV1 was a Toyota Avalon, traveling eastbound.  V1 was driven by a 66-year old female. V1 traveled over the double yellow line to the left into oncoming traffic. V2, a Buick Le Sabre, and V3, a Dodge Caravan, were both traveling westbound.  V2 was driven by a 60-year old female and V3 was driven by a 59-year old male. The left front of V1 struck the left front of V2, and then V1 struck the left front of V3, scraping down the side toward the left front door.  V2 came to final rest off to the right side of the roadway, with its two left wheels still on the roadway.  V3 came to final rest close to the point of impact off to the right side of the roadway, with its two left wheels still on the roadway. All three vehicles needed to be towed from the scene because they could not be driven.  The driver of V1 needed to be transported due to unknown injuries. The driver of V2 was not injured.  The only injury in V3 was to a passenger, and the passenger needed to be transported.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is unknown, because the researcher was not able to obtain an interview.  The driver of V1 would not return the researcher\'s phone calls. It was known from the medical report that the driver of V1 was taking a prescription medication used to treat osteoporosis. Another associated factor (coded to all three drivers) was the weather, because it was raining at the time of the crash and the roadway was wet.\n\nThe driver of V2 was traveling westbound and turned right to avoid the crash.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  Unfortunately, the researcher was only to attain about half of the interview, via phone.  The researcher tried a few other times to attain the rest of the information. The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors included the use of bifocals and the weather condition at the time of the crash.\n\nThe driver of V3 was traveling westbound and turned right to avoid the crash.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent this crash.  Unfortunately, the researcher was not able to attain an interview.  The researcher tried a few times to attain the information. Neither the Critical Precrash Event nor the Critical Reason was coded to V3 because it was not involved in first harmful event.  The only associated factor was the weather (rain).  \n

This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. It was not physically divided, and had a traffic-control device, for a construction zone.  The conditions were as follows: early afternoon, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for the two vehicles involved were both on a +6% roadway.  The posted speed limit for V1 (V1) and V2 (V2) was 64 kph (40 mph). \n\nV2 was a 2005 Mercury Sable was traveling northbound and was stopped for a stop/slow sign for the construction zone.  Upon realization of the impending crash, the driver of V2 stated that he could not do anything.  V1 was a 2002 Dodge Neon, traveling northbound.  V1 struck V2 in the center part of V2\'s rear bumper.  The impact caused V1 to push V2 up the roadway.  V1 and V2 came to final rest in the roadway.  V1 was towed due to damage.  V2 was able to be driven from the scene.\n\nI spoke to the construction worker on scene, which was holding the stop sign.  He was only able to give a few words, due to the language barrier.  He attested that V2 was waiting for the sign to change, so V2 could proceed.  He further stated that V1 pushed V2 up the roadway some.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 78 year old female that stated she was coming over the hill breaking and she did not remember seeing the brake lights on the vehicle ahead of her.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is looked but did not see the brake lights of V2.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 64 year old male that stated he was stopped at construction during that time a car came from behind and hit him.  He saw the car in his rearview mirror half second before impact.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other motor vehicle traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.

This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway is not physically divided, and has a stop sign in the east and west directions of this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: early afternoon, partly sunny, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for the two vehicles involved were all level.  The posted speed limit for the two vehicles involved was 40 kmph (25 mph).\n\nV1 (V1) was a 1994 Ford Explorer, traveling eastbound, and had a stop sign at the intersection.  V1 reported to the Police that he stopped at the stop sign and looked for traffic, after looking and not seeing any he proceeded.  V2 (V2) a 1998 Toyota Sienna was traveling northbound and did not have a stop sign at the intersection.  V2 struck V1 on the right front door and the right rear door.    \n\nThe driver of V1 was taken to a local Hospital via ambulance to be checked out.  The driver of V2 did not need treatment, because she did not suffer any injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle crossing over or passing through the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  Unfortunately, the driver of V1 would not return the researchers phone calls for a Driver Interview.   This vehicle needed to be towed from the scene, due to its disabling damage.  An associated factor is the large over growth of shrubs that were at the corner blocking the view of the cross street.  He was on several medications for urinary track infection, pain, anticonvulsant, and muscle relaxant.  The pain medication has possible side effects of light-headedness, dizziness and sleepiness.  The anticonvulsant medication has possible side effects of drowsiness, fatigue, dizziness, tiredness, poor muscle control and double vision.  The muscle relaxant medication has possible side effects of sleepiness, tiredness, drowsiness, dizziness, weakness and light-headedness.\n\nV2 was 1998 Toyota Sienna traveling northbound and did not have a stop sign at the intersection.  This vehicle needed to be towed from the scene, due to its disabling damage.    \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2, refused to give the researcher an interview.  An associated factor is the large over growth of shrubs that were at the corner blocking the view of the cross street.

The crash occurred while V1 (V1) was going southbound on a two-lane roadway, not physically divided, with double yellow solid lines marked on the roadway.  Conditions were as follows: mid evening, with clear skies, and a completely dry roadway.  Just prior to the crash location, a posted left arrow sign, for an upcoming curve, on the side of the roadway.  The speed limit was 35mph (56kph), and the roadway had a negative 6.5% grade.\n\nV1 was 2000 Toyota Tundra that was traveling downhill and negotiating a left curve.  V1 traveled off the roadway to the right side.  V1 struck a utility pole at the front center and came to rest against the utility pole while the back of the truck moved up the embankment to the right and struck a small tree with its right side.  The driver was taken to a nearby hospital to be checked and to have a blood test done.  Unfortunately, the driver left the hospital once he arrived at the hospital.  The truck needed to be towed due to the disabling damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was unknown reason for critical event.  There was no driver interview given after several attempts of trying to contact.

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway was not physically divided, and there was no traffic control device involved in this crash.  The conditions were as follows: early morning, clear skies, and the roadway was dry.  The gradient for the two vehicles involved was level.  The posted speed limit for the two vehicles was 56 kmph (35mph).  \n\nV1 (V1) was a 2000 Chevy Blazer, traveling westbound.  V1 was driven by a 38-year old male. V1 traveled over the double yellow line to the left into opposing traffic. V2 (V2), a 2001 Ford Taurus, was traveling eastbound.  V2 was driven by a 17-year old male. The left front of V1 struck the left side of V2, pulling the outside of the left front door off.  The police report narrative indicated that after striking V2, V1 left the scene. V1 was pulled over by police shortly after the crash, and the driver of V1 told police that he thought he had hit a curb. Police indicated that the driver of V1 was unsteady on his feet, confused, and lethargic. An ambulance arrived on scene and tested his blood sugar, which was normal. The driver of V1 finally admitted to police that he was taking several prescription medications, including a narcotic pain reliever and a muscle relaxant. Police took the driver of V1 to a hospital for a possible head injury and also for drug and alcohol testing. The results of those tests were not made available.\n\nBoth V1 and V2 were towed from the scene because they could not be driven.  The driver of V2 was not injured.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as "Type of driver error unknown" because the researcher was not able to obtain an interview.  The driver of V1 would not return phone calls. Associated factors included the use of prescription medications and aggressive driving because V1 was reported by a witness (to police) to have been weaving in and out of his lane prior to the crash.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was traveling westbound and turned slightly right to try and avoid the crash.  With this maneuver, the driver unfortunately could not prevent the crash.  The researcher was able to attain the interview, via phone with the driver\'s mother because he was under 18.  The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  One associated factor coded to this driver was a sight line restriction in that a large vehicle that was traveling in front of V1 blocked the driver of V2\'s view of V1 until V1 entered V2\'s lane.

This crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway is not physically divided, and has traffic lights for each lane at this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: mid morning, sunlight, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for V1 (V1) was 6%, while the gradient for V2 (V2) was level.    The posted speed limit for V1 was 56 kmph (35 mph).  The posted speed limit for V2 was 64 kmph (40 mph).\n\nV1 was a 2004 Dodge Ram 1500, traveling northbound, and he claimed to have a green light at the intersection.  V2 was a 1996 Pontiac Sunfire, traveling eastbound, she was stopped at a red light and then proceeded when it turned green.  As V2 crossed the intersection she struck V1 on the left side door.  V1 drove over the north side of the intersection traffic light and came back onto the roadway, for it\'s final rest.  V2 rotated counterclockwise and its final rest was in the same direction as the oncoming traffic.  \n\nThe driver a V1 was a 46 year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver stated that his traffic light was green. As he traveled through the intersection he was hit on the left side of his truck he then continued forward and knocked down a traffic signal and a guide wire. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle crossing over or passing through the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is illegal maneuver.  Although the drive stated that his light was green the evidence shows that he probably ran the red light.  Due to the damage V1 sustained in the crash, this vehicle needed to be towed from the scene.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 19 year old female that was taken to a local Hospital via ambulance to be checked out.  She stated that she was stopped at the red light waiting for it to turn green.  When the light changed she proceeded and struck V1 in the left side.  Her vehicle rotated 180 degrees counterclockwise.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.

This crash occurred on a two-way, seven-lane roadway (seven lanes only at the intersection). The roadway is physically divided, and has traffic lights for each lane at this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: late morning, sunlight, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for V1 (V1) and V2 (V2) was level, and just came off of a positive slope, and a curve to the right.    The posted speed limit for V1 was 40 kmph (25 mph).  \n\nV1 was a 2000 BMW 328i, traveling northbound, and he had a green light at the intersection, but heard an ambulance approaching from the cross street from the right and stopped while in the middle of the intersection.  V2 was a 1995 Nissan Altima, traveling northbound and was coming up to V1 that was stopped because of the Ambulance.  V2 struck V1 in the left rear.  V1 was pushed across the intersection, then into the curb lane for it\'s final rest.  V2 went across the intersection, then into the curb lane for it\'s final rest.  .  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 42 year old male.that was taken to a local Hospital via ambulance to be checked out.  He stated that he heard the ambulance and stopped to let the ambulance pass.  While he was stopped a car struck him from behind.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: other motor vehicle in lane, traveling at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  This vehicle was towed from the scene.  \n\nThe Driver of V2 was a 22 year old male that did not need treatment, because he did not suffer any injuries.  The driver of V2 did not give the researcher an interview, after numerous attempts.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as: other motor vehicle in lane, stopped in the lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: unknown driver error.  \n\n

\n\nThis accident occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway. The roadway is not physically divided, and has traffic lights for each lane at this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: early morning, dawn, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for V1 (V1) was 4%.  The gradient for V2 (V2) was -4%. The gradient for V3 (V3) was level.  The posted speed limit for V1 and V2 was 72 Kmph (45 mph).  The posted speed limit for V3 was 64 Kmph (40 mph).  \n\nV1 was a 2005 International Harvester 2 axle straight truck, traveling northbound, and he had a light that was changing to red at the intersection, but proceeded through.  V3 was a 1990 Mercury Cougar traveling eastbound and was coming up to the intersection with a green light.  V2 was a 1993 Ford Escort wagon that was stopped in the opposing traffic from V1.  V1\'s left rear wheel struck V2 over the right front.  V1 then struck the traffic light, for his lane.  Then V1 went over the double yellow lines and struck the left side and rear of V2.  V1 ended up on its left side across the roadway, down about 22 meters from the edge of the intersection.  \n\nThe driver of V3 was taken to a local Hospital via ambulance for possible broken bones.  The Driver of V1, and V2 did not need treatment, because he did not suffer any injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle crossing over (passing through) the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as: decision errors illegal maneuver.  The driver of V1 gave his interview on scene to the researcher.   Due to the damage V1 sustained in the crash, this vehicle needed to be towed from the scene.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as: not involved in first harmful event.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 gave the researcher an interview, after a few attempts.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V3 was coded as: other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V3 did not give the researcher an interview, due to no phone number available and trying to look up.  The officer also stated that he could not talk to him, due to a language barrier.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005005447382.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred at a four-way signalized intersection. The southbound roadway (V1) had five lanes, and the eastbound roadway had six lanes (V2).  Neither roadway was physically divided, and there were traffic lights for each lane at this intersection.  The conditions were as follows: early afternoon, sunlight, clear skies, and dry, level roads. The posted speed limit for both roadways was 56 kmph (35 mph).  \n\nV1 was a 1991 Toyota Camry, traveling southbound, and its driver claimed to have had a yellow light at the intersection.  V2 was a 1998 Toyota Corolla, traveling on the eastbound roadway attempting a left turn onto the northbound roadway.  V2 entered the intersection and started to turn left. The left side of V2 was struck by the front of V1.  The driver of V1 was accelerating as he neared the intersection on a supposed yellow light.  When he saw V2 enter the intersection in front of him, he locked up his brakes.  He was unable to stop. V2\'s final rest was in the middle of the intersection.  \n\nThe driver a V1 was an 18-year old male who did not sustain any injuries.  The driver gave an interview on scene.  The researcher was also able to inspect the vehicle on scene.  V1 did not need to be towed due to damage.  It was stated to the researcher that the driver was not on any medications and did not suffer from lack of sleep.  While talking to the driver of V1 he seemed like he might have had some problem or possibly an illegal drug in his system, because of the way he was talking and walking.  The police marked unknown for alcohol and drugs on the police accident report, and the driver of V1 was not tested. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: this vehicle crossing over (passing through) the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was an illegal maneuver (running a red light). Two witnesses interviewed by police reported that V1 had a red light while V2 had a green turn arrow.  Associated factors coded to the driver of V1 were inattention - the driver of V1 stated that he had been thinking about some concerns he had, work stress, and aggressive driving. \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 20-year old female who was taken to a local hospital via ambulance to be checked out.  She needed to be removed from her vehicle by EMS after the fire department removed the door.  There was no driver interview obtained after numerous attempts to contact the driver.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle turning left.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  No associated factors could be coded to this driver due to the lack of an interview.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005005447402.json
preprocessing
This V4 chain reaction crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane roadway.  There are parking lanes on each side of the roadway. The posted speed limit on the roadway was 56kph (35mph).  There was some rain, just prior to the crash. The gradient for all the vehicles involved was level. \n\nV1 (V1), a 2000 Ford Explorer, was traveling in the southbound lane, at an unknown speed, intending to continue straight on the roadway.  V4 (V4) was a legally parked vehicle, a 2005 Subaru Outback.  V3 (V3) was a 1992 Ford Ranger, which was stopped in the roadway in front of V1.  V2 (V2), a 2004 Mercury Mountaineer was stopped in front of V3 on the roadway.  The right side of V1 made contact with the parked car, V4.  V1 left front struck the right rear of V3.  From the chain reaction, the front of V3 struck V2 in the rear.  V1, was in the parking lane for final rest.  The final rest for V3 and V2 is unknown, because they were drivable, and left the scene prior to my arrival.\n\nThe driver of V1 did not suffer any injuries from the crash.  He was on scene, and the researcher contacted him at a later date via phone.  V1 was towed from the scene as a result of damage.  The driver of V1 expressed a work related dispute that played a part in this crash.  This dispute played a part in the crash, in two ways.  First is that he was thinking about that issue while driving.  Second is the stress, related to this work dispute.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other motor vehicle stopped in lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as too fast for conditions.  \n\nV4 was a parked vehicle as stated.  Pictures were taken of the vehicle from the outside.  This vehicle was marked as other vehicle, in this case.\n\nThe driver of V3 did not suffer any injuries as a result of the crash.  The researcher was able to contact the driver and attain pictures for this vehicle.  V3, was stopped, had no chance of avoiding the collision.  This driver did not have any fatigue or medical related problems that contributed to this crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle not involved in first harmful event.  The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\nThe driver of V2 complained of pain, but refused EMS transport.  The researcher was able to contact the driver and attain pictures for this vehicle.  V2, which was also stopped, had no chance of avoiding the collision.  This driver did not have any fatigue or medical related problems that contributed to this crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was not involved in first harmful event.  The reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\n

This accident occurred on an undivided two-way, two-lane roadway at a 4-way intersection. The roadway was controlled by traffic signals.  The conditions were as follows: early afternoon, sunlight, clear skies, the roadway was dry and level. The posted speed limit for V1 and V2 was 40 kmph (25 mph).  \n\nV1 (V1) was a 1997 Ford Ranger, traveling northbound. V1 was following V2, a 1987 Buick Park Avenue. The driver of V1, a 41-year old male, stated that northbound traffic had a green to yellow light at the intersection.  When the light changed to yellow, the driver of V2 slammed on his brakes.  V1 could not stop in time and the front of V1 struck the left rear of V2.  \n\nThe driver of V1 did not need treatment, because he did not suffer any injuries.  The driver of V2, an 81-year old male, was taken to a local hospital via ambulance to be checked out.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: other motor vehicle stopped in lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as:  false assumption of other\'s actions. This was chosen because the driver of V1 assumed that the driver of V2 would continue on through the yellow light. An associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was following too closely - had V1 been farther back from V2, it is likely that the driver of V1 could have had more space in which to brake. The driver of V1 gave his interview via phone to the researcher.   Due to the damage V1 sustained in the crash, this vehicle needed to be towed from the scene.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as: other motor vehicle in lane with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 refused an interview with the researcher.\n\nThe researcher used information given in the Police Report for some of the above information.  It is the researcher\'s view that V2 stopped suddenly and V1 came up from behind and was not able to stop in time.  While the researcher was on scene, he noticed that this roadway that V1 and V2 traveled are very busy, in comparison to the area.\n\n

The conditions were as follows: late evening, clear skies, the roadway was dry and there were no atmospheric conditions.  The gradient for the two vehicles involved were both on a -2% roadway.  The posted speed limit for V1 (V1) and V2 (V2) was 72 kph (45 mph). \n\nV1 was a 2005 Toyota Tundra, traveling southbound.  V1 struck V2 in the center part of V2\'s rear bumper.  The driver side airbags for V1 inflated, and the driver was wearing his seatbelt.  The impact caused V1 to push V2 further down the roadway.  V1 and V2 came to final rest in the roadway.  V1 was towed due to damage.  V2 was able to be driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane and was stopped. He took his eyes off the road to look at the items and when he looked back it was too late to stop. This crash occurred at an intersection of a parking lot driveway and a two-way, undivided two-lane roadway.   V1 (V1) was traveling on the painted median in the center of the road, which officially ended at the intersection with the driveway. On the other side of the intersection with the driveway, the center median became a left turn-only lane for the next intersection.  V2 (V2) was exiting the driveway parking lot.  The conditions were as follows: early afternoon, partly cloudy skies, and the roadways were dry.  The gradient for (V1) was level, while the grade for (V2) was a positive 2.5 percent slope.    The posted speed limit for V1 was 40 kmph (25 mph).  There were no speed limit signs for the parking lot driveway that V2 was exiting. V2 had a stop sign; V1 had no traffic control device.\n\nV1 was a 2003 Ford Focus traveling southbound, intending to continue straight at this driveway-intersection.  V2 was a 1994 Chevy Lumina minivan traveling east, intending to turn left to travel north.  V1 did not see V2 coming across her pathway and struck V2 in the left front, with the front of V1.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 21-year old female, did not have any injuries.  There was no driver interview obtained after numerous attempts to contact the driver.  V1 needed to be towed due to damage.  There was no vehicle inspection after numerous attempts to contact the driver, tow company, and the insurance company.  The police report did not indicate any drugs or alcohol being a factor in this crash.   The police reported V1 traveling at an unknown speed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as: other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to V1. Two associated factors were coded to the driver of V1 - an illegal maneuver due to driving on the median and a sight restriction due to stopped non-contact vehicles in the southbound lane. \n\nV2 was driven by a 20-year old female. The driver and passengers of V2 did not have any injuries.  There was no driver interview obtained after numerous attempts to contact the driver.  V1 did not need to be towed.  There was no vehicle inspection after numerous attempts to contact the driver, tow company, and the insurance company.  The police report did not indicate any drugs or alcohol being a factor in this crash.   The police reported V1 traveling at an unknown speed.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle turning left at the intersection.   The Critical Reason was coded as an "other" recognition error - the impending problem was masked by the traffic flow pattern (the vehicles in the southbound lane). One additional associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was a sight restriction due to the stopped vehicles in the southbound lane.  \n

The crash occurred on a north/south undivided two-lane roadway. The road was straight and dry and had a positive grade of 2.5 percent in the southbound direction. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph). The crash occurred in the mid-morning hours on a clear day.\n\nV1 was 1999 Toyota Camry that was traveling south.  V1 traveled off the roadway on the right side.  The front right corner of V1 struck a utility pole, coming to rest against the utility pole while the back of the car rotated back onto the roadway.  The driver, a 74-year old female, was taken to a nearby trauma hospital to be checked after striking the windshield with her head.  An interview over the phone was obtained and the driver explained that she was told that she had "blacked out." She also stated that she was very familiar with the area because she has lived there all her life.  The car needed to be towed due to the disabling damage. A witness had told police that the driver of V1 had not moved when its light had turned green on a nearby roadway. After several seconds, the driver of V1 finally initiated a left turn onto the southbound roadway,. It then traveled forward and within seconds, impacted the utility pole.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was when it traveled off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an illness (heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act). The driver also stated that she had heart and lung problems for which she took several medications. It was believed that one of the heart conditions caused the blackout. At the time of the crash, the driver of V1 was on her way to her doctor.  There were no other factors involved with this crash.   \n\n

This roadway included a white dashed line to denote 2 lanes of travel per direction, with a double yellow solid line in the center.  Conditions were as follows: late morning, clear skies, and a completely dry roadway.  Just prior to the crash location, there was a traffic light for westbound traffic.  There was an uphill grade of 4 percent.  The speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\nV1 was 2002 Hyundai Elantra driven by a 48-year old male who experienced a seizure while driving.  V1 traveled off the roadway to the right side.  V1 went over a concrete curb and went up an embankment and struck a utility pole with the left side of the car.  The car came to rest against the utility pole while the back of the car was still up the embankment.  \n\nWhen the researcher arrived on scene, the four occupants were not there, and the police officer was very short during any conversation. An associated factor coded to the driver was alcohol withdrawal, as the driver of V1 had a history of alcohol abuse. A blood test conducted at the hospital two and one-half hours after the crash was negative for both alcohol and drugs.   \n

This crash occurred at a four-way intersection.  The weather at the time was clear with no adverse conditions.  One roadway travels North and South, while the intersecting roadway travels East/West.  The East/West roadway is a two-way two-lane roadway. The North/South roadway is a two-way, two lane roadway, with a shoulder and a bike lane on each side.  Neither lane is physically divided.  Both lanes are leveled and have a posted speed limit of 40 kpmh (25 mph).\n\nV1 was a 1996 Chevrolet Blazer.  This vehicle was traveling eastbound, stopped, and was attempting to make a left-handed turn to go northbound at the intersection.  When the vehicle proceeded to turn the front of V1 contacted the left side of V2 causing V2 to lose control and hit a light pole.  V1 after impact pulled to the side of the North/South roadway.  V1 suffered scrapes on the front bumper, grill, fender and headlight.\n\nV2 was a 1994 Oldsmobile 88 Royale.  This vehicle was traveling westbound crossing through the intersection when it was contacted on its\' left side by V1.  V2 then lost control, striking a light pole on the northwest corner of the intersection. It came to rest on the northwest corner of the intersection\n\nThe driver of V1 states that while he was stopped at the intersection, there was a transit bus stopped in the opposite direction of travel.  The driver then states that the operator of the transit bus waved him on to turn.  Then as the driver was turning V2 came streaking by the right side of the transit bus, from the parking lane, into V1\'s path of travel.  The driver states that there was no way they could stop in time and they had no choice but to brake and strike V2. Driver of V1 takes medication for Diabetes Type II, and blood pressure.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to V1 as, this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for Critical Pre-Crash Event was also coded to V1 as, turned with obstructed view.\n\nWe were unable to get a full interview from the driver of V2 due to the fact that he sought legal counsel after the crash, and we could not get permission from the counsel to speak to the driver.  The information we were able to get says that the driver of V2 was  trying to make a right hand turn at the intersection to go northbound.  When the driver attempted to turn they were struck on the left side by V1.  The driver of V2 was transported to a local hospital with unknown injuries.  V2 was towed due to damage on the left side, and left front of vehicle.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event was this vehicle turning right at intersection.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nIt is this researchers determination that V2 was not turning right at the intersection as the driver had stated, but instead was in fact coming around the bus as stated by driver of V1.  Also in the conversation with driver of V1 states that the driver of V2 had alcoholic beverages in the vehicle, though none were found or evident at time of inspection.

preprocessing
The crash occurred at a T-intersection on an eastbound/westbound roadway. V1 was traveling westbound on a five-lane (two westbound and two eastbound with a center turn lane) undivided roadway. V2 was traveling on a two-lane (one northbound and one southbound) undivided roadway. Both asphalt roadways were dry, level, and there were no adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit for both roadways was 40 kmph (25mph). The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours on a weekday. Traffic was heavy on the east/westbound roadway. \n\nV1, a 4-door 1999 Nissan Altima, was traveling westbound in lane #1 when it struck with its front end the left side of V2, a 4-door 1987 Buick Lesabre. V2 had been southbound on the intersecting roadway, and was attempting a left turn at the T-intersection. V2 had a stop sign posted at the corner of the T-intersection and had stopped before initiating its turn. According to the interview, the driver of V2 was attempting to merge into the oncoming traffic and didn\'t see the vehicle coming from her left. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 39-year old male, stated that there was a curve several feet before the intersection and it took away his ability to see V2 crossing in front of him. The driver of V1 was familiar with the roadway - he drove on it daily. The driver of V1 was not injured. V1 was not towed.\n\nThe driver of V2, a 91-year old female, stated that she couldn\'t understand why the driver of V1 couldn\'t see her merging into traffic. She stated that after the curve there were several feet of straight roadway before the T-intersection. V2\'s driver was familiar with the roadway - she drove it weekly. The driver of V2 was transported to a hospital with possible rib fractures. V2 was towed due to damages from the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from a crossing street, turning into the opposite direction. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1, although one associated factor was coded to him. It was believed that the driver of V1 was traveling too fast for the roadway. When questioned, he reported that he was traveling between 31-40 mph. The posted speed limit was 25 mph. In determining if there was a sight line restriction, it was decided that at a posted speed of 25 mph, it was not a factor. Furthermore, since the driver of V1 drove on the roadway on a daily basis, he should have been familiar with any roadway limitations. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V2 was when she began to turn left at the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Pre-Crash Event was coded to this driver as inadequate surveillance (e.g. failed to look, looked but did not see). It was believed that the driver of V2 did stop at the intersection before entering the intersection; however, she did not see V1 approaching. One associated factor coded to this driver was the use of unidentified prescription medications for the treatment of high blood pressure and diabetes.  \n   \n

The motor vehicle accident occurred on a north/south roadway that had five travel lanes, three northbound, two southbound.  This roadway does not have a physical divider.  The surface was level, asphalt, and there were no traffic control devices at the scene. \n\nV1, a 2003 Ford Taurus driven by a 45-year old female, was traveling northbound on the roadway when the driver missed its turn off.  The driver made a U-turn and started to travel southbound on the roadway.  The driver intended to make a left hand turn into a parking lot, then cross through the lot to enter the roadway for which she missed the turn-off.  The driver waited in the southbound travel lane (in lane 2) for northbound traffic to allow her to enter the lot. A motorist in the second northbound lane and one in the third northbound lane stopped and waived the driver on.  The driver proceeded to cross the double yellow lines and cross over the northbound travel lanes to enter the lot.  After crossing over the first two lanes, the driver reported that a vehicle in the first lane of northbound traffic was traveling at a high rate of speed and crossed into the driver\'s path.  The driver also states that she had no way to avoid striking the vehicle (V2).\n\nV2, a 2001 Acura 3.2 CL coupe driven by a 26-year old male, was traveling north in the first lane of travel. He stated that he had begun to slow down because traffic ahead of him had slowed for a red light further up the road. The driver of V2 stated that as he was approaching the stopped traffic, V1 came out of nowhere and hit the left side of his vehicle. He accelerated and steered to the right, but the front of V1 then hit the rear of his vehicle.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for the driver of V1 was coded as This vehicle traveling - turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was an othe decision error - turned with obstructed view. Associated factors coded to this driver include a sight restriction caused by the non-contact vehicles whose drivers waived V1 on, and a false assumption - the driver of V1 assumed that because the two non-contact drivers were waiving her on, that the way must be clear.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from the opposite direction - over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. One associated factor coded to him was the sight restriction due to the stopped (no-contact) vehicles. \n

preprocessing
The accident occurred in the early afternoon hours in the middle of an intersection of two one-way streets. Both roadways were controlled by traffic signals that were operating properly in both directions.  Both roadways were dry, straight, and level. The weather was clear.  \n\nV1, a 2003 Suzuki motorcycle, was traveling north on the northbound roadway.  V2, a 1998 Honda Civic coupe, was traveling west on the westbound roadway. V1 and V2 entered the intersection at approximately the same time, and V1 struck the left side of V2 at about the "B" pillar.  The driver of V1 was ejected after impact and was thrown approximately 20 feet, landing on the asphalt.  V2 came to rest facing southbound in the southwest corner of the intersection.\n\nThe operator of V1, a 46-year old male, was transported to the hospital with major injuries.  Later that day, the driver of V1 was pronounced deceased at the hospital from injuries sustained in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as "other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path."  The Critical Reason for Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. According to witnesses, V1 entered the intersection on a green light. Due to the death of the driver of V1, no associated factors could be coded to V1.\n\nV2 was driven by a 21-year old male who entered the intersection on a red light. It was not known why he did not stop - no interview was obtained. The driver was transported to the hospital with moderate injuries.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded "this vehicle traveling - crossing over (passing through) intersection."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as an illegal maneuver - failed to stop for traffic control device.  This vehicle, according to witnesses, entered the intersection on a steady red signal. No interview was obtained from the driver of V2, and so no associated factors could be coded to V2.\n

This motor vehicle crash took place on a two-lane roadway.  This roadway has a set of rail tracks dividing the two lanes.  The roadway runs north/south with one lane in each direction and the posted speed limit was 40 kmph (25 mph).  The north/south roadway was not controlled by any TCD\'s (traffic control devices).\n\nV1, a 1995 Jeep Grand Cherokee Sport Utility Vehicle, was traveling northbound in lane one.  V2, a 2001 Hyundai Sonata, came out of a parking lot onto northbound lane one, attempting to turn right.  V1 was unable to stop and ended up striking the left side of V2 with its front end.  Both vehicles came to rest.\n\nNo interview was obtained from the driver of V1, a 26-year old female. According to an eyewitness account, V1 was traveling at about 30mph. V2 pulled out of the lot carelessly, not looking in either direction nor making a full stop at the stop sign while exiting the parking lot. The eyewitness was in a vehicle traveling behind V1 at time of the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for the driver of V1 was when the other vehicle encroached into her lane from a driveway, turning into the same direction. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1. Due to the lack of an interview, no other information was known about the driver of V1 or her actions.\n\nNo interview was obtained from the driver of V2, an 82-year old male.  According to the eyewitness, V2 pulled out from the parking lot at about 10- 15 mph.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for the driver of V2 was when he began to turn right at the intersection.  The Critical Reason For the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as "Type of driver error unknown," due to the lack of an interview. It may have been a surveillance issue, a misjudgment of the other\'s speed, or even a false assumption. Since the reason for the actions of V2 could not be ascertained, the Critical Reason had to be coded as an unknown driver error.  No other information about the driver of V2 was known.

This crash took place in a four-way intersection.  The intersection is controlled by tri-color traffic control devices.  That day the weather was clear and the roadway was dry.  The north/south portion of the roadway consists of two lanes, one in each direction, with no barrier separating the lanes only double yellow lines.  The east/west portion of the intersection also consists of two lanes, one in each direction, and is not physically divided by barrier only double yellow lines.  \n\nV1 a 1998 Honda Civic EX was traveling eastbound and V2 a 1996 Nissan XES was traveling southbound.  V1 went through the intersection even though his light had turned red.  V2 entered the intersection with the green light.  V1\'s front contacted V2\'s right side.\n\nThe driver of V1 states that they were driving towards the intersection and did see the light but was "stuck" and was unable to react in time to stop at the light.  The driver states that he entered the intersection on a solid red light and struck V2 on its left side between the "A" and "B" pillars below the beltline.  V1 came to rest on the other side of the intersection after impact. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as:  this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as:  recognition error, inattention (i.e. daydreaming).  Associative factors: The driver of V1 has been working 10 hours a day for the past two weeks due to a death in his bosses family (the driver of V1 is the Assistant Manager).\n\nThe driver of V2 says that they were on their way to the barbershop when he stopped at the light.  The light turned green and driver of V2 entered the intersection when V1 entered the intersection at a high rate of speed and struck V2 on its right side with V1\'s front.  The passenger in the front was transported with minor injuries.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for this vehicle was coded as: other vehicle encrochmen, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.

This motor vehicle crash happened on a roadway.  This roadway travels east/west, with two travel lanes westbound and two travel lanes and one left turn lane eastbound.  The roadway is not physically divided.  The crash took place mid-block about 9 meters west of the traffic control signal.\n\nThe driver of V1 was stopped at a traffic light, when the light turned green the driver proceeded to accelerate, traveling in lane two, in the westbound lanes.  V2 entered the roadway from a parking lot and crossed the path of V1, trying to turn onto the eastbound lanes.  V1 contacted V2 with its left front.  Both cars came to rest at impact.  \n\nV1\'s driver was coming from work and states that they did not see V2 until V2 crossed the path of V1.  The driver states that they were traveling about 40-48 kmph (25-30 mph) at time the of impact and tried to avoid contacting V2 but could not stop in time.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded for this vehicle as:  Other vehicle encroachment, from driveway, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V2 states that they were stopped about 10-15 minutes waiting for traffic.  The driver then states that when the light turned green that they proceeded to cross over the westbound lanes of travel, intending on going eastbound on the roadway.  \xe2\x80\x9cThat\'s when the guy came out and hit us on the left side.\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as: This vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as: Decision error, misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.\n \nASSOSIATIVE FACTORS:  The driver of V2 was following another vehicle that was not involved in the motor vehicle crash.  The driver of V2 also works in construction which could have contributed cause of the strenuous labor involved in the driver\'s job.
