This motor vehicle crash occurred on a major highway.  That day there were no adverse conditions, it happened around sunset, and there were no streetlights on at the time.  The highway is a twelve-lane highway that runs north/south - six lanes in each direction, with the six lanes divided into groups of three by grassy medians with curb edges that border the roadside.\n\nThe crash involved only one vehicle, a 2005 Ford Escape Sport Utility Vehicle, which rolled over.  It was traveling in lane two of the center southbound lanes.  The Ford lost control and struck the curb at the edge of the roadway, causing it to trip over onto the grass median.  The vehicle came to rest on its roof leaning against a tree.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 51-year old female, stated that she was driving in the center southbound lane (lane two) when a vehicle in lane three tried to encroach into V1\'s lane.  After two attempts by the vehicle in lane three to try to enter V1\'s lane, it entered into V1\'s lane of travel, forcing V1 to change lanes abruptly to lane one.  The driver of V1 stated that she tried to regain control but was unsuccessful. She believes she rolled over 2-3 times before waking up upside down inside the vehicle and someone asking her to get out of the vehicle.  The driver could not recall exactly when the vehicle started its rollover sequence and feels that she may have blacked out as a result of the forces being applied by the rollover sequence.  The driver of V1 was wearing her seatbelt and refused treatment initially but was then transported to the hospital for a check-up.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as "This vehicle loss of control due to other cause of control loss," specified as "avoidance maneuver." This was chosen because a witness verified to police the presence and actions of the no-contact vehicle (cutting off V1).  The Critical Reason For the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as overcompensation, a performance error. The driver in the interview stated that she had waited for traffic to die down before heading home because she hates all the traffic on the highway.  She also stated that she tries to avoid this highway as much as she can. This was coded as an experience-related associated factor. Another factor coded to this driver was the use of a prescription allergy medication.

The following crash took place in the middle of a 4-way intersection.  The east/west roadway is a one-way street going west, with a stop sign visible approaching the intersection.  The crossing street is a two-way not physically divided roadway, this roadway has no TCD (traffic control device) at the intersection.\n\nThe driver of V1 a 2000 Ford F-150 was traveling northbound and V2 a 1996 Ford Taurus was traveling westbound.  V2 stopped at the stop sign and because of her obstructed view slowly drove into the intersection.  V1\'s view was also obstructed by the same parked vehicle and was unable to see V2 pulling into the intersection. V1\'s front contacted V2 in the left side.  V2 continued across the street and contacted a parked vehicle in the left side.\n\nThe driver of V1 states that he was traveling northbound.  As they approached the intersection a vehicle (V2) had made a rolling stop through the stop sign right into their lane of travel.  The driver states that at the speed they were going there was nothing they could do so they slammed on the brakes and struck V2 with the front end of the vehicle.  They also said that there was a vehicle blocking the driver\'s sight of vision to the intersecting roadway.  The driver stated that, had that car not been there they would have probably seen the vehicle and slowed down.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as:  other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V2 stated that she was traveling westbound approaching the intersection.  She state that they came to the intersection and made a complete stop at the intersection. The driver also states that when they completed their stop their view of the crossing street was being blocked by a vehicle parked on the corner.  They proceeded through the intersection slowly when the driver saw V1 coming at them.  The driver states that they don\'t remember what happened until the fire/rescue paramedics were pulling them out of the vehicle.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as:  this vehicle traveling, Crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as:  recognition error, inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). \n\n\nASSOSIATIVE FACTORS:  One major factor was the vehicle that both drivers state was blocking their views of each other.  Both drivers were familiar with the area

preprocessing
The accident this day took place on a two-lane, undivided north/south roadway at a T-intersection with an east/west roadway.  The east/west roadway intersected the north/south roadway at about a 25-30 degree angle.  The east/west roadway was controlled by a stop sign, while the north/south roadway had no traffic control device.  The posted speed limit on the north/south roadway was 40 kmph (25 mph), and the east/west roadway was posted at 32 kmph (20 mph). V1, a 1996 Ford Taurus, was traveling north. V2, a 1995 Isuzu Rodeo, was traveling west. At the time of the crash, it was raining heavily and the roadway was wet.\n\nThe driver of V1, a male of unknown age, was driving his two daughters to school.  He stated that he was following a non-contact vehicle as he approached the T-intersection.  The driver of V1 stated that the vehicle in front of him made a right hand turn into the eastbound roadway.  The driver of V1 attempted to go around the non-contact vehicle as it made its right turn. As he did so, V2, which had been stopped facing west at the stop sign, pulled out onto the north/south roadway, intending to turn left. The left front corner of V1 impacted the left rear side of V2. After being struck by V1, V2 was rotated in a counterclockwise direction, striking a utility pole aft the "C" pillar on the right side of the vehicle.  V2 came to rest against the pole facing east. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as "Other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, turning into opposite direction."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver include the non-contact vehicle in front of V1 that partially blocked V1\'s driver from seeing the actions of V2, the heavy rain, and the wet roadway. The driver of V1 stated that one of his daughters had a school trip that day and that was why he was driving them to school.  The driver stated that the two children were belted and secured in the back seat and were not causing any distraction at time of the accident.\n\nThis researcher was unable to get in contact with the driver of V2, a 25-year old female.The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as "This vehicle turning left at intersection."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event coded to this vehicle was "type of driver error unknown."  This was chosen because of the absence of an interview with the driver of V2. Due to the lack of an interview, the only known associated factors that were coded to this driver were the weather (the heavy rain) and the wet roadway.\n\n \n

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the early evening hours while still daylight at a T-intersection.  The main street was an east/west two-lane two-way roadway with no traffic control. The posted speed limit was 40 KMPH (25 MPH). The crossing street ran north/south and ended at the T-intersection.  The north/south roadway was a two-lane two-way roadway controlled by a stop sign. The east west roadway had a shoulder on either side, which diminished as it neared the intersection.  The roadway was divided by two solid yellow lines.  There were no adverse weather conditions that day and both roadways were dry.   \n\nV1, a 1998 Ford Taurus station wagon, was driven by a 20-year old female. V1 was traveling west on the east/west roadway. V2, a 1994 Pontiac Grand Am, was driven by a 24-year old female. V2 was traveling south on the north/south roadway. According to police and witness reports, the driver of V2 came to a complete stop at her stop sign, facing south.  The driver of V2 then entered the intersection and attempted to turn left to travel east on the east/west roadway.  As V2 entered the intersection, its left side was struck by the front right of V1. The momentum of V1 pushed V2 off of the roadway and down the east/west roadway traveling westbound, coming to rest approximately 51.6m from impact in the eastbound lanes.  V1 rolled off of the sidewalk and came to rest facing south in the middle of the two east/west lanes.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as "other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction." The Critical Reason For the Critical Pre-Crash Event was not coded to V1, although excess speed was coded as an associated factor. A witness who had been traveling behind V1 reported that V1 was traveling at a high rate of speed prior to impact. The extent of damage to V2 and the post-impact trajectory of the vehicles supported the claim of excess speed, as the posted speed limit was 40 KMPH (25 MPH). All other information was unknown due to the lack of an interview with the driver of V1.\n\nThe Critical Pre Crash Event for V2 was coded as "this vehicle traveling - turning left at intersection."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as "Type of driver error unknown," due to the lack of an interview. \n

The V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection. The asphalt road was dry, level, and there were no adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35mph). The crash occurred early evening on a weekend. \n\nV1, a 2001 Nissan Maxima, was traveling southbound, and was turning left at the intersection when mid-way through V1\'s front contacted V2\'s front. V2 is a 1994 Subaru Legacy.   \n\nThe driver of V1 is a 30-year old male. According to the brief interview he said he was in a hurry and thought that V2 was going to stop.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was turning left at intersection and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as aggressive driving behavior. \n\nThe driver of V2 is a 26-year old male who stated during the interview that he was traveling north on the roadway, and the traffic light was green.  He proceeded to cross through the intersection when V1 traveling south struck the front of his car.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n\n

The crash occurred in the mid-afternoon hours on a five-lane undivided roadway. There were 3 lanes eastbound and 2 lanes westbound. At the time of the crash, it was raining heavily and the asphalt was wet.  The posted speed limit was 56 KMPH (35 MPH).\n\nV1, a 1994 Nissan Quest minivan, was driven by a 36-year old male. V1 was traveling eastbound in the first lane of travel, approaching an intersection.  V2, a transit bus, was driven by a 55-year old male. The bus was stopped in the first lane of travel to let off passengers at a posted bus stop sign.  V1 came up behind V2 and the front of V1 struck the rear of V2 while V2 was letting off passengers.\n\nThe driver of V1 stated during the interview that he had been talking on a cellular phone with a friend prior to the crash.  Immediately before the crash, the driver ended the conversation and looked down to hang up the phone and to place the phone on his lap. When he looked up again, he saw the transit bus (V2) at a complete stop.  The driver of V1 stated that there was no way he could have stopped in time and \xe2\x80\x9cstomped\xe2\x80\x9d on the brakes, but his vehicle slid into the rear of V2.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was stopped in his lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was an internal distraction (hanging up the phone). The conversation was coded as an associated factor, as was the wet roadway and the weather (rain).\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was when another vehicle was in the same lane traveling at a higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No interview was obtained from the driver of V2, but he was not thought to have contributed to the crash. Associated factors coded to this driver include the wet roadway and the weather (rain).\n

The crash happened on a roadway that travels north/south.  This roadway consists of two lanes, one southbound left turn lane, two shoulders on either side of the roadway and two bicycle lanes on either side.  The weather conditions that day were clear.  The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours. \n\nThe driver of V1 was traveling southbound on the roadway approaching the intersection.  The driver of V1 did not see V2 stopped in the travel lane.  V1 contacted the rear of V2 with its front end.  Neither driver required medical attention.  V1 was towed do to major damage to its front end.\n\nThe driver of V1 stated that he was traveling southbound coming from a local restaurant.  He was driving about 3 minutes traveling on the southbound part of the roadway.  He states that he saw the light had turned red and was in the process of stopping the vehicle.  The driver states that he looked down for a unknown reason and when he looked up he realized that he would not be able to stop in time and hit V2.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as:  other motor vehicle stopped in travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as: recognition error, internal distraction.\n\nThe driver of V2 had a load in the back of his vehicle.  The approximate weight was estimated at around 100lbs.  The driver states that he was at a complete stop waiting for the light to turn green when the next thing he knew he was getting hit in the back.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded to this vehicle as: other motor vehicle in travel lane, traveling in same direction with a higher rate of speed.  There was no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.\n\nASSOSIATIVE FACTORS:  The driver of V1 is a high school student who has had a permit for one year and has just recently received his license, therefore inexperience could have been a causal factor.\n

The crash occurred in the northbound side of a six lane physically divided north/southbound highway, three southbound and three northbound lanes. During the time of the crash the highway was under construction, approaching a work zone, lane three was closed allowing access to lanes one and two. There were traffic barricades blocking lane one.  \n\nThe concrete highway was dry, level, and there was no adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit was 89kmph (55mph). The crash occurred early afternoon and the full access controlled highway had a consistent flow of traffic. \n\nV1, a 2005 Mitsubishi Lancer was traveling north and had entered lane two of the work zone when its front-end struck the rear of V2, a, 1999 Ford F-350 pick-up. The driver of V1,a 56 year old male stated that he had merged into lane two and preceded driving several feet when V2 suddenly stopped in front of him causing V1 to rear-end V2. The driver of V2, a 49-year-old female said that she was traveling at a consistent speed of approximately 64 kmph (40 mph) when she was rear-ended by V1. V1 was towed due to damages and all three occupants were transported to the hospital for minor injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded other motor vehicle in lane stopped, and the Critical Precrash reason was coded inadequate surveillance (failed to look far enough ahead).  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded traveling in the same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Precrash reason was not coded to this vehicle.      \n\n

The asphalt roadway was dry, level, and there no adverse weather conditions. The crash occurred on a weekday around noon and the traffic flow was busy.    \n\nV1, a 1998 Toyota RaV4, was traveling north, in lane one.  After crossing the intersection V1 attempted to change lanes to the parking lane along side the east curb edge, the parking lane had several vehicles parked unattended. The crash sequence is as follows;  V1\'s front contacted the rear of V2, a 2001 Mercedes Benz. V2\'s front contacted the rear-end of V3, a 1989 Mercury Tracer. Then V3\'s front contacted the rear of V4, a 1989 Dodge Aries.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was transported directly to the hospital with cuts to his forehead. \n \nThe V2 crash occurred at the entrance to an intersection. The roadway for both vehicles was asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph) for this southbound direction. A signalized traffic device controlled the traffic for all directions. There weren\'t any turning lanes. The traffic flow was normal and the weather was clear. The crash occurred in the early afternoon on a weekday. \n\nV2 (V2) decelerated at the intersection while V1 (V1) continued tracking, at a constant speed. V1 contacted the rear of V2 with its front. V1, a 1995 Jeep Cherokee, was traveling south, in lane three, on a three-lane roadway when the V2, a 2003 Chevrolet Silverado, decelerated in front of it. V1 contacted the rear of V2 with its front. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 25-year old male, said he didn\'t understand why V2 stopped/ slowed down at the intersection. They both had the green light. He did say that he wasn\'t fully paying attention. However, he wasn\'t sure what diverted his attention. He did say that he was conversing with the passenger and listening to the radio. The driver just bought the vehicle less than a month ago and was taking the vehicle back for problems: transmission/ engine problems. He was sure that he was traveling 50 mph (80 kmph) prior to the beginning of the crash sequence. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 19-year old male, refused to comment on the crash, or give access to his vehicle. His vehicle was not towed and allowed to leave the scene before  the  Researcher arrived. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was other vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped. The Critical Reason was coded as a driver related factor, internal distraction (i.e., talking with passenger). Associated factors coded to this driver included following too closely to forward vehicle. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded  as other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\nThe police recorded the crash as non-reportable. However, V1 was towed due to damage. \n

This crash occurred in the evening, the weather that evening was clear with no adverse conditions, the roadway was dry.  It took place on a major highway.  The highway travels east/west.  It consists of six total travel lanes, three in each direction, divided by a physical median with a positive barrier.  The two vehicles contacted in the westbound lanes while coming off the on-ramp, the on-ramp was not a factor (they were both on the roadway at the bottom).  The on-ramp had a yield sign at the bottom where the roadway levels out.\n\nV2 was stopped at the bottom of the on-ramp waiting for traffic at the yield sign.  V1 was also trying to merge into traffic, but did not notice V2 stopped at the bottom of the ramp due to being distracted by traffic on the roadway, driver of V1 was trying to merge into.  After V1 contacted the rear of V2 with its\' front they both came to rest in the merging traffic lane.\n\nThe operator of V1 states that he thought the operator of V2 had already merged into traffic. Driver of V1 was paying attention to the other traffic and never saw that V2 had not merged into traffic as he had thought.  V1 rear- ended V2 at the bottom of the ramp.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded other motor vehicle in lane other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as, recognition error inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see).  A possible factor is that driver of V1 had only had 2 hours sleep the night before and had felt fatigued.\n\nThe driver of V2 states that she was stopped completely at the bottom of the ramp waiting to merge into traffic. The driver states, that while she was waiting for traffic, more than 10 seconds, she was struck from behind by V1.  She suffered no injuries.   \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other motor vehicle in land traveling in same direction with higher speed.  There was no Critical reason coded to this vehicle.  The driver of this vehicle has a hyperopic (far-sighted) condition, she does not need her glasses to drive.  This was thought not to be a factor in the crash.\n\nBoth drivers are students at a local university, they both were in there \xe2\x80\x9cfinals\xe2\x80\x9d week.  Driver of V1 stated that he had been up late the night prior studying.\n\nOther Factors: Although neither driver clearly stated, I feel that both drivers were concerned about their exams.  They both attend the same university about one mile away from the accident scene.  It was the week for final exams.

This crash occurred during the morning hours, the weather that day was clear with no adverse conditions, the roadway was dry.  It took place at a Intersection on a major roadway.  The roadway travels north/south.  The crossing street travels east/west.  The north/south roadway consists of four total travel lanes, two in each direction, not divided by a physical median.  There is a bike lane, and a shoulder on each side.  \n\nV2 was traveling northbound through the intersection on the north/south roadway.  V1 was traveling westbound on the east/west roadway. After V1 contacted the right side  of V2, V2 flipped over and came to rest facing southbound on the north/south roadway.  As V2 flipped over it contact V3 which was in the lane next to V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 25 year old male who stated that he doesn\'t remember what happened because it was all so fast.  He thinks that he was checking the radio when he looked up and saw the yellow light.  He tried to get through when he saw the car cut in front of him.  He braked and then hit V2.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded to this vehicle as; this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded; recognition error internal distraction.  The driver of V1 was on medication for blood pressure and depression.\n\n We were unable to get an interview from the driver of V2. The PAR states that V2 was crossing the intersection when V1 hit V2 in the right side causing V2 to flip over and hitting V3 which was in lane 2 next to V2.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nV3 was driven by a 25 year old female student.  She stated that she was driving in lane 2 next to V2.  She saw V1 go through the red light and strike V2.  Then she was hit by V2.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event and  Critical Reason were not coded to this vehicle because it was not part of the first harmful event.
../resources/summary/2005006589004.json
preprocessing
This motor vehicle accident took place mid-block, on a two-way, four lane highway in the early hours of the morning (daylight).  The highway runs east/west; it has a shoulder on either side and also a bike lane on either side.  A concrete non-positive barrier physically divides this highway.  There is slight elevation in both directions and the posted speed limit in each direction is 48 kmph (30mph).\n\nV1 is a 1992 Toyota Corolla.  This vehicle was traveling eastbound on this east/west highway.  The driver crossed onto the raised concrete center curb median into westbound traffic and then steered back into the eastbound lanes.  The driver then crossed over both eastbound lanes of traffic, traveling onto the sidewalk and then striking the guardrail located on the right roadside.  V1 came to rest on the sidewalk approximately 15 meters from its impact point with the guardrail.  \n\nThe driver, a 24-year old female, stated that she was on her way to a medical clinic to pick up medication - she was recovering from a drug addiction. The driver had stopped at the light at the previous intersection and when the light turned green, she started to proceed normally when her left front wheel was "slipping. It kept turning, I tried to straighten the wheel back when I crossed the curb (divider).  Next thing I know I\'m looking at the traffic coming at me, I was scared.  I closed my eyes - that\'s all I remember."  Physical evidence at the scene showed no distinguishable markings on the concrete median that could be linked to the vehicle.  However, there were markings on the right side curb, tread marks in the grass where the driver departed the roadway, and paint transfer on the guardrail.  The driver was transported to a trauma center for multiple contusions and a fractured nose.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was when the driver of V1 departed the roadway on the right side. The Critical Reason for The Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as "poor directional control; e.g. failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected," a performance error. Associated factors coded to the driver include fatigue (driver had only 5 hours of sleep in the last 24 hours) combined with the use of a prescription medication that had the possible side effects of dizziness and fatigue, and driver inexperience (she had only a learner\'s permit). The driver also claimed that she was uncomfortable with the steering on the vehicle - she stated that the wheel kept "sticking."

The V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection. The northbound roadway (V1) was a two lane undivided asphalt, dry, and level roadway.  The eastbound roadway (V2) was also a two lane undivided roadway; however, there were metal trolley tracks planted in cement on both sides of the roadway. The posted speed limit was 40 kmph (25mph) for all directions. The intersection was controlled by signalized traffic lights without pedestrian crossing for all directions. The crash occurred in the early afternoon on a weekend. There were no adverse weather conditions and traffic flow was normal.\n\nV2, a 1995 Mazda Millenia, was traveling eastbound, speed unknown, and was crossing through the intersection when its front contacted the left front side of V1, a 1995 Honda Accord. The police report indicated that it was unknown as to which vehicle had the right of way; however, scene evidence, vehicle damage, and final resting points indicated that V2 ran the red light. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 30-year old female, was issued several citations. One of the violations was for driving a motor vehicle without a valid driver\'s license. The other was for driving with illegal movement and another for not having the vehicle properly insured. The driver of V2 was unavailable for an interview. She was taken from the scene to the hospital with minor injuries.      \n\nThe driver of V1, a 24-year old female, stated that she had the right of way and had the green light. She stated that V2 drove through the red light and struck her vehicle on the left side. This impact spun V1 in a clockwise direction and its front left side contacted a pole on the southeast corner of the intersection. The driver of V1 was not injured.    \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1. An associated factor code to this driver was unfamiliarity with the roadway - this was the first time she had driven on it.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as an illegal maneuver. Associated factors coded to this driver include several prescription medications for the treatment of asthma. Other associated factors were unknown due to the lack of an interview.\n

The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35mph). The crash occurred at an intersection of a one-way street heading west. It was nighttime and the roadway was light by overhead streetlights. The crash occurred during the middle of the week and the traffic was consistent.\n\nV2, a 1994 Oldsmobile 88 Royale LS, left its parking position, on the right side of the road, entered the roadway drove approximately 100 feet and suddenly stopped to make a left hand turn onto an intersecting small street when it was struck in the rear by V1, a 1989 Dodge Ram van with its front end. \n\nThe driver of V1, 40year old male, states that V2\'s sudden stop, happened so suddenly that he was unable to stop in time. The impact by V1 pushed V2 several feet beyond its intended left turn intersection. The driver of V1 said that his travel speed was 40 kmph (25 mph) and that he could see the vehicle clearly and wasn\'t sure if his full attention was on the roadway, He may have looked for a moment at the vehicles radio. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded other motor vehicle in lane other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded decision error - too fast to be able to respond to unexpected action of others. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 28 year old female, said that her travel speed was less than 32 kmph (20 mph) because she new her intended turn and was familiar with the roadway. She also stated that V1 was probably traveling too fast although she didn\'t see V1\'s approach from behind. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection. The crash occurred on a southbound one-way roadway. The asphalt road had one travel lane with parking on either side. It was dry and level. The posted speed limit was 40 KMPH (25 MPH). The crash occurred several feet after an intersection. At the point of the crash, there weren\'t any traffic control devices. It was early morning and traffic was light.  There were no adverse weather conditions.\n\nV1 was a 4-door 1997 Nissan Maxima driven by a 36-year old female. The Nissan was traveling southbound when the driver heard a thumping sound coming from her front left tire. The car pulled hard to the left and sideswiped a 2001 Ford F250 van that was parked on the east curb straddling the street and pavement. After impact, V1 traveled a few feet further southbound and then came to rest facing in an eastbound direction. It was apparent that V1 experienced a suspension failure prior to the impact, which pulled the vehicle in a left/eastward direction, causing it to impact the parked van, V2. The driver stated that she was familiar with the vehicle and was unaware of any previous problems with the car and had driven the vehicle several times in the recent past without incident.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded: this vehicle loss of control due to disabling vehicle failure. The Critical Reason for the Pre-crash Event was coded as a suspension failure. No additional associated factors were coded to the driver of V1.\n

The crash occurred in the intersection of a two-lane two-way roadway. The asphalt roadway was dry, level, and there were no adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35mph) for all directions. There are stop signs at each of the four corners before the intersection. The crash occurred on a weekday evening and the traffic was consistent and heavy. \n\nV1, a 2003 Dodge Durango SUV, was traveling south on the roadway and stopped at the stop sign before entering the intersection. His intention was to continue traveling south. He looked in all directions before continuing and noticed V2, a 1992 Toyota 4 door Camry stopped at the corner of the intersection heading westbound.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 38year old male, stated that he believed that he made eye contact with the driver of V2, a 53-year-old female, before he proceeded. He said that it was stop and go for several seconds, he\'d take off slowly and put on brakes and then the driver of V2 would do the same. It happened a few times before he actually applied the gas and accelerated quickly. He assumed she was going to let him go first. He said that he did not have time to react or stop fast enough to prevent hitting V2. All he could do was hit the brakes before he impacted the right side of V2 with his font-end.\n\nThe driver of V2 couldn\'t be contacted for an interview. She was transported to the hospital for observation. She told the police that she was not injured. She was just shaken-up and scared. V2 was towed due to damages from the crash.\n\nThe driver of V1 was obviously shaken-up as a result of the crash. However, decided not to be transported to the hospital. He was more concerned with getting into a crash with his uncles car. The car that he was driving belonged to his uncle and he reluctantly gave me the interview because he had to deal with his uncle. He admitted that he had been in a few crashes before. He said that his uncle thinks that he is a bit of a reckless driver. He is familiar with the roadway and the vehicle and has been a driver for several years.\n \nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle crossing over (passing though) the intersection, and the Critical Precrash Reason was also coded for this vehicle, V1 false assumption of the other\'s actions. It is the researchers opinion that the driver of V1 did stop for the stop sign before entering the intersection, however, did not proceeded at a considerable speed which would have allowed him to respond to the other drivers actions. V2 was impacted on its right side at the B pillar, mid car, and the distance from the corner/ stop sign is approximately 100 ft which is enough distance to react to a critical moment. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.

The V2 crash occurred in the middle of a T-intersection. The roadways for both vehicles were asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph) for both directions. V1 (V1) had a stop sign controlling its direction; there was no control device for V2 (V2). The crash occurred in the early afternoon on a weekday. The traffic flow was light and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a 2005 Ford Expedition, was traveling westbound and stopped at the corner, adhering to the passive stop sign located on both sides of the corner. She said she looked both ways before making her intended right turn; however, her view was obstructed by several vehicles parked on the southeast corner. She accelerated into the intersection and the front of her vehicle contacted the right front of V2, a 1992 Pontiac Bonneville.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 21-year old female, was aware of the posted stop sign, and said that she felt comfortable with the rented vehicle. She gave no other explanation for the crash besides her inability to see the traffic to her left. After the initial impact, V1 continued traveling north for a few feet and spun around 45 degrees clockwise before striking a narrow pole on the northeast corner of the intersection, where it came to final rest.   \n\nThe driver of V2, a 26-year old female, stated that she had the right of way and didn\'t see V1 until the last second and she then applied her brakes. She was issued a citation for driving without proof of insurance. Although V2 was towed, police logged the crash as a non-reportable accident.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was when it began to turn right at the intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see). Associated factors coded to this driver include a sightline restriction caused by the parked vehicles on the side of the roadway and unfamiliarity with both her vehicle and the roadway.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into same direction. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver. \n\n

The V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way offset intersection. The asphalt road was dry, level, and there were no adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit was 40 kmph (25 mph) for both roadways. East and westbound traffic was controlled by stop signs; north and southbound traffic had no traffic control device. The crash occurred in the mid-afternoon on a weekend. The traffic flow was moderate without congestion.\n\nV1, a 1996 Ford Taurus, was traveling northbound at approximately 56 kmph (35 mph) passing through the intersection with the right of way when V2 (V2), a 1989 Pontiac Grand Prix that was traveling eastbound, crossed in front of it. The front of V1 struck the right side of V2.  Although V2 had a stop sign, the driver of V2 stated that she didn\'t see it because she was adjusting the radio and also because the stop sign was completely white, not red with white letters.       \n\nThe driver of V2, a 38-year old female, suffered only minor injuries and went to the hospital later after driving home first. She said that she rarely drives this route and was apprehensive about entering the intersection because it looked busy. When asked if she thought that her adjusting the radio interfered with her operating the vehicle she said "no."\n\nThe driver of V1, a 22-year old male, was transported directly to the hospital and was later interviewed by phone. He stated that he had the right of way and that V2 crossed in front of his path. He was familiar with the intersection and knows to be careful but it all happened fast.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path. The Critical Reason was not coded to V1. One associated factor coded to this driver was excess speed, because by his own admission, he was traveling at least 10 mph over the speed limit. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as an internal distraction because the driver was adjusting her radio as she entered the intersection. Associated factors coded to this driver include the discolored stop sign (a roadway-related factor), inadequate surveillance, unfamiliarity with the roadway, and an illegal maneuver (failed to stop for TCD). \n\n

The asphalt roadway was dry, level, and there weren\'t any adverse weather conditions. The crash occurred on a weekday  during rush hour. The traffic flow was busy and at times congested. The rather small intersection was not busy, however, the southbound lane that V1 entered is a major roadway and very busy.    \n\nV1, a 1994 Pontiac Grand AM*, was traveling east on a one-lane roadway, travel speed unknown, when it made a right turn onto a four lane (two south and two north) roadway, traveled several feet and contacted, with its front end, the rear of a parked vehicle, (V2), a 1996 Nissan Maxima. V2 was parked legally. V2 was pushed up several feet after the impact and incurred moderate damage.   \n\nThe driver of V1 (V1) said that while he was making the right turn onto the major roadway was attempting to light his cigarette. The driver of V1 was also driving illegally, without a current drivers license.  \n\n\n*Police PAR list the vehicle as a 1994 model. However, I ran the VIN and it listed the year at 1992

This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a busy four-way intersection. The asphalt road was dry, level, and there weren\'t any adverse weather conditions. The posted speed limit for the roadway was 56 kmph (35 mph). The crossing roadway\'s speed limit was 40 kmph (25 mph). \n\nThe intersection was controlled by traffic signals for all directions. The crash occurred on a weekday in the early evening while still daylight. The traffic flow was very busy and at times congested. The roadway had six lanes - three north and three south. Lane one on each side was used for turning lanes during the daytime and at nighttime as parking lanes. There were no arrows or signs to indicate this.      \n\nV1, a 1997 Dodge Stratus 4-door sedan, was headed south, and stopped, at the red light, in lane two. V1 was behind a non-contact vehicle, also headed south. According to the driver of V1, the light turned green and the vehicle in front of her didn\'t move.  The driver of V1 went around the vehicle to proceed with her left turn. However, just as she began her turn, the front of her vehicle struck the front left of V2, a 1995 Honda Accord 4-door sedan that was traveling north on the same roadway in the opposite direction. After the initial impact, V1 rotated counterclockwise and came to final rest facing north. V2 continued traveling northward, rotating slightly clockwise.    \n\nThe driver of V1, a 22-year old female, was obviously shaken after the crash. She stated that she didn\'t see V2 coming from the opposite direction, although there was a lot of traffic at the busy intersection. She said that she traveled on the roadway daily and never had a problem before. She said that the non-contact vehicle in front of her obstructed her view. She felt that if maybe she\'d waited until the vehicle in front of her had cleared first, the crash might not have happened. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 43-year old female, said that there was nothing unusual about her drive that day other then V1 turning in front of her and striking her front left. She said that she couldn\'t understand why the driver of V1 didn\'t see the oncoming traffic. She reported that she didn\'t have time enough to apply her brakes.         \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was when it began to turn left at the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-Crash Event was also coded as inadequate surveillance, failed to look. An associated factor coded to this driver was a conversation with her right front seat passenger.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was when V1 encroached into her lane from the opposite direction, over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to V2 and no associated factors were coded to the driver of V2.\n

This three-vehicle crash occurred in the middle of a single lane two-way intersection, one southbound and one eastbound, both with parking lanes on either sides. The roadways were asphalt, dry, and level and the posted speed limit was 56kmph (35 mph). Signalized traffic devices controlled both directions. The crash occurred in the early afternoon on a weekday. The traffic flow was normal and the weather was clear. \n\nV1, a 2004 Chevrolet Malibu police plain clothes vehicle, was traveling southbound on the single lane roadway when it contacted, with its front, the left side of V2, a 2003 Ford Crown Victoria marked police cruiser, traveling eastbound on the crossing one way roadway.  After the initial impact, V2 left tire blew out causing it to pivot and rotate counter-clockwise and contact, with its right side, a fire hydrant located on the southeast curb of the intersection. The impact caused the hydrant to dislodge and hit a woman sitting on her steps located on the curb area several feet from the corner.  V2 continued to rotate counter-clockwise and contact, with its left side, the concrete wall where it came to final rest on the curb facing eastward. \n\nMeanwhile, V1, after the initial impact, rotated counter-clockwise and was struck on its right side by the front of V3, a 1999 Ford Crown Victoria marked police cruiser, traveling eastbound. V3 rotated slightly clockwise and remained in the middle of the intersection. All three vehicles were towed due to damages. All of the occupants and the pedestrian were transported to the hospital with moderate injuries.        \n\nAll three drivers refused interviews. They said its police policy not to discuss the events of the crash. However, a witness sitting on adjoining steps from the pedestrian struck by the hydrant, said the police were coming from everywhere traveling at a high rate of speed through the intersection without stopping for the traffic lights. There were several police vehicle passing through the intersection, she said, prior to the crash vehicles and that\'s what caught her attention. The actual speed of the vehicles is unknown.          \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason coded for V1 as other decision error, police vehicle on emergency run. The driver was not willing to be interviewed so there are no associated factors coded to this driver. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as crossing over (passing through) the intersection.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  An associated factor coded to this vehicle was a decision error, police vehicle on emergency run.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V3 is not involved in the first harmful event. The Critical Reason was not coded for this vehicle.  An associated factor coded to this vehicle was a decision error, police vehicle on emergency run.\n

The V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection. The eastbound roadway was a one-way 5-lane roadway. The intersecting roadway had two lanes northbound and three lanes southbound. The roadways were asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph) for all directions. The intersection was controlled by signalized traffic lights with pedestrian crossing for all directions. The crash occurred in the late afternoon on a weekend. There were no adverse weather conditions and traffic flow was normal.\n\nV1, a 2002 Ford Windstar, was traveling eastbound in lane three, a non-turning lane. As he approached the intersection, the light turned green. He realized that he needed to make a left turn. He noticed V2, a 1999 Toyota Corolla, in lane four to his left and thought it was going to turn left also. However, as he turned in front of V2, his vehicle\'s left side was contacted by V1\'s front right corner. The driver of V2 had intended to go straight. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 49-year old male, was from out of town and had driven for several hours prior to the crash to visit his daughter in college. He was unfamiliar with the roadway. His explanation for his action was that he needed to make a left turn. V1 was not towed. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 35-year old female, stated that she had the right of way and that V1 crossed in front of her. She thought V1 was going to go straight, since it wasn\'t in a turning lane. V2 was towed due to damages. The police, however, listed the crash as a non-reportable accident. There weren\'t any injuries resulting from the crash. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was when it began to turn left at the intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as an illegal maneuver (turning from the wrong traffic lane). Associated factors coded to this driver include false assumption of other driver\'s actions (he assumed that V2 was going to turn) and unfamiliarity with the roadway.\n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was when V1 encroached into its lane from an adjacent lane. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to the driver of V2. \n\n

This single vehicle crash began in the middle of a two-way intersection. Both the southbound and eastbound roadways were one-way one-lane roadways. Both were dry and level with a posted speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph). The intersection was controlled by signalized traffic lights without pedestrian crossing for both directions. The crash occurred in the mid-afternoon on a weekday. There were no adverse weather conditions and traffic flow was normal.\n\nV1, a 2001 Mitsubishi Montero, was traveling southbound at an unknown speed when it entered the intersection at the same time as a non-contact vehicle that was traveling east. The driver of V1 reacted by jerking the wheel hard to the left, and then back to the right. The driver of V1 lost control and the vehicle rotated clockwise. V1 then rolled over two one-quarter turns to the left, ending up on its top, sliding a few feet before coming to final rest facing south. V1 had major damage and was towed.  \n\nThe driver of V1, a 24-year old male, stated that he was traveling southbound when a vehicle sped in front of him from his right. In order to avoid hitting this vehicle, he sharply turned to his left and rolled over the vehicle onto its top. At the time of the crash, the driver was on leave from the military and was familiar with the intersection. The passenger, his wife, was transported to the hospital with minor injuries, and later refused an interview. The driver of V1 was not injured and has since returned to the military.          \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as control loss due to a sudden sharp turn to the left. The Critical Reason was coded as overcompensation, a performance error. An associated factor coded to the driver was conversation with the passenger. \n

The one-vehicle crash began on the curved section of a two-lane north/southbound cobblestone undivided roadway. The south/north two-lane roadway was wet, and level. Planted in the cobblestone road were metal trolley tracks in cement in both directions of the roadway. The posted speed limit was 40 kmph (25mph) for both directions. There were no traffic-controlled signals. The crash occurred in the mid afternoon on a weekday. It was raining and the cobblestone roadway was wet and slippery. Traffic flow was normal.\n\nV1, a 2005 Chrysler Sebring, was traveling southbound on the slippery cobblestone road when she attempted to avoid contact with another vehicle. While negotiating a curve to the right, she traveled off the road and struck a pole with its front left and the wall with its right back side. The pole was 16 meters in diameter and the wall was 40 meters high. V1 was lodged between the pole and the wall facing south at final rest. V1 was towed due to damages.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 21-year old female was visibly shaken. She said she was driving south and was aware of the cobblestone and how slippery it gets when it rains. Her travel speed she said was approximately 48 kmph (30mph). She was attempting to avoid contacting another vehicle to her left and turned to the right while traversing a curve right and lost control because the cobblestone, was wet. The driver first, was not interested in being transported to the hospital. However, deciding after her mother arrived at the scene to be transported.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded control loss due to rain and wet cobblestone, while negotiating a curve. The Critical Reason was as a decision error driving to fast on wet cobblestone while traversing a curve. The associated factor is driving slightly over the speed limit.  Another associated factor is the road design; possible speed limit and the surface condition of cobblestone when wet.  This road has been paved over with asphalt since this crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005006589543.json
preprocessing
This single-vehicle crash occurred on a two-lane major thoroughfare. The highway merged from three to two lanes several hundred feet before the point of impact. The roadway was cement, dry, and level with a curve to the right. The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph). There were cement barriers on each side of the roadway. There were no traffic control devices. The crash occurred in the mid-evening hours on a weekend. It was dark out but overhead lights illuminated the roadway. Traffic flow was normal and the weather was clear.   \n\nV1, a 2005 Honda Pilot, was traveling eastbound in lane one. V1 had merged onto the highway several hundred feet prior to the point of impact from the on-ramp. At that point the highway consisted of three lanes. Several feet after the emergence onto the highway, the lanes narrowed to just two lanes. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 60-year old male, reported that after he merged onto the highway, another vehicle crossed in front of him from lane two and slowed down. In an attempt to avoid contact with the vehicle, he quickly steered left and applied the brakes. He lost control of the vehicle and struck the cement barrier on the north side of the highway. After the initial impact, V1 rotated to the right and its left rear side contacted the guardrail. V1 came to final rest facing south across both lanes of travel. A witness contacted police after the crash with a different version of events. The witness stated that V1 had passed him at a high rate of speed and then V1 came up fast upon a slower-moving vehicle. In an attempt to avoid striking this slower vehicle, the driver of V1 slammed on his brakes while steering left sharply. These actions caused V1 to skid into the cement barrier. V1 was towed due to damages. The driver was transported to the hospital with minor injuries. The passenger, a 14-year old male, was not injured.          \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was control loss due to excess speed The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as too fast to be able to respond to the unexpected actions of others. Associated factors coded to this driver include conversation with the passenger and use of prescription medications to control diabetes and high blood pressure.\n
../resources/summary/2005006589562.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred in the evening hours on the bituminous northbound lanes of a divided urban highway.  The two northbound were dry, level, curved to the right, and featured shoulders on both sides as well as a posted speed limit of 80kmph (50mph).  There were no adverse atmospheric conditions and the roadway was dark but lighted with normal traffic flow.\n\nV1, a 2000 Mazda 626, was traveling north in lane one when its left side was contacted by V2, an unknown type van, as it re-entered the roadway from the shoulder. The initial impact caused V1 to lose control of her vehicle and began to swerve off the road to the left.  She drove a few feet up the embankment on the side of the road digging her left side tires into the grass/dirt causing them to blow out and damage her undercarriage.  V1 abruptly steered right descended down the hill and began to rollover. V1 re-entered the roadway still turning clockwise and rolled over two quarter turns onto its top coming to final rest facing south.  V2 continued traveling and didn\'t stop.\n\nV1 was driven a 25-year old female in good health on her way home.  She stated she didn\'t expect a vehicle (V2) to be traveling on the shoulder.  When she finally saw V2 encroaching from the left shoulder into her lane. Both driver and passenger were transported to the hospital with moderate injuries and V1 was towed due to damages.    \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded other motor vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction) - over left lane line.  The only associated factor coded to this driver was fatigue; she said that she\'d worked 12hrs that day (but claimed she wasn\'t tired).  V1 was not thought to have contributed to this crash.  \n\nV2 left the scene without stopped therefore no driver interview or vehicle inspection could be obtained.  The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as this vehicle traveling, over the lane line on the right side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as an unknown decision error.  There are no known associated factors coded to this vehicle, as the driver wasn\'t interviewed.

\n \nThe V2 crash occurred in the middle of a five-way intersection. The roadways were asphalt and dry for both vehicles. V1 had a 4% uphill grade while V2 had a 4% downhill grade. The posted speed limit was 40 kmph (25 mph) for all directions. V1 and 2, east and westbound travel directions, were controlled by asignalized traffic devices. The crash occurred in the late afternoon on a weekday. The traffic flow was heavy and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a 1999 Oldsmobile Delta 88, was traveling westbound on the two-lane east/ west roadway, proceeded through the intersection when its front  contacted the right side of V2, a 2004 Hyundai Sante Fe. V2 was also traveling through the intersection eastbound direction, 180 degree opposing direction, intending to make a left turn  to travel northbound. Both vehicles had a green light as they proceeded through the intersection.     \n\nThe driver of V2, a 63-year old female, said she was traveling east on the two-lane roadway at approximately 40 kmph (25 mph) through the intersection intending to make a left turn northbound when her vehicle was contacted on its right side by V1traveling westbound. She said the light was green. She stated before she had a chance to react, her vehicle was struck by V1. She doesn\'t remember doing anything inside the vehicle or looking anywhere outside the vehicle that would distract her attention. She did say that the traffic was busy and the crash could have been avoided had she seem V1 sooner. She\'s a seasoned driver. She been licensed for over 45-years and is familiar with the roadway; she travels on it daily. The driver of V2 was not injured. V2 was towed due to damages.   \n\nThe driver of V1 was unavailable for comment and could not be reached. V1 wasn\'t towed. However, the PAR damage indicator listed the damage as disabling. Both driver and passenger of V1 were transported to the hospital with possible injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was when it began to turn left at the intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see). \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. No associated factors were coded to this driver. \n\n\n\n

Case Summary #2005-06-041\n \nThe single-vehicle crash occurred off-road on the wet grass beyond the asphalt, dry, and level roadway. The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 mph). There weren\'t any traffic control devices. The crash occurred in the early morning hours on a weekday. The traffic flow was normal and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a 2003 Subaru Forester, was traveling northbound on a wide three lane roadway when it drifted off-road and contacted a tree and the guardrail located on the grass/ dirt west of the northbound road. After contacting the tree with its front left, V1 traveled several feet steered left rotated counter clockwise 180 degrees and contacted the metal guardrail with its right side rear where it came to final rest facing south. V1 was towed due to the damages.     \n\nThe driver of V1, a 34-year old male, was traveling north at approximately 89 kmph (55 mph) when the driver fell asleep and his vehicle drifted off road to the left and contacted the tree and the guardrail. The driver said that he was on his way to work and was tired from studying. Although the crash occurred at approximately 8:00 hours in the morning, he\'d been awake for seven hour. The driver travels on the road daily and said he was aware of the speed limit, as well as, is familiar with the roadway. He figured he accelerated while he was asleep. \n\nThe driver said he\'d awaken suddenly and realized he was off the roadway and steered to the right but it was too late he\'d already contacted the tree. He then, believes he steered to the left and rotated counter clockwise while sliding on the wet grass and contacted the guardrail.   \n \nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event was coded as off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason was coded as sleeping that is, actually asleep. Associated factors coded for the driver include driving over the speed limit 89 kmph (55 mph) on a 64 kmph (40 mph) roadway. Driver fatigue; the driver normally sleeps six hours. However, only slept five hours the previous night. Also, strenuous non-work activities; the driver spent most of the night and early morning hours studying and was tired.  \n\n\n\n

preprocessing
This V2 crash occurred in the middle of a four-way intersection. The roadways for both vehicles were asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 56kmph (35 mph) for both directions. Signalized traffic devices controlled all the directions into the intersection. The crash occurred in the late afternoon on a weekday. The traffic flow was normal and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a 1993 Mercury Villager, was traveling westbound through the intersection when it contacted, with its front, the left side of V2, a 1990 Plymouth Acclaim traveling southbound through the intersection.  After the impact V1 rotated (15 deg) slightly clockwise and came to final rest.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 57-year old female, refused to be interviewed and would not comment on the crash. The police report indicates she was traveling through the intersection and contacted V1. She reported to the police that V2 disregarded the red light and she didn\'t have enough time to stop. However, statements made by the police to this researcher contradict that statement.  The driver suffered minor injuries and was transported from the scene.  V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe driver of V2, a 35-year old male, said he was traveling approximately 48kmph (30mph) as he approached the intersection.  He entered it, at a steady speed, and was contacted by V1.  He assures that the light was green and his travel speed was within the speed limit.  He said he didn\'t see V1 until the last minute; that is, when it made contact with his vehicle.  . V2 damages were disabling and had to be towed.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) an intersection. The Critical Reason was coded as an illegal maneuver as V1 violated a traffic control device.  There were no known associated factors as the driver refused to be interviewed. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. There were no known associated factors, as V2 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n\n\n

\n \nThe single-vehicle crash occurred approximately 200 feet beyond a four-way intersection. The roadway was asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph). The crash occurred late evening and the roadway was illuminated by overhead streetlights. The traffic flow was light and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a modified 1987 Chevrolet S-10 Blazer, was traveling northbound in lane one on a four lane, two northbound and two southbound, non-positive divided roadway, when V1 drifted off road and contacted with its front, the rear of V2, a 2002 Chrysler Town & Country, parked on the right/ east side of the roadway. V1, after pushing V2 a few feet, came to final rest directly behind V2. V1 was towed/ pulled away from V2 and left on the side of the road. The damage to V1 was disabling. \n\nThe driver of V1, an 18-year old male, said he was traveling on the road when he fell asleep and drifted off road and hit the parked V2. He said he wasn\'t sure if he intended to park or continue going north. He did say he remembers talking to his passenger and adjusting the radio just before closing his eyes and falling asleep, for a coupe of seconds. When he opened his eyes, he didn\'t realize V2 was parked. He said he was tired and didn\'t get a lot of sleep the night before.  \n\nV1\'s driver wasn\'t familiar with the roadway. He rarely travels on it. He\'s a fairly new driver. He\'s had his driver\'s license for one year. Police found various types of drugs and alcohol inside the vehicle. He was arrested for DUI. It is unknown if the driver was tested for alcohol or drugs and no results were obtained. Although V1 suffered disabling damage, police logged the crash as a non-reportable accident. \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the right side of the travel lane. The Critical Reason was coded as sleeping, that is actually sleep. Associated factors coded to this driver include inexperience driver, driving while under the influence, conversing with the passenger and adjusting the radio/ CD player. \n

Case Summary #2005-06-044\n \nThe single vehicle crash began on the eastbound side of a six-lane fully controlled highway and ended on an adjoining off ramp. Both roadways were asphalt, dry, and level. The posted speed limit for the highway was 80 kmph (50 mph) and the posted speed limit for the off ramp was 56 kmph (35 mph). The crash occurred late night on a weekday. The roadways were illuminated by over-hanging streetlights. The traffic flow was light and the weather was clear.\n\nV1, a 2001 Toyota 4Runner, was traveling eastbound, in lane two when it crossed over to lane one and contacted with its right side the cement guardrail located on the right side of lane one. After contact with the barrier, V1 continued accelerating beyond the barrier exited the highway, crossed over two of the off ramp lanes, jumped the curb, and contacted the mesh fence and concrete barrier, with its front, where it came to final rest. V1 was disabled as a result of the impact and was later towed.   \n\nThe driver of V1, a 53-year old male, said he was cut off by another vehicle. The police noted no evidence of a phantom vehicle. Neither was there any evidence of contact with another vehicle. Evidence suggests V1 decided to exit the roadway from lane two across lane one. During the interview, he stated that he was going to a location near the off ramp. However, later said he was on his way home. He said after he contacted the guardrail, he applied his brakes lost control steered right and impacted the fence and cement guardrail. The driver of V1 was not injured.   \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the right side of the travel lane. The Critical Reason was coded as poor directional control, a performance error. Associated factors coded to the driver included talking on a cell phone (i.e., internal distraction) and overcompensation (a driver performance error).\n\n\n\n

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of an undivided three-lane roadway.  There was an intersection 64 meters west of the point of impact and a store parking lot entrance at the point of impact.  The parking lot was outlined with trees in large planter boxes.  The planter boxes on the right side of the eastbound lane partially obscured the view of V2 up to up to 60 meters prior to impact.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 56 KMPH (35MPH).  The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours on a weekday.\n\nV1, a 1991 Chrysler LeBaron convertible, was traveling east.  V2, a 2001 Buick LeSabre sedan, was turning left (west) out of the parking lot.  As V2 pulled out it was contacted on its left side by V1\'s front end in the eastbound lane of the roadway.\n\nV1 was driven by a 22-year old female who refused treatment by EMS personnel.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.  An interview of the driver of V1 was not obtained.\n\nThe critical pre-crash event for V1 occurred when V2 encroached into V1\'s lane to turn left and proceed west.  The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to V1. However, the driver of V1 was thought to have contributed to the crash. As per a witness, V1 had gone through a red light at the previous intersection and was traveling at a high rate of speed. Based on the witness statement, the driver of V1 was also coded as driving aggressively. The tree/planter box on the right side of the roadway may also have served as a sightline restriction.  Due to the lack of an interview, it was not known if there were other contributing factors (e.g. distractions, non-driving activities).\n\nThe driver of V2, an 82-year old male, stated he was stopped waiting for traffic to let him out of the parking lot.  When he saw a break in traffic, he checked left and right and proceeded onto the road and was struck on the left side by V1. The driver of V2 also stated that he noted that the traffic signal at the nearby intersection was red and thought that no one would be coming from the eastbound direction. The driver of V2 refused medical treatment on scene.\n\nThe critical pre-crash event for the driver of V2 occurred when he pulled out of the driveway to make a left turn.  The critical reason for the critical event was coded as inadequate surveillance.  The driver of V2 stated that he could still see the eastbound roadway despite the tree/planter box to his left. \n

This crash occurred on a weeknight on a rural two lane unlit roadway.  On scene, the investigating officer noted a smell of alcohol and the driver had fled the scene.  The speed limit was 25MPH (40KMPH).  The grade was downhill with a slight curve to the right.  Driver ignored repeated attempts to interview.\n\nV1 was a 2003 Mercedes Benz C240 driven by a 36 year old female.  There were no other occupants.\n\nThe driver of V1 was negotiating a -9.8% downhill grade with a slight right hand curve.  The vehicle traveled into the opposing lane, the driver corrected and overcompensated to the right.   The vehicle left the roadway and entered a yard striking a utility pole and a tree with its front-end plane until finally coming to final rest in the yard.  The critical precrash event was this vehicle traveling off the roadway to the right.  The critical reason for the critical precrash event was poor directional control.\n\n

This Crash occurred in the afternoon on a weekday on a two lane asphalt roadway intersection.  There was a downhill grade of -24.6%.  The posted speed limit was 35MPH (56KMPH).\n\nV1 was a 1998 Volkswagen Beetle driven by a 54 year old female.  There were no other occupants.\n\nV1 was trying to slow down and come to a stop at the intersection.   The brakes failed to stop the vehicle and it went over a raised median on the left side, though the intersection, made 180 degree turn, and attempted to drive back toward the hill.  The vehicle impacted a disconnected trailing unit legally parked on the shoulder.  The vehicle came to rest under the trailing unit.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was control loss due to disabling vehicle failure.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was due to brakes failed.

preprocessing
This crash occurred in the late evening hours of a weeknight on the right hand shoulder of an unlighted two-lane roadway.  The bituminous roadway had a downhill grade greater than 2% with sharp curve to the right and a posted speed limit of 40kmph (25mph).  There were no adverse atmospheric conditions and the roadway was dry. \n\nV1, a 1991 Honda CRX, was negotiating a right hand curve at a high rate of speed, 80kmph (50 mph) when he crossed the yellow lines on the left.  The driver than steered the vehicle to the right and the vehicle departed the road on the right side.  He overcompensated the steering input to the left and when the vehicle reentered the roadway it tripped and rolled 2 quarter turns.  The vehicle came to rest on its roof in the original travel lanes.\n\nV1 was driven by a 26 year-old male in good health who was commuting home.  He stated he tried correcting his vehicle after it started skidding, but could not keep it from rolling over.  The driver could not remember much as he suffered a concussion as a result of the crash.  He was transported to a treatment facility with unknown severity of injuries and V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded as this vehicle traveling, off the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason of the Critical Event was overcompensation.  Associated factors for this crash include traveling too fast for conditions as the driver was traveling at roughly twice the legal limit.  \n

This crash occurred on a dry 2 lane loose dirt-gravel roadway on a weekday night.  The speed limit was 40kmph (25mph) and there was a grade of 8.2%.  The roadway was curved at the point of impact with a hillside obscuring the view of the two drivers.\n\nV1 was negotiating and uphill right hand curve.  V2 was proceeding opposite vehicle1 and negotiating a downhill left hand curve.  The driver of V1 pulled over and stopped the driver of V2 crossed over and stuck V1\'s left front with V2\'s left front.  \n\nV1 was a 1993 Cadillac Seville driven by a 45 year old male.  The driver states he was going around the bend when he saw another car coming the opposite way, he stopped and the other car hit him in the door.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\nV2 was a 2004 Pontiac Grand Am driven by a 17 year old male.  His mother stated that he was in a hurry becuase he was late for curfew.  Another associated factor was that he was an inexperienced driver.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was this vehicle over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason was coded unknown.

This crash occurred during the evening hours of weekday on a two-lane bituminous suburban roadway.  The dark, wet roadway was level with a curve to the left and featured a speed limit of 56kmph (35mph).  The atmospheric conditions were cloudy with rain.\n\nV1, a 1990 Honda Accord hatchback, was westbound negotiating the left-hand curve traveling approximately 97kmph (60mph).  As the road straightened back out, the driver continued with the curve and ran off the road to the left.  V1 struck a parked car  (V2 a 1999 Nissan Altima) on the side of the road, continued forward striking a retaining wall, which sent the vehicle airborne and into the side of a house.  V1 came to final rest in the fist floor of the two-story residence.\n\nV1 was driven by a 19 year-old male who could not be located for an interview.  The driver sustained non-incapacitating injuries and was transport to a treatment facility after he was extracted from the vehicle.  V1 was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, off the road edge to the left.  The Critical Reason was a driver decision error, traveling too fast for conditions.  The associated factors were traveling too fast for conditions (unknown reason), as well as the atmospheric and roadway conditions (the rain made the curved roadway wet and slippery).\n\n

This crash occurred on a rural, two lane, traveled asphalt roadway.  The road was wet from rain.  The speed limit was 56 KMPH (35 MPH).  The grade was level.  The driver interview and vehicle inspection were denied by the owner.\n\nV1 was a 1990 Oldsmobile 88 driven by a 44 year old female, there were no other occupants.\n\nV1 had successfully negotiated a curve when the vehicle departed the roadway on the right side ran over the curve sign and traveled approximately 40 meters and struck a utility pole.  \n\nThe Critical PreCrash Event was this vehicle traveling off the road edge on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical PreCrash Event was too fast for conditions.  The conditions being rain, wet road surface and 10+ miles per hour over the speed limit.

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a curved two lane suburban roadway in the afternoon on a weekday.  The roadway was wet from rain earlier in the day.  The speed limit was 40kmph (25mph) with an advisory limit of 24kmph (15mph).  The grade was 10/61 with a super elevation of -4/61.  V1, a 2004 Volvo XC90 SUV, was southbound proceeding uphill negotiating a curve when V2, a 2000 Honda Civic 4dr, traveling in the opposite direction crossed the centerline and struck V1.\n\nV1 was driven by a 37 year-old female who claimed to be in good health despite taking hormones.  She stated that she saw V2 as soon as she rounded the bend and attempted to avoid the crash by braking and steering to the right.  She could not avoid V2 and was struck.  The driver was uninjured and V1 was towed from the scene.\n\nV2 was driven by a 74 year-old female who claimed to be in good health and was delivering for Meals-on-Wheels.  She stated she was not familiar with the area and usually has a navigator to assist her.  She was looking for an address when she began to lose control of her vehicle.  She panicked and slammed on her brakes, causing full lock up, and skidded into the path of V1.  She suffered minor injuries and was transported for treatment and V2 was towed from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroaching from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason was coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors include driver inattention as she was focused on previous argument.  The roadways were also wet and the shrubbery lining the roadway caused a sightline restriction. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded this vehicle control loss due to - traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a driver related factor of traveling too fast for the conditions of the wet downhill turn.  Associated factors include driver inattention, as she was focused on an exterior factor (looking for a street address) as well as traveling too fast for conditions as she did not realize that caution was required.  The driver also had a performance error when she panicked making the situation worse.  The driver was also unfamiliar with the area and normally had a navigator to assist her.  The roadways were also wet and the shrubbery lining the roadway caused a sightline restriction.\n
