This crash occurred in the evening hours of a weekday on the western roadside of a bituminous two lane, two-way, undivided street.  The roadway was dry, straight, and level with no traffic flow restrictions and a posted speed limit of 40kmph (25mph).  It was a dark, but lighted roadway with cloudy skies.  V1, a 1981 Oldsmobile Delta 88, was northbound in lane one when the vehicle drifted to the left eventually departing the roadway to the left and striking a utility pole before coming to final rest.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 45 year-old male who refused to be interviewed for this study.  The driver did tell police that he swerved to avoid a cat in the roadway causing him to lose control of his vehicle.  The police officer on scene stated he smelled alcohol on the driver and performed a field sobriety test.  The driver of V1 was found to intoxicated and taken into custody after he was released from the medical facility he was transported to.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason was coded as a critical non-performance error-alcohol related.  The associated factor for this crash was alcohol related as the driver was found to be severely intoxicated.
../resources/summary/2005008586001.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the left of two southbound lanes of a four-lane undivided urban roadway. There was a gas station entrance on the west side of the roadway at the point of impact. There was also an intersecting street on the east side of the roadway 10m north of the point of impact. The roadway had a posted speed of 64 KMPH (40 MPH) and the southbound lanes had a positive 4.9% grade. Conditions were daylight and dry with cloudy skies and a temperature of 8\xc2\xb0C (47\xc2\xb0F.)  The crash occurred at 17:30 on a weekday.\n \nV1, a 2001 Ford Focus sedan, was exiting the gas station heading east. The driver of V1 intended to cross the roadway and travel east on the intersecting street. V2, a 2002 Ford Windstar minivan, was traveling south in the left southbound lane. A non-contacted truck was in the right southbound lane turning right (west) into the gas station. As V1 crossed the left southbound lane, the front of V2 contacted its left side. Both vehicles came to rest in the left northbound lane.\n\nV1 was driven by a 19-year old female who was transported to a local hospital due to a complaint of head pain.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 occurred when the driver turned left from the gas station entrance. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was inadequate surveillance. As the truck made its turn from the right southbound lane, it prevented the driver of V1 from seeing V2 as it approached from in the left southbound lane.\n\nThe 54-year old female driver of the V2 stated she was traveling less than 40 kph (25mph) in the left southbound lane when V1 emerged from in front of the truck and crossed her travel lane. The driver stated that while she may have attempted to apply the brakes, she had little time to react. V2 was also towed due to damage. The driver was not transported to a medical facility. \n\nNo Critical Reason was coded for the driver of V2.  The Critical Precrash Event occurred when V1 turned across the path of V2.\nThe driver of V2 has been diagnosed with Myasthenia Gravis. She also stated that while her condition prevented her from performing strenuous activity, it had no effect on her ability to safely operate a vehicle. She was taking two prescription medications at the time of the crash: Mestinon, which is a cholinesterase inhibitor, and CellCept, which is an immunosuppressant. The driver stated that the medications were taken as prescribed, and did not affect her ability to drive. \n
../resources/summary/2005008586021.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred off the East bound lane of an undivided two lane traveled asphalt roadway.  There was a restaurant parking lot on the south edge of the roadway.  The posted speed limit was 64 KPMH (40 MPH).  The roadway had a positive elevation of 3.2% and a positive super-elevation of 3.2%.  Conditions were dry, in the evening on a weekday. The setting sun was remarkably bright, but was located behind the vehicle.\n \nV1, a 2001 Buick Century sedan, was traveling East with one driver and one occupant.  The driver intended to drive home from shopping.  The driver fell asleep and departed the right side edge of the roadway. The front of the vehicle contacted a wooden fence and a utility pole support wire. The front of the vehicle then contacted a tree, rotated 90 \xc2\xba clockwise and came to rest facing south off the right road edge.\n\nV1 was driven by an 80 year old male and a 79 year old female passenger who were transported to the hospital with complaint of chest pain.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 occurred when the vehicle traveled off the right side road edge.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was that the driver fell asleep.  The driver stated that they had just completed a \xe2\x80\x9crestful\xe2\x80\x9d six-day cruise, but were forced to drive home when their flight was cancelled. Over the previous two days, the driver and passenger alternated driving for 26 hours.\n\nDriver fatigue was a major factor in this crash. The driver indicated that during the previous 26-hour trip, he slept for periodic four-hour intervals, but admitted that he had difficulty sleeping in the moving car. The driver stated that the night before the crash, he attempted to sleep from 23:30 to 07:30. However, he didn\'t sleep well and he estimated that he was actually asleep for a total of four hours. The driver denies taking any medication and stated that he had no pre-existing medical conditions. \n\nMedical records indicate that 60 years prior, he had a lung and both scapula removed as the result of a war injury. He was diagnosed with Hodgkin\'s lymphoma 20 years prior but was tumor free at the time. None of these factors appeared to be relevant to this crash.\n

preprocessing
This crash occurred in the intersection of two asphalt residential streets. It was on a weekend evening, with daylight and there were no adverse weather conditions.   The speed limit for V1 was 32 kmph (20mph) and there was a 12% downhill grade with a stop sign at the intersection.  The speed limit for V2 was 40 kmph (25mph) and there was a 12% downhill grade.\n\nV1 was traveling east as it approached the intersection that was controlled by a stop sign. V2 was traveling north as it approached the intersection. The front of V1 contacted the left front wheel of V2. V1 came to rest heading north at the east curb just north of the intersection. V2 came to rest heading northwest on the northwest corner. V2 was towed due to damage and the occupant of V2 was transported to a medical facility.\n\nV1 was a 1998 Ford Contour driven by a 20 year-old female. There was a 7 month-old passenger in a child seat in the right rear seat.  The driver stated that she stopped at the stop sign and as she was turning right got hit on the right front of her vehicle.  It is the researchers opinion that the driver of V1 was not telling the truth and did not stop at the stop sign and was intending to go straight across the intersection.  The angle of the vehicles and the damage to both vehicles supports V1 going straight across the intersection.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was an illegal maneuver (running a stop sign).  A witness to the crash stated that he saw V1 traveling at a high rate of speed and that the driver of V1 did not slow for the stop sign. The driver of V1 stated that she did stop for the stop sign and was traveling 24 kph (15 mph)\n \nThe PAR states that the driver of V1 did not have a valid driver\'s license at the time of the crash, although she did have one in the past. The driver stated that her license was reinstated just prior to the crash. \n\nV2 was a 1999 Chevrolet Malibu driven by a 17 year-old male. There were no passengers in the car.  He stated that he was going down the street with the right-of-way.  He never saw the other car (it was coming down the street very fast) and he got hit on the driver\'s side.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was the other vehicle encroaching from crossing street, across path. No Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded for this vehicle. The airbag system data module recorded the maximum velocity change as -7 kph (-4mph.) \n\nBecause the driver of V2 was inexperienced and familiar with the roadway, it is possible that this driver did not look to the left for crossing traffic because he had the right of way. This driver had only been driving for six months at the date of the crash. He indicated that he never saw V1 approaching because of V1\'s speed. He stressed the fact that he \xe2\x80\x9chad the right-of-way\xe2\x80\x9d.

It was late evening on a weeknight and there were no adverse weather conditions. The street was not lighted.  \n \nV1, a 1989 Jeep Wagoneer, was traveling East with the driver and one passenger inside. The Jeep pushed the Tahoe 1.7m east before both vehicles came to rest.\n\nV1 was driven by a 25-year-old male. The driver and front right passenger were transported to a medical facility for treatment.  The driver stated that he was looking at his wife as he was speaking to her. He stated that he was distracted and hit the other vehicle.  The driver indicated that, he had recently had his brakes worked on and they weren\'t quite right.  While he was not comfortable with the condition of his vehicle\'s brakes, he was uncertain if this contributed to the crash. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 occurred when the vehicle traveled left, over the left edge of the travel lane and into the parking lane. The Critical Reason for the Precrash Event was an internal distraction.

There was a grade of -1.6 percent and the roadway was straight but the entrance ramp curved to the right. The vehicle began to rotate clockwise and crossed both travel lanes. The back left of V1 swiped the concrete barrier on the left side of the travel lanes. V1 then crossed the travel lanes in a northerly direction and then the right shoulder. The front of the vehicle contacted the other concrete barrier and V1 came to rest straddling lane 1. The driver stated that she fishtailed due to the wet roadway and was unable to regain control. She indicated that surrounding traffic was not a factor in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was V1 traveling off the edge of the road on the left side. The speed limit was 25mph (40 kph).\n\nV1 was a 2004 Hyundai Elantra with two occupants. V2 was a 2003 Honda Civic with one occupant.\n\nV2 was stopped heading east in the right curb lane. V1 entered the roadway from a parking lot on the north road edge intending to make a right turn to travel west. V1 crossed the centerline and entered the right eastbound lane, where the front of V1 contacted the front of V2. Both vehicles came to rest near the point of impact.\n\nThe Critical precrash event was V1 traveling over the left lane line and encroaching into the travel lane of V2. The critical reason for the critical precrash event was attributed to V1 as panic / freezing. \n\nThe driver of V1 told the researcher that this was her first time driving any vehicle. The occupant was teaching her how to drive. The driver was interviewed some time after the crash, and she stated that she had just re-started the engine after it had stalled, and when she made the turn the steering wheel wouldn\'t turn, she went on to state that she applied the brakes and skid into V2.\n\nThe researcher spoke with the passenger of V1 briefly on scene. She said the driver told her that she didn\'t know what happened. The police officer on scene told the researcher that the driver told him that she panicked and confused the accelerator with the brake pedal. Given the lack of physical evidence and the configuration of the scene, the researcher coded the critical reason based on the driver\'s statement to the police officer.\n\nAn interview was not obtained for the driver of V2.\n\n\n

This crash occurred in the early afternoon of a weekday at the intersection of a divided five-lane roadway and a highway off-ramp.  The bituminous off-ramp was dry and straight with an uphill grade greater than 2%.  The road also had a speed limit of 56kmph (35mph).  The five-lane roadway was divided into three eastbound lanes and two westbound lanes.  The roadway was dry and straight with a downhill grade greater than 2%.  The speed limit for this roadway was 40kmph (25mph).  It was daylight and cloudy at the time of the crash. \n\nV1, a 2004 Chevrolet Colorado Pick-up, was northbound in lane two of the highway off-ramp approaching the intersection, intending to turn left.  V2, a 2004 Jeep Liberty, was eastbound in lane one of the roadway approaching the same intersection.  As V1 proceeded into the intersection with the green light its front end struck the right side of V2.  Both vehicles came to final rest in the center of the intersection.\n\nV1 was driven by a 37 year-old male in good health who was wearing lenses that corrected an unknown condition.  He stated that as he approached the intersection the light turned green and he proceeded into the intersection, intending to turn left.  That was when he struck V2.  The driver was transported to a treatment facility with minor injuries and his vehicle was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no associated factors and V1 was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nV2 was driven by a 23 year-old female in good health and on her way to do some shopping.  She stated that the crash was her fault, as she ran the red light but would not give a reason why.  She was transported to a treatment facility with minor injuries and her vehicle was towed due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a decision error, an illegal maneuver by the driver of V2 (running the red light).  The associated factors for V2 include inadequate surveillance as the driver failed to look either side ahead, as well as an illegal maneuver, failure to stop for a TCD.

V2 was a 2004 Chevrolet S10 pickup with one occupant. \n\nV1 was traveling west in the westbound lane. V2 was traveling east in the eastbound lane. V2 was a 2004 Ford Expedition that was traveling northbound on the divided highway in lane three. V2 was driven by a 47-year old man. V1 was driven by a 20-year old female with an infant in the backseat. \n\nThe front of V2 hit the left side of V1 as it was attempting to make the left turn onto the northbound roadway. V1 then spun out of control and hit a utility pole on the right corner of the intersection. Both the driver of V1 and the infant passenger were airlifted to a trauma center. The weather conditions were normal on a regular sunny day.\n\nV1, a 1988 Pontiac Fiero, was traveling northbound on the roadway and pulled into a turning lane to head west onto a residential area. V2, a 1992 Ford Ranger, was traveling southbound in the opposite direction at a constant rate of speed. V1 was driven by a 19-year old male who turned left at the intersection. V2 was driven by a 25-year old male whose vehicle struck V1 while it was turning. The front of V2 struck the right side of V1. V1 spun out of control at impact and skidded onto a small median on the west side of the intersection. V2\'s final rest was in lane 2 of the roadway facing north.\n\nOn arrival of the scene, both occupants had already been taken to the hospital for treatment. Upon speaking to the driver of V1, he stated that he didn\'t remember anything from the accident. The last thing he said he recalls is leaving home and then waking up in the hospital the later part of the evening of the accident. An attempt to talk to the driver of V2 was unsuccessful. The diagnosis was a closed head injury.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when he began to turn left at the intersection. No associated factors were coded.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from the opposite direction, over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. No associated factors could be coded due to the lack of an interview.\n

The weather conditions were sunny and dry.\n\nV1, a 2004 Grand Marquis was traveling northbound turning left against the light at the intersection from lane number 2 (which is not a turning lane). V2, a 2004 Mitsubishi Galant, was traveling southbound on the highway going straight when its front struck V1\'s right side. V1 then struck V3, a 1995 Honda Accord, which was stopped at the intersection going east.  V1 then continued along its path and struck V4 (1997 Toyota Camry), which was also stopped at the intersection going east where V1 came to rest. The door of V1 had to be cut by EMS to remove the driver.  V1 and 2 were both towed due to damage.  V3 and V4 were both able to be driven away.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 23-year-old male. The passenger fled the scene. The driver of V1 stated he was making a left turn at the intersection when V2 hit him on his right side.  The driver of V1 was transported with non-incapacitating injuries.\n \nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was "this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection." Associated factors include conversation with the passenger and inadequate surveillance.\n\nThe driver of V2, a 22-year-old male, stated that V1 turned against the light when he had the right of way, causing him to strike him. One associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was conversation with a passenger.\n\nV3 was driven by a 35-year-old female. No Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to V3, as it was not involved in the first harmful event. No associated factors were coded to the driver of V3.\n\n

This incident occurred on a two-lane undivided winding roadway that had no traffic control devices. The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours while it was raining out. The posted speed limit was 48 kmph (30 mph).\n\nV1 was a 1993 Ford Explorer driven by a 24-year old female. Upon arrival, the driver of the vehicle was waiting in another car with a friend that had been traveling behind her. The driver and her friend told police that she wasn\'t speeding and that she just lost control of the car for no reason. She stated that the car started to slide and she lost control. She was uninjured. Police on the scene stated that accidents on this stretch of roadway were plentiful and one officer stated that there was mud on the roadway that comes from a house that is being worked on about 50 yards from where the accident occurred. Numerous attempts to get in contact with the driver were unsuccessful. She was issued a citation and released.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason was a decision error - too fast for curve/turn. In addition to excess speed, associated factors coded to the driver of V1 were the weather (rain) and the wet roadway.\n

V1 drove down the dead-end street, made a U-turn at the end, and then drove back down the street where it made a right turn onto its initial roadway and then fled the scene. \n\nV2 was towed due to damage. The non-contact vehicle that had cut him off didn\'t stop.\n\nV1 was driven by a 25 year-old male who upon arriving on the scene was removing personal belongings from the vehicle. The only associated factor for this crash was traveling too fast for conditions, as the driver did not realize that caution was required.

It had been raining on and off during the day making the roadway wet.  There was also construction work occurring on the roadside, which tracked mud onto the roadway.\n\nAs V1, a 1998 Chevy Blazer, attempted to negotiate the curves of the road but the driver lost control, causing V1 to begin a clockwise spin and depart the roadway.  V1 rode up the embankment and began to rollover.  As V1 rolled over it struck a fire hydrant with it left side and finally came to final rest on the roadside on its top.\n\nV1 was driven by an 18 year-old male in good health and on his way to his friend\'s house.  He stated he was traveling at 40kmph (25mph) when the car started to swerve and he attempted to regain control by braking and steering to the left and to the right, but this only caused the vehicle to skid even more and eventually roll over.  The driver was transported to a treatment facility with non-incapacitating injuries.  V1 was towed due to damage.    \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as a control loss due to traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for Critical Precrash Event was traveling too fast for the curve.  There were several associated factors coded this vehicle as the driver was traveling too fast for conditions, not realizing that caution was required.  As the driver had poor directional control of his vehicle due not only to unfamiliarity with the roadway (it was his first time driving it) but also the fact that he had his driver\'s license for only three months prior to the crash.  There were also roadway and weather factors involved as it was raining which caused the road to be wet.\n\n\n

This crash occurred on a northbound, dry, level, straight, two-lane roadway near a shopping plaza.  There was a heavy overcast but no adverse weather conditions.  The shopping season had started that weekend and there was more traffic than usual.  V1, a 2003 Chevy Impala, was northbound in lane 1 on his way to a hardware store. He was going straight when the vehicle in front of him stopped and did not move causing him to stop.  He stated that the driver signaled him to go around.  He then changed lanes into lane two in order to pass the stopped vehicle.  He proceeded but did not notice V2, a 2004 Nissan Xtera, stopped in lane two at the intersection because of a stop sign. V1 front struck V2 in the rear before ending up on the embankment.\n\nV1 was driven by a 79 year-old male who claimed he was in good health despite a history of high blood pressure and asthma for which he took unknown medications.  The driver of V1 stated that he usually walks to that shopping plaza but since there was a lot more traffic, he chose drive rather than walk.  The occupant of V1 was taken to the hospital with a possible injury and V1 was towed from the scene.\n\n The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason was coded as a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  Associated factors for this crash include a misjudgment of the other vehicle\'s velocity as well as an experience factor since the driver only rarely drove this road. \n\n V2 was driven by a 43 year-old female in good health, was rested and running an errand.  She was stopped behind several other cars that were stopped at a stop sign.  She was uninjured and V2 was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other motor vehicle in lane traveling at higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle and the driver was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005009276724.json
preprocessing
\nThis crash happened on a 6 lane highway with two left turn lanes.  No information has been obtained from this crash.  When the reasercher arrived on the scene, one vehicle was loaded onto the tow truck and the second vehicle was in the process of being loaded onto the truck.  Search for a PAR has turned up unsuccessful.  Both vehicles seemed to be towed due to damage and no occupants were on scene.  By the time the reseacher had parked and walked back up into the intersection, the officer and the tow truck had pulled away.

This incident occurred on a two-way four-lane highway. The roadway was wet and the weather conditions were raining at the time of this crash. The speed limit for this portion of roadway is 89 kmph. The crash occurred in the late part of the afternoon on Christmas Day.\n\nV1, unknown year Ford Taurus driven by a female, lost control due to: traveling to fast for conditions. The vehicle was towed due to disabling damage. No PAR has been generated for this incident thus far. V1 was traveling in Lane 3 and hit the barrier on the left side of the road.\n\nThe pre-crash event for this vehicle is: This vehicle Control loss due to: Traveling to fast for conditions\nThe critical reason is: Too fast for conditions - Rain\n
../resources/summary/2005009276785.json
preprocessing
Case # 2005-09-048\n\n\nThis incident occurred on the northbound lane of a two-lane roadway. The roadway has a posted speed limit of 35 mph.  Conditions were dark and it was very cold. The crash occurred in the late part of the afternoon.\n\nV1 was a 2003 Ford Focus that was traveling southbound on the roadway behind Vehicle number 2. V2 was a 1997 Ford LTD 9000 driven by a 50-year-old male.  Driver of V1 stated that V2 was coming from the opposite direction and was making a wide left turn onto a dirt roadway. The driver of V1 may have assumed V2 was making a left turn and would yield so she continued. V2 turned left and as a result, V1 was struck in the left side by the right rear tire of V2. From the angle of V2\'s and V1\'s rest, it would be impossible for V2 to have been coming from the opposite direction and make a left turn and hit V1 from that angle. \n\nV1 and V2 were traveling on the same side of the road going in the same direction. V2 was making a wide right turn onto a roadway and V1 attempted to go around and pass V2. As a result, the left side of V1 struck the right rear tire of V2.\n\nThe driver of V1 was transported to the hospital for injuries. \n\nThe critical pre-crash event for V1 is: Other motor vehicle in lane: Traveling in same direction while decelerating. The critical reason for critical precrash event is: Aggressive driving behavior.\nThe critical precrash for V2 is: Other motor vehicle in lane: Traveling in same direction with higher speed. Critical reason for precrash event is not coded for this vehicle.\n\nThe CDC for V1 is 07LFEW2. The CDC for V2 is 12RWWU1.\n\n

preprocessing
This crash took place in the southbound lanes of a four lane divided roadway with a grass median.  There were two southbound lanes and two turn lanes, the left turn lane beginning 85 meters back from a traffic signal-controlled intersection.  Conditions were daylight and dry with overcast skies in the early afternoon on a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 80 kpmh (50 mph).  \n\nV2, a 1993 Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera, was stopped for the traffic control signal in lane two behind a late model SUV.  V1, a 1997 Dodge Ram Van was traveling south in lane 2 alongside another vehicle in the adjacent lane 1, both approaching the intersection.  V1 was distracted by the driver of the vehicle in lane 1 and was not able to stop before making contact to the rear of V2.  \n\nV1 was driven by a 53 year-old male who was not injured.  The driver refused to be interviewed.  The policeman at the scene stated that the driver of V1 was distracted by the driver of the vehicle in lane one and was tracking her via the right front window.  V1\'s driver did not return his attention to V2 or the traffic ahead in time to stop.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 is the other motor vehicle in lane stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is recognition error, external distraction.\n\nV2 was driven by a 20 year-old male who was not injured.   He had stated that he had come to a complete stop behind the SUV, and was watching the cross traffic pass through the intersection for 3-4 seconds before being struck.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 is the other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction while decelerating.  There is no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.

This crash took place in the southbound lanes of a three lane divided roadway with a positive barrier.  There were two southbound lanes and two turn lanes, the left turn lanes beginning 23 meters back from a traffic signal-controlled intersection.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the late afternoon hours of a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 89 kmph (55 mph).\n\nV3, a 2002 Ford Escape and V2, a 2000 Mitsubishi Galant were both stopped for the traffic control signal in lane two respectively.  V1, a 2000 Buick Regal was traveling south in lane two approaching the intersection at a high rate of speed.  V1 was not able to stop before making contact to the rear of V2.  V2 then made contact to the rear of V3 before an additional contact with V1.\n\nV1 was driven by a 26 year-old male who was not injured.  The driver refused to be interviewed.  The Critical Precrash Event for V1 is the other vehicle in lane stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event is unknown.\n\nV2 was driven by a 39 year-old female who was transported with incapacitating injuries via helicopter.  This driver refused to be interviewed.  The Critical Precrash Event for V2 is the other motor vehicle in same lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  There is no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nV3 was driven by a 20 year-old male who was transported with possible injuries.  This driver also refused to be interviewed.  This vehicle was not involved in the first harmful event and was towed due to damage

This Crash took place at the intersection of two rural two-lane roadways.  Conditions were daylight and dry in the early evening of a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 48 kmph (30mph).  \n\n   V1, a 2001 Volkswagen Cabriolet, was traveling north approaching the intersection.  This vehicle attempted to turn left and struck the northwest curb while departing the roadway.  V1 continued off the roadway, made contact with its front plane to a tree, rotated counterclockwise making contact with two additional trees on its right plane, then came to rest.\n\n   V1 was driven by a 19-year old male who was transported with incapacitating injuries.  He stated that he had been following a friend to an unknown destination.  Both vehicles were traveling at a high rate of speed.  When the lead vehicle turned left at the intersection he attempted to do so also.  V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was this vehicle off the edge of the road on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was too fast for curve.

\nThis crash took place at an intersection of two roadways.  The east/west roadway was three lanes divided by a grass median; with a left turn lane beginning 25 meters from a signal-controlled intersection.  The north/south roadway was three laned undivided.  It had just began to rain in the early evening of a weekday.  Both roadways had posted speed limits of 48kmph(30mph)\n\nV1, a 1993 Toyota Camry, was traveling east in lane two approaching the intersection.  V2, a 1997 Honda Accord, was traveling north in lane two approaching the same intersection.  V1 and V2 made contact in the intersection.\n\nV1 was driven by a 40-year old male who was not injured.  The driver stated that he had returned his attention forward from the rearview mirror to notice the signal light change.  He attempted to stop but could not.  The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded inadequate surveillance.  \n\nV2 was driven by a 30-year old female who was not injured but there was a second occupant transported.  Both driver and occupant refused to be interviewed.  The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  There is no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.  \n\n

This crash took place at an intersection of two roadways.  The north/south roadway was three lanes divided by a raised median, with left turn lanes begining 20 meters back from a signal-controlled intersection.  Conditions were daylight and dry during heavy lunchtime traffic on a weekday.  The road had a posted speed limit of 56kmph (35mph).\n\nV2, a 2004 GMC Yukon, was traveling south in lane two approaching the intersection.  V1, a 2002 Chevrolet Tahoe was traveling north in the left turn lane preparing to turn left through the intersection.  V1 initiated its turn and made contact with V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 43-year old male  who was not transported.  \n\nThis Critical Pre-Crash Event was when this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event  was coded unknown decision error.\n\nV2 was driven by a 48-year old male and had two additional occupants who were all transported with minor injuries.  The driver of this vehicle stated that he saw V1 approaching the intersection and that when V1 initiated its turn, he attempted to steer right while braking, but could not stop in time.  This vehicle was towed due to damage .  \n\nThe Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  There is no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.\n\n\n

This crash took place on a two lane undivided roadway near a T-intersection.  Conditions were daylight and dry with clear skies shortly after noon on a weekend.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\n   V1, a 1997 Chevrolet 300 conversion van, was traveling east on the roadway.  V2, a 1999 Infinity QX sport utility vehicle, was traveling west on the same roadway.  The vehicle traveling directly in front of V1 slowed quickly and to avoid making contact, the driver of V1 steered left, made a lane departure to the left, and this vehicle\'s right front made contact to the front right of V2.  The critical pre-crash event for V1 was when it traveled over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was coded as an incorrect evasive action. One associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was inattention. He reported that he had been thinking about some concerns immediately before the crash. V1 was driven by a 60 year-old male who was not injured.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  The critical pre-crash event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into her lane from the opposite direction-over the left lane line. The critical reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and no associated factors were coded to her. V2 was driven by a 42 year-old female who was not injured.  V2 was also towed due to damage.

The roadway had a posted speed limit of 35mph (56kmph ).\n\nV1, was traveling north, approaching a driveway enterance.  V2, was traveling north behind V1.  V1  attempted to turn right into the driveway when the front plane of V2 came into the rear plane of V1.\n\n\n Upon arrival to the crash scene this researcher was  not allowed access to gather any information.  This researcher was going to attempt to gather the information (follow up) after recieving a copy of the PAR.  To this date there has been negative results in obtaining this PAR. \n\n\n*  This researcher was refused inspection to both V1 and V2, by both drivers.

This crash took place on a two lane, two way roadway at a driveway enterance.  Conditions were dry, just after noon on a weekday and the bituminous roadway had a posted speed limit of 35mph (56kmph).\n\nV1, a 1990 Volvo 240, was traveling east and climbing a slope approaching the driveway.  V2, a 2000 Volkswagen Jetta, was heading west stopped waiting to turn left.  V2 initiated a left turn attempting to enter the driveway and V1\'s front plane came into contact with V2\'s right plane.  V1 continued in it\'s original travel lane before coming to rest.  V2 was rotated clockwise and came to rest on the south side of the roadway.\n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event for V1 was coded Other Vehicle Encroachment, from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event for V2 was coded This Vehicle Traveling, turning left at intersection.  This vehicle\'s critical reason was also coded unkown decision error.\n\n

The roadway had a posted speed limit of 64kmph (40mph).\n\nV1, a 2001 Honda Civic, was traveling north negotiating a set of curves.  V1 departed the roadway to the right, re entered the roadway, entered the oncoming lane, departed the roadway to the left and contacted a tree before coming to rest.\n\nV1 was driven by a 20 year-old male and had a 20 year-old male occupant who were both transported via medivac with incapacitating injuries.  Both driver and occupant refused to be interviewed.  The vehicle was towed due to damages.\n\nThe Critical Pre Crash Event for this vehicle was coded off the edge of the roadway to the right side. ../resources/summary/2005009501501.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a three-lane, undivided roadway.  There was one southbound lane and two northbound lanes; however, the two northbound lanes merged into a single lane close to the point of impact.  Approximately twenty meters north of the impact, there was a road crew repairing the bituminous roadway.  The crew was laying a narrow strip of asphalt, and was reducing both north and southbound traffic to a single lane by means of a handheld stop sign.  This crash took place during early afternoon hours on a weekday and there were no adverse weather conditions.\n\nV2, a 1972 Ford F600 heavy straight truck, was traveling north in lane two behind an unknown non-contact vehicle.   V1, a 1989 Honda Accord, was also traveling north in lane two.  As V2 approached the roadway workers, northbound traffic was signaled to stop to allow southbound traffic to pass.  V2 came to a complete stop, but V1\'s front plane struck the rear plane of V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 60-year old female who was not injured.  This driver refused an interview.  V1 was towed due to damage.  The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded other vehicle stopped in lane. The Critical Reason for the Pre-crash Event was coded as an unknown driver error due to a lack of interview. A traffic flow interruption was coded as an associated factor because of the construction work on the roadway up ahead.\n\nV2 was driven by a 64-year old male who was not injured.  The driver stated that he was driving at a safe distance behind the non-contact vehicle and came to a slow controlled stop for the road crew.  He stated that he almost did not even know that contact was made to his vehicle.  V2 was not towed due to damage.  V2\'s Critical Pre-crash event was coded other vehicle traveling in same direction with higher speed.  A Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver include inattention, a focus on the work crew up ahead, use of a heartburn medication, and a traffic flow interruption due to the road construction ahead.\n\n

\nThis crash occured in the mid morning hours of weekday, at the offset intersection of two roadways.  The north/south roadway was three lanes divided by a grass median and was not controlled by any traffic control devices.   The east/west roadway was two lanes, two way undivided and controlled by a posted stop sign.  Conditions were clear and the posted speed limit was 64kmph (40mph).\n\nV2, a 1998 Ford E250 Van, was traveling west in lane three approaching the intersection.  V1, a 2005 Toyota Corolla, was stopped for the posted stop sign facing south.  V1 entered the intersection and its left plane came into contact with the front plane of V2.  V2 was deflected approximently 10 degees counter clockwise and came to rest near the median.  V1 was deflected  approximently 30 degrees clockwise and came to rest on the median after hitting the sign.\n\nV1 was driven by a 20 year-old female who stated that she was still upset from an earlier argument with her boyfriend.  She was in the process of droping her daughter off at a babysitters so that she could take her boyfriend to get some job applications.  This driver nor either of the two occupants were injured and the vehicle was towed due to damage.  \n\nThis vehicle\'s Critical Pre Crash Event was coded This Vehicle Traveling crossing over passing through intersection.  The Critical Reason was coded Driver Related, Inadequate Surveillance.\n\nV2 was driven by a 53 year-old male who stated that he saw the other vehicle but did not think it would pull out into the intersection.  He was not injured, and V2 was not towed due to damage.  \n\nThis vehicle\'s Critical Pre Crash Event was coded Other Vehicle in Lane in Crossover.  A Critical Reason was not coded to this Vehicle.\n\n

\n\n  This crash occured at the intersection of two roaways.  The first roadway was an undivided S curve, with two northbound lanes and two southbound lanes.  The second roadway intersected the west edge of the S curve forming a T intersection.  This was a two lane two way undivided roadway.  The bitimous road surfaces were wet and there was a light rain during the morning hours of a weekday.\n\n   V1, a 2000 Dodge Durango, was traveling south in lane one negotiating a curve right and approaching the intersection.  V2, a 2003 Toyota Corolla, was traveling north negotiating a curve left approaching the same intersection.  V2 attempted to turn left at the intersection and both vehicles front planes came into contact.  V2, was rotated approximentely 10 degrees counter clockwise before coming to rest close to impact.  V1 rotated clockwise and made contact to a light pole with its front plane before coming to rest.\n\nV1 was driven by a 35 year-old male, who stated that he was negotiating the curve and approaching the intersection when the other vehicle turned left in front of him.  The critical pre crash event for this vehicle was coded Other Vehicle Encroachment, but the Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nV2 was driven by a 28 year-old female who stated that she had gone off her intended route and was looking for a cross street to change direction.  She saw the opportunity to turn and thought htat she could get across V1\'s path in time.  This vehicles critical pre crash event was coded This Vehicle Traveling (turning left at intersection).  The critical reason was coded a Decision Error, Misjudgement of Gap or Other\'s Speed.

preprocessing
This crash took place in the eastbound lanes of a three lane divided roadway.  Conditions were dark with streetlamps on, just prior to dawn on a weekday.  The roadway was bituminous, dry, and level. The posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 mph).\n\nV2 was traveling east in lane three.  V1 was exiting a commercial parking lot adjacent to the roadway, turning right.  V1 entered the roadway into eastbound lane one, then immediately entered lane two, and while attempting to enter lane three, was struck on the left side by the right front of V2.  V1 was rotated clockwise approximately 40 degrees before coming to rest partially in lane two.  V2 continued to travel in lane three for approximately 22 meters before coming to rest.\n\nV1, a 1987 Dodge Colt, was driven by a 46-year old female who stated that she did not see the other vehicle until it was too late, and that the other vehicle did not have its headlights on.  The driver of V1 was transported with minor injuries.  V1 was towed due to damage. The Critical Pre-crash event for this vehicle was this vehicle traveling over the lane line on left side of travel lane.  The Critical Reason was coded as inadequate surveillance. Associated factors coded to this driver include fatigue and inattention - the driver admitted that she had been thinking about some concerns prior to the crash.\n\nV2, a 1998 Ford Contour, was driven by a 25-year old female who stated that she saw the other vehicle but didn\'t know what it was going to do.  When she saw that V1 was changing lanes into her lane, she attempted to avoid the crash by braking.  V2\'s driver was not injured and this vehicle was towed due to damage.  The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction) over right lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. Fatigue was coded as an associated factor for this driver because the driver stated that she felt tired at the start of her trip.\n\n

\n\nThis crash occurred in the eastbound lane, of a two way undivided roadway, at the intersection with another two lane two way roadway.  The north south roadway had a posted stop sign, however, the east west roadway had no traffic control device.  Conditions were daylight and dry with no adverse conditions in the morning hours of a weekday.\n\nV2, a 1996 Honda Accord, was traveling east negotiating a curve left and approaching the intersection.  V1, a 1986 Ford F-150, was also traveling east and negotiating a curve left approaching the same intersection.  V2 intended to turn left at the intersection and was stopped waiting on oncoming traffic.  V1\'s front plane came into contact with the rear plane of V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 44 year-old male who stated that while en route to a worksite his co worker was telling him a joke.  The co worker was using hand movements to tell the joke distracting the driver\'s attention.  The driver stated that he returned his attention to the road ahead just before impact.  The Critical Pre Crash Event for this vehicle was coded  Other Vehicle in Lane (stopped) and the Critical Reason was coded a Driver Related factor, Internal Distraction.\n\nV2 was driven by a 43 year-old male who was taking his children to a relative\'s before heading to work.  The driver stated that he was stopped waiting on oncoming traffic to pass before intending to turn left.  The Critical Pre Crash Event for this vehicle was coded Other Vehicle in Lane (Traveling in same direction with higher speed).  A Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.

preprocessing
\n\nThis crash took place in the westbound lanes of a five lane divided roadway during the daylight hours of a weekday.  The straight and level roadway had a posted speed limit of 55mph (89kmph).\n\nV1, a 1992 Honda Civic was traveling west in lane three.  The driver of V1 attempted to change lanes to the right, but in the process realized that there was another vehicle already traveling in that lane.  The driver of V1 then attempted to re enter the original travel lane, but over compensated.  V1 departed two lanes to the left, departed the roadway to the left, and made contact to the raised divider with its front plane.  V1 re entered the roadway, rotated clockwise, and rolled two quarter turns coming to rest on its top plane in lane three.\n\nV1 was driven by a 32 year-old female who was transported with non incapacitating injuries.  She stated that she had looked in her right side mirror prior to begining her lane change right, and thought she had room to move over.  As she was half way into lane 4 she heard a horn blow and saw another vehicle overtaking her from the rear.  The driver stated that she cut her wheel left attempting to return to her original travel lane but lost control.\n\nThe Critixcal Pre Crash Event for this vehicle was coded This Vehicle Traveling ( off the edge of the road on the left side).  The Critical Reason was coded Overcompensation.

\nThis crash took place in the early afternoon of a weekday on a three lane undivided roadway.  The roadway had two northbound lanes and a single southbound lane.  Conditions were daylight and dry and the road was bitimous with a posted speed limit of 45mph (72kmph).\n\nV2, a 1998 Oldsmobile Intrigue, was traveling south negotiating a curve left and approaching a parking lot entrance on its left hand side.  V1, a 1996 Oldsmobile Ciera, was also traveling south on this same route.  V2 approached the driveway entrance, stopped and was awaiting a break in oncoming traffic to initiate a left turn into the driveway.  V1\'s front plane came into contact with the back plane of V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 75 year-old female who stated that she did not travel this roadway often, but was en route to the grocery store.  She also stated that she never saw V2 until contact was made.  This driver was transported with possible injuries and the vehicle was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event was coded Other Motor Vehicle in lane (stopped) and the Critical Reason was coded Inadequate Surveillance.\n\nV2 was driven by a 24 year-old female who stated that she was on her lunch break from work and en route to pick up a carry out order.  She stated that she had come to a complete stop and was waiting to turn when V1 struck her from behind.  This driver was not injured and this vehicle was not towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event for this vehicle was coded Other Motor Vehicle in lane (same direction, higher speed).\n\n

preprocessing
\n\nThis crash took place during the early afternoon of a holiday on a four lane divided roadway.  There were two eastbound lanes and two westbound lanes divided by a median.  Conditions were daylight and dry and the roadway had a posted speed limit of 30mph (48kmph).\n\nV1, a 1992 Honda Accord, was traveling west in lane one negotiating a curve right.  Just after passing the apex of the curve this vehicle lost control and departed the roadway to the right.  V1 struck the curb, then struck an overhead light pole before re entering the roadway and coming to rest in its original travel lane.\n\nV1 was driven by a 17 year-old male who stated that his mother had left the house and left her keys to the car at home.  He took the car without her permission and was going to his friends house.  The driver stated that as well as being fun, he was driving too fast to get back home before his mother.  Just prior to the crash the driver was on his hand held cell phone telling his friend that he was almost there.  This driver was operating the vehicle with a drivers permit which had a restriction demanding proper supervision.\n\nThe critical pre crash event was coded This Vehicle Traveling (off the roadway to the right) and the critical reason was coded Poor Directional Control.
../resources/summary/2005009501684.json
preprocessing
This crash took place in the southbound lanes of a four lane undivided roadway.  There were no adverse conditions and the bituminous roadway had a posted speed limit of 30mph (48kmph).\n\nV1, a 2001 Ford Ranger, was traveling south in lane two behind a slower moving NC vehicle.  V2, a 1992 Buick LeSabre, was traveling south in lane one.  V1 attempted to change lanes to the right in order to go around the NC vehicle and was struck in the rear plane by the front plane of V2.  V1 then crossed oncoming traffic and departed the roadway to the left before coming to rest in the grass.  V2 came to rest a short distance from the point of contact on the right shoulder.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 62 year-old male who stated that the vehicle he was following was being driven under the posted speed limit.  He was attempting to pass this vehicle and was sure that the driver of V2 saw him and understood his intentions.  The critical pre crash event for this vehicle was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle traveling - over lane line on right side of travel lane\xe2\x80\x9d.  The critical reason was coded as a decision error - \xe2\x80\x9cAggressive Driving Behavior\xe2\x80\x9d.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 26 year-old male who stated that the driver of V1 cut right in front of him and that although he applied his brakes he could not avoid the collision.  The critical pre crash event for this vehicle was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cOther vehicle encroachment - from adjacent lane (same direction) over left lane line\xe2\x80\x9d.  A critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n

preprocessing
\nThis crash took place on a wet, bituminous, two-lane, undivided roadway just after noon on a weekday.  The roadway had a posted speed limit of 40kmph (25mph).  V1, a 2000 Chevrolet 1500 pick up, was traveling south in lane one.  Just ahead of him V2 a 2005 Chrysler Town and Country, also traveling south began to decelerate as it approached a signal-controlled intersection.  V1 did not decelerate and struck V2 in the back plane before both vehicles came to final rest in the roadway.\n\nV1 was driven by an 18 year-old male in good health, who was traveling back to his place of work from his lunch break.  He stated that just prior to contact, he was reaching and looking down inside the vehicle to recover a soft drink from the center console area.  When he returned his attention to V2 it was too late.  He was uninjured and V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded other vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction while decelerating.  The Critical Reason was coded as a recognition error, internal distraction as the driver was reaching for his drink.  An associated factor included inadequate surveillance as the driver took his eyes off the road and failed to look far enough ahead. \n\nV2 was driven by a 41 year-old female who claimed to be in fair health and suffering from a headache for which she had taken medication for) at the time of the crash.  She was en route to her husbands\' place of work with her 3 year-old daughter.  She stated that there were approximately three to four non-contact vehicles between her and the intersection and she began to slow down when they did.  Neither occupant was injured and V2 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded as other vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed.  No critical reason was coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors include her inattention as she was conversing with daughter at the time of the crash.\n

This crash took place during the early afternoon of a weekday at an intersection of two roads and a driveway controlled by a traffic signal.  The bituminous, dry north/south roadway was two-way, undivided and had four lanes with a posted speed of 56kmph (35 mph).  The west roadway was two-way undivided with three lanes.  \n\nV1, a 2005 Dodge Caravan, was stopped for the red signal preparing to turn right from the driveway exit.  V2, a 2000 Ford Expedition, was traveling north in lane two, approaching the intersection while negotiating a slight curve left.  V3, a 2000 Saturn SL2, was traveling south in lane two approaching the same intersection.  V4, a 1997 GMC C-series truck, was traveling south in lane one.   As V1 turned right on the red signal and attempted to enter lane two it was struck by V2.  V2 rotated approximately 30 degrees counterclockwise, crossing the centerline contacting V3.  V3 was than pushed into lane one where it was struck in the back plane by V4.\n\nV1 was driven by a 59 year-old female who claimed to be in fair health and was wearing her glasses that corrected a hyperopic (far-sighted) condition.  She stated that she was conversing with an occupant about recent financial problems just prior to initiating the turn right.  She also stated that she saw V2 but thought that she had time to pull out and complete the turn.  Both occupants suffered possible injuries and were transported for treatment.  V1 was towed from the scene.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as this vehicle traveling, turning right at intersection.  The Critical Reason was coded as a decision error: misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.  Associated factors include driver inattention as she was conversing with the passenger in her vehicle as well as the financial problem on her mind.\n\nV2 was driven by a 44 year-old male in good health but fatigued as he was heading home.  He stated that he was driving a little fast but saw V1 and did not think that the vehicle would attempt the turn until he passed.  His vehicle collided with V1 as he traveled through the intersection.  The driver was uninjured but V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other vehicle encroachment (from driveway, turning into the same direction).  A critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors for this crash were the driver\'s fatigue as well as traveling too fast for conditions as the driver stated he was in a hurry to just get home.\n\nV3 was driven by a 22 year-old female who sustained fatal injuries on scene.  The Critical Precrash Event was coded as other (not involved in first harmful event) and a critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nV4 was driven by a 43 year-old male who refused to be interviewed.  This vehicle was not involved in first harmful event and not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n \n\n\n\n

\n\nThis crash took place at the intersection of a two way, three lane undivided roadway and a parking lot exit.  Conditions were daylight and dry shortly after noon on a holiday weekend.  The bituminous roadway had a posted speed limit of 35mph (56kmph).  V1, a 1993 Mazda Prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9, was leaving a parked position and stopped at the driveway exit waiting to make a left turn into southbound traffic.  V2, a 1991 Honda Accord Wagon, was traveling north in lane two approaching the parking lot exit.  A NCV was also traveling north in lane one, approaching the parking lot entrance preparing to turn into it.  The NCV initiated its turn at roughly the same as V1 attempted to enter the trafficway partially obscuring each vehicle\'s view of one another.  As V1 traveled across lane two it was stuck by the front lane of V2.\n\nV1 was driven by a 38 year-old female who stated that she was in an argument with her occupant that began as they entered the parked vehicle.  She further stated that as she initiated her left turn, she saw the NCV but she did not see V2.  She was transported with minor injuries and the vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as this vehicle turning, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason was coded a recognition error, internal distraction as she was fighting with her husband at the time of the crash.  An associated factor is a sightline restriction as the turning NCV partially blocked V1 view of oncoming traffic. \n\nV2 was driven by a 28 year-old male who was unable to be located for an interview.  V2\'s driver was not injured and drove away from the scene.  This vehicle was not located for inspection.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded as other vehicle encroachment, from driveway- turning in opposite direction.  A critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.  A possible associated factor for this vehicle was the sightline restriction caused by the NCV.  \n\n
