V1, a 2003 Jeep Liberty compact SUV, was traveling northbound in lane 1 of a 2-way, 2 lane, straight, bituminous roadway.  At the time of the crash the roadway was dry, it was dark and there were no adverse weather conditions.  A non-contact vehicle, headed northbound also, was stopped in the roadway waiting for traffic to clear so it could turn left at an uncontrolled intersection.  V1 braked and steered right in an effort to avoid striking the NC vehicle in the rear.  V1 exited the roadway to the right, entered the ditch where it struck a metal post with it\'s front.  V1 continued off- road striking a the edge of a driveway with it\'s front and ramping into the air.  V1, front, then struck a 4" by 4" sign post and landed with it\'s right side against some brush.\n\n  The female driver and the male passenger were uninjured.  Both occupants were restrained but no airbags deployed.  The driver possessed a valid driver\'s license, was familiar with the vehicle and the roadway. The driver was conversing with the passenger as she approached the stopped, turning vehicle.  She had turned her head away from the road to talk then looked back to see the vehicle stopped in front of her. Neither drugs nor alcohol were a factor in the crash.\n\n  The vehicle was towed due to damage.  V1 was found to have no mechanical defects which may have contributed to the crash.
../resources/summary/2005011268002.json
preprocessing
V2, a 2003 Pontiac Grand Am, was traveling northbound in the right lane on a fully controlled, divided highway. The grassy median sloped downward and had a center metal guardrail. The two-lane, straight, level, bituminous roadway was wet at the time of the daylight (mid-morning) crash.  A non-contact vehicle moved from lane two into the right lane in front of V2.  V2 swerved into lane two to avoid contact with this non-contact vehicle.  \n\nV1, a 2001 Buick Century, was traveling northbound in lane two of the same roadway, and had no time for avoidance maneuvers.  The left back of V2 struck the right front of V1. V2 spun counterclockwise and went off of the roadway on the left with the right side leading.  V2 rocked up onto the right side wheels and continued to rotate until the back of V2 contacted the guardrail.  The left front of V2 sustained damage from contact with the ditch.  V2 rotated to the left and came to rest facing northwest near the guardrail.\n\nV1 steered left at impact with V2 and lost control.  V1 steered right and rotated clockwise and went off of the road to the left.  V1 rotated back to the left and came to a stop facing north near the guardrail, past the final rest of V2. V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  V1 was towed from the ditch and to a tow facility, but was drivable.  No airbags deployed during the crash. Both drivers declined medical treatment. \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 51-year old female. The Critical Precrash Event for this driver was when another vehicle encroached into her lane from an adjacent lane (same direction) over the right lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash. She had taken no medications on the day of the crash and was wearing her prescription lenses that corrected both myopic and hyperopic conditions. \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 26-year old male. The Critical Precrash Event for this driver was when he traveled over the lane line on the left side of his travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance, a recognition factor. This was chosen because the driver reported that he was looking at the non-contact vehicle and in avoiding that vehicle, he changed lanes without looking over to his left. His focus on the non-contact vehicle was coded as an associated factor, as an "other" recognition factor.  There were no reported alcohol, drugs, sleep, emotional, health, environmental, or mechanical factors contributing to the crash.  Both drivers were familiar with their vehicles and with the roadway.
../resources/summary/2005011268022.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1995 Toyota Camry 4 door sedan, was westbound in lane 2 of a 6 lane undivided straight, level urban roadway (3 lanes eastbound, 3 lanes westbound). V1 was approaching a controlled 4-way intersection with a north/south roadway.  V2, a 1992 Honda Accord station wagon, was stopped in lane 3 of an undivided, 5-lane urban roadway (1 northbound, 4 southbound) facing south, at the same controlled intersection.  V3, a 2005 Ford Escape SUV, was stopped beside V2 in the second lane of travel, also facing south at the same intesection.  When the light turned green, V2 and V3 accelerated to proceed straight through the intersection.  V1 continued to proceed straight through the intersection on a red light.  V1\'s front contacted the left side of V2.  The force of this impact forced V2\'s right side into the left side of V3.  At the time of the daylight crash, there were no adverse weather conditions and the roads were dry. Vehicles 2 and 3 were towed due to damage.  V1 was driven from the scene.  None of the occupants in any of the three vehicles were injured.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded \xe2\x80\x9cOther vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.\xe2\x80\x9d The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle; however, several associated factors were coded to its driver. First, an illegal maneuver was coded (running a red light). A complete interview with the driver of V1, a 53-year old male, as well as an inspection of his vehicle was obtained at the scene.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  He was not late or in a hurry and speed did not seem to be a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or aggressive driving on his part but he was cited for running a red light. When questioned, the driver of V1 stated that he was not distracted by anything; however, he thought he had a green light as he entered the intersection. An associated factor coded to this driver was inadequate surveillance, because he failed to look before entering the intersection. The driver of V1 was taking a diabetes medication that had no known performance-impairing side effects. He was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition to a level of 20/10. The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that mechanical defects contributed to the causation of the crash. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was coded \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle traveling - crossing over (passing through) intersection.\xe2\x80\x9d The Critical Reason was coded as inadequate surveillance, because the driver of V2 failed to look to either side ahead before entering the intersection. A complete interview with the driver of V2, a 55-year old female, was obtained at the scene and the vehicle was later inspected.   The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle and was running a short errand at the time of the crash.  She was not late and not in a hurry and was properly licensed for her vehicle.  There were no indications of fatigue, aggressive driving or vehicle defects as contributing to the cause of the crash. She was wearing her prescription lenses (bifocals) that corrected both myopic and hyperopic conditions.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because she was not involved in the first harmful event (the impact between the front of V1 and the left side of V2).  The driver of V3, a 64-year old female, was not thought to have contributed to the crash. A complete interview with the driver of V3 and an inspection of that vehicle were obtained.  The properly licensed driver of V3 was familiar with both the roadway and vehicle.  She was taking three prescription medications - a blood pressure medication, a cholesterol-lowering medication, and an antihistamine. Only the antihistamine had any possible performance-impairing side effects (drowsiness). The driver of V3 was wearing her prescription lenses at the time of the crash, which correct a hyperopic (farsighted) condition to a level of 20/20. When the crash occurred, the driver of V3 was running errands and was not late or in a hurry. There were no indications of aggressive driving or fatigue on the part of the driver of V3.  The inspection of V3 revealed no indications that its mechanical condition contributed to the causation of the crash.  \n\n  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268042.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1995 Ford F250 pick-up truck pulling a horse trailer, was traveling eastbound on an undivided two-lane straight and level roadway.  V2, a 2002 Pontiac Grand Prix, was traveling on the same road in front of V1.  At the time of the crash it was clear and dry in the early afternoon hours. The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph). The driver of V2, a 54-year old female, began to slow in response to backed-up traffic ahead of her that was waiting to turn left onto an intersecting street.  The driver of V1, a 35-year old male, was traveling approximately 19 feet behind V2, and was looking out of his right side window at a store.  When the driver of V1 looked forward again at the road ahead, V2 was almost stopped in front of him.  The driver of V1 attempted to brake and steer to the right, but stated that the vehicle did not seem to respond.  The front of V1 struck the back of V2, overriding the rear bumper.  The trailer towed by V1 was fully loaded with 112 bags of pine shavings that did not shift during the crash.  The total weight of the cargo was 2,000 lbs.  V1 and V2 both came to a stop on the shoulder of the road facing east.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was in his lane in front of him traveling in the same direction while decelerating.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was an external distraction (looking at a store) that was coded to this vehicle. An associated factor coded to this driver was inadequate surveillance, in that he failed to look far enough ahead prior to the crash. If he had done so, he would have noticed that traffic ahead of V2 was in the process of slowing. Also, traffic was heavy at the time of the crash, and he should have expected slow-downs. Another associated factor coded to V1 was that the driver of V1 had helped to load the cargo, but had failed to utilize the available brakes on the trailer. The driver of V1 was familiar with the roadway and his vehicle, and was wearing his prescription lenses at the time of the crash, which corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition to a level of 20/20.  He was not fatigued and was taking no medications. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when another motor vehicle was in the same lane behind V2, traveling at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  The driver of V2 was being treated for hypertension and irregular heartbeat and was taking a medication with no known performance-impairing side effects. She was wearing glasses at the time of the crash that corrected an unknown condition. An associated factor coded to both drivers was the traffic congestion on the roadway that caused traffic ahead of V1 to slow down.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268043.json
preprocessing
V1, 1999 Ford Contour 4dr, was traveling west on a 3-lane interstate divided by a concrete median barrier (6 lanes total) in the third lane of travel. The bituminous roadway curved to the right, and at the time of the crash, was ice-covered.  The crash occurred in the predawn hours of the morning and the roadway was not illuminated. V2, 2000 Ford Ranger pickup truck, was merging westbound onto the same roadway in lane 1.  The driver of V2, a 51-year old female, lost control and began to rotate clockwise and then counterclockwise as she crossed the left lane line into lane 2.  The driver of V1, a 20-year old female, saw V2 begin to lose control and began braking in response. As she braked, she too lost control. V1 rotated clockwise over the right lane line into lane 2.  The left side of V1 was struck by the front left of V2 while both were spinning on the ice in lane 2. V1 was towed due to damage.  The bumper of V2 was pulled away from the front left tire and V2 was driven from the scene.  Neither driver was injured. Complete interviews and inspections were obtained for both vehicles.  \n\n  The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to poor road conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users," a decision error. The icy condition of the roadway was coded as an associated factor. Even though V2 lost control first and the driver of V1 was simply reacting to V2 when she lost control, it was thought that had V1 maintained control of her vehicle she would not have entered the second lane of travel and the crash might not have occurred. In other words, had V1 been traveling at a slower speed, she might not have lost control when she braked and would have remained in her own lane (lane 3). Instead, V1 skidded into lane 2 where it was struck by V2. The driver of V1 had been traveling on this roadway for some time and was familiar with both her vehicle and the roadway. She knew that the roadway was ice-covered. Even though she claimed to be traveling at a speed well below the posted limit, it is likely that this was still too fast for the roadway, given its condition at the time. Possible under inflation of V1\'s tires were found during the inspection, otherwise, no other mechanical defects were detected.  The driver was properly licensed for the vehicle and was not in a hurry and no drug or alcohol involvement was evident. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. No citations were issued to either driver.\n \n  The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was also when she lost control of her vehicle due to poor road conditions. Although the Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2, she was believed to have contributed to the crash. It was believed that V2 was also traveling too fast for conditions. While she may not have been aware of the condition of the interstate because she was just entering it from the ramp when she lost control, she was still traveling too fast. It had snowed earlier in the day and some of that snow remained on the roads, packed down and now ice-covered. As with V1, the condition of the roadway was coded as an associated factor. There appeared to be no fatigue or emotional factors on the part of the driver of V2.  The driver was both properly licensed for and familiar with the vehicle and the roadway.  She reported that she was not in a hurry. She stated that she had prescription glasses to correct a hyperopic (farsighted) condition but was not wearing them at the time of the crash. She reported that she was taking no medications. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. No citations were issued to either driver.\n\n   It should be noted that over 20 vehicles lost control on this same stretch of roadway in a 1-hour period and it was difficult to see the ice, as it was in intermittent patches.
../resources/summary/2005011268062.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2004 Lexus ES330, was southbound on a two-lane undivided roadway (one lane each direction) slowing to look for a parking space.  V2, a 1998 Gillig Low Floor bus was traveling behind V1 on the same roadway in the same direction. It was the late hours of the evening and it was dark outside, but the straight, level, slush-covered roadway was illuminated by streetlamps. The driver of V1 noticed a parking space on the opposite side of the street and decided to make a U-turn in order to turn his vehicle around and park on the other side of the street. In preparation of making this U-turn, he pulled as far to the right side of the roadway as he could while decelerating. The driver of V2 saw V1 pull to the right and assumed that the driver of V1 would wait for the bus to pass before initiating the U-turn. As the bus began to pass V1 on the left, the driver of V1 initiated the U-turn. The front right corner of the bus impacted the left side of V1 in the opposing lane of traffic.  The driver of V2 had braked and steered left when he realized what V1 was doing, and struck a legally parked vehicle that was parked on the opposite side of the street with its front left.  V1 rotated back southbound and the left side of V1 came to rest against the right side of V2. V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  V2 was drivable after the crash. The left rear passenger of V1 was transported to the local trauma center; the driver and other two passengers of V1 denied any injuries.  The driver and 10 adult passengers of V2 denied injuries.  V1 was equipped with driver, right front and side curtain airbags, which did not deploy.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when this vehicle began traveling over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, a decision error. The driver of V1 was cited for making an illegal U-turn.  Several associated factors were coded to the driver of V1. First, he falsely assumed that the bus, which he knew was behind him, would stay behind him until he completed his U-turn. Second, before beginning his U-turn, he did not check his rear mirrors again to locate the bus (inadequate surveillance). Third, he was focusing on the parking space on the other side of the street (exterior distraction). Fourth, he was distracted by conversations with and among his passengers. At the time of the crash, the driver of V1 was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition. He was taking no medications, was not fatigued, and was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was also when it began traveling over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2; however, he was thought to have contributed to the crash. When the driver of V2 observed V1 decelerating and pulling over to the right, he correctly interpreted the actions of V1 as being in preparation of making a U-turn. However, he falsely assumed that the driver of V1 would wait until V2 passed V1 before initiating its turn. Further, the driver of V2 received a citation from the police for improper passing. Therefore, an illegal maneuver was coded as an associated factor, as well as a false assumption.   At the time of the crash, the driver of V2 was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition. He was taking no medications, was not fatigued, and was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  \n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when the driver of V1 attempted an illegal U-turn in front of V2, whose driver falsely assumed that V1 would wait for him to pass. Associated factors (for V1) included conversation with passengers, an exterior distraction, inadequate surveillance, and a false assumption.
../resources/summary/2005011268063.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1992 Ford Probe, was entering the northbound lane one of a 5 lane, 2 way, without a positive barrier, urban roadway from an entrance ramp with a yield sign.  V2, a 1999 Ford Windstar minivan, was northbound in lane 1 of the 5-lane roadway passing by the entrance ramp.  At the time of the crash, the bituminous roadway was dry, it was dusk but lighted and there were no adverse weather conditions.  Lane 1 is wider at the point of the merge but there is not a full width merge lane present.  While merging, V1, left, contacted V2, right. \n \nBoth vehicles were towed.  No injuries were sustained by the occupants of either vehicle.\n\nComplete interviews and inspections were obtained for both vehicles.\n\nNo mechanical defects were detected for V1.  The driver of V1 was cited in the crash.  She was familiar with the vehicle and properly licensed for it but not so familiar with the roadway.  She had just left the dentist and was in pain and taking pain medication.  She was not in a hurry and, though she denied being fatigued, had experienced sporadic sleep habits in the days prior to the crash from a recent illness and the dental problems. There did not appear to be any evidence of excessive speed or aggressive driving on her part.  Pre-crash movement for V1 was merging.  This vehicle\'s Critical pre-crash event was traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel.  The critical reason was coded to this vehicle for an illegal maneuver (failure to yield), trying to merge into an occupied lane.\n\nNo mechanical defects were detected for V2.  The driver was familiar with both the road and the vehicle.  She also had driven less than 30 minutes at the time of the crash.  She was properly licensed for the vehicle and was not cited.  There were no indications of excessive speed, fatigue, aggressive driving or drug use being involved on her part.  The movement of V2 was going straight.  The Pre-crash event was other vehicle encroachment from the entrance to a limited access highway and a Critical event was not coded to this vehicle.\n  \nAlcohol use by either driver was not found to be a factor in the crash.
../resources/summary/2005011268082.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a two-way, two-lane road at the point where the road is oriented to the south just prior to a curve to the east.  Conditions were dark, unlit, and foggy in the hour before daylight.  The wet bituminous road had a posted speed limit of 64kph (40mph).\n\nThis is a Y intersection where the north/south road intersects the road that curves to the left running north/south to east/west. The crash took place at the base of the curve as it met the straight road heading north/south.  This road was controlled by a stop sign, with an advance warning sign alerting drivers to the presence of the stop sign, prior to the intersection.  This road also had a posted speed limit of 64kph (40mph).\n\nV2, a 1999 Jeep Cherokee, was traveling straight south (eastbound) on the road just approaching the curve to the left, in a line of vehicles slightly spread out.  The driver of V2, a 35-year old male, saw headlights coming out of the dark, right in front of him, with no time for avoidance actions. \n\nV1, a 1991 Pontiac Grand Prix driven by a 43-year old male, was northbound on the north/south road.  V1 stopped at the stop sign, looked for on-coming traffic from the north and westbound traffic coming from his right, and proceeded to go straight through the intersection, intending to cross the eastbound lane and travel westbound.  The driver of V1 stated that as far as he could see, it was clear before he went.  He also stated that due to the fog, he apparently could not see far enough ahead.  The front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the eastbound lane and pushed V2 toward the westbound lane. \n\nV3, a 2004 Ford Taurus, was traveling straight, approximately 50 feet behind V2, driven by a 28-year old male.  When V1 struck V2, and V2 came to a stop in the road partially in the westbound lane, the driver of V3 braked, with full ABS application, and tried to swerve to the right to avoid V2.  The front left of V3 struck the back right of V2.  V3 then attempted to travel to the right of V2 to avoid further damage, but V1 came to rest in the eastbound lane partially on the roadside, directly in the path of V3.  The front left of V3 struck the left front and passenger area of V1.  V1 was pushed to final rest facing northeast off of the road on the west side by V3. \n\nV1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V1 was restrained with a lap and shoulder belt. The driver, who was 6\' tall and weighed almost 300 pounds, contacted and bent the steering wheel and was transported with incapacitating injuries to a local trauma center.  The Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cfog\xe2\x80\x9d weather - related factor.  The driver of V1 was wearing his prescription glasses, and had existing health conditions, which required him to take medications for cholesterol, blood pressure, sugar, and attention deficit disorder.  The driver mentioned past family concerns and current work stress, but felt that emotionally he was feeling better than he had in a long time.  The driver of V1 was familiar with his vehicle and with the roadway, and had a valid license.  \n\nV2 came to rest slightly into the oncoming lane of traffic facing southeast, near the point of impacts.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The restrained driver was transported to a local trauma center, with moderate injuries.  The Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over right lane line.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V2 was healthy, was taking no medications, did not need corrective lenses, and has no emotional, sleep, or work-related concerns.  The driver of V2 was familiar with both the vehicle and the road, and the vehicle had no mechanical defects.  V2 had numerous tools in open crates in the cargo area of the Jeep, which were found scattered throughout the interior during the inspection.  There were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection.\n\nV3 came to rest just off of the road on the west side and was drivable from the scene after the crash.  The restrained driver of V3 was not reported as injured, and the airbags did not deploy.  Although the other motor vehicle was stopped in the lane, the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to V3, as this vehicle was not involved in the first harmful event.  V3 was following too closely to respond to unexpected actions of V2, described by the driver as 50\' ahead of him in the fog, but the Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle, as this was a secondary impact.  The 2004 Ford Taurus was a loaner, which the driver had picked up two days prior to the crash.  The driver had been driving passenger cars for 12 years and seemed familiar with the type of vehicle and the roadway.  The driver wears required lenses to correct a myopic condition, but has no other emotional, health, work or sleep-related issues.  The driver was holding a cup of coffee in his right hand while steering with his left hand.  He is properly licensed, and based on the vehicle inspection, V3 had no mechanical defects contributing to the crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268102.json
preprocessing
The crash area is a junction of two interstate highways, where the east/west roadway merges to the northbound leg of the north/south roadway.  The eastbound collector lane is straight, and the westbound ramp curves right, to combine briefly as one two-lane road, before the right lane ends and the road then merges with the northbound highway.  Both the ramp and the collector lane are one-way.  The crash occurred at the point where the ramp combines with the collector as a two-lane road, with a paved right shoulder without rumble strips, and a concrete barrier wall on the left dividing the collector road from the main north/south highway.  At the time of the crash it was a cold, clear weekday evening, and the dark and unlit, bituminous roadway was level and dry.  The posted speed limit on the highway is 105km/h (65mph) with no other posted speed signs for the ramp or the collector lane.  Advisory merge signs are posted at the entrance to the ramp, indicating that the right lane will merge to the left.\n\nV1, a 1995 Ford Club Wagon, driven by a 50 year-old male, was eastbound on the highway and had exited the ramp on a left hand curve and was traveling straight on the collector lane to the northbound highway.\n\nV2, a 1996 Mercury Sable, driven by a 23year-old female, was westbound on the highway and had exited and was traveling on the right hand curve on the ramp to the northbound highway.   V1 reached the combined 2-lane collector ahead of V2, but V2 was traveling at a higher rate of speed.  As V2 moved into the straight portion of the road where it merged with the collector lane from the eastbound ramp, V2 lost control and left the roadway on the right.  V2 rotated counterclockwise and returned to the roadway where the right front of V2 struck the right back of V1.  \n\nV2 continued across the traffic lane and the front of V2 struck the concrete barrier wall on the left and continued to rotate counterclockwise striking the wall again with the left back.  V2 continued to rotate until it came to final rest facing southeast in the right hand lane.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V2 was transported to a local trauma center due to injuries.\n\nV1 spun off to the right following the impact with V2. V1 rotated clockwise and continued in lane one in a lateral yaw with the left side leading.  The lower left side of V1 contacted the leading edge of a metal guardrail on the right shoulder. V1 became airborne, striking the guardrail with the left driver\'s greenhouse area.  V1 rolled over 4 quarter turns with the left side leading contacting the ground and came to rest on it\'s wheels facing southeast.\n\nThe unbelted driver of V1 was ejected from the vehicle.  The front left, front right, and back left windows were all broken out during the crash, and the upper portion of the windshield was separated.  All of the doors of V1 remained closed.  V1 came to rest against a tree (app. 30cm in diameter), causing damage to the upper left passenger area.   V1 sustained moderate intrusion to the driver\'s area and was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V1 was treated with life support at the scene and transported to a local trauma center where he was pronounced dead.\n\n\nA witness to the crash was traveling on the eastbound highway and had exited and was traveling on the collector lane to the northbound highway.  The witness observed V2 out of her right peripheral vision, seeming to be traveling too fast to safely negotiate the ramp to the collector lane without striking the concrete barrier wall.  The witness observed V1 ahead of V2 traveling at a lower rate of speed. The witness did not observe any braking or steering/swerving precrash by V1.  The witness vehicle braked and came to rest one foot away from V2 at final rest, which was facing backwards in the right hand lane. The witness also stated that the pavement was dry, and there was no precipitation at the time of the crash, although it began to rain/snow shortly thereafter.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'other motor vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane-same direction over the right lane line\'.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  It is unknown whether there were any Contributing or Associated Factors for this driver.  He was familiar both with his vehicle and with the roadway, and had been driving for 34 years.  There did not appear to be any vehicle related defects at the time of inspection.  The driver was alone in the vehicle, driving his regular commute home after work.  The police did not indicate any alcohol or drug use, but the medical examiner\'s report is pending.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was \xe2\x80\x9cthis vehicle loss of control due to traveling too fast for conditions\xe2\x80\x9d on the curved ramp.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was \xe2\x80\x9ctoo fast for curve.\xe2\x80\x9d   V2 lost control at the end of the curved ramp causing her to leave the roadway on the right.  The driver of V2 most likely corrected the vehicle to the left resulting in the counterclockwise yaw.  V2 then re-entered the roadway and struck V1.  It is unknown what the Contributing or Associated Factors for the driver of V2 might have been.  She was driving her own vehicle, on a local highway route near her home.  The driver has a medical history of rubber band surgery for frequent shoulder dislocations.  The driver indicated that she drinks alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use.  The driver lists only birth control pills for prescription medication.  The police accident report indicates that the driver holds a valid driver\'s license.  Although the report listed a Hazardous Action of \xe2\x80\x9cCareless/Negligent Driving\xe2\x80\x9d there were no citations issued in the crash.

preprocessing
V1, a 2004 Kia Rio 4dr sedan, was southbound in lane 4 (the inside lane of 2 left turn lanes) of a 6 lane, bituminous, urban roadway intersecting a 5 lane, urban roadway at a controlled intersection.  V1 was making a left turn on a green arrow onto the 5 lane roadway to go eastbound.  V2, a 2002 Ford Ranger Pick-up, was stopped in lane 3 (the left turn lane) of the 5 lane urban roadway facing west, the first car in that lane, waiting for his own green arrow to turn left.  V2 saw the southbound traffic turning left toward him and, being experienced with that intersection, started to back up knowing that this traffic sometimes cuts the corner too sharply.  V1 cut the corner too sharply and crossed into the lane occupied by V2.  V1, front, contacted V2, front, in lane 3 of the east-west roadway.\n  \n  Both vehicles were towed from the scene.  Neither driver was reported as injured.  Complete Interviews and vehicle inspections were obtained for both vehicles.  Alcohol or illegal drug use were not factors in this crash.\n\n  The driver was found to be familiar with the roadway and the vehicle as well as being properly licensed for that vehicle.  He was an experienced driver with the only restriction on his license being that the vehicle he is operating must be equipped with power steering (which it was). He was not late or in a hurry and speed did not seem a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to his actions and he was not cited in the crash.  The driver suffers from cerebral palsy and takes various prescribed drugs daily but they were not believed to be contributing factors to the crash.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that the mechanical condition of the vehicle contributed to the cause of the crash.  The pre-crash movement of V1 was turning left at the intersection, the critical pre-crash event was over the lane line on the left side of travel and the critical reason was poor directional control e.g., failing to control vehicle.  He was turning left in the inside of 2 left turn lanes which had a lane line that was supposed to separate and guide them through the left turn.  This dotted white line was found to be badly worn and hardly visible.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was found to be both familiar with and properly licensed for his vehicle.  He was also familiar with that roadway/intersection, traversing it daily.  He was not late or in a hurry being only 1 mile from his destination.  There were no indications of fatigue, medical or mental conditions as being contributors to the crash.  The driver was not cited in the crash.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications of mechanical problems with the vehicle.  The pre-crash movement was backing up (in left turn lane), the critical pre-crash event was other vehicle encroachment from crossing street turning in opposite direction and the critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.  This vehicle had not encroached into the intersection  before backing up but knew that turning traffic cut the corner of his lane many times while turning so tried to back up when he saw them coming.\n  There were no indications of alcohol or illegal drug use on the part of either driver.
../resources/summary/2005011268123.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a rural two-way, two lane, gravel/slag road on a clear weekend afternoon.  The road was mostly ice-covered, and contained potholes and ruts, which ran longitudinally down the center portion of the roadway.  The road was straight and had a negative 4.9% grade.  The unposted speed limit was 89km/h (55mph).\n\nV1, a 1997 Saturn 4-door sedan, was traveling eastbound.   The 15-year old unlicensed driver was traveling at a reduced speed (56km/h 35mph), but lost control of V1 due to ice on the roadway.  V1 began to slide to the right in a clockwise rotation, and the driver began to tap lightly on the brakes and steer to the left.   V1 then began to rotate counterclockwise, and the driver steered to the right.  V1 left the roadway on the left side and the front of V1struck a 30cm diameter tree 1.6 meters north of the road edge.  The top 5 meters of the tree broke off at impact and fell on the roof of the vehicle.  V1 came to rest on the road facing north, in the westbound lane.  \n\nThe driver and passenger airbags deployed in the impact. The driver and two passengers were transported to a local trauma center due to injuries.  The vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to poor road conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "Too fast for conditions," a decision error. The driver was cited by police for \xe2\x80\x9cspeed too fast.\xe2\x80\x9d Associated factors coded to this driver include distraction in the form of conversation - as per the driver, she and her two passengers were talking on a cell phone (that was on speaker mode) to another friend at the time of the crash. The driver of V1 was an inexperienced driver who was unlicensed and not familiar with either the vehicle or the roadway. The driver stated that her mother had taught her everything she knew about driving and that she had been driving for one year. Another associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was "poor directional control" due to her actions after the vehicle began to skid. Finally, the condition of the roadway was also coded as an associated factor - the road was not paved and had longitudinal ruts running down it, along with a multitude of potholes. The roadway was also covered in slush and ice. \n\nThe driver of V1 was wearing contact lenses to correct a myopic condition, and stated that she had no health problems and takes no medication.  There appeared to be no fatigue or emotional factors.  Police did not consider either alcohol or drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  There were no atmospheric conditions or vehicle defects found to be related to this crash.\n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when the unlicensed and inexperienced driver of V1, who was traveling too fast for the ice-covered roadway, lost control, departed the roadway and struck a tree.  Associated factors included distraction by conversation, driver inexperience, unfamiliarity with the road and the vehicle, poor directional control, and the condition of the roadway.

V1, a 2003 Pontiac Vibe, was eastbound on a two-way, two-lane undivided roadway.  It was the early hours of the weekday morning, dark and unlit.  The statutory speed limit on the level, bituminous, slush covered roadway was 89km/h (55mph).\n\nThe 27 year-old male driver of V1, traveling approximately 64km/h (40mph), noticed an approaching curve to the right and attempted to slow his vehicle.  The driver gently braked on the snowy/slushy road, but encountered an icy patch on the pavement.  V1 began to swerve to the right.  The driver slightly steered left to correct and V1 then began to swerve back and forth.  The driver, conscious of overcorrecting, was continuing to make slight steering adjustments with both hands on the wheel, however V1 began to swerve further back and forth each time.  V1 left the roadway on the right side, skidding longitudinally less than 30 degrees to the right.  The nose of V1 fell over a 90-degree embankment/culvert and V1 rolled two-quarter turns to the right and came to rest on the roof in a creek.  The front row seating area was completely submerged.  V1 sustained damage to the top (00TYDO2). V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe fully restrained upside down driver of V1 was able to release his seat belt and unsuccessfully attempted to open the driver\'s door. While disoriented due to the position of the vehicle, the dark and the water, the driver then attempted to move to the front right door, but found himself in the rear cargo area and located an air pocket.  The driver then opened the rear hatch and exited the vehicle with the help of a bystander.  The driver denied any injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when he lost control of his vehicle on the curve due to poor road conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cEnvironmental/highway related due to the slick icy road.  A contributing factor of \xe2\x80\x9ctraveling too fast for conditions-did not realize caution was required\xe2\x80\x9d was coded because although the driver knew that the road was slick and was attempting to drive at a lower speed, he did not know that there was ice and could not control V1 when he encountered it on the road.  There were no other contributing or associative factors including emotional, physical or medical conditions at the time of the crash.  The driver was not fatigued, and was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests, and the driver was not issued a citation.  The driver had a valid drivers license with no restrictions or endorsements.\n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when the driver of V1, encountered ice on the slushy road, lost control, left the road on the right side, and rolled/fell over an embankment and came to rest in a creek on it\'s roof.  A contributing factor of \xe2\x80\x9ctraveling too fast for conditions-did not realize caution was required\xe2\x80\x9d was also coded.  There were no associated factors coded for V1.\n

The crash occurred on a two-way bituminous roadway in the early evening hours on a weekday.  The roadway consisted of three lanes with a travel lane in each direction; a center left turn lane, and bicycle lanes between the travel lane and the curb in each direction.  Conditions were dark but lighted, it was lightly snowing, and the straight roadway was snow, slush and ice covered.  The posted speed limit was 56kph (35mph).  \n\nV1, a 2000 Suburu Legacy driven by a 31 year-old male, was southbound on the road traveling up a 3% grade.  The driver slowed behind a bus turning right onto a side street in front of V1.  As the bus turned, the driver of V1 sped up and lost control on an icy section of the road.  The driver attempted to brake and steer the vehicle left to regain control but V1 spun clockwise, crossed the bicycle lane and struck a curb on the right road edge.  The driver steered left and V1 then rotated counterclockwise and crossed the lane edge on the left, the left turn lane and into the path of V2.\n\nV2, a 2002 Ford Focus driven by a 34 year-old male, was northbound on the same roadway when V1 traveled out of control from west to east on the road in front of him.  The front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the northbound travel lane, and came to rest facing southwest in the same lane.  V2 rotated to the left and was pushed partially into the bike lane, where it was struck by V3.\n\nV3, a 2005 Mazda 3 driven by a 29 year-old female, was northbound in the lane behind V2, and after V2 spun counterclockwise in front of V3, the front of V3 struck the left side of V2.  V2 came to rest in the northbound bike lane area in the mouth of a commercial driveway facing northwest.  V3 came to final rest in the bike lane facing north.\n\nVehicles 1 and 2 were towed due to damage.  V3 was driven from the scene.  The driver and passenger airbags in V1 and V2 deployed.  Medical treatment of drivers and passengers, all restrained with lap and shoulder belts, was refused at the scene.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle loss of control due to traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as environmental/highway related- slick roads (low friction road surface due to ice).  Contributing factors were coded for the driver of V1. The driver had taken a driver\'s education course in his native country and holds an international driver\'s license obtained 6 months earlier that required passing a written examination for this country.  He was cited for \xe2\x80\x9cSpeed too fast\xe2\x80\x9d in the crash, and it was not clear on-scene if the driver understood that driving slower than the posted speed limit was necessary during poor road conditions.\n\nAnother factor coded for this driver was fatigue as he worked doing research at the university all night and slept 4 hours during the day and described himself as \xe2\x80\x9cfeeling tired today\xe2\x80\x9d.  An associated factor was coded for this driver as he is usually the passenger in the vehicle driving down that road, and only drives it himself monthly.       \n\nThe driver was cited for \xe2\x80\x9cSpeed too fast\xe2\x80\x9d in the crash.  The driver was wearing a contact lens to correct a myopic condition and stated that he was on medication as a preventative measure and also takes Vitamin B daily.  A possible associative factor was coded for his antibiotic, which is preventative for many different infections, and has potential side effects including drowsiness, confusion, dizziness and visual disturbances.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  The driver of V2 became aware of V1 as it traveled across the lane lines from his left to his right.  The driver braked, but V2 did not slow down prior to impact.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no associated factors coded to V2.  The driver was wearing contact lenses to correct a myopic (nearsighted) condition.  He was taking no medications, was not fatigued, and was comfortable both with his vehicle and the roadway.  The driver reported no emotional concerns and holds a valid driver\'s license.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was not coded for the driver of V3 because V3 was not involved in the first harmful event.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  A contributing factor of  \xe2\x80\x9cfollowing too closely-did not realize too close to forward vehicle\xe2\x80\x9d was coded for this driver.  Another contributing factor of \xe2\x80\x9chighway/ roadway related-slick surface (low friction value due to ice) was coded to this driver.  The driver of V3 should have realized that due to the road conditions, she should have been driving more than 1.5 car lengths behind V2.  Had the driver of V3 not been following too closely behind V2, she could have stopped her vehicle in time to avoid being part of the crash in the lane ahead of her.  The driver of V3 was taking no medication and reported no health issues, was not fatigued, and was familiar with both her vehicle, which was in good condition, and the roadway.  The driver held a valid license with no restrictions, and there were no indications of emotional or stress related concerns.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.

V1, a 1997 Chevrolet Cavalier 4dr, was southbound in lane 1 of a 2 lane, 2 way, bituminous, straight, rural roadway turning left (east) onto a rural, 2 lane, 2 way, straight, level roadway that turned into a gravel/slag roadway 30meters east of the intersection.  At the time of the crash it was dark, unlit, snowing and the roadways were very snow covered.  As V1 was turning left, it was unable to complete the turn, exiting the eastbound roadway to the right.  The front of V1 struck a tree >10cm.   Both occupants of V1 refused treatment.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n    A partial interview and a vehicle inspection were obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  She had been working, stopped to pickup her child from babysitter\'s and was on her way home, (within a mile of the babysitter\'s), when the crash occurred.  The driver did say that she was not in a hurry but indications are that she was driving too fast for road conditions.  Her sleep and work habits as well as her medical, mental and stress factors are unknown but she was in an extreme agitated state at the scene.  She seemed to be a single mother working full time.  \n\n   A successful download of the EDR was performed.  The vehicle inspection revealed that the air pressure in all for tires exceeded the recommended pressure by at least 20lbs per tire.  Tread depth for each tire was found to be 50 to 60%.  This seemed to be the only mechanical defect found on the vehicle but the vehicle had over 150k miles (241k kilometers) on it at the time of the crash.\n\n  V1\'s movement prior to recognition was turning left, the critical precrash event was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side and the critical reason was attributed to a slick road surface condition.  Associated factors assigned to this vehicle/driver included traveling too fast for conditions, being in a hurry, the snowy weather condition, and an over inflated tire condition. \n\n  The driver was not cited in the crash but was advised that she had been driving too fast for conditions.  The use of alcohol was not involved for this driver.
