preprocessing
The crash occurred in the evening hours of a weekday on a four-lane divided roadway.  The road has two lanes in each direction divided by a grassy median.  The vehicles were traveling in the eastbound one-way lanes, where there is an additional left turn lane.  Conditions were dark, unlit and it was snowing.  The straight and level cement road was snow covered in places and the posted speed limit was 80km/h (50mph).  \n\nV1, a 2002 Ford Ranger compact pick-up truck, driven by a 20 year-old female, was eastbound in the right lane slowing to turn right onto an intersecting residential street.  V1 was moving at approximately 10-15 mph with her right turn signal on, checked her rear-view mirror and did not observe any vehicles in the road behind her. The driver then looked forward to begin to turn onto the intended street.  The driver checked her mirror a second time and observed V2 directly behind her.\n\nV2, a 2003 Pontiac Grand Prix, driven by a 36 year-old male, was traveling eastbound in the right lane at a speed of 35-40mph, and the front of V2 struck the rear of V1 in the right lane, just prior to the residential street.  V1 came to rest still facing east with the left side still partially in the right lane in the intersection.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver denied any injuries, and the driver and passenger airbags deployed.  \n\nV1 came to rest facing east with the left side in the right lane ahead of V2 at the far side of the intersection.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver denied any injuries.  The Critical Precrash event coded for V1 was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same lane with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver of V1 used caution driving on the snow covered road and exercised extra caution by checking her rear-view mirror prior to slowing for the turn.  The driver had no health, emotional, or sleep related issues, and was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway.  V1 had no mechanical defects upon inspection.  The driver had a valid driver\'s license and the police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was Other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction while decelerating.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded for this driver was Inadequate surveillance.  A Contributing Factor coded was roadway related slick surface due to icy conditiol.   By the time the driver of V2 realized V1 was turning, he was already just two car lengths behind her.  The driver of V2 was cited for Speed too fast for conditions.\n                              \nA second Contributing Factor coded to the driver of V2 was fatigue.  The driver of V2 was in an ambulance on-scene and observed by EMS and police to require a Breathalyzer test.  A second police vehicle was called to administer the test.  The driver\'s test results were .00.  The police coded driver fatigue on the Police Accident Report, with no drugs or alcohol, and drove him to his home following the crash with no further testing.  The driver stated that he had spent the 12 hours prior to the crash at a local hospital with his mother who was a patient.  He stated at a later date that he felt rested at the start of the trip the day of the crash, but appeared on scene to be less than fully alert.  An Associated Factor for this driver was that he was operating the vehicle with a suspended Driver\'s License, for which he was cited.  The driver stated that he was not upset, had no concerns, and no emotional or health related issues.  The vehicle was in good operating conditions, and the driver was familiar both with the vehicle and with the roadway.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268243.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a two-way, four-lane divided highway.  The grassy median had metal guardrails only along the bridge supports on either side of the road as it passed under an overpass.  The cement road was level and curved to the left.  It was late afternoon just prior to dusk on a weekday and had begun to snow shortly before the crash, lightly covering the road.   The posted speed limit on the highway was 113km/h (70mph).\n\nV1, a 1994 Isuzu short bed pickup truck driven by a 21 year old male, was traveling east in lane one at approximately 89km/h (55mph) when the back of his truck began to fishtail on the snowy road as V1 came in contact with an icy area.   The driver pumped the brakes and attempted to steer left and right to control the vehicle.  The back of the truck swung to the left and V1 left the roadway on the right side with the left side leading.  V1 traveled laterally in a clockwise rotation down an embankment until the tires dug in and tripped V1 into a rollover as the embankment then began to slope upward.  V1 rolled 4 quarter turns with the left side leading and then rolled back 1 quarter turn onto the driver\'s side as V1 swung around facing back toward the highway and came to final rest. \n\nThe fully restrained uninjured driver of V1 exited the vehicle through the open backlight area.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \xe2\x80\x9cthis vehicle control loss due to traveling too fast for conditions\xe2\x80\x9d.   The snow at the time of the crash had not been falling long enough for the driver of V1 (or most others in the area) to adjust his speed accordingly.  The cold pavement, particularly under the overpass, was conducive to creating slippery, icy patches.  The driver\'s stated travel speed was below the posted limit but that was related to evening rush hour traffic.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cEnvironmental/Highway related-slick roads (low friction road surface due to ice\xe2\x80\x9d.  A driver decision error was coded for \xe2\x80\x9ctraveling too fast for conditions-did not realize caution was required\xe2\x80\x9d due to the fact that the driver did not recognize the need to slow down as soon as it began to snow.  Although the driver had only been driving the truck full time for a few months, the crash occurred at the end of a record setting winter season of snowfall, possibly indicating more of a decision error than inexperience.\n\nOne possible Contributing Factor for this crash was the 6 x 50# sandbags located in the bed of the compact pick-up truck.  The driver put them in to add weight and they were put in lined up in 2 rows of three from wheel well to wheel well right in the middle of the bed.  The driver described the rear of the truck as spinning out as soon as he hit the icy patch, and then fishtailing/wagging back and forth.  Additionally, another Contributing Factor was coded for the vehicle tires as the driver described the tires on the truck as in poor condition and at inspection the pressure in the rear tires was found to be 19 and 22 pounds per square inch and the tread of all four tires was measured at 3 and 4 32nds of an inch each.\n\nA possible Associated Factor was noted for frequency of driving the road, as the driver stated that he was driving that route home after his first day of work at a new job, but one he held 5 years prior.  Although he was familiar with the road, he had not driven on it in the recent past.  However the roadway environment was similar to most of the highways in the area.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was wearing contact lenses to correct a myopic condition, but indicated no other health related conditions.  The driver has a valid driver\'s license with no endorsements, and was in compliance with his corrective lenses restriction.  The driver does not take any medication, and there were no reported alcohol, illegal drugs, sleep, emotional or distraction factors contributing to the crash.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268263.json
preprocessing
The crash took place on a five-lane, bituminous, straight, level, dry, urban roadway.  There were two eastbound lanes with the third lane a left turn lane, and two westbound lanes.  At the time of the daylight crash there were no adverse weather conditions.\n\n  V1, a 1999 Chrysler Concorde, was proceeding south out of a commercial (gas station) driveway turning left (east) onto a 5 lane roadway.  This driveway was approximately 60 meters west of a fully controlled intersection.  In order to travel east on this roadway, V1 needed to cross 2 westbound lanes and 1 center turn lane used by the eastbound traffic at the aforementioned intersection.  V2, a 1989 Dodge Caravan, was westbound in lane 2 of the 5-lane east/west roadway.  V2 had just proceeded through the intersection west of the driveway and V2 was traveling at a constant speed.  Traffic was backed up in lane 1 of the westbound lanes so V1 was going between stopped cars in lane 1 to turn left.  \n \nThe Chrysler Concorde (V1) was driven by a 24-year old female that was uninjured in the crash.  She stated that she was in the gas station driveway waiting to turn left onto the roadway.  She looked left and thought she had enough time to turn left onto the eastbound lane.  As she pulled out she got struck in the left side by the other vehicle.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was turning left at the intersection and the Critical Reason for the Pre-crash Event was turned with obstructed view, an "other" decision error.  The stopped traffic in lane 1 had motioned her into the roadway and blocked her view of V2.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was not late or in a hurry.  The driver reported that her health was good, was wearing prescribed contacts and had had her normal amount (6.5) hours of sleep the night before the crash.  She had worked 5 days (30hours) since her last day off.  The driver did say she was constantly fatigued, before this short trip (she had been driving <30 minutes) and usually when she awoke.  She also suffers from depression and takes two medications for it, the possible side effects are dizziness, blurred vision, tiredness and sleeplessness.   The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that mechanical defects contributed to the cause of the crash.  The driver was cited for failure to yield to oncoming traffic.\n\nThe Dodge Caravan (V2) was driven by a 34-year old male that was uninjured in the crash.  There were two passengers in the V1 was his wife and the other was his child they were both uninjured.  He stated that he was traveling west on the road to take his child to the hospital for her vaccination.  He was driving in the center lane, lane two.  The driver said that it looked like the other driver was a student and she didn\'t have good judgment when she pulled out in front of him.  He applied his brakes but was unable to stop before he hit V1.  This vehicle was towed due to damage.   \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was other vehicle encroachment, from driveway,  turning in opposite direction and the Critical Reason is not coded to this vehicle.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle.  He was also properly licensed for the vehicle and had only driven less than 30minutes on scheduled local trip.  He was not in a hurry and excess speed was not a factor in the crash.  There were no indications of fatigue, medical complications (including vision or hearing) or aggressive driving on the part of the driver.  The only mechanical factor associated with V2 discovered during the inspection was excessive tread wear on all 4 tires but this may not have mattered since the road was dry and the driver had no time to brake substantially before the impact.
../resources/summary/2005011268283.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane bituminous roadway during the morning hours of a clear, dry weekday morning.  The straight roadway had a statutory speed limit of 89km/h (55mph).  V1, a 1998 Mercury Mystique, driven by a 40 year-old male, was eastbound on a >2% downhill slope.  The driver was observed by a witness slumped over the wheel prior to the crash.  V1 left the roadway on the right side, and continued tracking until it contacted the left and right trees of three trees with one base, each >10cm in diameter.  The left front door of V1 was removed to extricate the driver, and V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \xe2\x80\x9cthis vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cdriver related factor:  critical non-performance error-other physical impairment\xe2\x80\x9d.  The driver of V1 stated that he has epilepsy with a history of seizures and stated that he did have a seizure prior to the crash.  The driver takes the prescribed medication Tegretol for his seizure disorder.  This medication carries many possible side effects but the seizure itself was thought to be the only cause of the crash.  There were no other Contributing or Associated Factors.  There were no emotional, fatigue, stress or other health factors.  The driver was familiar both with his vehicle and with the roadway.  There were no environmental or mechanical factors thought to have contributed to the crash.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  The driver of V1 holds a valid driver\'s license.  The police stated that the driver would be re-evaluated regarding the status of his driver\'s license.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268323.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in an intersection controlled by a traffic signal on a clear, dry weekend in the late afternoon.  V1, a 1994 Chevrolet Blazer, was traveling northbound in lane one on a three-lane, straight, level bituminous road.  The driver of V1, a 20 year-old female, saw the green light ahead and as she approached the intersection she leaned down to pick up a container of decongestant medicine.  When she looked back up the light was yellow and she decided to go through the intersection, traveling slightly above the posted 56kph (35mph) speed limit.  Traffic was stopped in the westbound left turn lane of the cross street and the driver did not see any vehicles moving near the intersection.\n\nV2, a 2001 Chrysler Sebring, was traveling westbound on a five-lane straight, level, bituminous road in lane two approaching the same intersection.  The traffic signal turned green for V2 so the 28 year-old female driver, moving at about the posted 72kph (45mph) speed limit, proceeded through the light.  The front of V2 contacted the right side of V1 in the intersection.  The driver of V2 saw V1 two seconds prior to the crash and had no time for avoidance maneuvers.  The left side of V2 then struck the right side of V1.  V2 then traveled to the northwest corner where it left the roadway.  The front of V2 struck the cement base (85cm) of a signpost and came to rest with the left side against a utility pole facing northwest.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver and passenger airbags deployed and the fully restrained driver, who was extricated from the vehicle, was transported due to injuries.  The five year-old male and the three year-old female in the rear seat also were transported to a local trauma center.  \n\nV1 rotated counterclockwise to final rest in the northwest quadrant of the intersection facing north.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage and the fully restrained driver and 25 year-old male in the right front seat were transported due to injuries.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to this driver was \'this vehicle traveling-crossing over (passing through) intersection\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'a decision error/illegal maneuver\'.  The driver stated that instead of slowing down for the yellow light she decided to go through it, which then turned red as she did so.  An \'internal distraction\' was coded as a Contributing Factor which occurred when the driver leaned over to pick up her medicine, which resulted in her taking her eyes off of the road and the traffic signal.  An additional Contributing Factor was coded of a \'sight line restriction\' because the driver of V1 stated that due to several large vehicles stopped in the westbound left turn lane blocking her view of V2, she did not see V2 until just prior to impact.  Related to this, an associated factor was coded for this driver\'s myopic vision, that she does not have corrective lenses for, although they are not required on her driver\'s license.  \n\nThis driver also was coded for other Contributing Factors of fatigue, as she works 55 hours per week, has young children who \xe2\x80\x9cwear her out\xe2\x80\x9d, and had been moving furniture at home during the week prior to the crash.   Health conditions coded include asthma, allergies and a cold.  Her medications are a prescribed bronchodilator for the asthma, progestin, and an over-the-counter decongestant for the allergies and cold.  Some of the possible side effects for these medications are dizziness, sleeplessness, anxiety, tension, and tremors, which can be increased by the use of some antihistamines.  Finally, the crash occurred the day before a holiday and the driver\'s schedule was filled with a series of short stops in preparation for the next day.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no contributing or associated factors coded for this driver.  She was wearing her required corrective lens, reported no health, stress or emotional concerns and was familiar both with the roadway and her vehicle.  The vehicle had no mechanical defects found during the inspection.  The driver is properly licensed and police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.
../resources/summary/2005011268343.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in an intersection controlled by an on colors traffic signal, in the afternoon on a clear, dry weekday.  V1, a 1992 Chevrolet Lumina, was southbound on a two-way, four-lane, straight, level, bituminous roadway with a posted speed limit of 56kmh (35mph).  V1 was traveling in the left lane approaching three non-contact vehicles stopped to make a left turn at the intersecting road.  V1 changed lanes to the right curb lane and proceeded through the intersection although the signal was amber prior to V1 entering the intersection.  \n\nV2, a 1994 Saturn SL, was northbound on the same road and had stopped on the green light at the intersection for 3-5 seconds, waiting to turn left.  V2, driven by 24 year-old female, accelerated from the stop and proceeded to turn left.  The front of V1, driven by a 47 year-old female, struck the right side of V2 in the intersection.   Neither driver had time for avoidance actions.  V1 came to rest facing south in the southbound curb lane at the southwest corner.  V2 came to final rest facing northeast in the eastbound curb lane just west of the intersection.  V1 was driven from the scene.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  Both fully restrained drivers were transported from the scene to a local trauma center where they were treated and released.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was Other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded Critical event not coded to this vehicle.  A Contributing Factor coded to this driver was \'other recognition factor of impending problem masked by traffic flow pattern.\'  The non-contact vehicles, coded as a \'sight line restriction,\' in the southbound left lane prevented Driver1 from seeing V2 pulling out from her northbound left lane until she was already in her path of travel.  Another Contributing factor coded was fatigue, as she stated that she wakes up frequently during the night and never gets a good night of sleep.  She reported that she wakes up fatigued every day and felt fatigued at the beginning of the driving trip prior to the crash.  \n\n Associated Factors coded for this driver include health conditions of recurring back problems and asthma, which were not felt to have contributed to the crash.  Prescribed medications are two bronchodilators with possible side effects of dizziness, heart palpitations, shakiness and tremors.  Over the counter extra strength pain reliever was also taken which has almost no side effects.  The driver was wearing her corrective lenses to correct a myopic condition.  The driver is properly licensed and a Hazardous Action of \'negligent/careless driving\' was noted on the PAR, although no citation was given.  The driver was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway.  The vehicle was not found to have any mechanical defects at the time of inspection.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V2 was This vehicle turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded  False assumption of other road user\'s actions. The primary associated factor coded for this driver was False assumption of other road user\'s actions. A second associated health factor coded for this driver was pregnancy, as she was in her 20th week of gestation.  The driver had no other health conditions, was well rested, and reported no emotional or stress concerns.  She had a valid driver\'s license and was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway.  There were no vehicle defects found during the vehicle inspection.  Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor for either driver and ordered no tests.
../resources/summary/2005011268363.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a two-way, two lane bituminous roadway on a clear, dry weekday afternoon.  The straight and level road had a statutory speed limit of 89 kmph (55 mph).   A two-way, two-lane road intersected the main road on the left, past the location of the crash.\n\nV1, a 1994 Saturn LS driven by a 17-year old female, was traveling westbound behind V2.  V2, a 2002 Cadillac DeVille driven by a 60-year old female, was following 3 other vehicles when the lead vehicle stopped to turn left at the intersecting road.  The vehicle in front of V2 stopped suddenly.  V2 was able to stop her vehicle safely and check her side and rearview mirrors to see that V1 was approaching quickly.  The driver of V2 noticed that there was no shoulder on the right on which to pull over.  She made sure to stop far enough behind the vehicle in front of her, so if V1 struck her back, she would not hit it.\nThe front of V1struck the back of V2 in the westbound lane, as V2 had almost come to a complete stop.  V2 was pushed forward a short distance following the impact and then pulled forward to a stop in lane one. V2 was driven from the scene of the crash.  The fully restrained driver and the 3-year old female in the back center in a child seat, did not require medical treatment.\n\nThe crash occurred when the driver of V1 looked away from the road while traffic was still moving and reached down to adjust the radio controls.  When the driver looked back to the road, V2 had almost come to a stop in front of her and she had no chance for avoidance maneuvers.  Both air/bags in V1 deployed.  The driver and the right front 17-year old passenger, both fully restrained, did not require medical treatment.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction while decelerating.   The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was a \'recognition error of internal distraction\' coded for this driver adjusting the radio controls.  Contributing Factors coded for V1 were \'inadequate surveillance for failure to look far enough ahead\', and another distraction because the driver was also having a social discussion with her friend, the right front passenger.  The driver was familiar with both the vehicle, which was in good condition, and the roadway.  She was well rested and was wearing contact lenses to correct a myopic condition, in compliance with a license restriction, and had no health or emotional concerns. The 17 year-old driver had completed a private driver\'s education course and state graduated licensing requirements.  \n\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed\'.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this driver.  The driver was very attentive to both the road and the surrounding traffic.  Appropriate evasive maneuvers were taken.  Associated Factors for this driver were her menopause medication with a possible side effect of mild dizziness, the fact that she was conversing with her granddaughter in the back seat, and that she was somewhat in a hurry.  She was familiar both with her vehicle, which was in good condition, and the roadway.  There were no health or emotional concerns and she was well rested.  \n\nBoth drivers had valid drivers licenses.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor and ordered no tests.  A citation was given to the driver of V1 for \'failure to stop in assured clear distance ahead\'.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268383.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2003 Ford Focus 4dr, was southbound on a 2 lane, 2 way, rural, straight, level, gravel roadway.  The roadway had just been graded and new gravel applied.  It was daylight at the time of the crash and there were no adverse weather conditions.  V1 lost control on the loose gravel, went into a counterclockwise yaw, exited the roadway to the left (east side of road) and struck a tree >10cm with it\'s front.  The driver was uninjured.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The crash happened less than 100 meters from the driver\'s residence.  The elderly driver was familiar with the vehicle but had only started driving recently after not driving all winter.  She was familiar with the route but had only driven on the freshly graded/graveled road once when she left home earlier to run an errand.  She was properly licensed for the vehicle was not complying with the corrective lenses restriction at the time of the crash.  Instead she was wearing non-prescription sunglasses.  She was not late or in a hurry but a witness observed that she was going at a high rate of speed when she lost control.  There were no indications of fatigue or medical conditions contributing to the cause of the crash.  The vehicle inspection revealed that all 4 tires were over inflated.\n\n  The vehicle\'s pr-event movement was going straight, the critical pre-crash event was off the edge of the road on the left side and the critical reason was poor directional control e.g., failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected.\n\n  Associated factors were possible side effects of medication and driving without prescription lenses.  Contributory factors were that the tires were over inflated and the coefficient of friction for the roadway was reduced due to freshly applied gravel.\n\n  There was no indication that alcohol was involved.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268384.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred at an intersection on a clear and dry, sunny weekend in the late afternoon.  V1, a 2001 Ford F150 pick-up truck, was southbound on a straight, level, bituminous, two-way, two-lane road with a statutory speed limit of 89 kmph (55 mph), controlled by a stop sign at the intersection.  V2, a 2003 Mercury Sable, was eastbound on a two-way, 3 lane, straight, level, bituminous road with a posted speed limit of 80 kmph (50 mph), with no traffic control at the intersection.\n\nV1 a 2001 Ford F150 was traveling southbound, he stopped at the stop sign and then proceeded through the intersection.  V2 a 2003 Mercury Sable was traveling eastbound with no traffic control.  V1\'s front hit V2 in the left side.  V1 came to final rest facing southeast on the southeast corner.  V2 rotated counterclockwise following the impact and came to rest facing west on the southeast corner.  \n\nThe 46 year-old male driver of V1 stopped at the stop sign, looked but did not see V2, and pulled into the crossing roadway.  The front of V1struck the left side of V2.  The driver of V1 stated that possibly the two wooden utility poles on the northwest corner might have obstructed his view of the oncoming V2.  The driver saw the other vehicle at the last moment prior to impact and had no time for avoidance maneuvers.  The fully restrained driver denied any injuries in the crash.  V1 was towed due to damage from the scene.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see)\'.  The two wooden utility poles were close together and had a combined diameter of approximately 75 cm.  It was observed during the scene inspection that the poles could completely block the view of a single vehicle as it approached the intersection.  (See scene images)  Further consideration was given to the possibility that the right A pillar of V1 might have contributed to the sight line obstruction.  A Contributing Factor was coded to this driver of a sight line restriction - the two poles.   Had the driver double-checked prior to pulling into the intersection, he would have seen V2.  There were no health, emotional, or stress related conditions attributed to this driver, and he was not taking any medications.  He was not fatigued and was familiar both with his vehicle and with the road.  The driver reported no internal or external distractions.  There were no mechanical defects found during the inspection.  The properly licensed driver was issued a citation for Failure to Yield the Right of Way.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe 79 year-old female driver of V2 was traveling about 45 mph entering the intersection when she noticed V1 out of the corner of her left eye just prior to impact.  The driver stated that she pulled the steering wheel to the right attempting to avoid the crash.  The fully restrained driver refused medical treatment at the scene.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. The driver\'s daily medications coded as Associated Factors include a drug prescribed to lower high blood pressure with possible side effects of dizziness and lightheadedness, and over the counter aspirin.  She was wearing bifocal lenses to correct myopic and hyperopic conditions, and two hearing aids to correct a mild hearing loss.  The driver was attentive and only accompanied by her small dog that was in a carrier and restrained.  The driver reported no fatigue, stress or emotional issues at the time of the crash.   There were no defects found during the vehicle inspection.  The properly licensed driver was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268423.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, two lane bituminous roadway with a statutory speed limit of 89 kmh (55 mph).   The conditions were clear and dry on a weekday in the early evening hours.  V1, a 2005 Ford Explorer XLT, driven by a 53 year-old female was eastbound on the roadway negotiating a curve to the right.  The driver of V1 fell asleep at the wheel and V1 left the eastbound lane, crossed the westbound lane, and left the roadway on the left side.  V1 crossed the paved shoulder and continued onto grass where the front of V1 struck a metal delineator post and a molded plastic mailbox and post mounted on a 4"x 4" wood post.   V1 went down a short 28% slope into a ditch and back up out again at the edge of a driveway, where it ramped up into the air across the driveway.  V1 continued airborne until the front of the vehicle struck and broke a spruce tree, (9 cm diameter trunk at point of break 150 cm above ground), and then another similar tree, just past the first one.  V1 contacted the ground and continued for a short distance before it became airborne again.  V1 continued on the ground and down an 8% slope where the front right contacted a large tree (95 cm diameter trunk).  V1 then rolled over and the front of V1 struck a small metal fence as it rolled three quarter turns and came to rest on the left side facing southeast.   The driver woke up as V1 was traveling through the spruce trees, and stated that the vehicle seemed to be moving very fast, and she had no opportunity for avoidance maneuvers.  She stated that she was going near the speed limit prior to falling asleep.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \'this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.\'   The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a \'non-performance error - driver asleep.\'  The Contributing Factor coded for this teacher/driver was fatigue due to the minimal 3 hours of sleep she had the night before as she was up grading final exams late until 2:30 am.  The driver then was awake at 5:30 am to begin a 12-hour workday.   She stated during the interview that she felt energized at the beginning of the day in anticipation of her last day of exams and final farewells with her students. She felt relaxed at the start of the trip home, but began to feel tired about ten minutes into the drive.  The driver fell asleep five minutes later as V1 was negotiating a curve and left the roadway.  She stated that she had work related concerns in the week prior to the crash, but felt very calm and stress free at the end of the workday.\n\nThe driver has pre-existing health conditions of asthma and allergies, which require medication as, needed.  The driver had not taken any prescribed or over-the-counter medication in the time prior to the crash.  She was wearing her contact lenses to correct myopia and kerataconus (contacts worn to smooth out a pointed cornea), as required on her driver\'s license, which was valid with no endorsements.  \n\nThe Explorer was brand new and had been driven by the driver only that day, although she had fifteen years of experience driving similar size and type of vehicles.  There were no mechanical defects found during inspection.  The 2005 Explorer has Advanced Trac with Roll Stability Control.  V1 rolled as it contacted the large tree with the front right corner as the front left wheel was traveling down a slope.   The driver was familiar with the road as she drives it daily.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.   There were no citations issued in the crash.  The fully restrained driver was able to unbuckle her seatbelt and get out of the vehicle under her own power.  The front airbags deployed in the crash.  The driver was transported to a local trauma center where she was treated and released due to injuries.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268464.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a clear, dry morning in the daylight, on a two-way, three-lane, straight, level, bituminous roadway.  V1 was traveling northbound at approximately 64kmh (40mph) with a posted speed of 72kmh (45mph).  \n\nThe 47 year-old female driver of V1, a 2001 Ford Explorer 4 door, fell asleep as she attempted to turn right into a fast food restaurant driveway.  The driver stated that she had been feeling sleepy throughout her 25-30 minute drive from home to work.  The driver reported that she had been shaking her head and rolling down the window in an attempt to remain awake.  Feeling increasingly sleepy, she decided to pull off of the road and turned approximately 30 meters short of the intended driveway.  The driver stated that she did not remember anything past beginning her turn.  V1 exited the roadway on the right, went up the cement curb, across the grass and the front of V1 struck a <8cm diameter metal post.  V1 front then struck the front and rode up onto the right side of a legally parked unoccupied vehicle in a restaurant parking lot. V1 then rolled into a second legally parked unoccupied vehicle, where it came to final rest facing east with its\' right side wheels on top of the first vehicle.  The vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage, and the fully restrained driver reported no injuries sustained in the crash and did not seek medical treatment. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \'this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'driver related error-critical non-performance error-the driver was asleep.\'   \n\nA Contributing Factor of \'driver fatigue\' was coded as the driver stated that she had started a new prescribed medication for treatment of Lupus four weeks ago and that it made her tired.  She also has Epilepsy, which requires her to get 8-10 hours of sleep per night, and she did sleep 8 hours the night prior to the crash, but reported that she has felt fatigued upon awakening every day since taking the new medication.  The driver stated that she was certain that she fell asleep and did not have a seizure, as she has only had three seizures in 44 years, and that they were triggered by strobe lights.  She was scheduled to have her prescribed medications evaluated in three weeks.  The medication lists dizziness as a possible side effect.\n\nThe driver\'s physical factors and their related prescribed medications were coded as Contributing Factors.  The driver has a seizure disorder medication and is also being treated for depression with another prescribed medication, both that have possible side effects of drowsiness, tiredness, and dizziness and carry warnings about driving.  The driver also has a severe osteoarthritis condition of her lumbar spine, but had not taken any additional medication for that condition the day of the crash.\n\nThe driver was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway and there were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection.  The driver stated that she had no emotional or work related stress or concerns on her mind prior to the crash, but reported that she is going through a divorce and that she is seeing a psychiatrist and a therapist.  The driver stated that she had been \xe2\x80\x9cfalling asleep all the way to work, I kept rolling the window down, felt like falling asleep\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthis condition has happened before\xe2\x80\x9d.\n  \nThe properly licensed driver currently has no restrictions on her driver\'s license but a re-examination will be ordered as a result of this crash.  There were no citations issued and alcohol or illegal drugs were not considered and the police did not order tests.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268483.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the early evening hours on a two-way, two-lane, straight, bituminous roadway.  Conditions were light, clear and dry and the road had a posted speed limit of 72kmh (45mph).\n\nV1, a 1997 Dodge Ram pick-up truck driven by a 28 year-old male, was traveling east on the roadway.  V1 turned left in front of V2 which was traveling westbound on the same road.  The intended turn destination of V1 was a private driveway on the north side of the road.  The front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the westbound lane of traffic.  V1 came to final rest facing north.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V1 was transported to a local trauma center from the scene.\n\nV2, a 1996 Ford Ranger compact pick-up driven by a 16 year-old male, came to final rest facing southwest partially in the driveway.  The driver of V2 stated that he saw V1 put his blinker on to turn left as he was approaching, but that V2 did not stop and wait for traffic to pass and instead just slowed a bit and then turned right in front of V2.  The driver of V2 had no time for any avoidance actions.  The driver and passenger airbags deployed and V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver and right front occupant of V2 were transported to a local trauma center from the scene of the crash where they were treated and released later that evening.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'turning left at intersection\'.  The critical Reason for the Critical Event was \'a recognition error-inadequate surveillance, looked but did not see\'.  The driver checked oncoming traffic and then began to slow for the left hand turn into the private driveway.  V2 crested a hill and was traveling down slope far enough in advance for the driver of V1 to observe had he looked again at the oncoming travel lane prior to turning.  The driver stated that he did not see V2 until it was too late to avoid the crash.   V1 did not brake or have time to steer left or right.  There were no Contributing factors coded to this driver.  The driver reported no emotional, stress or work related concerns, and no medical conditions.  The driver was well rested and familiar both with his vehicle and with the roadway.  There was an adult passenger in the truck and a cell phone but the driver reported no conversation or cell phone use.  The driver was not in a hurry and was properly licensed.  Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no Contributing Factors coded to this driver.  Associated Factors coded to the 16 year-old were related to experience as he had only been driving for 2.5 months and had driven on the roadway only a few times.  The father of the driver who was the right front occupant indicated that there were no vehicles in front of V2 and that V1 turned immediately in front of V2.  The driver did not report any health, emotional, stress or physical factors, had not taken any medication, and does not wear corrective lenses. There were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection although the right front tire showed more wear than the other three.  The driver has a valid driver\'s license.  Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be a factor and did not order any tests.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268523.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, two lane, rural, slag road with a statutory speed limit of 89kmh (55mph).  Conditions were clear, dark, unlighted and dry on the straight and level road, in the late evening hours at the beginning of the weekend.  V1, a 1983 Ford Crown Victoria, was traveling westbound when it left the road on the left side and the front of V1 struck and broke a small metal sign post and then struck a utility pole.  V1 came to rest facing southwest against the pole.  The wooden utility pole (26cm diameter) remained upright, but a high voltage wire at the top of the pole was knocked loose and hung below the remaining wires.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe driver of V1, a 50 year-old male, was transported from the scene due to injuries and for the police to obtain a blood alcohol level.  The adult female passenger also was transported with the driver.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \'this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a recognition error of \'internal distraction\', as the driver was engaged in kissing the passenger in the center front seat prior to and at the time of the crash.  The driver left the state and was not available to be interviewed.  The passenger stated that neither of them knew that the vehicle had left the road until it struck the pole.  There were no avoidance actions.  Coded, as a Contributing Factor was \'driver related factor/other critical non-performance\' due to alcohol involvement.  The blood alcohol level of the driver was tested at a local trauma center where the report indicated that there was \'acute alcohol intoxication\'.  An Associated Factor coded for this driver was \xe2\x80\x9cdriver inattention-thinking of a future event\' as the couple was on a date and looking for a place to park.  \n\nThe driver was familiar with his vehicle and drives that roadway every once in a while with the same passenger.  No vehicle defects were found during inspection.  Police coded \'speed too fast\' on their report as a Hazardous Action, but did not issue a citation for speeding.  The driver was not fatigued, reported no stress related issues, or medical conditions per passenger and was not in a hurry.  The driver was properly licensed with no restrictions.
../resources/summary/2005011268543.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1997 Chevrolet Cavalier, was southbound in lane 2 of a 4-lane interstate divided by a grass median and guardrail (2 lanes each direction). The straight, cement, level roadway was dry and it was daylight.  V2, a 2003 Ford Focus, was stopped in lane 2 ahead of V1 in the same roadway.  V3, a 1996 Chevrolet Lumina, was also stopped in lane 2 of the same roadway in front of V2.  The front of V1 contacted the rear of V2. V2 was pushed into the rear of V3.  V1 was towed due to damage and the driver of V1 was transported for medical treatment.\n\n    This crash actually involved five cars total. After the Cavalier struck the Ford, which was pushed the Lumina, a 1998 Toyota Camry struck the rear of the Cavalier and a 1997 Dodge Caravan struck the rear of the Toyota.  No citations were issued to any of the drivers involved.\n\n    A partial surrogate driver interview and a complete vehicle inspection were obtained for V1. The driver of V1 was a 22-year old female. The father of the driver of V1 was interviewed, and he reported his daughter to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  It is unknown whether she was late or in a hurry but according to her father, with whom she resides, she had gotten her usual amount of sleep, had left at her usual time and was taking her normal route to work.  She was pregnant at the time of the crash.  The interviewee is responsible for the maintenance of V1 and the vehicle inspection revealed no indications that its mechanical condition contributed to the cause of the crash.  The pre-event movement was going straight, the critical pre-crash event was other vehicle stopped in lane and the critical reason is type of driver error unknown.  A factor that may have contributed to the crash was rush hour congestion.\n\n    A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver of V2, a 21-year old female, was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  The pre-event movement for V2 was decelerating in traffic lane, the critical pre-crash event was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed and the critical event was not coded to this vehicle. An associated factor coded to all three drivers was the traffic flow interruption in the form of the rush hour congestion.\n\n    A driver interview was obtained for V3 but he refused to let the vehicle be inspected.  The driver of V3, a 51-year old male, was stopped when rear-ended by V2.  The driver was properly licensed for the vehicle.  The pre-event movement was stopped in traffic lane, the critical pre-crash event was this vehicle not involved in first harmful event, and the critical reason was not coded to this vehicle. An associated factor coded to all three drivers was the traffic flow interruption in the form of the rush hour congestion.    \n
../resources/summary/2005011268563.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the westbound second lane of a four-lane straight, level, bituminous roadway at a T-intersection, with a roadway on the left, controlled by an on-colors traffic signal.  The conditions were clear and dry on the weekend evening at dusk.\n\nV1, a 1993 Ford Taurus, driven by a 19 year-old female, was following V2 in the left lane.  The drivers of V1 and V2 were related and both traveling to the same destination, with V2 leading the way.  V2, a 1993 Ford Crown Victoria, driven by a 43 year-old male, came to a stop at the intersection on the green light and was waiting for eastbound traffic to clear to make a left hand turn.  The driver of V1 did not realize that V2 was stopping to turn and when she saw V2 stopped in front of her she applied the brakes, without locking up, and the front of V1 struck the back of V2.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V1 was \'other motor vehicle in lane, other motor vehicle stopped.\xe2\x80\x9d  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cinadequate surveillance.\xe2\x80\x9d  Contributing Factors coded for this driver were \xe2\x80\x9cfalse assumption of other road users actions\xe2\x80\x9d, as she thought V2 was going to continue to go straight,  \xe2\x80\x9cdriver experience\xe2\x80\x9d as the driver of V1 had only been driving for three months, and \xe2\x80\x9cvehicle familiarity\xe2\x80\x9d, as she had only had the vehicle for two weeks.  \n\nInterviews were obtained for both drivers, although a language barrier existed for both.  The driver of V2 was interviewed on-scene, with minimal problems, but the driver of V1 was interviewed over the phone via an interpreter, resulting in some unattainable information.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V2 was \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling with a higher speed\xe2\x80\x9d.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this driver.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268583.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a straight, bituminous, 5 lane roadway with an upward 6% slope, with a posted speed limit of 56 kph (35mph).  Conditions were clear on the weekday afternoon. \n\nV1, a 1996 Mercury Tracer driven by a 51 year-old female, was traveling eastbound in the right curb lane between 30-45mph.  The driver of V1 had not been feeling well the day before and went to bed at 1800 hours, then woke up the day of the crash feeling better.  Throughout the morning, however, the driver again began "to not feel right; sleepy, tired and thirsty".  After driving for about 10 minutes, she decided to return home and continued for 15 minutes in that direction, to take prescribed insulin for her diabetic condition, and additional daily medications for high blood pressure, and cholesterol, which she had not taken since the prior morning.  As the driver of V1 approached an intersection with vehicles backed up and stopped at a red traffic signal, the driver lost consciousness, and the front of V1 struck the back of V2 in lane one.\n\nV2, a 2003 Jeep Grand Cherokee Laredo, driven by a 25 year-old male, had been stopped for 10-15 seconds at the red light, and had just accelerated to 10mph when the signal turned to green, as V1 struck V2.  The driver of V2 had been looking straight ahead prior to the impact and had no chance to avoid the crash.  The driver continued to look ahead after the impact and successfully avoided contacting the vehicle in front of him. V2 came to rest at an angle to the right against the right hand curb.  V2 was drivable following the crash and the driver denied any injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with low steady speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was critical non-performance-other physical impairment of the ability to act.   The Contributing Factor coded for this driver was illness-blackout (diabetic related).  The driver routinely takes 9 prescribed medications, but had only taken a pain reliever to alleviate bedtime foot pain the night before and was wearing a narcotic patch for pain the day of the crash.  Possible side effects of these pain relievers are light-headedness, dizziness and sleepiness.  The driver stated in the interview that she knows that she needs to take her medications regularly, particularly the insulin.  The driver of V1 was cited in the crash for Failure to stop in assured clear distance ahead.  V1 was towed due to damage, and the driver was transported to a local trauma center.   \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this driver.  There were no Contributing or Associated Factors coded to the driver of V2. \n\nA complete inspection of both vehicles revealed no mechanical defects and both properly licensed drivers were familiar with their vehicles and with the roadway.  Neither driver had emotional or stress related issues or had any associated factors coded.
../resources/summary/2005011268604.json
preprocessing
\nThe crash occurred on a rural highway divided by a grassy median with a posted speed limit of 113kmh (70mph) with two lanes in each direction.  The conditions were clear and dry on the straight, level, bituminous road on the weekday afternoon.\n\nV1, a 2003 Volkswagen Jetta, driven by a 23 year-old male, was traveling in the left lane at 75mph with his cruise control on, when a non-contact vehicle in the right lane began to move into his lane.  The driver of V1 braked without lock-up and swerved to avoid contact with the other vehicle and left the roadway onto the paved shoulder.  As V1 contacted the rumble strip on the shoulder, the driver then swerved to the right and re-entered the roadway.  V1 crossed the left and then the right travel lanes and left the roadway on the right side.  V1 traveled down a grassy slope and continued 15 meters until the front of the vehicle struck a tree >10cm in diameter.  V1 came to rest against the tree facing northwest and was towed from the scene due to damage.  The properly restrained driver of V1 denied injuries and did not seek medical treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was "this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side."   The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a "performance error-overcompensation".  The driver stated in the on-scene interview that had he continued straight on the left shoulder, he most likely could have maintained control and returned safely to the roadway.  He stated that when his tires hit the rumble strip he panicked and quickly steered right and lost control.  A Contributing Factor coded to this driver was "inadequate/incorrect evasive action-chose inappropriate/unsuccessful evasive action".  \n\nThe driver was properly licensed and familiar both with his vehicle and with the roadway.  The driver did not report any emotional, physical or work related issues and was well rested.  There were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection.  Police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

preprocessing
\n  V1, a 1998 Ford Escort, was exiting a commercial drive, southbound, crossing 3 lanes of a 5 lane urban roadway, turning left to go eastbound on that same roadway.  V2, a 1998 Ford F-150 pickup truck, was westbound in lane 1 of the same 5 lane, urban, cement, straight, level roadway.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry with a steady traffic flow.  V2, front, contacted V1, left.  Both vehicles came to rest facing southwest in the center (left turn lane).  The driver of V1 was injured, transported, treated and released.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was turning left at intersection.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from driveway, across path.   \n
../resources/summary/2005011268623.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a two-way, three lane, straight, level, bituminous roadway at an intersection controlled by stop signs for the two-way, two lane cross street.  Conditions were clear and dry on the weekend afternoon, on the road with a posted speed limit of 80kmh (50mph).  All three vehicles were heading westbound on the same road. \n\nV3, a 1999 Ford Contour, driven by a 36 year-old male was stopped at the intersection in the left turn lane waiting for traffic to clear to complete a left turn.   V2, a 1997 Eagle Talon driven by a 35 year-old female, was stopped behind V2, also waiting to turn left.  V1, a 2001 Saturn SL2, driven by a 25 year-old male, was traveling near the posted speed limit looking for the street signs of the cross street.  The driver of V1 who had moved from out of state 4 days prior to the crash, was unfamiliar not only with the road, but with the signage.  The driver did not notice V2 and V3 stopped in the road ahead of him as he looked right and then left for the street sign.  The front of V1 struck  the back of V2, and the front of V2 then struck the back of V3.  \n\nThe Critical Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was a \'Recognition Error of External distraction\' because the driver of V1 was looking to the left to locate and read the street sign for the cross street.   A Contributing Factor of \'Driver Experience-frequency of driving road- first time on road  was coded to this driver.     An additional Contributing Factor of \'Inadequate Surveillance-failed to look far enough ahead\'  was also coded.  Another Contributing Factor coded was \'other driver related experience-uncomfortable with general traffic speeds\', as the driver stated that the 50mph speed limit on the road was higher than he was accustomed to in the state from which he had moved that week.  \n\nThe Critical Event coded for V2 was \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling with a higher speed.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this driver.   V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver and 16 year-old male right front seat occupant denied injuries.\n\nThe Critical Event was not coded for V3.    V3 was driveable following the crash and the fully restrained driver reported no injuries.

\n  V1, a 2003 Pontiac Sunfire, was traveling westbound in lane 2 of 3 westbound lanes of an interstate roadway.  The straight, bituminous, positive grade >2% roadway was dry and it was daylight.  V2, a 1990 dodge Caravan, was westbound in lane 1 of the same roadway.  V1 was overtaking V2 when it drifted to the right over the lane line.  V1, right, contacted V2, left.  V1 the rotated cw striking the median wall with it\'s back.  V2 rotated ccw striking the median wall with it\'s back then it\'s front.  Neither driver was injured.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was passing or overtaking another vehicle.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was going straight. \n
../resources/summary/2005011268643.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on the westbound lanes on a highway with three lanes in each direction, divided by a median barrier wall, at the point where an entrance ramp joins the right lane.   The posted speed limit for the highway is 113kmh (70mph) for cars and 89kmh (55mph) for trucks.  At the time of the weekday afternoon crash, traffic was heavy but moving at close to the posted limit.  Conditions were clear and dry on the straight bituminous road, which sloped >2% upward at the point of impact.    \n\nV2, a 2002 International 9400 truck tractor without a trailer, was traveling in lane one going 89kmh (55mph).  As V2 neared the straight, level, entrance ramp, V1, a 1999 Chrysler Concorde, was traveling on the ramp about to merge onto the highway.  Due to the congested traffic conditions, the 34 year-old male driver of V2 could not move from his position in lane one.\n\nV1, driven by a 37 year-old female, came to the end of the ramp traveling at approximately the same speed as V2.  The left side of V1 struck the right second axle tire of V2, as V1 entered lane one of the highway.  The witness traveling behind the truck stated that at the last second, V1 swerved to the right in an apparent attempt to avoid contact with V2.  The driver of V1 then swerved to the left, and back again to the right at which time V1 spun clockwise and left the roadway onto the right shoulder, and then down a >2% grassy slope.  The front of V1 struck a cement wall which ran parallel to the roadway 12 meters from the shoulder.  V1 rotated counterclockwise and the right side of V1 struck the wall as V1 continued traveling westward.  The front of V1 contacted the wall as V1 rotated clockwise again, and then finally V1 continued to rotate clockwise until it came to rest with the left side against the wall.  In addition to the wall, V1 struck several small trees planted in front of the wall along the 15 meters between impact #2 and impact #5.  V1 came to rest facing northeast and was towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V1 was transported from the scene to a local trauma center.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V1 was "this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'unknown driver error.\'  The driver refused to give an interview after stating that she works and goes to school full-time and is very stressed and does not have time to talk.  The crash occurred at a freeway entrance ramp near the driver\'s home.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for the driver of V2 was "other vehicle encroachment from entrance to limited access highway".  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this driver. The driver of V2 pulled the still driveable truck over onto the right shoulder following the crash.  The driver reported no injuries.  When interviewed on-scene, the driver stated that he observed V1 on the ramp pre-crash, and tracked its\' movement with his right convex mirror, and thought the driver would slow to merge behind him as his vehicle was partially ahead of hers.  The driver further stated that due to vehicles in lane two, he could not move over to avoid V1, nor did he brake, which may have  resulted in striking V1 with the front of his truck.  The driver stated that he had no safe way to avoid contact with V1.  The driver of V2 had been trained in two truck driving courses, one through a community college and one through the trucking company.  The driver had 18 months experience and had driven V2 more than 10 times and was comfortable driving it with and without trailers.   The driver had dropped his last trailer early in the morning, then slept in the sleeper cab for 10 hours, woke up and had driven 20 miles towards picking up his next trailer when the crash occurred.  The driver had driven on that part of that highway 10 or 11 times.  He held a valid driver\'s license with endorsements for Hazardous Materials, doubles and triples.  The driver was wearing his required corrective lenses.  V2 was inspected on-scene and no mechanical defects were found.  The damage to the truck consisted of slight scraping on a metal splash guard and the right tire on the second axle.\n\nAn Associated Factor was coded to the driver of V2 for possible side effects of sleepiness and disorientation from his prescribed medication for high blood pressure.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268664.json
preprocessing
\nThe crash occurred on a two-way, straight, level, concrete north-south road at an intersection with a road on the west.  The conditions were clear and dry on the weekday afternoon, on the road posted with a 56kmh (35mph) speed limit.\n\nV1, a 1997 Toyota Camry, was traveling northbound at approximately 15 mph, in lane 2 trying to decide whether to go straight in lane 2 or to get into lane 3 and turn left.  The 25 year-old female driver of V1 decided to turn left at the last minute, switched to lane 3, the left turn lane, and proceeded to turn.  \n\nV2, a 200l Chrysler PT Cruiser, driven by an 84 year-old man, was southbound in lane two approaching the same intersection.  The front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the intersection.  The driver of V1 saw V2 approaching but thought that he was far enough away so that she could turn in front of him.  The driver of V1 stated that V2 appeared to be moving very fast, and that he saw her and should have stopped to let her proceed.  The V1 driver stated repeatedly during the on-scene interview that she did not understand why she received a citation for \xe2\x80\x9cfailure to yield right of way\xe2\x80\x9d, when V2 had adequate time to stop and instead hit her.\n\nA witness traveling behind V2 stated that V1 was clearly moving from lane to lane traveling down the road pre-crash, and then moved at the last minute into the left turn lane and turned left right in front of V2.  The witness stated that V2 was traveling about 15-20mph pre-crash, and locked up his brakes trying to avoid striking V1.\n\nV1 and V2 were towed from the scene due to damage.  The front airbags deployed in both vehicles and both drivers were fully restrained.   The driver of V2 was treated on-scene for a slight facial injury and both drivers refused further treatment at the scene.   \n\nThe critical Pre-crash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \xe2\x80\x9cthis vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.\xe2\x80\x9d  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \xe2\x80\x9cfalse assumption of other road users actions.\xe2\x80\x9d  The driver believed that V2 would stop to avoid a crash.  Contributing Factors coded to this driver are  \xe2\x80\x9cmisjudgment of velocity of other vehicle,\xe2\x80\x9d as the driver also thought V2 was traveling slower than he was.  A  \xe2\x80\x9cperformance error-other\xe2\x80\x9d was also coded as the driver has a misunderstanding of a basic driving law that states that traffic turning left must yield the right of way to oncoming traffic.  The driver has had Basic Driver\'s Education and holds a valid license with no restrictions.  \n\nThere were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspections.  Police did not consider illegal drugs or alcohol to be involved and ordered no tests.\n
../resources/summary/2005011268665.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2000 Plymouth Voyager minivan, was traveling westbound on a 2-lane undivided gravel/slag rural roadway. The roadway was dry, straight and level, and was bordered by a 40 cm deep ditch on its south side. There was no posted speed limit on the roadway, which by default in this State was 89 kmph (55 mph). The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours on a clear day. There was a minimum of loose gravel on this portion of the roadway. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 25-year old female, drifted into the oncoming lane for an unknown reason. Once she realized she had done this, she steered hard to the right, driving her vehicle into the ditch on the side of the road. She then attempted to re-enter the roadway by steering left. As V1 began to re-enter the roadway, it rolled over to its right, striking a mailbox in the process. The van rolled over 4 quarter-turns, coming to final rest on its wheels, facing northwest. The driver and her two juvenile passengers were transported, treated, and released. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when she traveled off the edge of the road on the right side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as overcompensation, a performance error. An associated factor coded to this driver was an unknown non-driving activity. As per the police report and the crash investigation, it appears that the driver of V1 became distracted by something and let her vehicle drift into the oncoming lane. Once she realized that this had happened, she jerked the wheel to the right to return to her lane. The driver of V1 denied being distracted; however, this statement was not deemed credible, given the circumstances of the crash.   \n
../resources/summary/2005011268683.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred during the late evening hours on a weekend night at a rural intersection of two undivided two-lane bituminous roads.  The conditions were clear and dry on the summer evening.  The unlighted intersection was controlled by 4-way stop signs and flashing red beacons.\n\nV1, a 2003 Chrysler Voyager minivan, was traveling eastbound on a straight, level road that had no posted speed (by default, 89 kmph/55 mph).  The van was observed by a witness as traveling around 45 mph, flashing its high beam lights and not slowing at all prior to traveling into the intersection without stopping at the stop sign.  V1 was driven by a 35-year old male.\n\nV2, a 2003 Ford F-150 pick-up truck, was northbound on the straight and level, intersecting road.  The driver of V2, a 56-year old male, stopped at the stop sign, and then proceeded into the intersection to turn left, assuming V1 would stop at its stop sign. The front of V2 struck the right front of V1.  V1 rotated clockwise and left the roadway on the northeast corner.  The left side passenger area of V1 struck a stop sign and V1 continued to rotate clockwise, continuing off of the road backwards, coming to rest against a group of pine trees in the front lawn of his home facing southwest.  The driver was transported from the scene due to injuries to a local trauma center, where a blood alcohol test was obtained.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nV2 rotated clockwise following the impact and came to rest in the eastbound lane of the east leg of the intersection facing northwest.  The fully restrained driver of V2 was transported from the scene due to injuries to a local trauma center.  V2 was towed from the scene due to front damage.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to the driver of V1 was "this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an illegal maneuver. A strong associated factor was the use of alcohol:  the driver of V1 was found to have a blood alcohol level of .205.  Additional associated factors coded to the driver of V1 included a pre-existing medical condition of post-traumatic stress disorder, for which he takes an unspecified antidepressant and an anticonvulsant, and aggressive driving. As per the witness statement, the driver of V1 went through the stop sign while flashing his high beams.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to the driver of V2 was "other motor vehicle encroachment from crossing street across path."  The Critical Reason was not coded to V2. One associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was a false assumption of other road user\'s actions. As per his interview, he stated:  "I must have seen headlights down the road and thought the car would stop at his stop sign, so I pulled into the intersection to turn left."\n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268684.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2000 Chevrolet Prism 4-door, was southbound in lane 2 of a 4-lane undivided bituminous roadway (2 lanes each direction).  V2, a 1988 Ford Ranger pickup, was stopped on the same roadway in the same lane waiting to turn left, facing southbound. At the time of the early evening crash, it was daylight and there were no adverse weather conditions. The roadway was dry and straight.  The crash occurred in the vicinity of a sag in the roadway.  The posted speed limit was 72 kmph (45 mph). The front of V1 contacted the back of V2.  A passenger in V2 was injured and transported.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver of V1 was a 33-year old male. He stated, "I don\'t know why I did not see the pickup stopped in lane ahead of me to turn left until I was so close that I hit him." The Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was stopped in his lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as inattention, a recognition error.  The driver was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2. V2 was driven by a 67-year old male. The Critical Pre-Crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle was in his lane traveling in the same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to the V2. No associated factors were coded to this driver. \n  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268703.json
preprocessing
\nThe crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a limited access urban highway, which was divided by a concrete median barrier wall.  The straight and level bituminous roadway had a posted speed limit of 113kmh (70 mph).  Conditions were dry and sunny on the weekday afternoon.   \n\nV1, a 2002 Pontiac Aztek, driven by a 25 year-old female, was traveling eastbound in lane three at approximately 70mph.  V1 activated her right turn signal and changed lanes to lane two.  The driver of V1 immediately saw a non-contact vehicle in lane one moving into lane two.  The driver of V1 swerved and over corrected to the left to avoid the vehicle, moving into lane three, and was headed to the left shoulder.  V1 then swerved to the right and realized the vehicle was heading back towards lane two.  The driver swerved left one more time and lost control of the vehicle.  V1 rotated counterclockwise and left the road on the left side.  V1 crossed the paved shoulder and the front of V1 struck the concrete median wall.  V1 bounced off of the wall, rotated counterclockwise and came to a stop on the shoulder facing west. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \'control loss due to traveling too fast\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'overcompensation\'.  The driver was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway and was properly licensed and wearing her required corrective lenses at the time of the crash.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268723.json
preprocessing
\n  V1, a 2003 Ford Taurus, was southbound in the left turn lane of a 5 lane, bituminous, 2 way, urban roadway intending to left at a controlled intersection with an identical roadway.  V2, a 1996 Mercury Villager minivan, was eastbound in the left turn lane of a 5 lane, bituminous roadway at the same controlled intersection intending to turn north.  The intersection was flat, with 90-degree angles, it was daylight and the roads were dry.  Both vehicles had left turn arrows.  As V2 was making a left turn to go northbound, V1 began its left turn as well striking V2\'s left side with it\'s front.  V1 was cited for disobeying the signal.  Both drivers were injured and transported.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection were obtained for V1.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle turning left at intersection and the critical reason for the critical event was coded as an illegal maneuver (violated red signal phase).\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection were obtained for V2.  The Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street,across path and the critical reason for the critical event was coded critical reason not coded to this vehicle. \n  \n
../resources/summary/2005011268743.json

\nThe crash occurred on a two-way, straight, bituminous road at an intersection controlled with an on-colors traffic signal on a cloudy weekday afternoon.  V1 was traveling eastbound approaching the intersection in lane 3 of 5 lanes, with a positive grade > 2%, and a posted speed limit of 72 kmh (45mph).  V2 was traveling westbound approaching the intersection in lane 2 of four lanes, with a >2% negative grade, and a posted speed limit of 56kmh (35mph).  The traffic signal was green for both directions.\n\nV1, a 1989 Pontiac Grand Prix driven by a 47 year- old male, turned left in front of V2.  V2, a 1993 Saturn SL2 driven by a 21 year-old female, was going straight through the intersection.  The driver of V1 had no avoidance maneuvers.  The driver of V2 braked without lock-up and steered right. The front of V2 struck the right side of V1.  Both vehicles rotated clockwise and came to rest facing east and were towed from the scene due to damage.  The unrestrained right front adult female passenger, and the two unrestrained children in the rear seat of V1 were transported from the scene due to injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was \'Driver related factor-inadequate surveillance (failed to look far enough ahead before turning left).  The driver of V1 was cited for \'Failure to yield right of way\xe2\x80\x9d and for driving with \'Unrestrained child passengers.\'  \n\nA Contributing Factor of strenuous non-work activities was coded for this driver due to the fact that he was moving and had loaded his possessions into his vehicle for 1.5 hours prior to the crash.  The driver is overweight and has high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and diabetes which affects his foot requiring him to wear an orthopedic boot which was on at the time of the crash.  Another Contributing Factor was coded for possible side effects for his daily medications for his health issues, which include insulin and unspecified blood pressure and cholesterol medications.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was \'Other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line\' and the critical reason for the critical event was coded \'Critical reason not coded to this vehicle\'.\n\n\n
