\n  V1, a 1999 Ford Escort 4dr, was eastbound in lane 2 of the 2 eastbound lanes of a straight, bituminous, level, interstate roadway.  A non-contact vehicle passed V1 on the right then cut in between V1 and the vehicle it was following.  The non-contact vehicle braked and swerved slightly back into lane 1.  V1 braked hard and swerved right to avoid the non-contact vehicle and drove off the road to the right where he entered a ditch.  V1 impacted the right side of the ditch with it\'s front-right, then it\'s right-rear and impacted the undercarriage while coming to final rest parallel to the roadway while still in the ditch.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry.  Traffic was medium to heavy at the beginning of that afternoon\'s rush hour.  The driver was uninjured.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The pre-event movement for V1 was coded successful avoidance maneuver to a previous critical event, the Critical Pre-Crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling off the right side of the road, and the critical reason was coded traveling too fast to be able to respond to the unexpected actions of other road users..\n
../resources/summary/2005011268803.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2000 Honda Odyssey, was northbound in lane 2 of a 4-lane, 2-way, undivided, straight, level, bituminous roadway.  V2, a 1984 Oldsmobile Cutlass 4dr, was stopped facing northbound in lane 2 of the same roadway waiting to turn left into a commercial driveway.  V3, 2003 Chevrolet Blazer, was southbound in lane 2 of the same roadway.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry.  V1\'s front struck the rear of V2. This impact pushed V2 across the centerline where the front of V3 struck the front of V2.  V1 came to rest facing north, V2 came to rest facing northwest and V3 came to rest facing southwest.  The driver of V2 was injured, transported and hospitalized.  The driver of V3 sought her own treatment.  All three vehicles were towed due to damage.\n\nA complete interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1. V1 was driven by a 41-year old male. He indicated that he was following a non-contact full-size cargo van in lane 2. Suddenly, the cargo van changed lanes to the right, apparently to avoid V2, which was stopped in front of it. The driver of V1 reported that he did not see V2 until the last minute, and he did not expect a car to be stopped in his lane ahead of him. The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as other motor vehicle stopped in lane and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as an other recognition error, focused on extraneous vehicle..  Associated factors coded to this driver include unfamiliarity with the roadway, and a sight restriction in the form of the non-contact vehicle that swerved to the right at the last moment.\n\nA partial interview and a complete vehicle inspection were obtained for V2. V2 was driven by a 37-year old male. He was attempting to enter the driveway for his place of employment at the time of the crash.  He was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway. The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver include alcohol use and prescription medication use. The medical records indicated that a blood sample was drawn from the driver of V2 one-half hour after the crash and he was found to have a BAC of .06. He told medical personnel that he had consumed alcohol the night before but not the morning of the crash. He also tested positive for barbiturates. \n\nA complete interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V3.  V3 was driven by a 22-year old female. No Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because she was not involved in the first harmful event. No associated factors were coded to this driver.\n

preprocessing
Case Summary 2005-11-058\n\nThe crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a limited access highway on a weekend during the day.  The roadway consisted of three lanes in each direction divided by a grassy median with trees and a metal guardrail next to the shoulder.  The road was level and curved slightly to the right and had a posted speed limit of 113kmh (70mph).  At the time of the crash it was raining hard and the well-traveled bituminous road was wet.  \n\nV1, a 2003 Chevrolet Malibu driven by a 33 year-old female, was traveling at approximately 60-65 mph in lane two.  The driver realized that the speed was too fast for the wet conditions and was intending to change lanes to the right, slower lane.  V1 began to hydroplane as non-contact vehicles in lane one and lane three passed V1 at the same time.  The driver of V1 felt her vehicle lose contact with the pavement and begin to swerve to the left, then to the right as driver steered right, and then back to the left again.  V1 left the center lane and rotated counterclockwise across lane three and the left shoulder until the back right of V1 struck the guardrail.  The right front of V1 struck the guardrail and the driver then steered left to avoid contact on the right passenger area where her 12 year-old niece was the front right passenger.  V1 rotated clockwise and came to rest 75 meters down the road in lane three facing east.\n\nThe fully restrained driver and passenger of V1 were transported to a local trauma center.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'this vehicle control loss due to poor road conditions-puddle/water on road.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'decision error-too fast for conditions\'.  An Associated Factor was coded for the driver\'s prescribed hormone medication which has a possible side effect of drowsiness.\n\n\n

\n  V1, a 1995 Chevrolet Monte Carlo, was northbound in lane one of a 2 lane, 2 way street at an intersection controlled by a stop sign.  V2, a 2003 Jeep Grand Cherokee, was eastbound in lane 2 of a straight, 4 lane, 2 way, not physically divided, uncontrolled, urban roadway that intersected the street occupied by V1.  V1 attempted to turn left (west) across the path of V2.  V2, front, contacted V1, left.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry.  V1 came to rest facing west on the westbound roadside.  V2 came to rest in its original lane facing east.  Both drivers were alone in their vehicles, both were injured and transported.  Both vehicles were towed due to damage.\n\n  A partial interview and a complete vehicle inspection were obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be driving on a suspended license.  The police would not release the names of the drivers involved until the PAR was completed.  By the time the driver information was obtained for V1 he had fled the area and could not be found.  What is known about his involvement in the crash comes from interviews with the vehicle\'s owner (his ex girlfriend) and a witness to the crash.  The Pre-event movement of V1was accelerating in traffic lane, the Critical Pre-crash event was turning left at intersection and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was inadequate surveillance.  Factors contributing to the driver\'s actions include his view to the left being blocked by an eastbound, non-contact vehicle in lane 1 turning right onto his street (and waving him out as he turned), failure to look or misjudged he gap of V2 from his left.  He also \xe2\x80\x9crolled the stop sign \xe2\x80\x9c instead of coming to a full stop before turning left.  He was cited for failure to yield and driving with a suspended license.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was found to be properly licensed for and familiar with her vehicle.  She was also familiar with the roadway.  The Pre-event movement of V2 was Going straight; the Critical pre-crash event was Other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n  It should be noted that the vehicles are numbered in this case according to the information obtained on-scene.  When the PAR was obtained, the vehicle numbers had been reversed.  \n   \n

\n\nThe crash occurred in an intersection of a roadway and a driveway from a shopping area.  The two-way, two lane driveway was straight, level and bituminous, with a statutory speed limit of 40kmh (25mph).  The roadway was two-way, 4 lanes divided by a paved flush median with a posted speed limit of 56kmh (35mph).  The bituminous road was level and curved to the left.  The conditions on the weekend afternoon were dry and clear.  \n\nV1, a 2000 Mercury Sable driven by an 81 year old female, was stopped waiting in the driveway for >30 seconds, waiting for traffic to clear to turn left onto the roadway.  The driver of V1 stated that she looked right and then left and thought it was clear and pulled fast out of the driveway.  The driver of V1 never saw V2 and had no avoidance maneuvers.\n\nV2, a 2000 Honda Accord was northbound in lane one on the roadway.  The driver of V1 swerved to the left and braked, with lock-up, but the front of V2 struck the left front of V1 between lane one and lane two.  The airbags deployed in V2 and the driver was transported to a local trauma center.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \'driver related factor-inadequate surveillance-looked but did not see.\'   An Associated Factor was coded for the drivers prescribed medication taken for arthritis and cholesterol which include possible side effects of headache, weakness and nausea.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 is \'other motor vehicle encroachment from driveway turning into opposite direction.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n

\n\n  V1, a 2002 Lincoln Continental, was westbound in lane 1 of a straight, level, 2 way, 2 lane, rural, gravel/slag roadway.  At the time of the crash it was dark-unlighted and the roadway was dry.  V1 exited the roadway to the right.  V1, front right, contacted a tree >10cm that caused the vehicle to re-enter the roadway and roll 2/4 turns left onto its roof.  V1 came to a stop on its roof facing north.  The unrestrained passenger was partially ejected through the sunroof during the rollover and was under the vehicle at final rest.  Of the 2 occupants of V1, the driver was injured and transported while the passenger was dead at the scene.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway and was properly licensed.  She was not in a hurry and had been driving for about an hour.  The vehicle seemed to be in good mechanical condition. A major factor contributing to the cause of the crash was the driver\'s BAC alcohol level.  This may have interacted with the medications she was taking to further inhibit her ability to control the vehicle.  \n

preprocessing
\n\nThe crash occurred in an intersection of an east/west, two-way, 5 lane, straight, level bituminous roadway with a posted speed limit of 56kmh (35mph) and a driveway from a business on the north side of the road.  The driveway was two-way, two lanes, divided with a small, curbed, grassy median, with a statutory speed limit of 40kmh (25mph), and was straight and level.  Conditions at the time of the afternoon weekend crash were clear, day and dry.\n\nV1, a 2002 Ford Focus station wagon, driven by a 46 year-old male, was waiting in the driveway for traffic to clear to turn left onto the roadway.  Traffic was backed up for the red light at an intersection located 20 meters west of the driveway controlled with an on-colors traffic signal.   Vehicles were stopped in lanes one and two westbound, and both drivers waved to the driver of V1 to pull out of the driveway.  V1 proceeded slowly out of the driveway across lanes one and two, and when V1 continued into lane three, the left turn lane, the left front of V1 was struck by the front of V2.  V1 came to rest in the left turn lane facing southeast and was towed from the scene.  The fully restrained driver denied any injuries.\n\nV2, a 2004 Honda CRV driven by a 33 year-old male, was traveling westbound in the left turn lane at approximately 20 mph, when V1 moved into his lane.  The driver of V1 and the driver of V2 could not see each other due to the line of non-contact vehicles stopped in the westbound lanes.  V2 came to rest in lane two of the eastbound lanes facing southwest.  V2 was towed from the scene.  The fully restrained driver and two passengers were transported to a local trauma center.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'Driver Related Factor/Recognition Error-Inadequate surveillance\'. An associated factor for this case was that the driver of V1 assumed that there was no moving traffic in the lanes beyond the stopped vehicles, and subsequently was struck by V2.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2 was \'Other vehicle encroachment from driveway, turning into opposite direction.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n

preprocessing
\n  V1, a 2003 Lincoln, was traveling eastbound in lane one of a two lane, two way, level, straight, rural, gravel/slag roadway.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry.  V1 drifted left and exited the road to the left.  V1, front, struck a tree >10cm.  The driver of V1 was transported.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  The elderly driver was diagnosed with a heart condition a few years prior to the crash.  On the morning of the crash, he had played 18 holes of golf (which had taken approximately 4 \xc2\xbd hours using a power cart).  By the time he finished, the temperature was approaching 90 degrees.  This was less than an hour before the crash.  It was determined later at the hospital that his fatigue coupled with the heat had combined to cause heart failure, which caused him to lose consciousness just before the crash.  \n\n  The Pre-event movement of V1 was going straight; the Critical Pre-crash Event was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side of travel and the Critical Reason for Critical Pre-crash Event was heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act.  The driver\'s physical condition/heart failure and his fatigue were the leading factors in the cause of the crash.     \n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268883.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the westbound lanes of a rural fully controlled highway, divided by a grassy median with trees. The bituminous roadway had two lanes in each direction with a posted speed limit of 113 kmph (70 mph).  The level roadway curved to the right and had paved shoulders with rumble strips on both sides.  At the time of the crash it was an early weekend morning, daylight, clear and dry.  \n\nV1, a 2005 full-size Chevrolet Silverado pick-up truck, was traveling westbound in the second lane of travel. V1 was driven by a 23-year old male who was returning from a week of working out of state, after driving through the night. The vehicle\'s cruise control was set at 70 mph. As the vehicle began to negotiate a right curve in the roadway, the driver of V1 fell asleep at the wheel and V1 departed the roadway to the left in the curve.  The driver woke up when the left wheels of the pick-up departed the paved shoulder.  The driver braked and overcorrected, steering right, and V1 rotated clockwise and re-entered the roadway.  The pick-up truck crossed both lanes and then the right shoulder, skidding in a clockwise rotation before departing the road on the right.  As the truck left the road, its left side was leading (facing north) and moving northwest.  The left back of V1 contacted and bent a delineator post on the roadside and continued down a 25 percent slope, rolling over 7 quarter turns with the left side leading.  V1 came to rest on the passenger side facing north and was towed from the scene due to damage.  The unrestrained adult lying down asleep in the second seat was transported to a local trauma center.  The fully restrained driver and adult male right front passenger sustained minor injuries.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event coded to V1 was "this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "driver asleep," a critical non-performance error. A contributing factor coded to the driver was fatigue, as the driver had not slept a full night since two nights prior to the crash, and had only taken a 2 hour and 30 minute nap in the truck, which ended 5 hours and 15 minutes prior to the crash.  \n\nAn additional associated factor was work related stress/pressure because the driver had been required to work extended shifts.  The driver and passengers had driven 10 hours to the out-of-state work-site 6 days earlier, and worked 8, 11, 13, 12 and 13.5 hours on the intervening days, for a total of 57.5 hours in five days.  The driver stated that the work was physically tiring and that they were all tired, but drove back because one of the passengers wanted to be home by the afternoon for a social event with his son.  Immediately following the last workday, one of the passengers began to drive back to their home state until the driver took over after his nap.  The driver stopped for a two-minute restroom break 45 minutes (and 57 miles) prior to the crash. The men were not running late and would have arrived home 4-5 hours before the planned activity.  Additionally, the three men were scheduled to be at work the following morning.\n\nAnother associated factor was overcompensation, a performance error. The driver stated that because he was off of the road to the left when he woke up, he immediately jerked the steering wheel to the right and over-corrected, sending the pick-up into a clockwise rotation and off of the road on the right side.\n\nOther associated factors were the driver\'s relative unfamiliarity with the road and with the work truck, which he had only driven that week, as it was his first week on the job, and the driver was not fully comfortable with the vehicle.  In addition, the driver stated that he noticed prior to the rest stop that the truck felt like it had a flat tire and the vehicle seemed to be bouncing, but he found nothing wrong upon inspection.  \n\nThe driver was cited for careless driving.\n\n
../resources/summary/2005011268903.json
preprocessing
\nV1, a 1998 Buick Century 4dr, was eastbound in the morning in lane 1 of a cement, level, 2 lane, 1 way roadway.  V2, a 2000 Sterling truck tractor with 2 gravel trailers, was standing, running, unoccupied, in lane 1 of the same eastbound roadway with it\'s 4 way flashers activated.  At the time of the crash it was bright, sunny and the roadway was dry.  V1, front, contacted V2\'s rear trailer.  The driver of V1 was injured and transported.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe driver stated that he had just left home 5 minutes prior to the crash, and was trying to clean the dew from his windshield (which was smearing) while driving into the sun.  He was not in a hurry and was going the speed limit.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash event was other vehicle stopped in lane and the Critical Reason for the Critical pre-crash event was decision error - drove with dirty windshield.  Some factors contributing to the crash may have been the driver\'s failure to look far enough ahead while adjusting climate controls and proceeding to drive into the sun\'s glare even though he knew he could not see clearly.\n\nThe driver of V2 had parked his truck in the roadway and walked into a construction site to see if there was room for him to make a delivery.  He heard the crash but did not see it.  \n\n

preprocessing
\n\nThe crash occurred in the intersection of a north/south roadway and a driveway from a retail area on the west side of the road.  The conditions at the time of the weekday morning crash were clear and dry on the bituminous two-way roads.\n\nV1, a 1996 Dodge Neon, driven by a 21 year-old female, was traveling east out of the driveway to go north onto the roadway.   V1 was stopped in the left turn lane of the three-lane driveway and the driver pulled out across the path of V2 to turn left into the opposite direction of travel of V2.  The driver stated that she might have glanced left briefly, but possibly not, and then looked right to wait for traffic to clear prior to pulling out of the driveway.\n\nV2, a 1997 Ford E-150 cargo work van driven by a 50 year-old female, was traveling south on the two-lane road.  A second southbound lane began prior to the driveway, in addition to a left turn lane for northbound traffic, but V2 continued in the left lane to go straight on the roadway.  The driver of V2 saw the Neon proceed across the lane in front of her and braked, with lock-up, and steered left.  The front of V2 struck the left front and passenger side of V1 partially in the left turn lane.  V1 and V2 were towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'driver related error-inadequate surveillance, failed to look to (left)side.\'  The driver of V2 observed the driver of V1 looking to her right, as V1 turned left out of the driveway.  \n\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from a driveway, turning into the opposite direction.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n

\n\n  V1, a 2002 Buick Rendezvous, was northbound in lane 2 of a 5 lane, 2 way, and bituminous, urban roadway approaching an electronically controlled intersection.  V3, a 2001 Jeep Grand Cherokee, was northbound in lane 1 of the same roadway 1 to 2 car lengths behind V1.  Both were traveling at a constant speed.   V2, a 2003 Toyota RAV 4, was eastbound in lane 1 of a 3 lane, 2 way, bituminous roadway approaching the same controlled intersection.  V2 was also traveling at a constant speed.  As V2 passed through the intersection, V1, front, contacted V2, right.  V2 rotated clockwise and was struck on its left side by V3, front.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadways were dry.  V1 and V3 were both driven from the scene.  V2 was towed due to damage.  None of the 3 drivers were injured but the passenger in V2 was injured and transported.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1. The driver of V2 was cited for disregarding a red light.  Some factors which may have contributed to his actions were his unfamiliarity with the road, fatigue and the internal distraction of his conversation with his passenger, his soon to be ex-spouse, about their impending divorce.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V3.  The driver of V3 was properly licensed for and familiar with his vehicle as well as familiar with the roadway. One factor, which may have led to his involvement in the crash, was his sightline to V2\'s approach being obscured by V1.\n           \n

\nThe crash occurred on a fully controlled urban bituminous highway, with two-lanes in each direction divided by a grassy median.  The straight, level road has partially paved shoulders with rumble strips on both sides, and a posted speed limit of 105kph (65mph).  Conditions at the time of the weekday afternoon crash were daylight, clear and dry.  \n\nV1, a 2003 Honda Accord, driven by a 19 year-old female was traveling southbound on her way to work in the left lane at a stated speed of 70mph, on the verge of passing a pick-up truck pulling a closed trailer in the right lane.  The driver of V1 saw the trailer begin to swing into her lane about to contact the right front of her vehicle, and swerved to the left shoulder to avoid the impact.  The driver felt the rear of her car lose control and turned the steering wheel to the right to attempt to reposition her car back onto the road.  V1 slid across the highway rotating clockwise and left the road on the right side.  As the left wheels of V1 left the right shoulder, V1 rolled 4-quarter turns to the left down a -25% sloped grassy embankment, and came to rest on the wheels facing north in some brush.\n\nThe fully restrained driver denied injuries, and V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Pre-event movement of V1 was coded as \'successful avoidance maneuver to a previous critical event\'.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \'This vehicle control loss due to traveling too fast for conditions.\'  The Critical Reason for the critical pre-crash event coded was \'driver related factor-performance error-compensation.\n

\n  V1, a 1997 Ford Escort 4dr, was eastbound in lane 1 of a 2 lane, 2 way, straight, level, bituminous roadway approaching a four way stop intersection.  V2, a 1992 International medium/heavy stake truck >10,000lbs GVWR, was eastbound in lane 1 of the same roadway already stopped at the intersection.  At the time of the crash it was dawn, cloudy and the roadway was wet.  V1, front, impacted V2, rear.  The driver of V1 was injured and transported.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway.  The Pre-event movement of V1 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was Other Motor Vehicle in lane, stopped, and the Critical Reason for the Critical pre-crash event was a driver related factor, driver sleeping.  A major factor on the part of the driver of V1 was that she got only 4 hours of sleep the night before the crash.  She was asleep when she rear ended V2 and took no avoidance actions.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  V2 was stopped behind another vehicle at the stop sign when it was struck.  The driver then looked in his rearview mirror and pulled forward as V1 was under the rear of his truck.  He then walked back and assisted the driver of V1. ../resources/summary/2005011268963.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on an undivided two-way, six-lane roadway on a clear, sunny weekend afternoon.  The straight, concrete road had a slight downward slope and a posted speed limit of 72 kmph (45 mph).  The three vehicles involved in the crash were all traveling southwest in lane three.\n\nV1, a 2002 Ford Taurus driven by a 48-year old female, struck V2 in the back. This impact pushed V2 into V3. The front airbags of V1 deployed, and V1 was towed due to damage. The fully restrained driver was transported to a local trauma center due to a pre-existing heart condition.  .\n\nV2, a 2000 Buick Park Avenue Ultra driven by an 80 year-old female, was traveling around 40 mph when it was struck in the back by V1, and the front of V2 then struck the back of V3.  The driver of V2 observed V1 through her rear-view mirror prior to the crash traveling at a higher rate of speed than V2.  V2 had no time for avoidance maneuvers.  V2 was towed with minor damage, and the fully restrained driver denied any injuries.  \n\nV3, a 1992 Oldsmobile Delta 88 driven by a 56-year old female, was traveling at about 40 mph when it was struck in the back by V2.  The driver of V3 was looking straight ahead prior to the crash and took no avoidance maneuvers.  V3 was drivable after the crash and the fully restrained driver complained of slight back and left hip pain but was not transported.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was "other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with lower speed."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was driver inattention.  Contributing Factors coded to this driver were fatigue due to her many health conditions, the use of many prescription medications that had the possible side effects of drowsiness, nervousness, dizziness, etc. The driver stated that on a daily basis, she took 14 prescribed medications and 5 over the counter products. Her health problems included congestive heart failure, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, overactive thyroid, kidney insufficiency, arthritis, depression, and acid reflux.  The driver also was late for church, and had concerns on her mind related to her health and job. The driver claimed that she had made a U-turn prior to the crash, and upon turning around, found that the sun was in her eyes and was distracted by it. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was "other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed."  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  Associated factors coded to this driver were her 8 prescribed medications that she took for diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and thyroid problems. The driver of V2 also had a hearing impairment for which she was not wearing her hearing aid. \nNo Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to V3 because it was not involved in the first harmful event.  An associated factor coded to this driver was her use of 10 unidentified prescribed medications for arthritis.\n

\n  V1, a 2002 Ford Ranger pickup, was westbound in lane 2 of a 2 lane, 1 way, bituminous, interstate roadway negotiating a curve to the right.  V1 ran off the roadway to the left, re-entered the roadway-swerved right and left then slid off the roadway to the left side and rolled over with the right side leading 2/4 turns.  At final rest V1 was on its roof facing north.  The single occupant of V1 was uninjured but V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A partial driver interview and a complete vehicle inspection were obtained for V1. After these initial interviews, the driver refused to give any further information on the crash.\n\n  The Pre-crash movement of V1 was negotiating a curve, the Critical pre-crash event was This Vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side and the Critical Reason for the critical pre-crash event was an unknown driver recognition error. \n\nThe crash occurred on a weekday afternoon on a fully controlled, four-lane highway, divided with a grassy median without a positive barrier.  The level roadway was curved right in the southbound lanes, and left in the northbound lanes.  The posted speed limit was 113 kmh (70mph).  The conditions at the time of the crash were sunny, clear and dry.  \n\nV1, a 2004 Ford Explorer driven by a 31 year-old female, was southbound on the road in the left travel lane.  The driver had left home 42 minutes before and was on her way to a graduation ceremony.  A non-contact vehicle in lane one swerved into V1\'s lane.  V1 swerved to the left onto the shoulder, paved with a rumble strip.  The driver of the Explorer steered back to the right and re-entered the roadway on the left.  The driver steered back to the left again and V1 left the roadway on the left. When the left side tires got into the gravel V1 began to rotate counterclockwise and continued into the grassy median with the right front leading, down a >2% slope, and then up a >2% slope.  V1 began to roll with the right side leading facing northeast into the northbound highway lanes.  The front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in lane one as V1 was rolling.  V1 came to rest facing southwest on its\' wheels after rolling 8 quarter turns.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage, and the fully restrained driver was transported to a local trauma center.\n\nV2, a 2003 Harley-Davidson Sportster motorcycle, driven by a 19 year-old male, was northbound in lane two traveling about 65 mph, per a witness passed by V2, moments prior to the crash.  V2 moved to lane one where it impacted V1. The driver and motorcycle came to rest on the right shoulder of the northbound lanes near V1.  The state required helmet worn by the motorcycle driver was a \'peanut\' style, without a full chin guard, which came off of the driver\'s head and landed off of the right side of the road. The driver of V2 sustained fatal injuries at the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was   \'incorrect evasive action\' from the previous critical event.   An Associated Factor coded to this driver was for her prescribed medication for depression with possible side effects of dizziness, sleeplessness, drowsiness, tiredness and anxiety.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other motor vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n

V2, a 1999 Ford F-150 pickup truck, was stopped in lane 1 of the same roadway facing south waiting to make a left turn.  At the time of the crash it was daylight but cloudy and raining.  Both drivers were properly licensed for their vehicles.  Both drivers were familiar with the roadway.  V1, front, contacted V2, back.  The driver of V1 was injured and transported.  V1 was towed due to damage. \n  A complete driver interview and complete vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver stated that he saw V2 but when he tried to stop, his vehicle \xe2\x80\x9chydroplaned\xe2\x80\x9d and he was unable to avoid contacting the back of V2.  The Pre-event movement of V1 was going straight, the Critical Pre-crash event was Other Motor Vehicle in Lane, Other vehicle stopped, and the Critical reason for the critical pre-crash event and Decision error, Too fast for conditions.  Some factors for V1 that contributed to the crash include the wet roads; the driver not realizing that caution was required due to the wet roads and the limited experience of the young driver.\n  A complete driver interview and complete vehicle inspection was obtained for V2. There were no driver performance factors coded for the driver of V2.\n  There appeared to be no drug, alcohol or fatigue factors on the part of either driver.

\nThe crash occurred on a weekday afternoon on a two-way, two-lane rural bituminous road.  The level road had an unposted speed limit of 89kmh (55mph).  The conditions at the time of the crash were daylight, cloudy and dry.  \n\nV1, a 1997 Mercury Tracer, driven by a 24 year-old male, was traveling eastbound on the road in a right hand curve.  The driver, who was on his way home from work dozed off while driving and crossed the centerline.  The front of V1 struck the front of V2 in the westbound lane.  The front airbags deployed and V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver was transported from the scene to a local trauma center due to injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'driver related factor-sleeping.\' Contributing Factors coded were \'work-related stress\' for this driver who stated he has a history of panic attacks and experiences high anxiety, and was thinking about a pending unrealistic delivery schedule.  The driver stated he either dozed off or was \'dazed out\'.  The driver\'s prescribed anti-anxiety medication has possible side effects of sleeplessness, drowsiness, tiredness, and nervousness.\n\nV2, a 1996 Jeep Cherokee Sport, driven by an 88 year-old male, was going straight traveling westbound just entering the left hand curve when struck by V1.  The driver of V2 did not see V1 until just prior to impact due to a non-contact vehicle right next to V2 in the eastbound lane ahead of V1.  V1 \'just popped out from behind the other car and there was no time to avoid the crash\' stated the driver during the interview.  The airbags deployed and the fully restrained driver and 73 year-old female right front passenger were transported to a local trauma center due to injuries.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over the left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n

Summary 075\n  V1, a 2000 Ford Econoline van, was westbound in lane 1 of a 2 way, 2 lane, bituminous, ->2% grade, straight roadway.  At the time of the crash the roadway was dry and it was dark.  V1 exited the roadway to the left, V1, front, struck a tree, then continued straight.  V1, front, then struck another tree with it\'s front left, ramped to the right, rolled over 1 quarter turn, struck another tree then came to rest on it\'s right side.  The driver was uninjured.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver stated that 3 deer were entering the roadway from his right and he swerved left to avoid them.  Evidence at the scene did not support this scenario but indicated instead a gradual run off road.  There was no evidence of attempted braking either on the road or off.  The driver was properly licensed for and familiar with his vehicle.  He was not found to be familiar with the roadway.  The Pre-event movement of V1 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was V1 traveling off the edge of the road on the left side and the Critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was poor directional control.  Some factors contributing to the crash include impairment of the driver by alcohol, open intoxicant in vehicle at the time of the crash (observed on-scene by the researcher), driver fatigue and his unfamiliarity with the roadway.   \n

\n\nThe crash occurred at an urban 4-legged intersection.  The conditions at the time of the weekday afternoon crash were clear and dry, and there was a moderate amount of traffic.  \n\nV1, a 1999 Chrysler 300, driven by a 56 year old male, was stopped at a stop sign on a two-way, two lane, straight, level bituminous road with a speed limit of 40kmh (25mph).  V1, after stopping for 5 seconds, checked left and right for traffic on the cross street, and then proceeded northbound across the other road.\n\nV2, a 1994 Ford Crown Victoria taxi cab on duty, driven by a 47 year old male with a 53 year old female passenger in the right back seat, was traveling westbound in lane one on a straight, 5 lane roadway.  V2 was going uphill on the concrete road, with a posted speed limit of 64kmh (40mph).  \n\nA witness traveling in the lane behind V2 noticed V1 crossing the road and realized V1 was on a path to strike V2.  The witness stated that neither vehicle braked or swerved to avoid the crash.  The front of V1 struck the left passenger side of V2 in lane one of the 5- lane roadway.  V1 then rotated counterclockwise and the right side of V1 contacted the back left corner of V2.  V1 left the roadway on the northwest corner and came to rest 38 meters from the point of impact facing west.  V2 rotated clockwise and left the roadway on the same corner and came to rest facing northwest.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nThe fully restrained driver and rear seat passengers of V1, ages 2 and 5 years old, refused treatment.  The fully restrained driver, and the 53 year-old female, unrestrained back right passenger of V2, was transported to a local trauma center due to injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash event coded to the driver of V1 was "This vehicle traveling-crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'Internal distraction.\'  The driver of V1 stated that he stopped at the stop sign, looked both ways for traffic, thought it was clear, and began to cross the intersection.  The driver noticed that the 2 year old in the back right child seat was attempting to stand up and began to tell her to sit.  The driver stated that he looked straight and then used the rear view mirror and turned around to yell at the child, while proceeding across the street.  \n\nContributing Factors were coded because the driver had many concerns related to his family and financial situation on his mind.  The crash happened after a court appointment regarding his daughters, and on his way to pay off his debts.  An Associated Factor was coded for possible side effects from the prescribed medication he takes for a disabling depression disorder and high blood pressure that include dizziness, drowsiness, sleeplessness and confusion.  In addition the driver stated that whenever he has his daughters, like the night before the crash, his sleep is very interrupted.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment-from crossing street, across path\'.  The Critical Reason was not coded to V2.  A Contributing Factor coded to the driver of V2 was \'impending problem masked by traffic flow.\'      \n

\n\nThe crash occurred at a four legged intersection controlled by an on-colors traffic signal.  Conditions at the time of the evening, weekday crash were clear and dry at the unlit intersection.\n\nV1, a 2003 Mercury Mountaineer driven by a 70 year-old female was southbound on a two-way, 3-lane, straight, level, bituminous road with a posted speed limit of 89 kmh (55mph), stopped at a red traffic signal.  The driver of V1 turned left on the red signal at the intersection to proceed east onto the other road, and was struck by V2.  \n\nV2, a 2002 Peterbuilt 357 CBE tractor trailer semi-truck pulling an empty trailer, driven by a 44 year-old male, was westbound on a two-way, 4 lane road.  The straight, level bituminous road had a posted speed limit of 89 kmh (55mph).  The driver of V2 had just shifted through his last gear and was traveling at 35 mph approaching a green light at the intersection.  The driver noticed V1 moving across his lane from the right, making a left turn, and put on his brakes well ahead of the intersection.  The front of V2 struck the left passenger area of V1.  \n\nV1 rotated counterclockwise and came to rest in the intersection facing east.  The side curtains in the Mountaineer deployed, and the fully restrained driver was transported to a local trauma center where she was treated and released with only a complaint of pain.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  V2 slid into the lane on the left after the impact and came to rest still facing west.  The fully restrained driver reported no injuries and the truck was drivable.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection\'.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'Inattention-daydreaming.\'  The driver stated that she was stopped for 5-10 seconds, enough to see 5-6 cars go by on the other road.  A Contributing Exterior Factor was coded because as her attention wandered, and she saw a northbound vehicle turn east, she thought the light must be green for their road, although the northbound car was legally turning right on a red signal.  Associated Factors were coded for possible side effects of her prescribed medications including dizziness, sleeplessness, anxiety, tiredness and nervousness.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\n\n

\n\nThe crash occurred on a straight, bituminous, two-way, two lane rural road with a posted speed limit of 89 kmh (55mph).  The conditions at the time of the weeknight crash were dark, clear and dry.\n\nAccording to witnesses interviewed at the scene, V1, a 1998 Saturn SL sedan, driven by a 39 year-old male on his way home, was traveling westbound on a >2% downhill slope.  V1, which was in front of the witnesses for a period of about 8 miles, was observed weaving back and forth across the lanes, alternately leaving the road on the right and then crossing the centerline and onto the left shoulder, while driving below the posted speed limit. After a vehicle passed V1 on the left, V1 accelerated and began to drive above the speed limit, while continuing to weave.  The witnesses were on a cell phone with emergency personnel to report the actions of the Saturn, when they caught back up to V1, where V1 had just struck V2 in the westbound lane. \n\nV2, a 2002 Dodge Dakota ST pick-up truck driven by a 31 year-old male, was traveling eastbound on the road when the front of V2 struck the left side of V1.  The fully restrained driver, 12 year-old front right and 6 year-old back left passengers were transported to a local trauma center.  V2 came to rest off of the road on the south side facing east and was towed from the scene due to damage.  \n\nV1 had left the roadway on the right, reentered the road, crossed the centerline, and then steered back to the right just prior to impact.  The unrestrained driver of V1 was ejected from the vehicle, and sustained fatal injuries as he impacted the ground in the westbound lane.  V1 came to rest facing east and was towed from the scene due to damage.   \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V1 was \'this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'other decision error,\' related to the driver\'s impaired ability due to a medically reported blood alcohol level of .21.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to the driver of V2 was \'other motor vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  An Associated Factor was coded for possible side effects of the prescribed pain medication the driver was taking for a recent leg surgery. Some of the effects include light-headedness, dizziness, and sleepiness.\n\n\n

\n\nThe crash occurred on a fully controlled urban highway divided with a median guardrail, with a posted speed limit of 105kph (65mph).  The two southbound lanes become four lanes, with the two left ones curving onto another highway.  Conditions at the time of the evening weekday crash were dark, wet and raining on the straight and level bituminous roadway.  \n\nV1, a 1994 Toyota Paseo driven by a 43 year-old female, was traveling southbound in lane one approaching an interchange area.  The driver of the Toyota had left her home 4 hours before, stopped for coffee, and 20 minutes later was only midway through her trip to a neighboring state.  The driver was unfamiliar with the exact location of the ramp to the eastbound lanes, and when she saw it at the last moment, she sharply turned the steering wheel to the left, losing control of the vehicle on the wet pavement.  V1 began to hydroplane and rotate counterclockwise, crossing 3 lanes and leaving the roadway to the 70cm wide paved shoulder, and dropping onto the dirt.  V1 went down and up the other side of a ditch and rolled with the left side leading 4 quarter turns and came to rest facing southeast.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver refused medical treatment.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'other decision error\'.  The driver saw the highway split at the last moment in the dark and rain, and decided to try to make the cutoff from lane one.  Contributing Factors were coded for the wet pavement; low tread on rear tires, and driver\'s unfamiliarity with the road, which she rarely drove.\n\n\n

\n  V1, a 1996 Ford Thunderbird, was westbound in lane 1 of a 2 lane, 2 way, straight, level, bituminous roadway.  V2, a 2005 Lincoln LS 4dr, was also westbound in lane 1 of the same roadway following a non-contact vehicle that was traveling approximately 10mph under the speed limit.  At the time of the crash, it was dark and there were no adverse conditions.  V2, who was about 1.5 car lengths behind the non-contact vehicle, started to pass it on the left, activating his left turn signal as he did so.  V1, approaching the rear of V2 from about 100 hundred yards back and going 10 to 15mph faster than V2, steered left to pass V2.  V1 had overtaken V2 and had left lane 1 and was in lane 2 when the driver of V1 noticed V2 moving into lane 2 its left blinker activated.  V1, right, contacted V2, left in a sideswipe type crash.  V1 steered left, braked, partially exited the roadway (onto the shoulder) to the left, re-entered the roadway, spun 270 degrees clockwise and struck a streetlight pole on the north side of the roadway with V1\'s right side.  V1 continued to rotate clockwise 90 coming to rest facing west just off the roadway to the north.  V2 continued west and came to rest on the north edge of the roadway, as did the non-contact vehicle.  No one was injured in the crash.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be driving on a suspended license, was fatigued and had just worked 9.5 hours.  He was familiar with the vehicle and drove the roadway daily.  The driver also tested positive for alcohol when given a PBT test at the scene.   The Pre-event movement of V1 was passing or overtaking another vehicle, the Critical pre-crash event was Other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with lower steady speed and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was the decision error by this driver going too fast to be able to respond to unexpected actions of others.  Some related factors include his fatigue, failure to look far enough ahead, false assumption of other road user\'s actions, aggressive driving habits and emotional concerns with his employer. \n \n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway.  The pre-event movement of V2 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was traveling in same direction with higher speed and the Critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n  \n

Conditions at the time of the dawn crash were clear and dry on the road, which had an unposted speed limit of 89kmh (59mph).  Traffic was heavy in all directions.\n\nV1, a 2000 Ford F150 XLT pick-up truck, driven by a 37 year-old male, was southbound in the left turn lane, stopped, waiting to turn eastbound.  When the light changed from green to yellow, V1 began to turn left, assuming the oncoming northbound traffic would stop for the red signal.  \n\nV2, a 2003 Honda Pilot, driven by a 40 year-old male, was northbound in lane one in a line of traffic, some of which were turning right.  As V2 approached the intersection, the light changed to yellow.  V2, traveling at a reported 45 mph, decided to continue through the intersection, assuming V1 would not complete his turn.  \n\nAs V2 headed straight for V1, both drivers braked and steered to the west, and the front right of V2 struck the front right of V1 in the intersection.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.  Both fully restrained drivers denied injuries, as well as the two children in child safety seats in the second row of V2.\n\nThe Critical Precrash event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'Driver related decision error-false assumption of other road users actions.\'  There were no contributing or associated factors coded to V1.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \' other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. \n  V1, a 1995 Chevrolet Lumina APV minivan, was making a boulevard turn from lane 4 of a westbound, 2 lane, and bituminous roadway with 2 left hand turn lanes to cross 2 one-way eastbound lanes of a 4 lane boulevard.  V2, a 2000 International medium/heavy refrigerated, straight truck, was eastbound in lane 2 of the 2 eastbound lanes of the same boulevard.  V1 rolled the stop sign and began to cross the eastbound lanes when the driver of V1 noticed that traffic was backed up across the boulevard.  She hesitated in the intersection instead of proceeding across.  V2 saw V1 enter his lane from his left, steered right and braked. preprocessing
\n\nThe crash occurred on an entrance ramp to a fully controlled, divided with a positive barrier, urban highway with a posted speed limit of 105 kmh (65mph).  Conditions at the time of the morning crash were daylight, clear and dry on the straight, level, bituminous roadway.\n\nV1, V2, and V3 were all traveling south on the entrance ramp intending to merge into lane one of the southbound road during rush hour traffic.  Two/three vehicles were in the lead, followed by V3 which was in front of V2.  Behind V2 was a non-contact vehicle, which was in front of V1.\n\nThe lead vehicles, unable to merge into traffic, came to a stop at the bottom of the ramp.  V3, a 2001 Toyota Camry driven by a 32 year-old female, and V2, a 2004 Lexus GX470, driven by a 42 year-old male, also stopped safely.  The driver of V2 noticed the vehicle behind him brake successfully but swerve to the right as if to go around V2 on the shoulder, then swerve back to the left and dart swiftly into the highway traffic. \n\nV1, a 2003 Dodge Grand Caravan, driven by a 31 year-old female, was driving about 40mph behind the line of traffic, when the vehicle in front of her suddenly braked, swerved to the right and then to the left and swung into the line of moving traffic on the highway.  The driver of V1 saw V2 stopped in the lane immediately ahead of her, applied her brakes, and the front of V1 struck the back of V2.  The front of V2 was pushed into the back of V3, causing minor damage to both vehicles.  \n\nV1 was towed from the scene due to damage, with the front airbags deployed.  V2 and V3 were drivable following the crash.  The fully restrained drivers of all 3 vehicles, and the 19 month-old passenger restrained in a child safety seat in row two of V1, denied injuries.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event code to V1 was \'other motor vehicle in lane, stopped.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'driver related error-too fast to be able to respond to unexpected actions of others.\'  \'Inadequate surveillance\' was coded as the driver \'failed to look far enough ahead\', and \'following too closely\' during the rush hour, in heavy traffic.  Also coded was \'false assumption of other road user\'s actions\', because the driver of V1 assumed that the other drivers would continue to proceed.  A Contributing Factor of \'rush hour congestion\' was coded for all 3 vehicles in the crash.\n\n The Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\nV3 was not involved in the first harmful event.\n

Summary 087\n\n  V1, a 1997 Ford Crown Victoria taxi cab, was westbound in lane 2 of a straight, level, 5 lane, bituminous, urban roadway.  At the time of the single vehicle crash it was dark but lighted and the roadway was dry.  V1 drifted left across the center turn lane and both oncoming lanes and exited the roadway to the left.  V1, front, struck a utility pole, severing it and came to rest facing west.  The driver called his office and someone came and picked him up so he left the scene and returned when the police and HVA were notified later.  He returned to the scene when requested by police.  He was uninjured but V1 was towed due to damage.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was properly licensed for and familiar with the vehicle.  As an employee of a taxi company, he was just returning to his home yard after dropping off a fare 12 miles away.  He was nearing completion of a 12-hour shift that began at 7pm the previous evening.  The driver stated that V1 experienced a mechanical malfunction that caused the vehicle to veer left and that the brakes did not respond when applied.  Inspection of the vehicle did not reveal anything to support this claim.  The Pre-event movement of V1 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was the driver related factor of the driver sleeping, falling asleep at the wheel.  Though the driver denies falling asleep at the wheel, scene evidence does not support his claim but rather indicates a gradual run-off-road with no attempts at avoidance actions.  Factors contributing to the crash include the length of hours that the driver had worked before the crash, the absence of any evasive actions by the driver, the performance error by the driver to maintain proper control over the vehicle and the driver being fatigued at the time of the crash.  After leaving the scene, the driver had gone home and gone to sleep.  Alcohol was not involved.\n\n \n
../resources/summary/2005011269223.json
preprocessing
\n\nThe crash occurred on a two-way, two lane, straight, rural road with an unposted speed limit of 89kmh (55mph).  Conditions at the time of the early morning weekday and dawn crash were clear.  The bituminous road was predominately ice covered.  Interviews were obtained from both drivers and both vehicles were inspected.\n\nV1, a 2006 Chevrolet Cobalt, driven by a 55 year-old female, was eastbound on the road traveling at about 45 mph approaching a railroad crossing.  The driver stated during the interview that she travels this route daily and always brakes and slows to cross the tracks.  As V1 braked and contacted the first set of tracks, the vehicle began to skid and rotate counterclockwise and the driver lost control of the Cobalt.  V1 continued across the second set of tracks and over the centerline into the westbound lane.\n\nV2, a 2001 Chevrolet Express 3500 cargo work van, driven by a 50 year-old male on his way to work, was westbound on the road, approaching the tracks.  While still 30 meters away, the driver, traveling at 35 mph on the icy road, saw V1 lose control and the driver of V2 began to brake.  V2 had slowed almost to a stop in lane 1 just prior to the tracks, when V1 crossed the centerline and the front of V1 struck the front of V2.  \n\nV1 came to rest on the south shoulder facing north.  V2 came to rest on the north shoulder facing northwest.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.  The unrestrained driver of V2 denied injuries.  The restrained driver of V1 was transported from the scene to a local trauma center.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle control loss due to traveling too\nfast for conditions.\'  The Critical Reason coded to the driver of V1 was \'Decision Error-too fast for icy conditions.\'  The driver stated that she had driven on the road to drop her son at school and was on her way back down the road, and did not realize the road was icy and that she needed to go slower.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n
../resources/summary/2005011269224.json
preprocessing
\n\n  V1, a 2005 Chevrolet Aveo 4dr, was westbound in lane 2 of 2 westbound lanes of a bituminous, interstate roadway, having a center median with a positive barrier, curving left.  V1 was overtaking V2, a 2001 Freightliner medium/heavy truck tractor pulling a single semi trailer, in lane 1 of the same roadway.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and the roadway was dry but the shoulders were icy.  As V1 was beginning to pass V2, V2 drifted to the left crossing the line-separating lane 1 from lane 2.  V1 braked and steered left, went onto the left shoulder, lost control on the ice, re-entered the roadway to the right and impacted the left rear wheel of V2\'s trailer with it\'s front.  It then spun clockwise onto the inside shoulder where it struck the median guardrail with it\'s right rear and came to rest on the shoulder facing east.  V1 was towed due to damage.  Neither driver was injured.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver stated that V2 drifted into her lane just as she was beginning to pass and she had to take evasive actions.  She was properly licensed for and familiar with her vehicle but only traveled on the roadway monthly.  The Pre-event movement of V1 was passing or overtaking another vehicle, the Critical pre-crash event was Other Vehicle Encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction) - over right lane line and the critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver only had 2 years experience driving a semi tractor-trailer truck but he seemed very professional and like his job.  I do believe that the reason he tracked the actions of V1 before the impact was because he drifted left out of his lane and quickly checked his side mirror to see if any traffic was there.  The Pre-event movement of V2 was negotiating a curve, the Critical pre-crash event was This vehicle traveling over the line on the left side of travel lane and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was the driver\'s performance error of poor directional control.  Factors contributing to the crash may include the roadway\'s curvature to the left coupled with his poor directional control while negotiating it.    \n\n\n  \n
../resources/summary/2005011269243.json
preprocessing
\n\nThe crash occurred at 4 legged urban intersection controlled by an on-colors traffic signal.  Conditions at the time of the weekday, afternoon crash were cloudy and dry.  Interviews were obtained with both drivers and both vehicles were inspected.\n\nV1, a 1995 Oldsmobile Achieva, driven by a 22 year-old female, was southbound on a 3 lane, straight and level concrete road traveling in lane one stopped at the intersection on a red traffic signal.  Per witnesses, V1 started into the intersection on the red signal and the right side of V1 was struck by V2.\n\nV2, a 1996 Ford Explorer, driven by a 55 year-old male, was eastbound on a 5-lane straight and level concrete road approaching the same intersection with a green traffic signal.  The driver of V2 had no time for avoidance maneuvers.  The front of V2 struck the right side of V1.  V1 then rotated counterclockwise while V2 rotated clockwise, and the right back of V1 struck the left passenger area of V2.  V2 came to rest facing south in lane one of the south leg of the intersection.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The airbags in V2 deployed and the fully restrained driver denied injuries.\n\nAfter the sideslap with V2, V1 continued to the southeast corner of the intersection and left the road striking a small post with the front left.  V1 then struck a fire hydrant with the front right corner.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver was transported due to injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'inadequate surveillance-looked but did not see.\'  The driver of V1 stated in the interview that she was totally alert and was sure the signal had turned green when she proceeded into the intersection.  After considering the witness statements, the police believed the signal was red for V1.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V2 was \'other motor vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.\'  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n\n

Summary 2005-091\n  V1, a 1995 Chevrolet Cavalier, was westbound in lane 3 (a left turn lane) of a bituminous, 5 lane, 2 way, urban roadway.  V2, a 2003 Honda Civic, was eastbound in lane one of the same roadway.  V1 attempted to turn left across V2\'s path into the driveway of an apartment complex.  At the time of the crash it was daylight and cloudy, the roadway dry.  V2, front, contacted V1, right.  V1 was towed due to damage.  The driver of V1 was injured and transported.\n  A complete vehicle inspection was obtained for V1 but the driver refused to grant an interview.  Through personal observation at the scene, the police UD 10 and the medical report the following information is known.  The driver was intoxicated at the time of the crash and was believed to be returning to his home.  His medical history did reveal his use of some prescribed meds.  The pre-event movement of V1 is unknown; the Critical pre-crash event is V1 turning left at intersection and the Critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was an unknown type of driver error.  It should be noted that a major factor in the cause of the crash was the impairment of V1\'s driver by alcohol.  His vehicle did not have the right of way.\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway.  The driver stated that she was going the speed limit in lane 1 when V2 turned in front of her.  The Pre-event movement of V2 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was other vehicle encroachment from the opposite direction -over left lane line and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n  Even though the crash happened during daylight hours, it was very cloudy.  \n   \n

\n\nThe crash occurred on a two-way, two-lane straight, level, bituminous residential street with a speed limit of 40 kmh (25 mph).  Conditions at the time of the weeknight crash were cloudy, dark, and dry.\n\nV1, a 2001 Kia Sephia, driven by a 28 year-old female, was southbound on the road when it left the travel lane and the front of V1 struck the back of a legally parked, unoccupied vehicle on the right side of the road.  V1 pushed the parked V25 meters where V1 came to rest against it.  Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to damage.  The driver of V1 was transported to the Police Department to undergo a Breathalyzer, where she recorded a Blood Alcohol level of .21.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded to V1 was \'this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the right side of travel lane.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coded was \'internal distraction.\'  The driver stated during the interview that she heard something fall and looked down and reached with her right hand to get it, and ran into the parked car.  A contributing factor was coded for alcohol consumption.  The driver stated that she had been drinking at home two miles away and was driving to the store when she had the crash.  \n
../resources/summary/2005011583083.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a 5 lane not divided roadway.  There were 2 lanes in each direction with the middle lane as the turning lane.  The roadway had a posted speed of 56 KMPH (35 MPH) and it was level.  Conditions were daylight and dry with clear skies.  The crash occurred near mid afternoon on a weekday.  \n\nV1, a 1999 Chevrolet Prism 4dr, was westbound in lane 2 of the roadway.  V2, a 1991 Toyota Corolla 4dr was also westbound in lane 2 of the same roadway in front of V1.  V3, a 2000 Ford Focus 4dr, was westbound in lane 2 stopped in front of V2.  V1 changed lanes partially into lane 1 then returned to lane 2.  Traffic in lane 2 was slowing for backed up traffic ahead.  V1\'s front, contacted V2\'s back, as it was slowing to a stop which caused V2 to accelerate forward, then contacting, V3\'s back.\n\nThe Chevrolet Prism (V1) was driven by a 20-year old male who was uninjured in the crash.  He stated that he was in lane 2 looking to move into lane 1 and as he began to move into lane 1 another vehicle speed by him.  To avoid being hit, he swerved back into lane 2 just as V2 was slowing down for traffic.  V1\'s front contacted V2\'s rear.  V1 was driven from the scene with minor damage. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was when this vehicle traveled over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was a decision error, misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed.  The driver was taking a blood pressure medication that was thought not to contribute to the crash.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  He was not late or in a hurry and speed did not seem to be a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to his actions but he was cited failing to maintain an Assured Clear Distance.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that mechanical defects contributed to the causation of the crash.  \n\nThe 50-year old female driver of the Toyota Corolla (V2) stated she was slowing for traffic in lane 2 when she was struck from behind by V1.  She then lost control of her vehicle and struck V3 in the rear.  The driver of V2 was transported, treated and released from the hospital.  The Corolla was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was other vehicle traveling in same direction with higher speed and the Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.  The driver was myopic (near sighted) and was wearing her glasses at time of the crash.  She was taking blood pressure medication that was thought not to contribute to the crash.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle. She was not late or in a hurry.  There were no indications of fatigue, medical complications or mechanical defects as being a factors contributing to the crash on the part of V2.  \n\nThe 43-year old female driver of the Ford Focus (V3) stated that she had just come to a stop in lane 2 when she was struck from behind by V2.  The driver of V3 was transported, treated and released from the hospital.  V3 was driven to the tow yard, which was across the street.   \n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of the Focus because he was not involved in the first harmful event (the impact between the front of the Prism and the rear of the Corolla).  The driver was myopic (near-sighted) and was wearing her glasses at the time of the crash.  She was taking medications for allergies and asthma, some of the side effects are, tremors, dizziness and fainting, shakiness, and nervousness, but was thought not to contribute to the crash.  The properly licensed driver of V3 was familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway.  She was running an errand on her lunch hour and was neither late nor in a hurry.  There were no indications of fatigue or medical complications on her part.  No mechanical defects were found to be present for V3.  \n
