preprocessing
V1, a 1999 Mazda 626 4dr sedan with 3 occupants, was eastbound in lane 1 of an interstate, bituminous, straight, level, divided traffic way -median strip with positve barrier (trees).  At the time of the daylight crash, it had been raining and the roadway was still wet.  The driver of V1 reported that he was proceeding eastbound when a truck in lane 2 began to merge into lane 1 contacting his left quarter panel with it\'s right front bumper.  V1 rotated counterclockwise across lane 2, exited the roadway into the median still rotating counterclockwise, struck a tree >10cm with it\'s left quarter, then spun counterclockwise to final rest facing north. (It should be noted that the truck allegedly involved, stopped and remained at the scene until the investigating officer let him go after determining that he had not impacted V1.  There are photos included in the case of the semi-truck.  The officer determined that V1 lost control and spun out in front of the semi truck).\n  \nAll 3 occupants of V1 were transported, treated and released.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n  \nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was from out of state, had been driving for close to an hour and was eating at the time of the crash.  He was an experienced driver, properly licensed for the vehicle and familiar with it.  He was not familiar with the road but was not in a hurry.  There were no indications of fatigue, emotional or work stress evident though he was eating and conversing with other occupants at the time of the crash.  He had also had recent surgery to c3 and c4 but that was reported as not restricting his driving.  He reported not having taken any prescribed drugs the day of the crash.  No citations were issued in the crash.  \nThe pre-crash movement for V1 was going straight, the critical pre-crash event was traveling off the edge of the road on the left side and the critical reason is unknown.\n\nThere were no indications that drugs or alcohol were a contributor to the cause of the crash.     \n
../resources/summary/2005011583163.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1994 Saturn SL1 4dr, was eastbound in lane two of a bituminous, three-lane, straight, flat, urban roadway.  V2, a 1992 Ford Crown Victoria, was eastbound in lane two behind V1.  V3, a 1992 Ford Taurus, was eastbound in lane two behind V2.  The roadway had two eastbound lanes and one westbound lane.  At the time of the daylight crash, the roadway was dry and there were no adverse weather conditions.  Vehicles 1 and 2 had just started accelerated from an intersection controlled by a traffic light when they saw a police car with lights and siren activated coming at them in lane one westbound.  They both decelerated with V1 changing lanes to the right and V2 preparing to do the same.  V3 had slowed when approaching the light and then accelerated when the light turned green.  Past the intersection, V3, front, contacted V2, rear.  V2, front, then contacted V1, rear.  V3 was towed due to damage.  Vehicles 1 and 2 were drivable.  The driver of V3 was injured and transported from the scene.\n\nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1. The Critical Pre-crash Event was not involved in first harmful event; the Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n  \nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the vehicle and the roadway and was properly licensed for the vehicle.  The Critical Pre-crash Event was other vehicle traveling in the same direction with higher speed; the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n  \nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V3.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle and was properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was not late or in a hurry but did report that she was irritated and upset about family issues.  She had been fighting a cold and had taken Tylenol the night before the crash.  She had begun to accelerate when the light turned green and then begun to cough, closing her eyes.  Her cell phone rang while it was lying on the passenger seat and she reached for it even though her eyes were closed.  As she hit the answer button and looked up she saw that V2 was coming to a stop in front of her and she had no time to react.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event wasother motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction while decelerating; the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was the distractions of coughing with eyes closed and reaching for the cell phone.  Associative factors for this crash were the driver was irritated when she awoke and was thinking about a family problem at the time of the crash.\n  \nA witness interview with a school crossing guard substantiated the crash events detailed within this summary. \n
../resources/summary/2005011583223.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2004 Honda Element, was exiting lane 1 of 3 eastbound lanes of a 6 lane interstate.  The long exit ramp was one lane, cement, level and curved right.  At the time of the crash it was dusk, unlighted and the roadway was dry.  There were no adverse weather conditions.  V2, a 2003 Saturn Vue, had run out of gas 1/3 of the way up the same exit ramp and was parked on the right shoulder, outside of the travel lane\'s right fog line, occupied but not running.  The front right of V1 sideswiped the left rear of V2.  V2\'s final rest was approximately 1 meter forward of the point of impact.  V1 continued up the ramp approximately 110 meters and stopped on the left shoulder.  \n\n  The driver of V2 was transported.  The driver of V1 was uninjured. Both vehicles were towed due to damage.\n\n  Complete driver interview and vehicle inspections were obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle and he was properly licensed for the vehicle.  He was not late, had been driving <1/2 hour and speed did not seem to be a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to his actions, but he was cited in the crash.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that the mechanical condition of the vehicle contributed to the causation of the crash but the driver did state that \xe2\x80\x9cthis vehicle seemed wider than any he had driven\xe2\x80\x9d and may have been uncomfortable with it\'s feeling of width.  \n\nDriver 1\'s pre-event movement was negotiating a curve, the Critical Pre-crash Event was V1\'s movement over the lane line on the right side of travel lane, and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was poor directional control.  Contributing factors in the crash could include the absence of lights or flashers on V2 and Driver 1 being intimidated by the apparent width of his vehicle. Driver 1 was assigned an associated factor for inadequate evasive action.  There were no indications that drugs or alcohol were a contributor to the cause of the crash.
../resources/summary/2005011583303.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred in the eastbound lane of a 2 lane, 2 way, level, ice covered, bituminous roadway curving left.  At the time of the morning crash light was dawning, there were no adverse weather conditions but a recent snow squall had left the roadway ice covered.  \n\nV1, a 1998 Jeep Grand Cherokee, was westbound in lane 1 of the roadway.  V2, a 1999 Pontiac Grand Am, was eastbound in lane 1 of the same roadway.  V3, a 1993 Mitsubishi Mirage, was also eastbound in lane 1 of the same roadway a short distance behind V2.  As V1 approached a non-contact vehicle on the right shoulder, the driver of V1 applied the foot brakes thinking the NC vehicle might pull onto the roadway.  V1 lost control, rotated counterclockwise and southward across the centerline into lane 1.  V2, front, contacted V1, rear.  V1 continued to rotate counterclockwise while V2 came to rest on the north shoulder facing east.  V3, left, then contacted V1, left, and came to rest on the south shoulder.  V1 continued to rotate counterclockwise and came to rest on the north shoulder facing east.  All three drivers were injured, transported, treated and released.  All three vehicles were towed due to damage.\n\nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver stated that she was going down the road following a line of cars at about 64-72kph (40-45mph).  There was a vehicle on the right shoulder.  She thought he was going to pull out in front of her so she put on the brakes and slid out of control.   \n\nThe movement of V1 was negotiating a curve, the Critical Pre-crash Event was this vehicle traveling too fast for conditions and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was slick roads due to ice.  She was not late or in a hurry having traveled less than 30 minutes but reported that even though \xe2\x80\x9cshe knew the roadway was very slick, she was just keeping up with traffic flow of 64-72kph (40-45mph).\xe2\x80\x9d  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle.  She was also properly licensed for the vehicle.  There were indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to her actions but she was cited for traveling too fast for conditions.  The vehicle inspection revealed no indications that the mechanical condition of the vehicle contributed to the cause of the crash.\n\nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection, with EDR download, was obtained for V2.  The driver stated we were in the eastbound lane on the road going about 72kph (45mph).  She had noticed and was talking about how slippery the road was.  She saw the Jeep spin out of control and come across into her lane right in front of her.  She hit the Jeep and then the Jeep hit the car behind her.  \n\nV2\'s movement was negotiating a curve, the Critical Pre-crash Event was another vehicle encroaching from the opposite direction-over left lane line and the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle.  She was also properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was not late or in a hurry on her way to work and excessive speed did not appear to be a factor.  There were no indications that fatigue or medical complications were contributing factors to the crash.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications of mechanical malfunction or disrepair.\n\nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V3.  The driver stated that he was eastbound on the road, there were two vehicles in front of him V1 and V2.  Then V1 spun around and ended up perpendicular to his car.  He hit the brakes and his car swung clockwise and V1\'s left back hit V3\'s left door.\n\nV3 was not involved in the first harmful event and the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle. There did not appear to be any drug or alcohol use by any of the drivers, which contributed to the cause of the crash.   The driver was familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle.  He was properly licensed for the vehicle and had been commuting to work along a familiar route for less than 1 hour.  He was not late or in a hurry and excessive speed did not appear to be a factor for V3.  There were no indications of fatigue or medical conditions as being contributing factors on the part of this driver.  No mechanical deficiencies were found when inspecting V3.  The movement of V3 prior to recognition was negotiating a curve.

preprocessing
V1, a 1997 Mercury Tracer, was eastbound in lane 2 of a straight, 4 lane, bituminous, 2- way, non-divided, urban roadway with an uphill grade >2% intending to turn left at a controlled intersection.  V2, a 2002 Ford Windstar, was westbound in lane 1 of the same roadway passing through the same intersection.  At the time of the daylight crash, the roadway was dry and there were no adverse weather conditions.  Several non-contact vehicles heading westbound were stopped in lane 2 at the intersection waiting to turn left.  V1 attempted to turn left and was struck on its right side by V2\'s front.  Both vehicles were towed due to damage.  The driver of V2 was injured and transported.\n  \nA complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be familiar with both the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was not late or in a hurry and excessive speed was not a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to her actions.  V1\'s Pre-Event Movement was stopped in traffic lane; the Critical Pre-Crash Event was turning left at intersection; the Critical Reason was Inadequate Surveillance.  A recognition factor was that the impending problem was masked by traffic waiting to turn left in lane 2 of the oncoming lane.  She tried the turn even though she could not adequately see the presence of the oncoming traffic in lane 2.\n  \nA complete vehicle inspection was obtained for V2 but the driver refused to give an interview.  It is unknown whether the driver was familiar with the car or the road but the police on-scene said he was properly licensed for the vehicle.  It is unknown if he was late or in a hurry but sources at the scene did not indicate that he was speeding or driving aggressively.  The driver was proceeding through the intersection when V1 pulled across his path.   His Pre-Event Movement was going straight; the Critical Pre-Crash Event was other vehicle encroachment - from the opposite direction-over left lane line; the Critical Reason for the Pre-Crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.  It is unknown if fatigue or medical complications contributed to his reactions/actions during the crash.  There were no indications that drugs or alcohol were a contributor to the cause of the crash.
../resources/summary/2005011583443.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1999 Ford Escort 4dr, was northbound in lane 1 of a 2-lane undivided bituminous, straight, urban street with a positive grade greater than 2 percent. The northbound roadway was controlled by a stop sign.  V1 proceeded to turn left from that street onto a 4-lane undivided bituminous roadway without a stop sign.  V2, a 2005 Ford Explorer Sport Trac, was eastbound in lane 2 of the roadway that V1 was attempting to turn westbound onto. The eastbound roadway had a negative grade greater than 2 percent and a posted speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph). At the time of the late afternoon daylight crash there were no adverse weather conditions but the roadways were wet.  The front of V2 contacted the left side of V1.  Both drivers were transported due to injuries.  V1 was towed due to damage.  The driver of V2 tried to flee the scene but was apprehended by police.  V2 was drivable but the driver was suspected of driving while intoxicated and was later arrested, and so the vehicle was towed to the local police department.\n\n  A complete inspection was obtained for V1 but the driver refused to grant an interview.  The vehicle inspection yielded no indications that the mechanical condition of V1 contributed to the crash.  It is unknown whether fatigue, driver inexperience, the lack of vehicle/road familiarity, or aggressive driving contributed to the crash.  It is known that the driver of V1 was cited for driving with a suspended license that was also expired and for failure to yield.  The driver also denied to the officer at the scene that he was the driver of the vehicle.  The Pre-event movement was coded as accelerating in traffic lane, the Critical pre-crash event was that V1 was turning left and the Critical reason for the critical pre-crash event was coded as "type of driver error unknown." Contributing factors to the crash may include the wet condition of the roadway and the driver\'s lack of proper driving skills as indicated by his suspended license.\n\n  A complete vehicle inspection was obtained for V2 but the driver refused to grant an interview.  The vehicle was found to be in excellent condition, a current model year with low miles.  The driver\'s familiarity with the vehicle is unknown but it was registered to him.  It is unknown whether fatigue, driver inexperience, the lack of road familiarity, speed, and/or aggressive driving were contributing factors to the crash.  It is known that the driver of V2 was arrested for Driving Under the Influence and had a BAC of .187 one hour and fifteen minutes post-crash. The Pre-event movement for V2 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was Other Vehicle Encroachment from crossing street, turning into opposite direction and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was not coded to this vehicle.  Contributing factors to the crash include the wetness of the roadway and the use of alcohol.
../resources/summary/2005011583463.json
preprocessing
The crash occurred on a clear, dry weekend mid-morning in an interchange area at the intersection of a roadway crossing over an interstate highway and an exit ramp controlled by an on colors traffic signal.  The level, concrete, one-way, two-lane (with an adjacent right channelized lane) road had a posted speed limit of 64kmh (40mph) and a downhill slope >2%. The traffic signal had turned green and a line of traffic was still at a complete stop. V2 was stopped behind V3 in lane one heading northeast.  \n\nV1, a 1989 Plymouth Reliant, was traveling northeast in lane two at 40-48kmh (25-30mph) behind a cargo van.  The 55 year-old female driver stated that she was uncomfortable driving behind a vehicle without windows because she could not see anything in the road ahead.  The driver of V1 changed lanes to the right and immediately saw that traffic in lane one was stopped.  The driver applied the brakes and V1, not equipped with anti-lock brakes, skidded longitudinally and then impacted V2.  The front of V1 struck the rear of V2.  The driver of V1 was cited for \'Careless Driving\'.  V1 came to rest in lane one facing north, partially in lane one, with the right rear of V1 on the right shoulder.  V1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver was transported to a local trauma center where she was treated and released.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V1 was \'other motor vehicle in lane-other vehicle stopped.\'  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was \'inadequate surveillance\' as the driver of V1 changed lanes without being able to safely see the traffic in the next lane.  A Contributing Factor of a \'sight line restriction\' was coded because the non-contact van right in front of V1 in lane two blocked her view of traffic ahead in lane one.  Associated Factors coded for this driver are related to health conditions and prescribed medications taken for diabetes, high blood pressure, cholesterol and a mild thyroid condition.  Possible side effects include headache, fatigue and dizziness, although these effects for all four medications are listed as mild or less common.  Additional health conditions are bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, a herniated disc at L5, and an impinged shoulder.  The driver stated that those conditions do not affect her driving and she had taken no medications for them.  The driver does not work due to medical disabilities.  The driver reported no fatigue, emotional or stress issues and was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway. The driver was experienced and properly licensed and was not in a hurry.  There were no vehicle defects found during inspection and police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  \n\nV2, a 1996 Plymouth Neon driven by a 16 year-old female, after impact with V1, was pushed forward into V3.  The front of V2 struck the rear of V3, a 1997 GMC Jimmy.  The front of V2 under rode the back of V3.  V2 came to final rest partially under V3 with both vehicles facing northeast in lane one.  V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver sought medical treatment from a local trauma center by private transportation, where she was treated and released, following the crash.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event coded for V2  \'other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  There were no Contributing Factors coded for this driver.  She was properly licensed and familiar with both her vehicle and with the roadway.  She reported no health or emotional concerns or stress.  The driver was wearing her required corrective lenses for a myopic condition.  Associated Factors include the driver having a social conversation with the passenger, and her birth control prescribed medication with no reported side effects that might affect driving.  Neither of these was thought to have contributed to the crash.  There were no vehicle defects found during the inspection.  Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe 53 year-old female driver, who was fully restrained and uninjured in the crash, drove V3, the 1997 GMC Jimmy, from the scene.  The Critical Precrash Event and the Critical Reason were not coded to V3.  The properly licensed driver reported no emotional or stress related concerns.  She was not fatigued, and was familiar both with her vehicle, and with the roadway.  There were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.  Associated Factors coded for this driver are related to her prescribed medications taken for diabetes, high blood pressure and menopause.  Possible side effects for the blood pressure medication are headache, dizziness and fatigue.  Possible side effects for the menopause medication are blurred vision, tiredness, dizziness, nervousness and weakness, and additionally carries a warning that the drug \'can make you tired; be careful when driving\'.   As the driver of V3 was stopped in traffic when struck, these were not thought to have contributed to the crash.

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the early evening hours during the week in the westbound lanes on a fully controlled, limited access urban freeway with a posted speed limit of 113kmh (70mph).  Conditions at the time of the crash were daylight with heavy rain.  The straight, level, concrete roadway was wet as V1, a 1997 Jeep Grand Cherokee began to merge from the entrance ramp.  \n\nThe 31 year-old female driver reported that the vehicle began to hydroplane as she was trying to move from the merge lane to the first travel lane at approximately 72kmh (45mph).  The driver began to brake lightly but said that it only made it worse and then the front of V1 began to spin to the left.  The driver tried to steer to the right and then to the left but the Jeep continued to spin counterclockwise until it was facing east and had moved across all three-travel lanes.  V1 crossed the paved shoulder and then slid down the grassy median embankment where it rolled 6 quarter turns and came to rest on its\' top facing northwest.  Bystanders noticed a small fire in the engine compartment and helped the driver exit the vehicle, while the fire was put out with a fire extinguisher.\n\nV1 was towed from the scene due to damage.  The fully restrained driver did not seek medical treatment following the crash.\n  \nV1\'s pre-event movement was merging.  The Critical Precrash Event coded to this vehicle was \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle loss of control due to poor road conditions-puddling.\xe2\x80\x9d  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded weather related, rain.   A Contributing Factor was coded for the left tires of the Jeep that had low amount of tread and may have been instrumental in the hydroplaning of the vehicle.  An Associated factor was also coded for the driver\'s medical condition of Crohn\'s disease for which she takes prescribed medication.  The driver reported no emotional or work related stress or distractions.  The driver was familiar both with her vehicle and with the roadway.  There were no mechanical defects found during the vehicle inspection. She was properly licensed for the vehicle and was not cited in the crash.   Police did not consider alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.

V1, a 1997 Chevrolet Cavalier 2dr, was exiting a private, dirt driveway facing north turning west onto a rural, gravel, >2% uphill-grade, straight roadway.  V2, a 1999 Dodge Durango SUV, was eastbound on the same rural roadway approaching the private drive.  At the time of the crash it was daylight, there were no adverse weather conditions and the roadways were dry.  V1 turned left out of the driveway and was struck in it\'s left side by V2, front.  V1 was towed to the driver\'s residence (the crash occurred in front of her house) and V2 was towed to a local garage.  The driver of V1 was injured and transported.  The driver of V2 was uninjured.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V1.  The driver was found to be familiar with the roadway and the vehicle as well as properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was not late or in a hurry.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to her actions although she does take allergy pills daily.   The vehicle inspection did not reveal any indications that the mechanical condition of the vehicle contributed to the causation of the crash.  \n\n  The Pre-event movement of V1 was accelerating in traffic lane, the Critical pre-crash event was turning left at intersection and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see).  Factors contributing to the driver\'s actions include sun glare, a mailbox and the crest of a hill, all to her left, as she pulled out at the time of the late afternoon crash.  It should also be noted that the driver is small in stature (5\'tall) making her even lower to the ground when seated normally in the vehicle.\n\n  A complete driver interview and vehicle inspection was obtained for V2.  The driver was found to be familiar with the roadway and the vehicle and was properly licensed for the vehicle.  She was also in compliance with the corrective lenses restriction on her license.  The driver was not late or in a hurry and excessive speed or aggressive drive did not seem to be a factor.  There were no indications of fatigue or a medical condition contributing to the driver\'s actions.  The vehicle seemed to be in good mechanical condition when inspected though scene evidence revealed skid marks from only 1 tire.  This could be attributed to the gravel surface of the roadway.  \n\n  The Pre-event movement of V2 was going straight, the Critical pre-crash event was other vehicle encroachment from driveway, across path and the Critical reason for critical pre-crash event was not coded to this vehicle.  \n\n

The crash occurred on the northbound lanes of a North / South interstate. There were two lanes in each direction separated by a positive barrier. The posted speed was 109 Kmph (65 mph). The roadway was dry concrete on a clear weekday morning. The driver of this one vehicle crash sustained moderate injuries and was transported to the local trauma unit.\n\nV1, a 2005 Ford Escape, was driven by a 27 year-old female who stated she was driving about 101 Kmph (60 mph) in lane 1 when the vehicle in front of her swerved to avoid a trash container in the roadway. She stated she steered to the right and does remember looking over her left shoulder to check traffic, but does not remember anything after that.  V1 was at an angle across the two lanes of travel facing into the traffic (southbound). The driver stated she was in good health and on was not taking any medications at the time of the crash. She does wear glasses for Myopic- (near sightedness).\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for this driver was coded This Vehicle Traveling - Off the Right Roadside; The Critical Reason for Pre-crash Event was coded - Poor Directional Control - e.g., failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected. An associated factor was that the driver was new to the area and had only driven this area of the interstate a couple of times.  A contributory factor was that the vehicle was traveling 101 Kph (60 MPH) and had no time to react.  Even though the speed limit is higher it is still present.\n\nA witness interview states that he had his cruise control on at 109 Kph (65 mph) and was overtaking the vehicle, which crashed. V1, a 2000 Pontiac Montana minivan, made a left turn from a private driveway onto a northbound 5-lane two-way, dry asphalt roadway on a downhill grade.  The posted speed limit on this roadway was 80 kmph (50 MPH). V1 entered the roadway by crossing over the two southbound lanes and then entering the third northbound lane, which was a left turn-only lane at a 4-way intersection. The driver of V1 intended to travel straight through the intersection, and so he began to change lanes to the right. He did not see V2, a 1994 Pontiac Grand Am, that was traveling in the second northbound lane. The northbound roadway had curved to the right prior to the private driveway that V1 had exited. As V1 began to change lanes to the right, the front of V1 contacted the left rear of V2 before coming to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 60-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 2-17 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health-related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling back home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition.  He did not sustain any injuries from the crash and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when he began to travel over the lane line on the right side of the travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see). Associated factors coded to the driver of V1 include an illegal use of a left turn lane (cited by police) and an unfamiliarity with the roadway. As per the driver of V1, this was the first time he had driven on this roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 28-year old woman who reported that she had been traveling between 66-80 kmph (41-50 mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health-related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and on her way home.  She does not wear corrective lenses.  She sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when the other vehicle encroached into her lane, from an adjacent lane (same direction) over the left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and no associated factors were coded to her.\n

The conditions were daylight and wet with cloudy skies in the early afternoon on a weekday.\n\nV1, a 1995 Chevrolet Lumina was traveling eastbound. preprocessing
This crash occurred just after the noon time hour where the entrance ramp from a north/south interstate merges with the eastbound lanes of another interstate.  The ramp had a 5% down hill grade with a 160.9 radius of curvature to the right.  The eastbound lanes were straight and level.  It was lightly raining and the roadways were wet.  The speed for the ramp was posted at 113 kmph (70mph) with an advisory speed of 64kmph (40mph) and the interstate lanes had a speed of 113 kmph (70mph).  As V1, a 1997 Pontiac Grand Am, was negotiating the right curve of the ramp (traveling between 51-60 mph) it lost control and began rotating clockwise.  The driver then attempted to regain control which caused his vehicle to rotate counter-clockwise crossing the two lane lines to the left before contacting the right rear corner of V2, a 2000 Jeep Cherokee. V2 rotated clockwise one complete rotation swerving across three lanes of traffic before coming to final rest off the road in the ditch on the south side of the interstate.  V1 after contacting V2 rotated clockwise and then contacted the center median wall with the front of the vehicle. Then rotated counter-clockwise to contact the median wall with the right back corner of the vehicle before rolling to final rest in lane two of the interstate.  \n\n           V1 was driven by a 20 year-old male in very good health on his way home from a relative\'s house. The driver stated as he negotiated the down hill curve the rear of his vehicle rotated clockwise and as he attempted to counter steered he lost control of his vehicle crossing all lanes of travel to contact V2 then contacted the center wall of the interstate.  The driver was uninjured and his vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle control loss due to traveling too fast for conditions.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related error- decision Error, too fast for conditions (too fast on a wet, curved road).  The associated factors were the speed of the vehicle, the wet roads, and low tread depth of the rear tires. \n\n        V2 was driven by a 36 year-old female in good health that was traveling home with the other occupant of the vehicle.  She stated they had been on the road for about 11/2 hours.  She stated that she never saw the other vehicle coming until it was too late and did every thing she could to keep her vehicle under control.  No injuries were suffered and V2 was able to be driven from the scene once it was pulled from the ditch back onto the road.\n\n         The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction) - over right lane line. The critical reason for the critical even was not coded to this vehicle. The only associated factor coded to this vehicle the driver\'s inexperience with the road as she stated she only drove it rarely. \n\n\n \n

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a 4-lane undivided (2 lanes in each direction) level wet asphalt roadway.  It was nighttime but the road was lighted. The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 mph).  The driver of V1, who was traveling eastbound in the second lane of travel, stated he had a clear view of the roadway. The driver of V2, who was waiting to exit a driveway located on the south side of the roadway, stated there was a non-contact vehicle that had been traveling eastbound in the first lane of travel, turning into the driveway he was exiting. The driver of V2 reported that he did not see V1 coming from his left until it was too late. V2 pulled out across the eastbound lanes of travel, intending to turn left and travel west. The front of V1 struck the left side of V2. The driver of V2 stated that he took no evasive actions. The driver of V1 stated that he locked up his brakes.\n\nThe driver of V1 was an 18-year old male who reported he was traveling at a speed between 49-67 kmph (31-40 mph) at the time of the crash. He had no related health problems, and had taken no medications prior to the crash.  The driver states he was rested and going to visit his girlfriend.  The driver did not sustain any injuries during the crash. The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another driver encroached into his lane from a driveway, turning into the opposite direction. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V1 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash. He was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 26-year old male who reported he had no prior health problems and had taken no medications prior to the crash. The driver stated he had stopped but did not see the other vehicle coming.  The driver sustained laceration to his left eyebrow.  He was transported to a local trauma center for his injuries .The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when he began to turn left at the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an \xe2\x80\x9cother\xe2\x80\x9d recognition error because the sight line for the driver of V2 was blocked by the non-contact vehicle that was in the first eastbound lane (getting ready to make a right turn into the driveway). Because the non-contact vehicle was blocking his view, the driver of V2 did not see V1 and entered the roadway in front of V1.  The driver of V2 also reported that he was in a hurry at the time of the crash, due to his work schedule. He was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. In summary, the crash occurred when the driver of V2 began to turn left at a point in time when his view of V1 was blocked by a non-contact vehicle. The fact that he was in a hurry was an associated factor in the crash.\n

This crash occurred at an intersection of two - two-lane, two-way roadways.  V1 was traveling westbound approaching an intersection controlled by a stop sign.  V2 was traveling southbound approaching the same intersection and had the right of way.  The road had a speed of 40 KMPH (25 MPH).  The north, southbound lanes were a level grade and the east west had a -3/122 grade.  Conditions were daylight with cloudy skies and the roadway was wet. The crash occurred in the early afternoon on a weekday.\n\n   V1 a 1986 Chevy pickup, driven by a 43 year-old maile, had slowed for the stop sign, looked both ways, then proceeded to cross the intersection without coing to a full stop.  V2 was approaching the same intersetion and was traveling straight through the same.  V2\'s left fender contacted the front right corner of V1.  V1 rotated counterclockwise facing south in the roadway. V2 after contact proceeded to the southwest corner striking the curb then contacted a tree with the left front corner of the vehicle coming to final rest with the right side of the vehicle making contact to a chain link fence.\n\n   A 21 year-old female, who was later transported to a local trauma center for minor injuries, drove V2, a 1986 Chevy Cavalier.  She stated that she saw V1 approach the stop sign; she assumed the vehicle would stop but it just slowed and did not stop.  She does not remember if she kept her brake on or if she let up on it to try to turn right so she would not make contact to the other vehicle.  She estimated she was traveling 48-56 kmph (30-35 mph) at the time of impact.  There were three other occupants in this vehicle.  The occupant in seat 13 had C-injuries but refused treatment.  The two occupants in the back seat were seat belted but not in child restraint seats; no injuries were sustained.  The vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\n  The Pre-Event Movement for V1 is going straight.  The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded to this vehicle as a Recognition Error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look but did not see).  An associated factor was this driver was going to a Doctor appointment out of town he reported he was on medication for pulmonary lung disease he refused to state medication he was on for his illness.  Another associated factor is that V1 performed an illegal maneuver by failing to stop at the stop sign by slowing and going.  His vehicle was driven from the scene.\n\n   The Pre-Event Movement for V2 was going straight; the Critical Pre-Crash Event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from a crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle.  an associated factor for V2 was that the driver was engaged in a conversation with her back seat occupants at the time of the crash.  The driver of V2 was driving with no license, no insurance, no registration, and no plate onhte vehicle.  Sh also stated she had no driver training.  One child in the back seat was 5 years old the other was 2 years old; neither were in child safety seats.\n\n  The driver of V1 reported that he had stopped for stop sign.  It seems likely that the driver of V1 executed a rolling stop through the stop sign.  He stated that he was late for a doctor\'s appointment at the VA Hospital.

The crash occurred in the eastbound lane one of a 5-lane, two-way roadway.  There were two eastbound and two westbound lanes with a left turn lane in between.  There were no control signals at the crash area the posted speed 64 KMPH (40 MPH); the roadway was of level grade and it was dark but lighted.\n\nV2 was a 1991 Buick Century that was traveling eastbound in lane one; V2 was slowing and had its right turn signal activated and was intending to enter a store parking lot.  As the driver slowed and looked right to observe the other vehicles in parking lot, V2 was struck in the back by the front of V1.  V1, a 1998 Buick LeSabre, was traveling in lane 2 and was in the process of changing lanes into lane 1 not realizing that V2 was slowing to turn.\n\nV2 was driven by a 27- year old female who was transported to a local trauma center with minor injuries. She stated she had just picked up dinner for the family and was stopping at a store for additional items.  She states she had her right turn signal on for 5-10 seconds before the crash. He stated he wanted to change lanes and looked over his right shoulder to check for clearance and then executed the lane change.  He then noticed that V2 was stopped and he could not avoid hitting V2.  The driver was not injured and the vehicle was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was other vehicle in lane traveling at a slower speed and turning right.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a recognition error - inadequate surveillance - looked, but did not see, failed to look.  Associative factors for this vehicle include the driver assumed that the other vehicle would continue to proceed.

preprocessing
V1 was traveling East on a two-way, two-lane, snow cover asphalt roadway with an up hill grade.  The crash took place in the evening on a weekday; the roads were ice and snow covered. \n\nThe driver of V1 stated that she thought the driver of V2 was crossing the centerline of the roadway. She tapped the brakes and started to loss control rotating counterclockwise and the front of V1 contacted the left front of V2.  V2 was traveling West on the same roadway with a down hill grade moving off onto the shoulder of the roadway trying to avoid the crash.  After contact, V1 rotated counterclockwise and came to final rest facing south across both lanes of the roadway.  V2 was pushed against the guardrail on the north side of the roadway to final rest.  The speed is posted at 88 kmph (55mph) the slope is a +5/122\n\nThe driver of V1 was an 88-year old female who stated she was traveling East at a speed of 56-64 kmph (35-40 mph) prior to the crash.  She also stated she has no prior health related problems and the only medication she is taking is over the counter medication for arthritis. She only wears glasses for reading and did not have the glasses on at the time of the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event for V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to poor road conditions (ice and snow covered).  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as other performance error (failed to control vehicle for weather conditions) associated factors included slick roadway and the weather (heavy snow).\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 38-year old male who stated he noted V1 crossing centerline and steered to the shoulder to try to avoid the collision with V1. He stated he was traveling at about 64 kmph (40 mph) on a down hill grade he did apply the brakes without lock-up. He has no prior health conditions and is taking no medication at the time of the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from the opposite direction, over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash. He took the avoidance maneuver needed. He wears glasses to correct a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  Two associated factors were coded to this driver that was coded to the other driver were: weather condition (heavy snow) and roadway conditions (slick). \n

This crash occurred on the southbound side of the north /south interstate.  There were five travel lanes each way with a concrete median wall dividing the highway.  The conditions were daylight and snow with cloudy skies.  The crash occurred in the early morning hours.  The posted speed was 112 kmph (70mph).\n\nV1 was a 2000 GMC Sonoma pickup that was traveling south in lane three.  There was a non-contact vehicle pulling a large trailer filled with snowmobiles passing in lane two. As the non-contact vehicle\'s trailer became even with the front of Vehicle1, the non-contact vehicle began changing lanes to the left.  Driver 1 then tapped the brake, losing control. V1 contacted the median wall with the front of the vehicle, then rotated \xc2\xbc turn counterclockwise making contact with the right rear \xc2\xbc panel to the median wall. V1 then rotated counterclockwise \xc2\xbe of a turn to come to final rest facing south in lane one.\n\nAn 18-year-old female who was treated drove V1 on scene for minor injuries. The driver of V1 stated that she had just entered the highway and moved into lane three for a clear driving lane.  She also stated that lane 4 was clear and lane 5 was snow covered.  The driver stated she was traveling at 72 kmph (45 mph) at the time of the crash. She stated that her classes had been canceled and she was on her way to a Doctor appointment and was in no hurry.\n\nThe pre-event movement for V1 was coded as "Going straight", the critical pre-crash event for V1 was coded "This vehicle loss of control due to traveling too fast", and the critical reason for the Critical Event was coded "Traveling too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users".   Associated factors included the trailer of the non-contact vehicle kicking up the loose snow on the roadway, the snow covered condition of the roadway, and a false assumption on the part of Driver 1.  Driver 1 was also taking medication for anxiety. Driver 1 had taken Ibuprofen for pain, but this medication was not thought to have been a factor in the crash.

There were no control signals; the roadway was straight and a -5/122 slope. The weather condition was daylight, dry, and clear.\n\nV1 was a 1993 Oldsmobile 88 that was westbound in lane two V2 was eastbound in lane two behind another vehicle and was traveling at a constant velocity. A non-contact vehicle was in the westbound lane one and the driver of V1 thought that this vehicle was entering her lane and drifted to the left and crossed the centerline into the eastbound lane two. The front of V1 struck the front of V2.\n \nV1 was driven by a 74-year-old female who stated that she was going home from dropping off a friend, and was traveling at about 59-64 kmph (35-40 mph). A vehicle had passed her on the right side.  As the vehicle passed her she stated that it encroached into her lane and, as she tried to keep from making contact, she crossed the centerline. By the time she realized she was in the wrong lane it was to late to avoid V2.\n\n  V2 a 1993 Chevrolet Pickup, was driven by a 67 year-old male, who states he was traveling eastbound in lane 2. The driver also stated that a non-contact vehicle was traveling in the same lane directly in front of him and abruptly swerved to the right to avoid V1. The driver of V2 stated he could not execute any avoidance maneuvers.\n\nThe Pre-Event Movement for V1 was going straight; the Critical Pre-crash Event was this vehicle over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate evasive action. Associated factors for V1 include 13 medications the driver of V1 was taking for back pain and other sorted illness; she was wearing prescription lenses that corrected a myopic condition; she further stated that she felt tired and usually does when she wakes up.   \n\n  The Pre-Event Movement for V2 was going straight. The Critical Pre-Crash event for V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded for this vehicle. An associated factor was that the driver of V2 was taking building materials to a rental home and was talking to the passenger of his vehicle. The driver wears prescription lenses that correct a myopic condition and is taking medications for Seizures.\n\n  \n\n

This crash occurred on a two-way two-lane roadway on a railroad crossing. This was a car verses Train crash. There was one lane north and one lane south.  This railroad crossing had working lights and bells that controlled the crossing.  The posted speed was 42kmph (25mph) the slope was a +18/122 it was clear, dry and day light hours.\n\nV1 was a 2002 Ford Explorer Sport, which had just turned south onto the roadway, which had a steep incline as the vehicle pulled across the railroad grade the driver heard the bells ringing. The driver tried to back off the tracks but was unable too before being contacted on the right front side of the vehicle by the train.  The vehicle then spun around and hit the train again with its right rear.  It then rolled over 3 quarter turns before coming to final rest on the driver\'s side of the vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V1 a 46-year old female was transported to the hospital with injuries. The driver stated that she was on her way to pick up her paycheck from her employer at the time of the crash. As she started up the grade she stated she had not noted the signal lights flashing or the bells ringing. She stated that after hearing the bells she looked to her right and saw the train was to close to get out of the trains path. After being contacted by the train and rolling to final rest she was able to climb out through the passenger window and walk over to the curb were she waited for the police and EMS to arrive.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded other, (specify) Crossing over railroad grade. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event for V1 was inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see). An associated factor to this driver was she was taking a medication to help her fall to sleep, some possible side effects are drowsiness, dizziness and daytime tiredness, slowness of movement.  She also stated her concern for a daughter\'s baby shower. \n

This crash occurred at a two-way two-lane intersection. There was a flashing control signal (red to the north and south and yellow to the east and west).  The roadways were both posted at a speed of 72 kmph (45mph).  The north side of the intersection has less than a 2% negative slope and the westbound roadway had a positive grade of 2.5%.  It was daylight and the roadway was wet and a light snow had fallen.\n\nV1 was a 1995 Ford Wind Star, which was traveling south decelerating to the stop. As the driver applied the brakes the wheels locked up on the slick roadway. Trying to avoid the crash, the driver steered right. This maneuver was not successful and V1 was contacted in the left drivers side door by the right front of V2. V1 spun off in a clockwise rotation and came to final rest off road in the grass on the north side of the east, west roadway. V2 came to final rest on the south shoulder of the east, west roadway.\n\nA 27-year-old female who drove V1 was transported to a local trauma center with minor injuries.  She stated that she was on her way to work one block away.  She also stated the road seemed clear but must have had black ice. Her vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle loss of control due to poor road conditions (puddle, pot hole, ice, etc.)\xe2\x80\x9d. The Critical Reason for the critical event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cSlick road condition\xe2\x80\x9d. She was wearing glasses to correct a myopic (nearsighted) condition. \n\nV2 was a 2004 Trail Blazer and was driven by a 30-year old female who was not injured, but her vehicle was towed due to damage. She stated that she was on her way home from taking her child to school when the crash had occurred.  She also stated that she tried to stop when she saw the other vehicle, could not stop, and contacted the left side of V1.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 is other vehicle encroachment (from cross street, across path). The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. At the time of the crash, driver 2 was driving into the intersection with the right of way.          \n     \n

V1 had a positive slope to the intersection with a stop sign. V2 had a level grade with no control signal. The North/South lanes had a posted speed of 40kph (25mph) and the East/West lanes had a posted speed of 72kph (45mph). It was a clear/ Dry day and the crash happened in daylight hours.\n\nV1 was a 1997 Ford Crown Victoria that was traveling south on the roadway and had just come to the stop sign.  After stopping and looking right and then left V1 edged forward waiting for several vehicles to pass V1 started into the intersection making contact with the right side of V2 just behind the right front tire. Then turning off to the right coming to final rest across the East and West lanes at an angle. V1\'s driver and V2\'s driver then pushed V1 off the road so as to not block traffic.\n\nV2 a 1992 Pontiac Transport was traveling west on the roadway approaching the intersection. Noticing V1 was entering the intersection V2 braked and started to turn left to avoid making contact with V1. V2 was not able to avoid contact and rotated clockwise skidding off onto the south shoulder of the roadway to final rest.\n\nV1 the Crown Victoria was driven by an 88 yr. Old male that was not injured in the crash. V1\'s driver stated he had stopped at the stop sign and waited for several vehicles to go by as he edged out into the intersection as another vehicle came by he did not see V2 coming and pulled into the path of the oncoming vehicle. The driver was seat-belted with lap and shoulder. \n    \nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was code crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see) this was chosen because the driver had stated he has waited for several vehicles to pass before entering the intersection. An associated factor in the anxiety medication the driver was taking. The medication has a warning about driving vehicles and judgment factors.\n\nV2 was driven by a 20 yr. He also stated he is in good health and had not taken any medications. The driver was seat-belted lap and shoulder.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded from crossing street, across path. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to this vehicle. There was no associated factor for this driver. \n

This crash occurred in an intersection at the mouth of an interstate exit ramp. The intersection was level and controlled by a traffic signal that was functioning properly. The exit ramp had a negative slope of 2.5%. The intersecting roadway had a positive slope of 2.5%. It was dry and daylight with clear skies. The speed was 56 kmph (35 mph). \n\nV1, a 1985 GMC Safari, was traveling in lane 4 of a 7-lane roadway. There were four lanes westbound and three lanes eastbound. As V1 approached the intersection he was initially going to turn left; he decided against turning as he was entering the intersection, changed lanes from four to three, and then attempted to go straight through the intersection. V2, a 2005 International Gravel Transport, had exited the interstate and was approaching the intersection intending to go straight. V1 proceeded through the intersection against a red traffic signal.  As the driver of V1 realized he had entered the intersection on a red light he braked and steered right trying to avoid the collision. V2 applied its brakes and the front of V1 was struck by the right side of V2.  After a subsequent side-slap, V1 came to final rest against the northeast curb of the intersection. V2 continued on for anther 400 feet and came to final at the east curb of the roadway.\n\nV1 was driven by a 34-year-old male who was reportedly not injured in the crash.  He offered that he was well rested and was on his way to pick up lunch. He stated that he had slowed to make a left turn but then changed his mind. He further remarked that if he would not of taken evasive actions he would have been contacted in the driver\'s door rather than at the front.  He admitted that he had not seen the light until it was too late to avoid the collision.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 is Crossing Over - Passing Through an Intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was Inadequate Surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). An associative factor was being in a hurry to get lunch and getting back to work.  He executed an illegal maneuver by failing to stop for a traffic signal.\n\nV2 was driven by a 39-year-old male who was characterized as uninjured. He had only been on the road for about one hour when the crash occurred.  He stated he was decelerating and looking for crossing traffic as he exited the interstate. He further stated that he wears prescription glasses that corrects a Myopic (near sighted) vision. The lenses are photo gray they change in the sunlight.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 is Other Vehicle Encroachment - from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded for this vehicle. An associated factor was the driver was wearing glasses that darkened in the sunlight and the truck he was driving was fully loaded with gravel. This load would make it very hard to decelerate or execute any avoidance maneuver.\n\nIt was later learned that the interior of V1 had an intense smell of alcohol. The driver of V1 was also seen at a corner store sitting on curb drinking a 40oz. beer shortly after the crash.  It\'s impossible to determine whether the driver had alcohol in his system at the time of the crash. \n

She does wear hearing aids.\n\nV2 was a 1998 Pontiac Grand Prix that was driven by a 26-year-old female who was not injured and stated she was in good health. It was in the evening during daylight hours.  The road had a -2/122 slope and the roadway was dry.  The speed was posted at 72 Kmph (45mph).  The driver of V1 was stopped in the left hand turn lane waiting to make a left turn.  There was construction .5 miles to the west in the intersection the traffic was backed up to the east in lane two of the westbound side.  A non-contact vehicle stopped to let V1 make its turn.  As V1 made its turn it did not note that V2 was approaching in lane 1 of the westbound roadway.  V1\'s front right then made contact with the front left of V2. V1 slid counter clockwise to the curb on the north side of the road to final rest, and V2 traveled off into the drive entrance on the north side of the road to final rest. V2 was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nV1 a 2000 Chevy S-10 pick up was driven by a 51 year old male who reported he had been sitting stopped in the left turn lane for about 4 minutes waiting to make a left turn when a vehicle in the westbound lane had stopped to let him make his turn. He also stated he didn\'t stop to check traffic coming in lane one of the westbound traffic because of the construction. He stated that he was not traveling fast because he was entering a restaurant driveway. The driver of V1 has no related health problems but does wear prescription glasses that correct a myopic - near sightedness - condition. This driver was wearing his lap & shoulder belt at the time of the crash he stated that his nose was swollen and his right hand sore but did not want EMS treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as left turn at intersection. The Critical Reason for The Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see).  An associated factor was the driver was wearing glasses for near sighted- myopic and had been sitting in the turn lane for about 4 minutes.  Due to the long wait time the driver may have gotten impatient.  Additionally, the driver was focused partly on the restaurant he intended to dine at.  That may have become an exterior factor contributing to this crash.  The traffic patterns were askew as well due to construction taking place shortly west of the crash site.\n\nV2, a 2000 Dodge Intrepid, was driven by a 41-year-old female who reported she was on her way to pick up something to eat. She also wears prescription glasses to correct near sightedness. She was wearing her lap & shoulder belt and was not injured in the crash.\n\n The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment - from opposite direction - over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Pre-crash Event was not attributed to this vehicle.  Two factors present were the driver\'s corrected vision and diabetes condition.

This crash occurred at an intersection on a four-lane undivided (2 lanes in each direction) level, dry asphalt roadway. This crash happened in the late morning hours on a clear weekday. The posted speed was 72 kmph (45 mph).  The driver of V#1 was driving southbound in lane #1. He stated that he had a clear view of the roadway and noted that the road where he wanted to make a left turn was just ahead. The driver of V#1 then changed lanes to the left and decelerated to a stop. V#2 was traveling southbound in lane #2 on the same roadway and its driver stated that V#1 changed lanes in front of him and suddenly stopped. He said that even though he braked hard and steered to the right, there was not enough space for V#2 to stop. V#2 then contacted V#1 in the rear, pushing V#1 through the intersection and rotating V#1 counterclockwise to come to final rest in the second northbound lane of the roadway. V#2 traveled another 40 ft. before coming to final rest in its original lane of travel (lane #2). \n\n    V1, a 1997 Pontiac Montana minivan, was driven by a 77-year old male who reported he was traveling at a speed of 56-64 kmph (35-40 mph) as he was not familiar with the area. He also stated he had just left paying respect to a friend in a nearby town and was traveling to a rotary luncheon when the crash occurred. This driver also stated that he was in good health despite being on medication for arthritis and acid reflux. He also reported that he wears glasses for a myopic (nearsighted) condition and wears hearing aids due to a 75 percent hearing loss.\n\n   V2, a 2000 Dodge Ram 3500 dump truck, was driven by a 22-year old male who reported he was traveling south at a speed of 64 kmph (40 mph). He reported that he has no health conditions and was well rested. He stated he was running an errand to pick up parts for a truck at home.\n\n   The Critical Precrash Event for V#1 was coded as "Other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction at higher speed." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. Associated factors coded to this driver include:  inattention, distraction by an exterior factor (looking for street signs), a misjudgment of the velocity of V#2, and unfamiliarity with the roadway. Physical factors included myopia, hearing impairment, and taking prescription medications. \n\n    The Critical Precrash Event for V#2 was coded as "Other motor vehicle in lane - other vehicle stopped." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "Too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users," a decision error. Associated factors coded to this driver (in addition to driving too fast) include inadequate evasive action and a hyperopic (farsighted) condition.

This crash occurred on a 4-lane two-way roadway divided by a grass median. The northbound side was closed due to construction. The southbound side was 1-lane each direction. The speed was posted at 56 kmph (35 mph). There were construction barrels marking the lanes. \n\n      V1 was stopped at a stop sign facing east wanting to make a left turn. As the vehicle accelerated into the northbound lane the driver panicked and the vehicle continued turning left traveling off the left side of the road and contacting a utility pole then bouncing back into the southbound lane to final rest. The driver was transported to the local trauma unit were she was treated for her injuries.\n\n      The Vehicle a 2004 Chevrolet Malibu was driven by a 79 year-old female.  She had picked up her grandson and traveled to the bank, the grocery store and was going to her sisters home when the crash occurred.  She stated that she had stopped at the stop sign, there was construction in the area and on the road she wanted to turn left on was closed for construction.  She was directed to take the southbound road which was converted to a two-way road during the construction.  After making her turn she panicked thinking she went down the wrong way on the street.  She went to put her foot on the brake and hit the gas by mistake, she continued turning left traveling off the left side of the road and contacting a utility pole    \n\n      The Critical Precrash Event was coded this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event coding was performance errors - panic.  The associating factors were the drivers\' health conditions, high blood presser, diabetes, poor eyesight, and bad circulation in her feet. The other factor would be that the driver was confused due to entering the construction area thinking she was going the wrong way.

The crash occurred in an intersection joining a roadway containing 4-lanes (2-lanes northbound and 2-lanes southbound) and a roadway containing 4-lanes (2-lanes eastbound and 2-lanes westbound).  The roadway had a -3/122 grade eastbound and a +5/122 northbound grade.  It was daylight and clear and the posted speed was 59 Kmph (35mph). V1 had come to a stop in the second lane of the eastbound lanes traveling next to a non-contact vehicle making a right turn.  This vehicle had a red light.  The driver of V1 thought he had a green light when the driver of the non-contact vehicle made a right turn on the red light.  V1 entered the intersection and V2, which was traveling north in lane 1, entered the intersection and contacted the right side of V1.  V1 rotated clockwise to final rest across the 2 lanes of the east/west traffic.  V2 traveled in the same lane to final rest. The driver of V1 was transported to a local hospital by her mother in a privately owned vehicle.  The driver and passengers of V2 were not injured in the crash.\n\nV1, a 1998 Pontiac Grand Am, was driven by a 28 year-old female who is 25 weeks pregnant and had stated that she had stopped for the red light.  She further added that when the light turned green she entered the intersection.  She saw the other vehicle coming and thought it would stop for the light. \n\nV2, a 1989 Dodge Ram 15-Passenger Van, was driven by a 61 year-old male. He had stated he was transporting 3 female passengers to doctor\'s appointments at the time of the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as This Vehicle Traveling - Crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor - illegal maneuver.  The driver of V1 was focused on the vehicle making a right turn and incorrectly assumed that the light had turned green.  The many associative factors for this vehicle include:  driver focused on extraneous vehicle; false assumption of other road user\'s actions; failed to stop for a TCD; took time off from work for doctor\'s appointment that 15 miles away.\n  \nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as Other Motor Vehicle Encroaching into Lane - Crossing Over and Passing Through Intersection. There was no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle. An associated factor to this driver was he was talking to the passengers of this vehicle. \n\nAn associated factor to V1 was that she was inattentive to the traffic light.  When the vehicle next to her made a right turn on red this driver thought the light was green.  An out-of-town police officer, who witnessed the crash, confirmed that V1 had a red light. \n\nIt was determined that the driver of V1 was driving on a suspended license. The driver of V2 would only give his last name when asked and stated that he would not allow the researcher interview his passengers nor inspect his vehicle.

preprocessing
This crash occurred in an intersection of an east/west and north/south roadway. The east/west roadway was a 3-lane roadway - one in each direction with a left turn lane.  The north side of the north/south roadway was 2-lanes - one in each direction, and the south side of the north/south roadway was 3-lanes - one in each direction and a left turn lane. The posted speed was 56 kmph (35 mph) for the east/west roadway and 48 kmph (30 mph) for the north/south roadway. The intersection was controlled by a traffic signal, which was working properly at the time of the crash. It was early evening but it was still daylight.  V1 was traveling south when it ran the red light, contacting the right side of V2 and rotating it counterclockwise. As it rotated, the right rear of V#2 impacted the left side of V#1. After the first impact, V1 also rotated counterclockwise before coming to final rest facing north in the intersection.\n\n                V#1, a 1996 Chrysler Concord, was driven by a 41-year old female who stated she is in good health and is on no medications at this time and does not wear glasses. She stated that earlier that day she had gotten some bad news and decided to get intoxicated. She does not remember anything about the crash. She does remember coming to in the EMS unit and being told she was in a crash.\n\n               V#2, a 1995 Chevrolet Cavalier, was driven by a 40-year old female who stated that she is in good health, although hypoglycemic. She does not wear glasses. She stated that she was on her way home from picking up her daughter from work and had just left the grocery store parking lot when the crash occurred.\n\n               The Critical Precrash Event for V#1 was coded "This vehicle traveling: crossing over (passing through) intersection." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). An associated factor was that the driver was intoxicated (medical records indicated a BAC of .346) and was diagnosed with clinical depression a few years ago but not taking medication at this time. Other associated factors coded to this driver include inattention, an illegal maneuver, inadequate evasive action, and excess speed. As per a witness who had almost been struck by V1 at the previous intersection, the driver of V1 had crossed the centerline and was traveling at approximately 45 mph. Due to these actions, she was also coded as driving aggressively.\n\n             The Critical Precrash Event for V#2 was coded "Other vehicle encroachment:  from crossing street, across path." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. An associated factor coded to this vehicle was that the driver was conversing with the passenger in the vehicle at the time of the crash. The driver of V2 was also taking a prescription medication to treat anxiety.\n\n           \n             While interviewing the driver of V#1, the researcher heard one of the driver\'s children (who were playing in the yard) comment that their mother had made them get out of her car just before the crash and had just missed hitting 3 or 4 other vehicles.

This crash occurred on the southbound lane of the interstate. There were 3-lanes of travel south with 1-median lane and a median wall dividing North and South travel lanes. The posted speed was 104 kmph (65 mph). The travel lanes slope was 0/122 the roadway was wet from rain it was daylight hours just after the 12 o-clock hour. The vehicle was traveling in lane #2 negotiating a curve when the vehicle loss control rotating counter clockwise traveling off the left side of the roadway and contacting the right front corner of the vehicle to the wall then rotating on to contact the right rear side of the vehicle to the wall and rolling to a stop with the vehicle facing north at final rest.\n\nThe Vehicle was driven by a 22 year-old female who stated that she was well rested and in good health and taking no medication at this time. She also stated that she had gone to her Uncles used car dealer ship to have her vehicle worked on and that her Uncle had let her drive this vehicle for the day. He thought she mite want to buy it after test-driving it so she could upgrade to a newer vehicle. She also stated that the vehicle felt funny from the start of the trip back home, but she said she thought it was because she had never driven this type of vehicle before. She had stated that as she traveled on the interstate and came into the rain the vehicle seemed to get more uncomfortable to drive. As she was negotiating the sweeping right curve the vehicle started to hydroplane and rotate counter clockwise. Then it shot at the wall off the right side of the roadway and hit the wall.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded this vehicle control loss due to: Traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical pre-crash event was coded Performance Errors: poor directional control e.g., failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected. The associating factors are that the driver stated she was traveling at a speed of 118 kmph (70 mph) and it was the first time driving this vehicle. She also stated the vehicle didn\'t feel right from the time she left the lot. \n

This crash occurred on a 4-lane, two-way undivided roadway.  The crash occurred on a weekday evening.  The skies were clear the roadway was dry. The posted speed was 56 kmph (35 mph). Witnesses stated that the vehicle in the crash was traveling at a high rate of speed and was all over all the four lanes. The vehicle then departed the roadway on the right side, traveling on the grass before impacting a traffic light pole, breaking it off.  The vehicle then traveled through the intersection, jumping the curb on the other side and striking a fire hydrant with the left side of the vehicle. It then contacted a bush and a sign in front of the building were it came to final rest. The driver was transported to the local trauma unit for his injuries. The vehicle was towed from the scene due to extensive damage.\n\nThe vehicle was a 1993 Ford F150 pick-up driven by a 59-year old male who stated that his doctor had put him on a strong antidepressant for both depression and sleep problems. He stated he was on his way to his son\'s home and while driving, the medication put him in a very relaxed state and after that he cannot remember anything. The driver reported that he has no other health problems and wears glasses only for reading.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event was coded "This vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side." The Critical Reason for the Critical event was coded as aggressive driving. Associated factors include the use of both illegal drugs (opiates, cocaine) and prescription medications - as per medical records, he was taking both an antidepressant and a muscle relaxant. Medical records also indicated that this driver suffered from manic depression. The driver of V1 reported that he was told earlier in the day that his mother had been taken to the hospital in poor health. Excess speed was also thought to be an associated factor.\n\nWitnesses stated that the driver was traveling at a high rate of speed and was traveling all over all four lanes of travel, running vehicles off the road and almost making contact to the vehicle of one of the witnesses. After making contact to the traffic light pole and breaking it off, the light pole made contact to the second vehicle listed on the police report. V#1 did not contact this vehicle.\n \nThis researcher had a long conversation with the driver trying to pick up little things about the crash. The driver stated that he does not remember anything about his mother but did know he was going to his son\'s home for some family problem. He also stated he was going to rehab for his drug problem. This driver left the hospital against the hospital\'s advice as stated in medical reports.\n\n

This crash occurred in lane 6 of a 2-way roadway with 3-lanes of travel going west and 2-lanes of travel going east and a left turn lane in the center. The posted speed was 72 kmph (45mph) the roadway was dry asphalt and level. The crash occurred during the mid day rush hour. \n\nThe driver of V1 was stopped in the left turn lane-facing west waiting to turn into a gas station. A none-contact vehicle traveling in the opposite direction came to a stop and waved the driver of V1 to go ahead and make his left turn. After a short glance the driver of V1 started across the eastbound lanes of travel then being contacted by V2 who could not come to a stop in time. V2 then contacted V1 on the right side of his vehicle rotating V1 counter clockwise and coming to final rest with the rear of the vehicle on the curb. V2 rotated clockwise with final rest still in the lane of travel.\n\n           V1 a 2000 Toyota Echo was driven by a 25 year-old male who stated he had come to a stop in the left turn lane and was waiting for traffic to clear. After waiting for several minutes an eastbound vehicle stopped and waved the driver of V1 through. The driver stated that he did not check the traffic like he should have and started his turn. This driver stated he was in good health and was not on any medications at the time of the crash.\n\n      The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded, this vehicle traveling: turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded recognition error: inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). \n\n         V2 a 2002 Chevrolet Venture Van was driven by a 28 year-old male who stated he and his family were traveling home after picking up birthday party supplies. He also stated he had just left the traffic light at the last intersection and did not feel he was to full travel speed for the roadway due to heavy traffic. The traffic was stopped in the second lane and in the turn lane. There was a truck in lane 2 blocking his view, the next think he knew a car crossed in front of his vehicle.  He didn\'t have much space to stop, he does remember locking up his brakes and glancing left and right.  There was no space to try for the left lane and the big interstate sign was on his right.  After we hit he just went forward and to the right just a little to final rest.  This driver stated he is in good health and he stated he works 3rd shift.\n\n    The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded, other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line. There was no Critical Reason coded to this vehicle.
