This crash occurred at an intersection in a rural area. The posted speed limit was 88kmph (55mph). There were two lanes of travel east & west one in each direction. And two lanes of travel north & south. The north & south travel lanes had the stop signs for the intersection with advisory sign\'s stating cross traffic does not stop. The east & west travel lanes slope where level and the northbound lane was a +2%, the southbound lane was +2.5%. It was a clear weekday. V1 had been following another vehicle because he was not familiar with this road of travel. V#2 was traveling west approaching the intersection when V#1 did a rolling stop and continued on into the intersection into the path of V#2. V2 contacted V1 on the left side at the driver door area rotating V1 counter clockwise and then coming to final rest across the ditch on the southwest side of the roadway. V2 rotated counter clockwise coming to final rest facing in the opposite direction on the southwest shoulder of the roadway. Both vehicles were towed due to damage. The driver of V#2 was transported to the local trauma unit. The Driver and passenger of V#1 were removed to the state medical examiner\'s office.\n\n          An 84 year-old male that was a fatality in the crash drove V1, a 2000 Buick Regal. Friends of the occupants of V1 that where on scene stated that the driver was in very good health for his age and that he did wear hearing aids at the time of the crash. They also stated that the driver had cataract surgery a year ago so the only time he wears glasses was to read.\n\n           The Critical Precrash Event for V#1 was coded this vehicle traveling: Crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded Recognition Error: inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see. An associated factor was that the driver\'s normal road of travel was under construction so he was following another vehicle that was showing him the way around the construction when the crash occurred.\n\n          V2 a 2002 Cadillac Deville was driven by a 71 year-old female, which refused the interview. Her insurance representative contacted me and stated that the driver of V#2 did see the vehicle come up to the stop and slow but not stop. There was nothing she could do to stop or do any avoidance actions.\n\n         The Critical Precrash Event for V#2 was coded Other Vehicle Encroachment: from crossing street, across path. The Critical reason for the critical event was not coded for this vehicle.\n\n          The witness\'s for this case were friends of the driver of V1 the #1 witness was driving the vehicle that the driver (V#1) was following this witness stated that he saw V#2 and knew he had time to cross in front of the west bound vehicle. After crossing he thought of his friend following him. When he looked in his rearview mirror all he saw was dust. He never saw the crash happen.\n\n            The 2nd witness was a very good friend of the occupants of V#1 he helped with the health of the driver and had stated at the scene that this was typical of this driver to not be focused on signs.\n

This crash occurred on a weekend evening on a two-way, two lane roadway. The driver was driving southbound, negotiating a curve when he lost control of the vehicle he was driving. The roadway was dry asphalt. The speed that was posted was 56kmph (35mph) the advisory speed was posted at 48kmph (30 mph) for the curve.  The Slope was level on the roadway and the S. E. was -12/122 to the curve. The vehicle in the crash came to final rest on the east side of the roadway after making contact with a group of trees.\n\n    The Vehicle driven was titled as a 1977 Chevrolet T-Bucket. This vehicle was driven by a 59 year-old male whom was DOA at the scene of the crash. This researcher found that the driver was negotiating a curve in the roadway, the backend of the vehicle lost traction in the curve sliding off the asphalt onto the gravel shoulder. As the driver tried to regain control of the vehicle it came back onto the roadway going across both lanes of travel then leaving the east side of the roadway and shoulder traveling across the grass to contact the front of the vehicle to the trees ejecting the driver at final rest.\n\n    The Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as performance error, overcompensation. This researcher found that this driver was in good health at the time of the crash. His daughter stated that while going through his home after the funeral she found out that he was a boarder line Diabetic. Another associating factor was that the vehicle was not equipped with seat belts. This researcher had found out that this driver lived in the area of the crash at one time and may have been going to visit someone. He knew the roadway very well so this researcher feels the driver may have been speeding at the time of the crash.
../resources/summary/2005012694782.json
preprocessing
\nThe crash occurred on the northbound side of a six-lane interstate. There were three lanes of travel, with one paved median lane with a positive barrier wall on the median side (west side) and a paved shoulder (east side).  This part of the interstate was curved to the right.  The slope was level and it had a super-elevation of  +3/122; the radius of curve was 281.45. The posted speed was 104kmph (65mph).  The roadway was dry and there were no adverse weather conditions. The interstate surface was cement.\n\nAs V1 was negotiating a right curve, the LF tire sustained a \'blow-out.\'  The driver admitted that the tire was repaired two days prior to the crash using \'fix-a-flat.\' As the LF wheel deflated and pulled to the left, the driver responded by overcompensating and steering hard right.  The vehicle traveled over two lanes of travel before departing the roadway and contacting an entrance sign.  The vehicle began to overturn left-side-leading two-quarter turns onto its roof.  The vehicle slid across an entrance lane on its roof before striking a curb, which initiated a third quarter turn almost fully onto its right side; before completely on its right side however, V1\'s wheels and undercarriage struck the inner wall of an overpass.  After striking the wall V1 returned to its roof and slid to final rest.  The driver was treated at the scene and the vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nA 17 year-old female, who had stated that she was in good health and was not on any medications at the time of the crash, drove this vehicle, a 1996 Saturn SLR. She also stated she does not wear glasses or contact lenses. She stated that she was traveling about 112 Kph (70 mph) and negotiating a right curve on the interstate when she felt the vehicle vibrating very hard and pulling to the right. She stated that she steered back to the left but the vehicle still pulled right. She further offered that, upon realization that she was going to strike a street sign, she again attempted to pull hard left; but after realizing the crash was imminent, she stated that she just held on and closed her eyes.  She also reported that after the crash she initially thought she was entrapped; however, she was able to free herself prior to the arrival of emergency personnel.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as Vehicle Control Loss - Blow Out / Flat Tire; the Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was a Vehicle Related Factor - Tires / Wheels Failed.   An associated factor was that the driver panic and froze after the vehicle began rotating.  She also mentioned that she oftentimes feels fatigued and inexperience could also have contributed to the crash.\n\nReview Note:  There is a conflict between the driver\'s statement and final coding.  The driver states that the vehicle pulled right and she attempted to steer left out of the rotation.  It is believed however that the opposite occurred.  When the LF tire blew out physics dictate that the vehicle will pull left and history shows that drivers, especially inexperienced ones, overcompensate in the opposite direction.  Despite the super-elevation, which was 2.4%, the dynamics involved are indicative of what has been deduced.\n\n\n

preprocessing
\n This crash occurred on a weekday in the late afternoon in the daylight hours. The weather was cloudy. The crash was on a 4-lane 2-way undivided roadway. There were vehicles parked in the curb lane on the either side of the roadway. The posted speed was 48 kmph (30 mph) and the roadway was straight and level. V1, a 1986 Chevy Sport van, was traveling south in the second lane of travel when it departed its lane of travel and contacted the left rear of V2, which was legally parked in the curb lane. V1 then pushed V2 down the roadway and up onto the sidewalk. V1 then contacted V3, another legally parked vehicle, at its left back corner and pushed it onto the sidewalk also. V3\'s final rest was partially on the sidewalk and partially in the curb lane.\n\n               V1 was driven by a 42-year old female who stated that she had taken a medication earlier that should not be taken when driving. She had not planned to drive anywhere that day but had received a call to pick up her son because he had no other way to get home. She also stated that she thought that she could make it to pick up her son and get back home before the medicine "kicked in." As it happened, as she drove south on the roadway, she blacked out. After that she could only recall being told by someone to sit on the curb until EMS got to the scene. She then remembers being in the emergency room at the hospital. She stated that she had been diagnosed as a manic-depressive. She was taking a pain reliever, a muscle relaxant, and a stomach medication. This driver was transported to the local ER for minor injuries. The driver told hospital staff that she had taken a higher dosage of the muscle relaxant medication than was prescribed. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n               The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as "this vehicle traveling over the lane line on right side of travel lane." The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a critical non-performance error - the driver blacked out from medication. This driver stated she should have not been driving while on these medications. The use of the prescription medications was coded as an associated factor, as was fatigue and the fact that the driver was a manic-depressive. Other assciated factors coded to this driver include being in a hurry and conversation with her children prior to the blackout.\n\nWitness #2 reported driving on the same roadway as the driver of V1 prior to the crash. She stated that V1 had cut in front of her V2 times and after the second time, she stopped her vehicle in her travel lane to wait and see where V1 was going to go before continuing. She also stated that after seeing the crash, she saw a young boy climb out of the right passenger side window and run off. A young girl came out passenger rear door. The witness stayed with the girl until the child\'s grandparents came to the crash scene and the police released her.     \n\n

\n                 This crash occurred on a straight four lane roadway with two lanes in each direction. The roadway was level. It was a clear weekday evening. The posted speed was 76 kmph (45 mph). V1 was stopped waiting on traffic to clear before entering the roadway. As V1 entered the roadway V2 was traveling south in lane 2 at posted speed. V2 could not stop or do an evasive action and then made contact to the left side of V1.  V2 then traveled on to the next drive entrance and turned in to parking lot for final rest. V1 rotated counter clockwise and then going back into the store lot to final rest.\n\nV1 a 2000 Cavalier was driven by a 34 year-old male who stated that he had been to the store to return bottles and was on his way back to his grandmother\'s home. He had looked both ways and thought he had enough time and room to pull out into the roadway.  He thought the other vehicle was speeding because as he pulled out he was hit and spun around.  The car was knocked into nutral and ended up in on coming traffic.  He also stated that he was in good health he wears glasses for hyperopic (far-sighted) and stated he was wearing them at the time of the crash. He also stated he was diagnosed as Bipolar Manic depressive.  But he is on medication and has no problem at this time.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded: This Vehicle Traveling: # 27 Crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the critical event was coded: Recognition Error, #113- Inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see.). An associated factor may have been the fact that the driver is Bipolar he seems to be very defensive about the crash and the traffic on the roadway. \n\n            V2 a 2004 Explorer was driven by a 57 year-old male who stated he was on his way to visit his son. He stated that he had slowed in the area of the crash because of other crashes in that area. He was in lane 2 a little back of the car next to him in lane 1.  The next thing the driver saw was a red car pulling out of the store lot.  He locked the brakes and looked right to see if he could get over and steered right and hit the car pulling out .  He spun around and swerved into lane one and turned into the next driveway.  The driver stated he is in fair health he is off on medical disability due to having 1/3 of his lung removed due to isocyanate poisoning. This driver stated he was diagnosed with sleep apnea and does use a CPAP treatment.  And he does wear glass for unknown condition.\n \n         The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded: Other Vehicle Encroachment: # 70 from driveway, across path. No Critical Reason was coded for this vehicle.\n                 \n\n                                         \n
../resources/summary/2005012694904.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a four-lane undivided roadway with two lanes in each direction. The crash occurred at a railroad crossing. It was a cloudy weekend afternoon. The posted speed was 56 kmph (35 mph). The pre-crash slope was level, but at the railroad crossing the slope was +3 percent. V#2, a 2001 Chevrolet Lumina, was traveling in lane #2 and slowed for the railroad crossing because of rough roadway. V#1, a 1996 Chevrolet Cavalier, was also traveling in lane #2, following V1. V2 was traveling at a constant velocity and did not realize that V1 was slowing. At the last minute, the driver of V#1 put on the brakes and steered left to avoid hitting V#2; however, the front right of V1 contacted the left rear of V2. Final rest for V#1 was in its original travel lane but slightly over double yellow lines to the left. V#2 was pushed to the right but stayed in its original lane.\n\n       V#1 was driven by a 40-year old female who stated she was not familiar with the area, as she had just moved into the area.  She also stated that she had a habit of looking both ways as she came to any railroad crossing. As she approached this railroad crossing, she looked both to the right and the left, looking for any trains. When she looked back straight ahead, she saw that the vehicle in front of her had slowed almost to a stop. There was no time to avoid the other vehicle. This driver stated that she was in good health - that she wore glasses for reading only and had been diagnosed with anxiety and depression but had not taken her medication that morning. Associated factors coded to this driver include the use of prescription medication, unfamiliarity with the roadway (this was the first time she had been on this stretch of road), and a false assumption of other road user\'s actions, in that she assumed that V2 would continue over the tracks at a normal speed.  \n\n        V#2 was driven by a 49-year old female who had stated she was on her way home from the library and was traveling west on the roadway. As she came to the railroad crossing she had slowed down because the tracks were in bad condition. She also stated that she normally looks in her rear view mirror but for some reason that time she did not. She also stated that she was in fair health. She is diabetic and was diagnosed with breast cancer and had just started chemotherapy. She was taking prescription medications for diabetes and cancer treatments.\n\n    The Critical Pre-crash Event for V#1 was coded: Other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction while decelerating. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an external distraction. The Critical Pre-crash Event for V#2 was coded: Other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason for Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to this vehicle.\n
../resources/summary/2005012694922.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred at an intersection on a weekday afternoon. There were 4 lanes of travel on the north/south roadway (two each direction), and on the east/west roadway there were 2 lanes eastbound and one lane westbound. V2, a police vehicle, was traveling north in lane two with its lights activated but no siren. V2 entered the intersection at the same time as V1, a passenger vehicle traveling east. The front of V1 impacted the left side of V2. V2 then skidded off onto the northeast curb. V1 rotated counterclockwise and came to final rest in the center of the intersection. The posted speed was 56 kmph (35 mph) on the east/west roadway (V1) and 48 kmph (30 mph) on the north/south roadway (V2).  There was a properly working traffic light at the intersection. The roadway was level and dry.\n\n           V1, a 1994 Buick Century, was driven by a 19-year old male. He stated that he was traveling east into the intersection on a green light. He also stated that he did not hear or see the lights or siren on the police vehicle. The driver also stated that he was in good health and was not on any medications. He does not wear glasses. This driver reported that he had just picked up the vehicle from a person who said he could have it if he wanted it, and that it would be junked unless he took it out of their yard.\n\n         V2, a 2004 Chevrolet Impala (police vehicle), was driven by a 53-year old male. The surrogate interviewee stated that the driver of V2 was traveling north on the roadway, traveling to a silent dispatch with lights activated, but no siren. He stated that as the driver approached the intersection he did not see the other vehicle due to a vehicle parked on a lawn at the intersection. He also stated that the driver assumed that all traffic would yield the right of way to him.\n\n        The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded: This vehicle traveling - crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). An associated factor coded to this driver was inattention to the driving task. The driver admitted that he was thinking about the vehicle as he drove it and this was his first time driving it. There was also a sight restriction coded, as there was a non-contact vehicle parked on a lawn at the intersection that partially blocked his view.\n\n        The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded: This vehicle traveling - crossing over (passing through) intersection.  No Critical Reason was coded to this vehicle. Associated factors included the driver of V2 falsely assuming that traffic would yield to him because he was driving a police vehicle with the lights activated, traveling over the speed limit for the roadway, being in a hurry to get to the police call, and a sight line restriction caused by the parked vehicle parked on a lawn near the intersection. \n\nTwo witnesses were interviewed and these witnesses had different views of the crash. One stated that they saw lights on the police vehicle and the other stated that there were no lights.\n\n        This researcher noted that the reconstruction officer used a math formula to mark the spot were each vehicle would have been. Using the assumption that V1 was traveling at 64kmph (40mph) and V2 at 56kmph (35mph), they would have had a clear view of each other. However, using the match with V2 traveling at the EDR reading speed, it would not put them in clear view of each other.  There was a full-size vehicle sitting on the lawn of a home on the southwest corner (for sale) that may have blocked each driver\'s view of the other.  \n
../resources/summary/2005012694923.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred on a curved two-lane undivided roadway. It was a clear weekend afternoon. The crash occurred in a residential area where the speed limit was 40 kmph (25 mph). The roadway had a downhill grade of 4 percent, and at the crash scene, the roadway was sharply curved to the left. \n\nV1 was a 1998 Chevrolet Venture minivan driven by a 17-year old male. He reported that he was on his way home from work and was giving a fellow employee a ride to his home. He also stated that he was tired and wanted to get home to rest. He reported that he was in good health, and wore glasses for a hyperopic (far-sighted) condition and was wearing them at the time of the crash. This driver also stated that he is a heavy-footed driver and that he had passed the occupant\'s home. He looked over at the occupant when the occupant was telling him to go down the street to turn around and come back to his house. As the driver of V1 approached the curve, he realized that he was going too fast and he slammed on the brakes while steering left. Even with these actions, the vehicle skidded off the right side of the roadway where the front of the van impacted a utility pole. Post-crash investigation revealed the van\'s odometer to be locked at 53 mph. Both the driver and passenger were transported to a hospital for injuries sustained in the crash. The van was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as too fast for curve/turn. Associated factors coded to the driver were fatigue, inattention, conversation with the passenger, being in a hurry to get home, unfamiliarity with the roadway, and driver inexperience.   \n\n

\n             This crash occurred on an interstate on a weekday evening. The weather was over cast. This crash happened on the southbound side of the interstate just after the merging area of the interstate the speed was posted at 105kmph (65mph) the slope of the roadway was level concrete and dry. As this vehicle tried to merge into lane #1 the drive noted another vehicle merging into its lane.  Then over compensating swerved crossing lane #3 and the median lane making contact to the divider wall braking off the left rear wheel assembly. The vehicle then slid back across the interstate to contact the guardrail on the right shoulder of the roadway coming to final rest at the guardrail.\n\n           The Vehicle in this crash was a 1996 Chevrolet Lumina driven by a 50 year-old female who stated that she is in good health and only wears glasses for reading. She also stated she is taking a thyroid medication. She had stated that she was on her way home from the movies and was merging onto the southbound interstate. She had stated that back where the East and West interstate merged that a non-contact vehicle was not letting her merge and as they came to merge onto the interstate south that she took lane 2 and then stated that she wanted to merge back into lane 1. Looking over her right shoulder saw that the non-contact vehicle was merging into her lane and that was when she pulled her steering wheel to the left so not to make contact to his vehicle. She then swerved to the left across the interstate and hit the center wall.  The vehicle skidded along the wall for a few feet and then it spun around back across the interstate and came to final rest along the guardrail.  \n\n          The Critical Precrash Event was coded: this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the left side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was: performance error overcompensation.\n\n         An associating factor was that the witness of the non-contact vehicle stated that he noted the driver and the front of the interior of the vehicle had pop (soda) spilled all over it. He thinks the driver was holding or taking a drink of the pop and didn\'t see that he was braking because of a slower moving vehicle, which caused her to veer to the left.\n

This crash occurred on a weekday night on a 4-lane undivided roadway. The roadway was a downhill grade of 2 percent. The posted speed limit was 72 kmph (45 mph). It was dark out at the time of the crash, but the roadway was illuminated. There was a city dump truck parked in lane 2 on the westbound side with its four-way flashers on. Workers were in front of the truck doing water main repairs. There was no driver in the truck at the time of the crash. \n   \n       V1, a 1995 Buick Rivera, was driven by a 58-year old male who was reported to have been intoxicated at the time of the crash. V2 was a 1993 International dump truck that was parked and unoccupied. The driver of V1 was traveling west in lane 2. The front of V1 contacted the rear of V2. The final rest for both vehicles was at point of impact. The driver of the Buick was to have stated to police and paramedics that he had had a few drinks with his friends and he did not see any 4 four-way flashers on the truck. The driver could not be reached for an interview.\n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as other motor vehicle stopped in lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was coded as inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see). An associated factor coded to the driver of V1 was alcohol use - the driver admitted that he had been drinking before the crash. Medical records and the police report also indicated alcohol use; however, the results of the BAC test were not made available. Another associated factor coded to the driver was the fact that this area of the road had recently been set up as a construction zone.\n\n        V2, a 1993 International dump truck, was parked in lane 2 facing west with its four-way flashers on. The driver stated that he had been out of the vehicle for about 2 minutes prior to the vehicle being hit. He also stated that he did not have the amber light on top of the truck activated at that time because the boss was unsure of where he wanted him to place the vehicle. A worker also reported that the trailer hauling the amber arrow (to indicate that drivers should use the adjacent lane) was still parked on the other side of the roadway and was not yet in use. It should also be noted that the rear and sides of the dump truck were completely covered in mud. There was no reflective tape on the back of the truck.\n

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a 4-lane undivided, dry, level roadway (two lanes in each direction) in the northbound lanes. The posted speed limit was 80 kmph (50 mph). The crash happened on a clear, mid-week afternoon. There were no traffic signals at the area of the crash. V1 was traveling north in lane #1 and V2 was traveling north in lane #2 approximately 6 meters (20 feet) behind V1. Suddenly, V1 veered left across the path of V2. V2 then contacted the left side of V1 and then both vehicles skidded across both southbound lanes and off the roadway into a parking lot on the west side of the roadway. The front left of V1 then contacted the right rear of V3, which was parked in the lot on the west side of the roadway. Final rest for V1, V2 and V3 was in the parking lot (this parking lot surface was gravel).\n\n       V1, a 1994 Pontiac Grand Am, was driven by a 61-year old female who stated that she was looking for a repair shop on her right so that she could set up an appointment to have gas tank repairs done. She also stated that she did not remember turning left in front of V2. She stated V2 hit her in the left side and when they came to final rest they where in the lot on the west side of the roadway. She also stated she was in good health. She does not wear corrective lenses. She did state that she was taking medications but that they do not affect her driving skills. She also stated that she was well rested and felt fine at the start of this driving portion.\n\n       The Critical Pre-crash Event for this driver was coded: this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an internal distraction, because it was believed (based on witness statements) that a dog inside of V1 had jumped on the driver of V1 immediately before V1 swerved into the path of V2.  Associated factors coded to this driver include poor directional control, the use of prescription medication, and an emotional condition, as the driver\'s daughter had stated at the scene that her mother had a mental condition. \n\n      V2, a 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt, was driven by a 50-year old female who stated she was traveling north on the roadway in lane #2 about 20 feet back from V#1, which was in lane #1. She also stated that V1 steered into her lane and she had no time to react. She did not want to steer left to avoid the collision because there was a semi-truck traveling south in lane #2 and she did not want to have a head-on collision with the truck. This interviewee stopped the interview at the health and sleep question part of the interview. \n\n      The Critical Pre-crash Event for this vehicle was coded other vehicle encroachment from adjacent lane (same direction) - over left lane line. The Critical reason was not coded to this vehicle.\n\n    A witness stated that he was standing at the roadside at the time of the crash and saw both vehicles traveling north at about the speed limit. V1 was in lane #1 and V2 was in lane #2. He also stated that a dog had jumped into the lap of the driver of V1 and she then steered left and crossed the path of V2. They had both just missed being hit by a southbound semi-truck. A second witness stated that he did not want to give his name or really get involved but he also saw the dog jump into the lap of the driver of V1. He then turned and ran so he would not be hit.\n\n         V3 was a parked and unoccupied 1991 Chevrolet S-10 pick-up, which only had minor damage to the right box side.\n\n\n
../resources/summary/2005012695001.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2002 Chevy Malibu, was traveling southbound on a 4-lane, two-way, icy asphalt roadway on a downhill grade.  V1 was traveling in the second lane of travel. The driver of V1 stated he thought he might be traveling too fast for conditions.  He tapped his brakes and started to fishtail, rotating in a counterclockwise direction into the oncoming lanes of travel.  V3, a 1999 Sterling tractor-trailer, was traveling on the same roadway traveling northbound, in the first lane of travel.  The driver of V3 stated that when he saw V1 begin to enter the northbound lanes, he tried to get as far over in his lane as possible but could not avoid contacting the right front side of V1.  V3 then departed roadway on the east side and contacted a fire hydrant, a telephone pole and a tree before coming to final rest. After striking V3, V1 rotated back into the second southbound lane of travel, where V2, a 2001 Dodge Ram, was traveling southbound.  The front of V2 contacted the right side of V1.  Both V1 and V2 came to final rest on the roadway. \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 27-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 50-64 kmph (31-40 mph) prior to the crash. He had no health related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.   He was rested and traveling to work. He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition. He sustained some minor injuries during the crash but refused to be transported to the hospital. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when he lost control of his vehicle due to his traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "too fast for conditions." The driver of V1 reported that as he began traveling down the grade of the roadway, he thought he was going too fast and tried to compensate by tapping his brakes. This action then sent his vehicle into a skid.  Associated factors included the speed of the vehicle (too fast for conditions), the slick roadway and the weather (snow).\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 25-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 18-32 kmph (11-20 mph) when he noticed that V1 was losing control.  When he observed V1 skidding toward him, he attempted to slow down further but could not avoid impact.  The driver of V2 was on his way to work.  He had no health problems and had taken no medication.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition. He was not injured during the crash.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V2 because he was not involved in the first harmful event (the impact between the front of V1 and the front of V3). Although he did not contribute to the crash (he took appropriate avoidance actions), two associated factors were coded to him: the condition of the roadway (slick) and the weather (snow).\n  \nThe driver of V3 was a 47-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 34-48 kmph (21-30 mph) prior to the crash.  This driver had history of high blood pressure. He was taking a cholesterol-lowering medication that had no known performance-impairing side effects. The driver was traveling for work and felt rested.  He had only traveled 10 miles before the crash occurred.  He was not injured during the crash. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V3 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from the opposite direction, over the left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V3 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash. He took appropriate avoidance actions. Two associated factors were coded to the driver of V3 that were coded to all three vehicles:  the condition of the roadway (slick) and the weather (snow).

preprocessing
V1, a 1995 Buick LeSabre, was traveling southbound on a five-lane undivided roadway (3 lanes southbound, 2 lanes northbound) in the second lane of travel.  The roadway was wet and level.  The crash occurred in the early afternoon hours on a weekday.  V2, a 1986 Dodge Ram pickup, was stopped facing south in the third lane of travel (a left hand turn lane) on the same roadway, intending to turn left at a 4-way signalized intersection.  The Dodge was stopped behind V3, a 1997 Saturn SL1, which was also stopped in the left hand turn lane waiting to turn left at the intersection.  V1 drifted from the second lane of travel into the third and the front of V1 contacted the back of V2.  This impact pushed the front of V2 into the back of V3.  All vehicles came to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 reported that he had no idea what had happened.  He said that he blacked out just prior to the crash.  The driver had one pre-existing health condition - asthma - but was not on medication.  The driver had been traveling for 10 miles before crash occurred.  He reported only having four hours of sleep the night before.  He was reported as having minor injuries, but refused medical treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was another vehicle was stopped in his lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act," a critical non-performance error.  This was chosen based on statements given by the driver of V1 to both the researcher and to police.  The driver also admitted that he was fatigued at the time of the crash, he reported that he was in a hurry to get somewhere and that he had been thinking about some personal problems.  Fatigue, being in a hurry, and thinking about personal problems were all coded as associated factors.\n\nThe driver of V2 was waiting behind V3 at the traffic signal, waiting for V3 to complete his left turn so that he could make his own turn.  While stopped in traffic, his vehicle was rear-ended by V1 and pushed into V3.  The driver of V2 was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition.  He was not injured.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was another vehicle was in his lane, traveling in the same direction but at a higher speed.  The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\nThe driver of V3 was stopped at a traffic signal in the left turn lane, waiting for the light to change so that he could initiate a left turn when he was struck from behind by V2.  V2 had been pushed into V3 by V1.  The driver of V3 was taking unknown medications for high blood pressure and cholesterol.  He was wearing prescription lenses for a hyperopic (farsighted) condition and was not injured.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reasons were coded to the driver of V3 because he was not involved in the first harmful event.  He was not thought to have contributed to the crash.

This crash occurred at a 4-lane 2-way intersection. The crash happened on a weekday around mid-day. The slope was +4/122. The roadway was dry asphalt. The posted speed was 56kmph (35mph). V2 was stopped in lane 2 waiting for oncoming traffic to clear so the driver could make a left turn in the intersection. As V1 approached the intersection the driver was looking for a store address to drop off a product delivery. V1 was about 1 \xc2\xbd vehicle lengths behind V2 the driver of V1 thought V2 had preceded to make its turn. When the driver looked back he was on the back of V2 making contact to the rear of the vehicle. V2 slid into the intersection to final rest. V1 skidded about 10ft. to final rest. A family member took the driver of V2 to the local Trauma Unit after the scene was cleared. \n\n              V1 was driven by a 51 year-old male who stated he was out helping his brother make product deliveries to local stores in the area. He also stated he did not know the area all that well. He stated he was driving on a suspended license for a previous crash. He also stated his health was not that good. He stated he was in the hospital recently for kidney failure, and takes medication for a heart condition, and medication for a nerve condition.\n\n           The Critical Precrash Event for this vehicle was coded: Other motor vehicle in lane other vehicle stopped. The Critical Reason for the critical event was coded recognition error: external distraction. The associated facts were the medications the driver was taking at the time of the crash. Also this driver has a suspended drivers license.\n\n         V2 was driven by a 24 year-old female who stated she was on her way to the day-care to drop off her son 2 year-old that was properly seated in the back right seat of the vehicle. \n\n        The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded: other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded for this vehicle was not coded.\n\n       This researcher was traveling East on the said roadway about 200 yard back and saw V1 skidding at an angle. Then saw a cloud of dust as I pulled up on the intersection I realized that what I viewed was a crash. I called 911 and then went to see that all persons were ok. The driver of V1 at that time had stated that he did not have a driver\'s license that it had been taken away for a crash that he was responsible for in earlier weeks. He also stated that he had a health problem (mental) but was ok to drive. As I checked on the driver of V2 she stated she was ok but was concerned about her child in the back seat.  After the driver got out to check her child and had a chance to move around then she noted her neck and arms were tingly. At that time I asked her to sit in her vehicle till the police arrived. When the police arrived the officer Stated that the driver of V1 was not to be driving by court order for previous crash.

V1, a 2003 Pontiac Vibe, was traveling westbound on a dry 5-lane undivided (3 lanes westbound, 2 lanes eastbound) asphalt roadway in dark conditions.  V2, a 1997 Oldsmobile Silhouette, was also traveling westbound on the same roadway. The roadway was dry, straight, and level, with a posted speed limit of 56 kmph (35 mph). Both vehicles were traveling in the first lane, with V1 following V2. V2 stopped for a red light at a 4-way signalized intersection.  The front of V1 contacted the back of V2 before coming to final rest on the roadway. Both drivers and the one passenger in V2 were transported to a local trauma center and treated for moderate injuries. \n\nThe driver of V1, a 53-year old female, reported that she was traveling between 31-40 mph.  She was unaware of how the crash had happened.  The police and ambulance reported that the driver might have had a seizure, which may have been the cause of the accident. There was no evidence of any braking on the part of V1. The driver of the V1 had been traveling to stay with family for a few days.  She had traveled for five miles before the crash occurred.  She had a history of cancer and high blood pressure, neither of which seemed to have a factor in the crash.  The driver reported that she felt rested and had no emotional contributors.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was stopped in her lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as "heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act," a critical non-performance error. This was chosen based on medical records that indicated that doctors believed the driver of V1 had suffered a seizure while driving and had temporarily relinquished control of her vehicle. Medical records indicated that the driver of V1 had a long history of seizure activity and was taking medication to control this. The seizure medication had the possible side effects of sedation, weakness, and sleepiness. The driver of V1 was also taking three other medications:  a cholesterol-lowering medication, a thyroid replacement therapy medication, and a medication used to prevent osteoporosis. None of these three medications had any known performance-impairing side effects. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. The driver of V1 was familiar with both her vehicle and the roadway. \n\nThe driver of V2, a 34-year old female, reported that she had been stopped at the red light when the rear of her vehicle was struck by the front of V1.  The Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle was in her lane, traveling in the same direction but at a higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash. She was speaking to a passenger in her vehicle when the crash occurred, and she took no avoidance actions. However, it must be pointed out that she was properly stopped for a red light and took no actions that contributed to the crash. The driver of V2 reported that she was rested and had no existing health problems.  She was not taking any medications prior to the crash.  There were no emotional factors that contributed to the crash.  She was familiar with both her vehicle and the roadway. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a clear weekday afternoon on an undivided 4-lane north/south roadway. The center lanes were asphalt and the outside north/south lanes were concrete. The roadway was level and dry and the posted speed was 72 kmph (45 mph). The crash happened on a long straight section of the roadway with no traffic controls. V1, a 2000 Chevrolet G-series van, was traveling southbound in lane 2. As it traveled down the roadway, the driver drifted across the double yellow centerlines and sideswiped the left side of V2, a 1999 Chevrolet G-series van that was traveling north in lane 2. The driver of V2 saw that V1 was coming across the lines and steered to the right to avoid being struck head-on.               \nV1 continued traveling south in the second northbound lane and struck V3, a 2000 Pontiac Grand Am, head-on. V3 bounced back in its original travel lane and was contacted in the rear by V4, a 1995 Pontiac Grand Am. V4\'s final rest was at its contact point. V3 slid back up to the right side doors of V1. V1\'s final rest was at an angle across Lanes 1 and 2 on the northbound side of the roadway. V2 drove to the next driveway and turned around and came back to the scene.\nV1 was driven by a 66-year old female that had apparently suffered a heart attack while driving south on the roadway. Her husband stated that they where on their way home from the doctor\'s office when the crash occurred. He also stated that the week before the crash the driver had been complaining that her arms were sore and tingly. That was the reason for the visit to the doctor. He reported that before the crash she had been taking no medications at all. He also stated that she was the one who took care of their wheelchair-bound son, lifting him in and out of bed, the tub, etc.             \nV2 was driven by a 32-year old male who stated he was in good health and does not wear glasses or take any medications. The driver stated that he was traveling north on the roadway going to a job site when he noted the southbound vehicle (V1) crossing the centerline. He then steered right so as not to be contacted, but the left rear side of his vehicle was sideswiped by V1. He then turned around in a nearby driveway and returned to the scene of the crash. \nV3 was driven by a 44-year old female who stated that she was in good health but took a medication for thyroid problems. She stated that she had gotten out of work early and was on her way home. \nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was:  this vehicle traveling over the lane line on the left side of travel lane. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a critical non-performance error:  heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act. It was the driver\'s husband\'s belief that the driver of V1 had passed away in the moments before the crash occurred. \n The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded: other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and no associated factors were coded to him.\nNo Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because she was not involved in the first harmful event. Associated factors coded to this driver include fatigue, following too closely, and the use of a prescription thyroid-replacement medication.\n                \n             \n                   \n\n
../resources/summary/2005012695043.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1998 Chevrolet Silverado, was traveling southbound on a wet four-lane undivided (two lanes each direction) asphalt roadway in the second lane of travel.  The roadway was level and curved to the right.  The posted speed limit was 72 kmph (45 mph). It was daylight and had just started to snow.  V1 was intending to go straight and was following behind V2, a 1994 Pontiac Bonneville. V2 was also intending to go straight. The driver of V1 was a 23-year old male. The driver of V2 was a 77-year old female.\n\nA car in front of V2 made a sudden stop.  V2 braked hard in order to avoid contacting the non-contact vehicle.  V1 tried to stop, but could not in time and its right front contacted the left rear of V2.  V2 came to final rest there on the roadway.  The momentum of V1 combined with the offset impact to the rear of V2 sent V1 to the left across the double yellow lines and into oncoming traffic. \n\nV3, a 2000 Pontiac Grand Am, was traveling the northbound on the same roadway in the second northbound lane. V3 was driven by an 18-year old female who claimed that she did not see V1 until the last moment because of the curve.  V1\'s front left contacted the left front of V3.  V3 then spun around 180 degrees and before coming to final rest facing south on the roadway.  V1 also came to final rest facing south on the roadway.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when another vehicle was in his lane traveling in the same direction while decelerating. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as inattention, a recognition error. It was believed that the driver of V1 was not paying attention to what was going on around him and then when V2 began to brake hard, he did not react in time. He admitted that he did not lock up his brakes even when V2 had slowed almost to a stop. For this reason, an associated factor coded to this driver was inadequate evasive action. The driver of V1 reported that he was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway. He reported that he was not in a hurry and felt rested.  No medical factors contributed to the crash.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle was in her lane traveling in the same direction, but at a higher speed. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. At the time of the crash, the driver of V2 was traveling to a doctor appointment.  She reported that she was in a hurry to get there. She stated that she was talking to her passenger in her vehicle at the time of the crash about the passenger\'s illness. She reported that she was upset by recent news she had received.  Although these factors were coded as associated factors, it should be pointed out that the driver of V2 was able to stop in time without striking the non-contact vehicle in front of her that had suddenly stopped. It is possible that her reaction time was delayed, but she was able to avoid the vehicle in front of her. She was wearing her prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition and was taking an unknown heart medication. She reported that she was not fatigued at the time of the crash. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because she was not involved in the first harmful event (the impact between the front of V1 and the rear of V2). The driver of V3 was on her way to work and was not in a hurry and not fatigued. She was familiar with both the roadway and her vehicle.  She claimed that she was attentive to her driving but had no time to react to V1 entering her lane due to the curve in the road. She was wearing her prescription lenses at the time of the crash that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition. She was also taking a prescription antibiotic that had no known performance-impairing side effects. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when the driver of V1, who was inattentive to the driving task, failed to brake in time to avoid striking the rear of V2. This impact redirected V1 to the left, where it entered the oncoming lane of traffic and struck the front of V3.
../resources/summary/2005012695062.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1996 Pontiac Sunfire, was traveling southbound on a four-lane, undivided wet asphalt roadway in daylight conditions. The posted speed limit was 89 kmph (55 mph). The driver of V1, an 18-year old male, intended to go straight through a 4-way intersection with another 4-lane roadway.  V2, a 2004 Chevrolet Silverado with a snow blade and pulling a trailer, was traveling westbound on an undivided four-lane wet asphalt roadway approaching the same intersection. The driver of V2, a 43-year old male, also intended to go straight through the intersection. V3, a 1995 Chevrolet Corsica, was stopped at the intersection facing east waiting to turn left onto the north/south roadway.  V3 was driven by a 55-year old male. V4, a 2005 Chevrolet Silverado, was traveling eastbound approaching the same intersection, intending to turn right. The intersection was controlled by a flashing beacon. North and southbound traffic had a flashing red light; east and westbound traffic had a flashing yellow light. North and southbound traffic was also controlled by stop signs.\n\nThe driver of V1 reported seeing the red light at the last minute and stated that he was traveling too fast to stop in time.  The driver of V1 swerved right to tried to avoid V2 but was unsuccessful.  The front of V2 struck the left side of V1. V1 spun counterclockwise 360 degrees before coming to final rest of the north road edge.  While rotating, the rear of V1 struck the right side of V2.  Following its impacts with V1, V2\'s left front contacted the left front of V3.  The front left of V4 then scraped up the right side of V3.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when he began to cross over (pass through) the intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an illegal maneuver, a decision error. This was chosen because the driver of V1 admitted that he saw the red light in advance but thought he was going too fast to stop in time. His speed was coded as an associated factor, as was conversation with his passenger. He was also coded as being inattentive to the driving task. The driver of V1 reported that while he was familiar with his vehicle, this was the first time he had driven on this particular roadway. He was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition at the time of the crash. He was taking no medications, and police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests. The police did issue a citation to the driver of V1 for failing to stop at a red light. Because it was believed that the driver of V1 intended to go through a traffic control device, he was also coded as driving aggressively.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from a crossing street, across his path. The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. An associated factor that was coded to the driver of V2 was a false assumption of another road user\'s actions, because the driver of V2 expected that north and southbound traffic would yield the right-of-way to him as he proceeded through the intersection. The driver of V2 reported that he was familiar with his vehicle and that he drove on the roadway approximately once a month. He reported that he was taking a cholesterol-lowering medication that had no known performance-impairing side effects. Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded to the driver of V3 because he was not involved in the first harmful event (the initial impact between V1 and V2). The driver of V3 was not thought to have contributed to the crash. He was stopped at the intersection waiting for traffic to clear so that he could initiate a left turn. The driver of V3 reported that he took a prescribed medication that had the possible side effect of dizziness and weakness. He also reported that he suffered from sleep apnea but that he was not fatigued at the time of the crash. He was wearing his prescription lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition and was familiar with both his vehicle and the roadway.  Police did not consider either alcohol or illegal drugs to be involved and ordered no tests.\n\nIn summary, the crash occurred when the driver of V1, who was somewhat inattentive to the driving task, failed to stop for a traffic control device and entered an intersection where V2 had the right-of-way. Associated factors included excess speed, conversation with a passenger, and aggressive driving.
../resources/summary/2005012695064.json
preprocessing
This crash occurred at an intersection of two 2-lane undivided roadways. The north/south lanes had a stop sign. The speed was posted at 40 kmph (25 mph). Both roadways were level. The crash occurred on a weekday evening around dusk. There were no adverse weather conditions. \n  \n         A 14 year-old male drove V1, a 1991 Chevrolet Astro van. The driver was not of driving age and had been diagnosed with Asperger\'s syndrome (a form of autism). The boy stated that he just wanted to go for a ride. His mother gave most of the interview. She stated that her son has wanted to drive ever since his older sister went through driver\'s training. The boy asked again and again when it was his turn to learn to drive. The mother stated that he was upset earlier that evening at his grandmother\'s house because there was no jelly in her home so he wanted to go to the store to buy some. The mother reported that they hid the vehicle keys in a fruit bowl on top of the refrigerator. The mother and grandmother got his mind off the keys by telling him that his aunt wrote a letter and had asked about him, so he started looking for the letter but instead found the keys. The mother stated that he went out the door without saying anything. She stated that a friend came over and told her that the van was gone. Then a neighbor came over and stated that the mother needed to come to the end of the street. There they found the van up against a house at the corner of the intersecting street, with the driver standing next to it. The driver had turned the corner at the intersection, drove over the curb, struck a speed limit sign, then a fence before striking a house at final rest. The driver was transported to the local hospital for head and back pain. The vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\n       The driver was said to be in good health and did not wear glasses, He took medications for his diagnosed problem. He stated that he drove to the corner, stopped and then turned on the turn signal like his mother does when she drives. He stated he started around the corner and the vehicle did not go straight after the turn. \n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded: this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a performance error - poor directional control (failing to control vehicle with skill ordinarily expected).  Associated factors coded to this driver include the driver having Asperger\'s syndrome, the medication that the driver was taking, inattention, and driver inexperience. \n

preprocessing
The crash occurred in the southbound lane of a 5-lane two-way level asphalt roadway.  There were two northbound and two southbound lanes with a left turn lane in the middle.  The roadway had a posted speed of 56kph (35mph).  The crash occurred in the late morning hours on a weekday with daylight, and dry Conditions.\n\nV1, a 1990 Buick Park Avenue, was traveling northbound in the left hand turn lane.  He was intending to make a left hand turn at the light.  The driver thought that he had ample time to make the turn, but his engine stalled as he was in the second lane of oncoming traffic.  V2, a 1986 SAAB 900 was traveling on the same roadway headed southbound.  The driver of V2 said that she thought the car would continue to make the turn, but instead the car stopped right in her path of travel.  The front of V2 contacted the right side of V1.  Both V1 and V2 came to final rest on the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 47-year old male who stated that as he was beginning to turn left his car sputtered and slowed to a stop in the second lane of the southbound traffic.  As he was checking out what happened to his car V2 hit his car in the right side.  The driver was uninjured and his vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle control loss due to stalled engine.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was vehicle related factor, engine failure.  He suffered from high blood pressure and asthma.  He had taken an unknown blood pressure medication.  He was rested and traveling to pick up his taxes. \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 54-year old woman who reported that she had been traveling south when she noticed that the car turning left across her path of travel had stopped.  She applied the brakes without lock-up but could not avoid the impact.  She was not injured during the crash, her passenger received minor injuries and was transported to the hospital.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle in lane, in crossover.  The Critical Reason was not coded for this vehicle.  Driver reported a history of tumors, high blood pressure, arthritis, and crushed vertebrae.  She had taken two medications one for arthritis and the other is unknown.  Both medications were thought not to contribute to the crash.  \n

This crash occurred on a four lane two-way roadway. The lanes of travel where north & south, the roadway was level asphalt. The weather conditions where clear, the roadway was dry. The speed was posted at 76 KMPH ( 45mph). Where the crash occurred there was an intersection that was on the east side of the roadway. The roadway was two-lanes in each direction.  V#1 traveling south had stopped to turn left onto an east bound roadway. After sitting stopped for several seconds watching on coming traffic V#1 proceeded to make it\'s turn. There was a non-contact work vehicle parked near the intersection in lane one of the east bound roadway, also as V#1 proceeded to turn, there was another vehicle approaching the intersection traveling west in lane one of the roadway. As V#1 turned it was contacted by V#2 at the right side of the vehicle. V#1 then slid sideways to final rest at the north east corner of the intersection. V#2 after contact rotated clockwise and came to final rest at a south-easterly angle in lane two of the north bound and lane two of the south bound side of the roadway. The driver of V#1 was transported to a local E.R. unit to be looked over for injuries. He stated he was ok. The drive of V#2 was transported to a local trauma unit due to injuries form the crash.\n\n    V1 was a 1992 Chevrolet Pickup driven by a 84 year-old male who is deaf and stated he wanted to decline the interview. The driver had his insurance company call me from out of state to ask about our research and told me she would let her client know it was ok to give me the information about the crash. After several attempts  the drive declined the interview.\n\n     The Critical Precrash Event for V#1 was coded: this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded Decision Error, misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed. An associated factor was that at the time V#1 stopped he may have had time to make his turn there was a non-contact work vehicle parked near the intersection in lane one of the east bond side.  As this driver waited to proceed another vehicle approached traveling west which may have caused hesitation in V#1\'s turn.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 41 year-old female who stated she had just came from the corner store and was traveling north on her way to her husbands place of work. She also stated she had just passed another vehicle and was in lane one when she saw V#1 edging forward to make a left turn onto the roadway to her right (east) and stated she hoped it would not turn. At the last moment V#1 turned, V#2 stated she applied the brakes and turned her head. After contacting V#1 her vehicle spun around not knowing in which direction. The driver stated when the vehicle stopped she crawled away from her vehicle to the curb where a person said to her to lay down he had called for help. The driver stated she thought her vehicle might catch on fire. This driver stated that she is in good health and is not taking any medications at this time. She does not wear glasses.\n\n        The Critical Precrash Event for V#2 was coded: other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded for this vehicle. An associated factor to this driver was that she had passed a vehicle in lane two on the right side not giving the driver of V#1 enough time to see her coming. Traveling too fast was coded as an associated factor due to an EDR reading which showed V2 was traveling at 76 mph 5 seconds prior to the impact.\n\n    #1 witness stated he had just turned from his work vehicle in time to see the contact of the vehicles. He stated he then ran hoping not to be hit and when the vehicle came to final rest he ran to the driver of V#2 as she crawled from her vehicle. The west bound non-contact vehicle went to the other driver. He stated he thought both vehicles were traveling at the speed they should of been traveling.\n\n   #2 witness was a husband and wife who state they were west bound coming to the intersection and saw V#1 turning into the street they were traveling. They also stated the V#1 seemed to slow down as he turned. He had stated that they saw the north bound vehicle traveling faster then the speed limit. They had stated that as they checked on the driver of V#1 they found that he was Deaf and they knew sign language so they interpreted for EM\'S persons.

V1, a 1997 Pontiac Grand Prix, was traveling westbound on the entrance ramp of a highway that was one-lane, one-way, icy concrete roadway.  The Driver of V1 stated she thought she might be traveling too fast for conditions.  She tapped the brakes and began rotating in a counterclockwise direction.  The vehicle departed the roadway on the right side and contacted it\'s left side to a breakaway light post.  The vehicle then contacted it\'s left side to a tree before coming to final rest off the road.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 51-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 32-40 kmph (20-25 mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health problems.  She had said she takes medication for neck pain.  She was rested and traveling to pick up a present. She did not sustain any injuries from the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when she lost control of her vehicle due to traveling too fast for conditions.   The driver of V1 reported that as she noticed that cars had to merge ahead so she attempted to slow down by tapping the brakes.  This action sent her vehicle into a skid.  Associated factors include condition of the roadway (slick) and the weather (sleet).

V1, a 2000 GMC Sierra was traveling northbound on a two lane, two way dry asphalt roadway on a level grade.  V2, a 1994 Acura Integra, was traveling southbound on the same roadway.  The driver of V1 stated that she had seen V2 coming from the opposite direction swerving in and out of the lanes.  The driver of V1 slowed down and steered to the right as far as possible trying to avoid contacting V2.  V1 could only get over so far because of a guardrail on the road edge.   V1 contacted the right side of V2 with its front.  Both vehicles then contacted the guardrail with their fronts before coming to final rest on the East road edge.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was an 18-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 40-50 mph prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems, and had taken no medications prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home from a friend\'s house.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (nearsighted) condition.  She sustained no injuries and refused to be transported to the hospital.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over the left lane line. She took appropriate avoidance actions.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 44-year old woman who reported that she had blacked out and did not remember anything.   She did report that she was on her way to pick up her taxes.  She had a history of high blood pressure, which may have been a factor in her loss of consciousness.  She was taking Metoprolol Tartate for her condition.  She does not wear prescriptive lenses.  Driver sustained severe injuries including a punctured lung and six broken ribs.  She was transported to a local trauma facility.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when the driver traveled over the lane line into the opposing lane.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as \xe2\x80\x9cheart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act.\xe2\x80\x9d  An Associated Factor included the high blood pressure condition of the driver.

This crash occurred southbound lane of a two-lane roadway. It was a mid-week night after dark with the streetlights on. There were overcast conditions.  The posted speed was 59 kmph (35 mph). The roadway was dry, level asphalt.  \n\nV3 had slowed to watch for his street to turn onto. V#2 slowed as well noting the taillights of V#3. V#1 was traveling at a constant velocity and did not see the slowed vehicles until it was too late. V#1 contacted V#2\'s back pushing V#2 into V#3. V#3 rolled forward about 50ft. coming to final rest in it\'s original travel lane. V#2 came to final rest at its point of impact in its original travel lane. V#1 rolled a few feet to final rest in its original travel lane.\n\nV1 a 1995 Ford Taurus was driven by a 19 year-old male who is in good health but takes medication for allergies that has possible side effects of drowsiness and fatigue.  He had just left home to go to work. At the time of the crash he states that he had just picked up his cell phone to call work. He stated that he was not in a hurry or late for work.  He suffered no injuries and his vehicle was towed from the scene due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V#1 was coded other vehicle in lane: traveling in same direction while decelerating. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded: recognition error: internal distraction (driver had just picked up his cell phone and was dialing at the time of the crash). An associating factor was fatigue as this driver stated that he only had 2.5hrs of sleep in the last 24hrs due to his work and school schedule.\n          \n           V2 a 1996 Ford Escort was driven by a 43 year-old male who is in good health.  This driver claimed that he did not see any headlights coming from behind him.  He stated he was slowing down behind V#3 when he was rear-ended by V#1.  The driver of V#2 was uninjured but the passenger was transported to a treatment facility with possible injuries.  V#2 was towed due to damage.\n\n         The Critical Precrash Event for V#2 was coded: Other vehicle in lane: Traveling in same direction with higher speed. There was no critical reason coded to this vehicle. \n \n          V3 a 2001 Pontiac Bonneville was driven by a 75 year-old male who claims to be in good health but does take several medications due to a heart bypass and angina attacks.  He also wears hearing aids.  He stated that he had slowed down because he does not see as well at night as in the day and did not want to pass his street (trees block it).  The driver suffered possible injuries but was not transported.  V3 was driven from the scene.\n\n         The Critical Precrash Event for V#3 was coded: Other: not involved first harmful event. There was no Critical reason coded to vehicle.

The crash occurred in the westbound lane of a 2-lane two-way roadway.  There is an intersection approximately 21m to the left of the driveway. Conditions were daylight and an icy asphalt roadway.  The crash occurred in the morning on a weekday.\n\nV1, a 1997 Chevrolet Venture, was pulling out of a commercial drive and slipped on some ice in the roadway.  V2, a 1991 Saturn was traveling westbound on the same roadway.  She did not see V1 pulling out until he was right in front of her due to a pile of snow on the side of the roadway blocking her view.  The front of V2 contacted the left rear of V1 before coming to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 26-year old male who had reported that he was stopped before proceeding and was traveling 3-17 kmph(1-10mph).  He did not sustain any injuries from the crash.  The driver of V1 stated that he was pulling out of a driveway to turn left when his car slid on a patch of ice.  He did not see the other vehicle because of the high snow bank that was blocking his view.  The other vehicle hit his vehicle in the left rear and spun him counter-clockwise.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for V1 is this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see).  He had no health related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and coming from the bank.  Associated factors included were the condition of the roadway (icy) and sightline restrictions (snow bank).\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 22-year old female not reported pregnant, who reported that she had been traveling 34-48 kmph (21-30mph).  She sustained no injuries.  The driver of V2 stated that she went through the green light and all of a sudden V1 turned left in front of her.  She could not avoid hitting him.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle encroachment from driveway, turning into opposite direction.  The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  She took appropriate avoidance actions.  She had no health related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and taking her mom to work.  She does not have a prescription for corrective lenses.  Two associated factors were coded to the driver of V2 that was also coded to V1 was the condition of the roadway (icy) and sightline restrictions (snow bank).

This crash occurred at an intersection between a four-lane one-way southbound roadway and a four lane one-way eastbound roadway. The eastbound lanes went down to three lanes on the East side of the intersection. The intersection was controlled by a properly functioning traffic light. It was a clear sunny weekend afternoon. The roadway was dry. The southbound roadway was curved to the left and had a +3/122 incline with a posted speed of 59 kmph (35 mph). The Eastbound roadway was straight and had a +6/122 incline with a posted speed of 42 kmph (25 mph). On the northwest corner was a building 4 meters from the eastbound roadway and 8 meters from the southbound roadway. There was also a cedar tree right at the corner of the building. \n\n       V1, a 2002 Chevrolet G-series van, exited the interstate southbound and was merging across all four lanes to turn into a parking lot on the southwest side of the intersection. V2, a 1992 Mercury Topaz was eastbound.  As V1 approached the intersection the driver was changing lanes from lane three to lane two at about the center of the intersection. V2 (traveling in lane #1) entered the intersection and contacted the right front side of V1 and rotated counter-clockwise to a final rest in lane three of the southbound lanes. V1 traveled off the road to the left through a fence and coming to final rest in some trees.\n\n       V1 was driven by a 21 year-old male who claimed to be in very good health. He stated he had just exited the interstate and was merging to the right so he could turn into a parking lot on the other side of the intersection. He and another occupant said they had a green light as they approached the intersection. The driver also stated that there was a building on his right side that was obstructing his view of the oncoming traffic.\n\n       The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded: this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the critical event was coded: a recognition error, inadequate surveillance. Associated factors were an obstructed view, and the driver was conversing with the other occupants.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 54 year-old male in health was good but does wear glasses for a Myopic (near sighted) condition. He also takes a medication for diabetes but does not feel it effects his driving.  He drives this roadway every day from work and claims to have gotten good at timing the traffic lights from his work place to the interstate.  He stated that his view of on coming traffic was obstructed by the building to his left (the north west corner).  He transported with non-incapacitating injuries and V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n    The Critical Precrash Event was coded: other vehicle encroachment; from crossing street, across path. The Critical reason for the critical event is not coded to this vehicle. An associated factor was the driver\'s obstructed view. \n\n     The witness to this crash told the police officer on scene that the southbound vehicle (V1) had run the traffic light.  The witness stated to me that as her vehicle was approaching the intersection she was about a half block back and the light was green but the next time she looked up as the vehicles were in contact and traveling to final rest the light was red.\n\n     The one occupant to V1 that gave me an interview stated as they exited the interstate the traffic light was green. He also stated the occupants of the vehicle were all talking about where the parking lot was on the other side of the intersection.
