This crash occurred in the merging area of an entrance ramp onto an eastbound interstate. The speed is posted at 113 kmph  (70 mph) with a flashing advisory of 64 kmph (40 mph). This is a curved ramp with a radius of curvature of 163.8 and super elevation of -6/122 to inside of curve. The off road super elevation from road edge to bottom of the ditch is  -17/122. It was a rainy weeknight. It was dark with no lights.  \n\n            V1, a 1999 Ford F-250 Super Cab, was merging onto the interstate from the ramp. As the driver applied the brakes to slow down the vehicle rotated clockwise and slid off the road tripping on the soft shoulder rolling 4 quarter turns to land on it\'s wheels at final rest facing in a southwesterly direction. This vehicle was found some 24 meters off the road at the interstate fence line. There was no driver or passenger with the vehicle upon arrival at the scene as they had already been taken to a local ER by a passer by.\n\n             V1 was driven by a 28 year-old male in good health but does suffer from asthma (the medication for which is not thought to have contributed to the crash). This driver stated that as he merged onto the interstate he applied the brakes and than stated it felt like the right rear tire locked and that is what stated the clockwise rotation and loss of control.  The driver suffered minor injuries while the occupant in right front seat suffered non-incapacitating injuries.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n          The Critical Precrash Event was coded: this vehicle control loss due to: traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as decision error: too fast for conditions- it was raining and a down hill right hand curve. The associated factors were the speed of the vehicle, the wet pavement and the vehicle had a 6 ft lift to the under carriage. This vehicle also had over sized tires and rims.  The driver also admitted his own inattention as he was thinking about other things, as well as conversing with a passenger.\n

This crash occurred at an intersection between a 4-lane north/south roadway and a two-lane intersecting roadway controlled by a stop sign.  The roadways were level, dry, straight, and asphalt.  As V1, a 2002 Buick LeSabre, traveled eastbound it failed to stop for the stop sign and entered the intersection.  V2, a 1998 GMC G-Series Van, contacted V1 left with it\'s front as it traveled through the intersection.  V1 began rotating slightly counter-clockwise then the left front wheel assembly snapped off causing the vehicle to rotate back clockwise across the roadway, off the road and up a hill coming to final rest in some small trees. V2 rotated around to the south side of the road coming to final rest on the southwest shoulder.\n \nV1 was driven by a 58 year-old female who was believed to have been in fair health however her sister who gave the interview stated that her sister was on many medications for allergies, asthma, and seizer disorder.  The sister also stated that the driver had an open candy bar that contained nuts in her hand despite the fact she had a severe allergy to nuts (this allergy is believed to have contributed to the crash as a reason V1 ran the stop sign).  The sister states that the driver was on her way home from a shopping center and she rarely drives this roadway but was forced to because of the construction going on in the area.\n\n         The Critical Precrash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a decision error, illegal maneuver.  The associating factors were the allergies she had to peanuts and there physical effects. \n\n         V2 was driven by a 49 year-old male in good health on his way home from his cabin up north.  His map did not show this roadway on it but he did not want to turn onto a roadway that he did not know.  He was hoping that the roadway would cross the roadway he was looking for.  He had stated he had never driven the roadway before and was not familiar with it. \n     \n         The Critical Precrash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason was not coded to this vehicle. The associated factors where the fact that the driver was unfamiliar with the area and had never driven this roadway before. He may have been talking to his wife who was looking at the map and may have been looking at the map also. \n\n         This driver stated that he was driving in lane two on the roadway and that there was a Motor Cycle next to him. She stated the driver of V1 appeared to be looking to her right as to be dialing a cell phone.\n   \n

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a four-lane, two-way, dry, level, asphalt roadway on a weekday afternoon.  The posted speed was 56 kmph (35 mph).  \n\n           V2, a 1991 Buick Park Avenue, was eastbound as it slowed to a stop intending to left turn onto anther roadway. V1, a 1996 Pontiac Grand Prix, was also eastbound and had just changed lanes when the driver realized V2 was stopped.  V1 applied his brakes but contacted the rear of V2.  V1 came to final rest at the point of impact. V2 rolled down the roadway crossing the double yellow line and climbed the curb before coming to final rest over the sidewalk on the north side of the roadway nearly 49 meters from the point of impact.\n\n            V1 was driven by a 20 year-old male in good health drove vehicle.  He had just left the Secretary of States office where he had just taken his CDL test and was on his way to apply for a driver\'s job with the Salvation Army. This driver states that he did not see a turn signal or brake lights, he also claimed that when he applied his brakes they felt soft and his foot went to the floor. He does not remember hearing his tires locking-up.\n\n        The Critical Pre-crash Event for V#1 was coded: other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded recognition error, inattention because he was thinking about the driver\'s test he had just taken and that he was going to apply for a driver\'s job that he wanted. The associated factor was a vehicle related problem of brake failure. While doing my vehicle inspection I applied the brakes and did not find a problem; however the driver stated that his father and Uncle had just replaced them the night before the crash. He thought there might have been an air bubble in the line.\n\nV2 was driven by a 75 year-old man.  He did not speak very good English so his daughter, an occupant of the vehicle, gave the interview. She stated that the driver is in good health but does have diabetes and a pre-existing heart condition. This driver does wear glasses for a hyperopic (far-sightedness) condition. They stated that they were on there way home from the dentist office so she could get ready for work. \n\n         The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle in lane traveling with higher speed. The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle. Associating factors to this driver may have been that he was conversing with his daughter and that she needed to get home so she could get ready for work.\n \n

This crash occurred at the intersection of a five lane, two-way, east/west road and a three lane, one-way northbound roadway.  All lanes were dry, level and asphalt (with the east/west roads having recently been repaved). The intersection was controlled by a four-way traffic light without a pedestrian signal.  The northbound speed was posted at 56kmph (35mph) while the east/west lanes were posted at 72 kmph (45mph).  It was a cloudy week day afternoon.  \n\n            V1, a 1997 Chevy Cavalier, was traveling north in lane two. V2, a 2000 Chevy Malibu, was traveling east in lane one. As V1 entered the intersection V2 front contacted V1 left Side.  V1 continued forward and where it contacted a utility pole on the northwest corner of the intersection where it came to final rest. V2 rotated counter-clockwise coming to final rest facing west in the middle of the intersection.\n\n             V1 was driven by a 39 year-old female who was very fatigued, but claimed to be in good health despite haven been diagnosed with a heart murmur.  She works 3rd shift and ran a few errands after work but was now on her way home.  She stated that as she approached the intersection she looked up at the light she saw it was green so she proceeded on. As she entered the intersection and crossed lane one of the eastbound traffic she noted a vehicle coming east and did not look as if it was going to stop.  She had no time to react as her vehicle was contacted on the left side. She then continued forward and hit the utility pole on the northwest corner. This driver was transported to a local ER unit to be treated for injuries. V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n            The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded decision error, illegal maneuver. The associated factors were that this driver had not slept in 27 hrs she was tired and less than a half mile from home.  The driver may have been thinking more about being home and getting some rest than the task at hand. \n       \n           V2 was driven by a 22 year-old female who was rest and in good health. She stated that she had just left her fathers home and was running a few errands before returning home to get ready for work. She stated that she was traveling east in lane one and had a green light as she approached the intersection.  At the last minute she saw a vehicle traveling north entering the intersection. She stated she applied her brakes and steered left. Her vehicle contacted the left side of the other vehicle. She stated the northbound vehicle rotated sliding sideway and went off to the northwest corner. She stated her vehicle rotated around and came to rest in the intersection.  She her 1 year-old child in the back seat, but neither occupant was injured. The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path. The critical reason for the critical event was not coded for this vehicle.  The associated factors for this driver was the fact that this driver was in a hurry to finish her errand and return home to get ready for work. She was also distracted since she had also been to the doctors earlier that day with her baby. The doctor stated that the baby was too big for an infant seat. The baby needed to ride in a child seat. The only seat she had in the vehicle with her was booster seat for an older child not a seat with a 5-point belt system.  She was pre-occupied with the fact that her child was improperly restrained.     \n     \n       A witness stated that he was traveling west on the roadway and saw the northbound vehicle coming into the intersection. He stated the light was green for him and the eastbound vehicle.  He also stated that if he had not stopped where he did V2 would have hit him.   \n  \n

This crash occurred at an intersection between two; five-lane roadways controlled by a traffic signal without pedestrian cross signals.  There were two lanes traveling both directions with a center left turn lane in each direction.  The bituminous roadways were straight, level, and dry at the time of the crash.  It was a clear weekday afternoon and the posted speed was 76kmph (45mph).  V1 (2005 Ford Five Hundred) was traveling south in lane two moving into the left turn lane as it approached the intersection.  V2 (1979 Chevrolet Malibu) was traveling north approaching the intersection in lane two with the green light.  V3 (2005 Buick Terraza) was westbound in lane one stopped at the light waiting to make a right turn.  V1 right side was contacted by V2 front as it began it\'s left turn in the intersection.  The force of impact pushed V1 in a northeasterly direction where it contacted V3 left side.  V1 came to final rest along side of V3 blocking the second westbound lane of travel.  V2 had rotated clockwise after impact and came to final rest facing east in lane one of the northbound lanes of the intersection.\n\n              V1 was driven by an 82 year-old female that claimed she is in good health but despite having a heart condition, which she takes medication for.  She does wear glasses to correct an unknown condition.  She had just come from having dinner and was on her way to the store.  She states that she was thinking of the things she needed to buy and that she was not in a hurry.  She said that it was very bright at the time of the crash. She states that she did slow to check traffic but did not see anything coming.\n\n       The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, turning left in intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded driver related error, recognition error inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see).  The associated factors were driver inattention as she was thinking about what she was going to buy at the store and that she did not look far enough ahead before making her turn.\n               \n             V2 was driven by a 58 year-old male who states that he is in fair health due to a heart condition and diabetes (for which he takes medication for).  He wears glasses to correct a myopic (near sighted) condition.  This driver stated that he was on his way to take his wife to the eye doctors.  He said that they were not in a hurry and that he had a clear view of the southbound vehicle.  He saw her move into the left turn lane but she did not stop she just continued to turn and he could not stop in time.  He states that after contact he rotated counter clockwise to face the left turn lane on the East side of the intersection.  That was his final rest.\n\n              The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction-over left lane line.  The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this driver.  The associated factor for this driver was inattention; his thoughts were on his wife\'s health at the time of the crash.  His wife has been on a feeding tube for some time now and is not in good health.  She was crushing up some medication and putting it into the feeding tube at the time of the crash.  \n\n           V3 was driven by a 48 year-old female traveling west on the roadway that had come to a stop at the intersection intending to turn right (she was driving a GM Corp. vehicle was advised to stop interview by her boss as it states in her contract that without consent from Corp. Head Quarters she could be terminated).  She did note that she had looked to the right and then looked to the left and saw vehicles coming so she did not make her turn.  She then claimed that a northbound vehicle crashed with a vehicle that she did not know where it came from.  She also indicated that her vehicle was struck on the left side by the vehicle that had come from the unknown direction.\n\n            The Critical Pre-crash Event for V3 was coded other, not involved in first harmful event. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was not coded to this vehicle. \n  \n

V1, a 1996 Chevrolet Silverado pickup, was traveling westbound on a five-lane, two-way undivided dry, asphalt roadway with a level grade in daylight conditions.  V1 was stopped in lane three (a left turn-only lane) intending to make a left-hand turn.  V2, a 2005 Buick Lacrosse, was traveling eastbound on the same roadway, in lane two approaching the same intersection intending to go straight.  The driver of V1 stated that she saw V2 with its blinker on and thought that V2 was also going to turn left.  The driver of V1 turned left and the front of V2 contacted the right side of V1 in the middle of the intersection before coming to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 63-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  She had a history of high blood pressure, and was taking two blood pressure medications, neither of which had any known performance-impairing side effects. The driver of V1 was rested and traveling home from work.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected both a hyperopic (far-sighted) and myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She sustained minor injuries and was treated on scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was "This vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection."  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a decision error - false assumption of other road user\'s actions, because she assumed that V2 would turn left instead of going straight through the intersection.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 38-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 82-97 kmph (51-60 mph) prior to the crash.  He also reported that he did not think that the driver of V1 would turn left in front of him because he had the right of way.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and on his way to show a customer the vehicle.  He does not wear prescriptive lenses, and was not injured in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was "Other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction, over left lane line." The Critical Reason was not coded to the driver of V2. One associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was an unfamiliarity with the vehicle - this was the first time that he had driven this particular vehicle. He reported however, that he drove on the roadway on a daily basis.\n

This crash occurred on a weekday morning just before noon.  There was a light blowing snow.  The roadway was a straight overpass that crossed over the interstate with a .03% uphill grade.  The posted speed was 72 kmph (45mph).  The overpass had a covering of ice.  As V1, a 2004 Chevrolet Tracker, began crossing the over pass it loss control rotating clockwise to the right.  The driver than overcompensated causing his vehicle to rotate counterclockwise and cross the centerline into the path of V2, a 1998 Ford Explorer. V1\'s right side was struck by the front of V2. V2 pushed V1 13m west before V1 struck the concrete barrier and both vehicles came to final rest. \n\n       V1 was driven by a 67 year-old male that was said to have been in good health. The occupant of the vehicle was pronounced dead at the scene and the driver was rushed to a trauma facility where he died a few hours later.   The son-in-law gave the interview but could give very little information as to the nature of the trip but did state that they may have been they may have been shopping or at the local skill center that was just west of the crash scene.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n      The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded vehicle control loss due to poor road conditions (ice covered road). The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as an environment related factor, highway related slick roads (low friction road surface due to ice).  The associated factors were the speed the driver was traveling at (did not realize that caution was required) and the steering overcompensation when the driver first began to lose control of his vehicle.  Also the son-in-law indicated that they were planning a large family dinner so the driver\'s thoughts and attention could have been focused on that.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 20 year-old in good health.  He stated that he could see the vehicle approaching from the west loss control and he started to decelerate. When the other vehicle crossed the centerline he states that he applied the brakes wanted to steer off the roadway but there was a bridge abutment to his right.  The driver suffered minor injuries while an occupant suffered non-incapacitating injuries for which he sought treatment for after being released from the scene.  A third occupant left the scene before police arrival with an unknown injury status.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe critical pre-crash event was coded other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction- over left lane line. The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle. The associated factors were possible inattention as the driver was conversing with his occupant and inexperience as he rarely drove this road.  Slick, icy roads could have also limited his vehicle\'s stopping ability.

V1 was in lane three and was attempting to make a left-hand turn.  V2, a 2003 Pontiac Vibe, was traveling southbound on the same roadway.  V2 was in lane two intending to go straight.  The traffic signal turned yellow and the driver of V1 assumed that V2 was going to stop and the driver of V2 assumed that V1 would stop.  The front of V2 contacted the right side of V1 and came to final rest in the intersection.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 53-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 2 and 17kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  He had a history of muscular disease but does not take medication for the condition.  He was rested and traveling to a family member\'s home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a Myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He did not sustain any injuries in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a decision error - false assumption of other road user\'s actions, because the light was turning yellow and he assumed the other driver would stop.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 32-year old female who reported that she had been traveling 50-64kmph (31-40mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She does not wear corrective lenses and sustained minor in juries in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as this other vehicle traveling encroaching into their lane, from opposite direction over left lane line. V1, a 1994 Buick LeSabre, was traveling eastbound on a two-lane, two-way, dry asphalt roadway with a level grade in dark-unlighted conditions.  There was no posted speed limit on the roadway, which by default would be 89 kmph, or 55 mph as reported on the police accident report. V2, a 1995 Volvo WhiteGMC tractor-trailer was turning left out of a private drive onto the same roadway.  V2 reported seeing V1 before he pulled out of the driveway but said that V1 was way down the road and thought he had time to pull out.  The front of V1 contacted the right side of V2 before they both came to rest off the south road edge.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 22-year old male who later reported that he could not remember anything about the crash.  Police reported that he had been traveling 113 kmph (70 mph) prior to the crash because post-crash, V1\'s speedometer was stuck at 70 mph.  The driver of V1 had no health-related problems and had not taken any medication.  He does not remember where he was going at the time of the crash.  He does not wear corrective lenses.  Alcohol presence was reported and may have been a contributing factor.  The driver of V1 was transported to a local trauma facility with serious injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other vehicle encroachment from driveway, turning into same direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V1, although alcohol and speed played a factor. Medical records indicated that the driver of V1 had a BAC of .19. Due to his claim that he had no recollection of the crash, it was not known if he took any avoidance actions or if he was distracted in any way prior to the crash.  An associated factor coded to this driver was excess speed - a post-crash inspection of V1 revealed the speedometer to be stuck at 70 mph.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 40-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health-related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling to work.  He does not wear prescribed lenses.  He was not injured in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was when he began to turn left onto the roadway.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a decision error - misjudgment of gap or other\'s speed, because the driver of V2 thought that he had enough time to pull out onto the roadway.

preprocessing
This crash occurred on a weekend afternoon on a straight, level stretch of roadway with open fields on both sides of the road and a posted speed of 89 kmph (55mph).  The roadway was asphalt covered with blown snow and ice. As V1, a 1996 Plymouth Breeze slowed because of the road conditions it began to lose control and rotate clockwise.  The driver then attempted to regain control by steering left which caused further loss of control as the vehicle began rotating counter-clockwise.  V1 than skidded across the centerline and contacted V2, a 2000 Chrysler Concord.  Both vehicles then side slapped and V1 rotated back clockwise to its final rest in the center of the westbound lane.  V2 rotated counter clockwise and slid off the roadway and came to final rest in the ditch on the north side of the roadway.\n\n           V1 was driven by a 17 year-old female in good health but does wear glasses to correct a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She stated that her vehicle did not start that morning so a friend offered his vehicle to drive to work.  It was the first time driving this vehicle and she stated it was like riding in a tin can.  She stated she travels this roadway going to work every day and knew that there were snow-covered areas and knew to slow down. She stated that in this area the vehicle felt like it was being pulled in to the snow and she did not want to be pulled into the ditch. She then overcorrected which caused it to skid in the opposite direction and she crossed the centerline where she contacted the westbound vehicle.   She stated that when the vehicles came to final rest she got right out of her vehicle and went to the other vehicle to help the other driver. It was after the EMS and police got to the scene that she realized that she needed to be looked at and was transported to the ER unit.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle control loss due to poor road conditions (puddle, pot hole, ice, etc.).  The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded environment related factor- highway related, slick roads (low friction road surface due to ice, loose debris, any other cause).  The associated factors were that the driver was driving this vehicle for the first time and was uncomfortable with it as well as this driver being young and inexperienced to winter time driving.\n\n         V2 was driven by a 33 year-old female in good health but takes medications for anxiety and tension (which are not believed to have contributed to the crash).  She also wears glasses to correct a myopic (near sighted) condition. She stated that she was on her way to her office to pick up medications for a patient. Then she was to take it back to the patient but never made it to her office. She stated she saw the East bound vehicle sliding in the snow which caused her to slow in hopes that the other driver would regain control of the vehicle.  V1 did not regain control and crossed the centerline and hit her.  She claims not to remember much after that.  She did remember that her car to final rest in a ditch on the side of the road.  She was transported with incapacitating injuries and her vehicle was towed due to damage. \n\n          The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction - over left lane line. The Critical Reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle. The associated factors to this driver were that she may have distracted from the task at hand as she was upset about her patient schedule and that she had to drive back to her office to pick-up medications for her last patient and drive back to the patient home before going back to the office to clock out for the day.\n             \n

This crash occurred in the eastbound lanes of a four-lane, one-way, slushy, concrete highway with a positive grade in daylight conditions.\n\nV1, a 2002 Hyundai Elantra, was traveling east bound.  V2 was also traveling eastbound on the same highway.  V1 was attempting to merge into the exit ramp lane when he lost control of the vehicle.   The front of V1 contacted the right side of V2.  V1 then rotated clockwise and contacted the V2\'s rear right side with its left side.  V2 then swiped the concrete barrier with its left side before both vehicles came to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 16-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling 82-96kmph (51-60mph) prior to the crash.  He had no prior health conditions and had taken no medication.  He was rested and on his way home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a Myopic (near sighted) condition.  He reported that he had hit a patch of ice that caused him to lose control.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle loss of control, poor road conditions (icy roadway).  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as Decision Error, too fast for conditions.  The roadway was icy and caution should have been taken.  Another factor in the crash was driver inexperience.  The driver of V1 had reported that he had only been driving one year prior to the crash.  Another factor was that he had not driven this roadway often.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 58-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling 82-96kmph (51-60mph) prior to the crash. He had a prior condition of high blood pressure, which was not thought to have contributed to the crash. He reported that he usually takes medication for this condition but had not taken prior to the crash.  He was rested and on his way to church.  He was transported to a local trauma facility with minor injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment, from adjacent lane (same direction) over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded for this vehicle, and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  He reported that he did not have time to attempt any avoidance maneuver.\n

This single vehicle crash occurred at a \xe2\x80\x9cT\xe2\x80\x9d intersection between an interstate exit ramp and a north/south roadway.  The ramp and roadway were both level and controlled by a properly working traffic light.  The exit ramp was icy, wet cement.  The intersection itself was partially covered with blowing snow and ice.  The crash occurred as V1, a 1994 Chevrolet Cavalier entered the intersection at a rate of speed too high for conditions.  The vehicle was in lane 1 intending to turn right (north), as the driver applied the brakes and steered right the vehicle slide straight ahead across the northbound lanes contacting a snow bank.   V1 was than redirected across the southbound lanes where it struck a utility pole on the western roadside and came to final rest.\n\n       V1 was driven by a 19 year-old male in good health that was rested and in no hurry. He stated that he was on his way home from a relative\'s.  He claimed he decelerated and steered right as he prepared to turn north. He stated the vehicle slide straight ahead where it contacted the snow bank and then veered to the left crossing the southbound lanes to contact a utility pole on the west side of the roadway. \n\n           The Critical Pre-crash Event was coded this vehicle control loss due to traveling too fast for conditions. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a decision error, too fast for conditions.  V1 was clearly traveling to fast to maintain control on the end of the ramp that was covered by ice and blowing snow.   The associated factors were the speed the vehicle was being driven at (this could be due to the inexperience of the driver) and the slick surface conditions of the roadway.\n\n\n

This crash occurred at an intersection between a two-way, four-lane roadway that runs north and south and a two-way, two-lane crossing street that is controlled by a stop sign shortly after noon on a weekday.  The roadways were straight, dry, level, and asphalt with a speed posted at 56kmph (35mph).  As V2, a 2000 Chevrolet Tracker, traveled north in lane two; V1, a 1998 Chrysler Sebring was sitting facing West waiting to turn left and travel South.  As a non-contact vehicle in lane one passed the intersection V1 started to make it\'s left turn onto the southbound lanes of the roadway. As it entered the intersection V1 front left corner contacted V2 front right side corner. V2 rotated counter-clockwise slightly to come to final rest alongside V1 facing northwest.  Although both vehicles sat side-by-side they did not side slap after the first impact. \n\n           V1 was driven by a 26 year-old male in good health but he does wear glasses to correct a myopic (near-sightedness) condition. He stated that he had just left a customers home about a block away from the crash and was on his way to another appointment. He was not in any hurry and felt well rested before the crash. This driver also states that he sat at the intersection waiting to turn left for some extra time because of the elevated R/R crossing to his right, which makes southbound traffic difficult to see.  This driver stated that he looked to the right and then left where he saw a white van northbound in lane 1 but did not see the red SUV in lane 2.  He claimed that as the van he had been looking at passed he looked back to the left and started his turn. He saw V2 and applied his brakes but it was too late and he could not avoid the SUV. They both rotated and went towards the northwest corner to final rest.  The driver suffered no injuries and V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n        The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a recognition error- inadequate surveillance (looked but did not see). The associated factors to this crash were the driver preoccupation with the threat of southbound traffic that he could not see as well as his inattention that stemmed from his concern over his an appointment schedule set for the day.\n\n          V2 was driven by a 43 year-old female in good health but does wear glasses for a myopic (near-sightedness) condition.  She stated that her daughter had had a half-day of school so they went for lunch and were now on their way home.  She stated they had driven about \xc2\xbd mile when the crash occurred. She stated that she saw V1 sitting at the stop sign, as it started to move forward her thoughts were that she hoped it would not pull out.  She stated they made contact and rotated to face the North West corner.  Both driver and occupant suffered minor injuries and were not transported.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\n      The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded other vehicle encroachment; from crossing street, turning into opposite direction. The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle. The associated factor to this vehicle was that the driver was conversing with the passenger just before the crash occurred and may have been inattentive to the roadway.     \n

\n\n            This crash occurred at a 4-way intersection controlled by a traffic signal with a flashing left turn arrow.  There are 3 lanes of travel East & West (1 in each direction and a left turn lane).  The roadway is level in all directions with a posted speed of 80kmph (50mph) eastbound and 72 kmph (45mph) westbound.  As V1, a 2004 Chevrolet Silverado Pickup, approached the intersection and moved into the left turn lane the light turned to green and a flashing arrow for the left turn lane.  V1 sat at a stop for a few seconds waiting to make its turn. While waiting the driver was conversing with his occupants. The driver noted the light had changed to amber. He then started his left turn thinking the through traffic had already turned red. As V1 crossed into V2 (1992 Jeep Cherokee) path V2 contacted V1 at the right front side of the vehicle.  V1 came to final rest facing southwest in the lane 1 at the apex of the southeast corner.  V2 came to final rest in lane 1 of the northbound lanes of the intersection \n\n        V1 was driven by a 58 year-old male who stated he is in good health despite having been diagnosed with diabetes and non-alcohol related cirrhosis of the liver (the driver does take medications for these conditions, but they were not believed to have contributed to the crash). He also stated that he wears corrective lenses for an unknown condition.  The driver claimed he has worked 10 hrs a day without a day off since 11/27/05.  The driver stated he thought the eastbound vehicle had a red light and after starting his turn he had no time to perform any avoidance maneuvers.  The driver of V1 was transported to the local trauma unit. Occupant 2 was trapped and was extricated before being transported to the local trauma unit.  Occupants 3 & 4 were not injured and were released to the family.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\n     The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor - decision error, false assumption of other\'s action.  The associated factors were this driver\'s fatigue from long work hours and having had no time off as well as this driver conversing with his occupants, which was a distraction to the driver attentiveness.  The driver also was also unfamiliar with this road as he only driven it rarely. \n\n      V2 was driven by a 23 year-old male that states he is in very good heath and traveling home with his occupant.  The driver stated he looked at he light then to the north of the intersection then as he looked back to look south the vehicle in the left turn lane started his turn. He stated there was no time to do anything but he still tried to steer to the left.  The driver and occupant of V2 were not injured and released.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n \n      The Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction-over left lane line. The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle.  The associated factor was the driver\'s inattention as he was conversing with the occupant as he drove into the intersection. \n\n       This researcher has found that the county road commission had studied the light and has changed the timing of the light as of 1/ 05/ 06.

preprocessing
This crash occurred at an intersection between two five-lane roads controlled by a three color with traffic signal with left turn arrows.  It was a dark but lighted weekday evening and the roadway was wet, level asphalt. The posted speed on the north/south roadway was 72 kmph (45 mph).  As V1, a 1998 Chevrolet Lumina, traveled south in it moved from lane 2 to the left turn lane as it approached the intersection.  The traffic light had gone from a green turn light to a flashing red light.  V1 came to a stop just over the crosswalk lines and waited for a chance to turn.  When the light turned from flashing red to a solid red V1 started it\'s turn. As V1 crossed the northbound lanes of travel it was contacted on the right front side by V2, a 1997 Chevrolet Lumina.  V1 then rotated counter-clockwise coming to final rest facing northwest straddling lanes 1 and 2 of the northbound lanes.  V2 after contact rotated clockwise coming to final rest facing east in the middle of the intersection.  V2 had a fire ignite in the heater core area of the vehicle that was extinguished by a truck driver passing by on a connecting roadway.\n\n        V1 was driven by a 72 year-old male that claimed to be in good health despite having had a quadruple bypass (the medication for which this driver feels does not effect his driving) and presently using a CPAP treatment for sleep apnea.  He also wears glasses to correct a myopic (near sighted) condition.  He had driven two trips out of the area for an auto auction that he works for. He stated after getting gas he was on his way home. He stated that as he drove to the intersection the left turn light had gone from green to red flashing. He stated he stopped just over the crosswalk line and waited for a clearing to turn. He also stated that he did not see the northbound vehicle until after he had started his turn. He stated the vehicle was to close for him to do any avoidance actions.  The driver of V1 was transported to an ER unit by POV (son) while V1 was towed due to damage. \n\n      The Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was coded as this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection. The Critical Reason for the Critical Event was coded as a driver related factor, recognition error, inadequate surveillance (e.g., failed to look, looked but did not see).  The associated factors to this vehicle were that this driver had just made two very long road trips for his place of work and was fatigued.  There was also unknown medication that could of played a factor in the crash even though the driver felt it did not.       This researcher talked to the son of the driver and asked him to talk with his father about his medications and explain that this research and its findings are used for safety.  The driver still stated they played no part in the crash so he felt there was no need to talk about them.\n\n     V2 was driven by a 19 year-old female that states she is in good health and was on her way to a basketball game from work with a friend.  She stated that as she approached the intersection she saw the vehicle in the left turn lane and at the last minute the vehicle started its turn.  She said she applied the brakes and steered right to avoid the crash. After contacting the other vehicle her vehicle rotated clockwise and came to final rest facing the eastbound left turn lane.  The driver was helped from her vehicle by passers-by and her and her passenger were transported to a local trauma unit for injuries.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V2 was coded as other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction- over left lane line.  The critical reason for the critical event was not coded to this vehicle the associated factor to this driver may have been that she may have been conversing with the passenger and she is on a medication for depression.  This medication may affect the driver\'s ability to react to the driving situation.
../resources/summary/2005012695502.json
preprocessing
V1, a 1996 Pontiac Sunfire, was traveling southbound on a three-lane, one way, dry, concrete highway with a positive barrier in daylight conditions.  V1 was traveling in the second lane of travel.  V1 reported that there was a non-contact vehicle in front of her that merged onto an off-ramp to the right.  At the last second the non-contact vehicle changed her mind and steered left back into V1\'s lane of travel.  V1 tried to avoid contacting the other vehicle and steered left.  V1 contacted the median wall with its right front and rotated counterclockwise.  V1 then contacted its right rear to the median wall before coming to final rest up against the wall facing north.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 25-year-old female who had reported that she had been traveling between 82-97 Kph (51-60 MPH) prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and was on her way home.  She was wearing her prescribed contacts that corrected a Myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She was also wearing over-the-counter sunglasses at the time of the crash.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was This Vehicle Traveling - Off the Edge of the Road on the Left Side; the Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a Performance Error - Overcompensation.  Associative factors include false assumption of road user\'s actions and insufficient steering and braking actions.

V1, a 2001 Ford Expedition, was traveling southbound on a one lane, one way, wet, highway entrance ramp in daylight conditions.  The highway was under construction and the on-ramp was backed up with traffic due to a yield sign at the bottom of the ramp.  V2, a 2002 Chevrolet Cavalier, was also traveling southbound on the same ramp.  V2, was waiting at the bottom of the ramp to merge into traffic.  V1 thought that V2 would merge without stopping and as the driver of V2 was looking over her left shoulder to merge, the front of V1 contacted the back of V2.  Both vehicles then came to final rest on the right side of the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 38-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that correct a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She did not sustain any injuries in the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a decision error, false assumption of other road user\'s actions, because she thought that V2 would merge without stopping. Associated factors coded to this driver include her focus on extraneous vehicles to her left, the fact that this was her first time driving on this roadway, and the traffic flow interruption due to the construction work zone.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 20-year old female who had reported that she had been stopped for more than ten seconds prior to the crash.  She was waiting for a break in traffic so that she could merge.  She had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling to her fianc\xc3\xa9\'s house.  She does not wear corrective lenses.  She sustained minor injuries and was transported from the scene to a local trauma facility.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash. One associated factor (coded to both drivers) was the traffic flow interruption due to the construction work zone.\n

V1, a 2000 GMC Jimmy was traveling westbound on a seven-lane, two-way, wet asphalt roadway, with a level grade in daylight conditions.  V1 had made several lane changes, passing slower traffic.  On the last pass, another non-contact vehicle was encroaching into his lane.  He swerved right to miss the vehicle and departed the roadway on the right side.  V1 rolled left; one quarter turn and spun counterclockwise on his left side before coming to final rest off the north side of the road.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 23-year old male that reported that he had been traveling 82-97kmph (51-60mph) prior to the crash.  He had a medical history of brain tumors and was taking medication to treat it.  The medication has possible side affects of drowsiness, mental confusion, dizziness, insomnia, double vision and tiredness.  He was rested and traveling to the bank.  He stated that he was in a hurry to get to the bank before it closed.  He sustained minor injuries from the crash, but refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle control loss due to poor road conditions, rain and wet roadway.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a decision error, too fast for conditions to be able to respond to unexpected actions of other road users.

preprocessing
V1, a 1996 Newflyer Bus was traveling eastbound on a two lane, one way, dry asphalt roadway in daylight conditions.  V1 approached the intersection and was intending to go straight.  V2 a 2003 Ford Explorer was traveling southbound on a four lane, one way, dry, asphalt roadway in the same conditions.  V2 approached the same intersection also intending to go straight.  V1 reported that he stopped for the stop sign but could not see V2 due to trees in the way of his sightline.  V2 thought that V1 would stop and yield the right-of-way.  The front of V1 contacted the right side of V2, before they both came to final rest in the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 42-year old man who had reported that he had stopped at the stop sign for 1-2 seconds and then proceeded traveling between 2-16kmph (1-10mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling to his next stop on his route.  He does not wear prescribed lenses, but was wearing over-the-counter sunglasses at the time of the crash.  He did not sustain any injuries from the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was coded \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection\xe2\x80\x9d.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see), because he stated that he did stop at the sign but did not see V2 approaching. An associated factor coded for this vehicle was a sight line restriction located to the driver\'s left.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 36-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling 34-48kmph (21-30mph) prior to the crash.  She had a history of high blood pressure and had taken her medication prior to the crash.  This was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected an unknown condition.  She sustained minor injuries and left from the scene to seek medical attention.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment, from crossing street across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  She took appropriate avoidance actions.

V2 a 1989 Chevrolet Cavalier was traveling northbound on the same roadway.  The driver of V1 stated that she could not see V2 approaching because of a SUV in the way.  The driver of V2 stated that she saw V1, but did not think that she would pull out.  The driver of V1 entered the roadway from the drive and the front of V2 contacted the left side of V1 before they both came to final rest in the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 21-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling between 2-16kmph (1-10mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems, and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She does not wear prescribed lenses.  She did not sustain any injuries from the crash.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was coded \xe2\x80\x9cThis vehicle turning left at intersection\xe2\x80\x9d.  The critical reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance: failed to look, looked but did not see. The crash occurred in the northbound lane of a two lane, two way, dry asphalt roadway in daylight conditions.  The intersecting road ran east/west and was controlled by a stop sign.  Both roads had a posted speed limit of 88kmph (55mph).\n\nV1, a 1997 Chevrolet Astro Van was traveling westbound.  V1 was approaching the intersection intending to go straight.  V2, a 2002 Pontiac Grand Am was traveling northbound on a similar roadway approaching the same intersection.  V2 was also intending to go straight.  The driver of V1, was reaching for an unknown object in his car when he looked up he saw a stop sign and the approaching V2, but it was too late to avoid contact.  The front of V1 contacted the right side of V2 before they both came to final rest off the west side of the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 34-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 82-97kmph (51-60mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken a depression medication prior to the crash.  The possible side effects of this medication are drowsiness, tiredness, dizziness and weakness.  He was rested and traveling to play golf.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a Myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He sustained some minor injuries during the crash but refused to be transported to the hospital.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was coded as a recognition error, internal distraction, because he was looking down in his car for something and not looking at the road.  An associated factor in this crash was that this was the drivers\' first time on the road and he was unfamiliar with the area.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 24-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling 82-97kmph (51-60mph) prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She was transported to a local trauma facility with minor injuries.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle encroachment, from crossing street, across path.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and was thought not to have contributed to the crash.

V1, a 1995 Chevrolet Cavalier was traveling northbound on a three lane, one way, dry, concrete highway in daylight conditions.  V1 was traveling in lane one and then changed lanes to lane two.  She noticed that another car was trying to merge into her lane, so she tried to change lanes back into lane one but overcorrected and lost control.  V1 departed the roadway on the right side and rotated in a clockwise motion.  V1 contacted its left front to the guardrail and then contacted it\'s left back to the guardrail before coming to final rest up against the guardrail.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 47-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling between 98-113kmph (61-70mph) prior to the crash.  She stated that she moved into the middle lane from the right and a van was moving into the middle lane from the left.  She swerved to avoid the van .  She was rested and traveling home from work.  The driver was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected a Myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She sustained minor injuries from the crash but refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling off the edge of the road on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a performance error, overcompensation, because she tried to avoid another vehicle coming into her lane and she over steered and contacted the guardrail.\n\nNote: the damage to the right side of the vehicle was from a previous crash.

V1, a 2004 Buick Rainier sport utility vehicle, was traveling northbound on a four lane, two-way, undivided dry asphalt roadway in daylight conditions.  V1 was attempting to turn left at a 4-way intersection.  V2, a 2003 Chevrolet Silverado pickup, was traveling southbound in the first lane of travel on the same roadway intending to go straight. There were no traffic control devices present for either V1 or V2, and the posted speed limit was 56 kmph (35 MPH).  A non-contact truck that was stopped in the second southbound lane, waiting to turn left at the intersection, blocked V1\'s view.  V1 turned left and its front contacted the front of V2.  V1 came to final rest on the roadway.  V2 departed the roadway to the left.  V2\'s front then contacted a fence before coming to final rest.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 47-year old female who reported that she was traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 MPH) prior to the crash.  She had no health-related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling to a hardware store.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected a hyperopic (far-sighted) condition.  She was uninjured in the crash and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was when she began to turn left at the intersection.  The Critical Reason for the  Critical Precrash Event  was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see).  An associated factor was that the driver of V1 could not see the oncoming vehicle because another vehicle was blocking her view.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 52-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 34-48 kmph (21-30 MPH) prior to the crash.  He had no health-related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling to work.  He does not wear corrective lenses.  He sustained minor injuries but refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction-over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2. One associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was a false assumption of other road user\'s actions - he reported that he saw V1 stopped at the intersection prior to the crash but thought that its driver would wait for him to pass before beginning the left turn.

V1 was traveling in lane two and was slowing to make a left-hand turn into a commercial drive. V2, a 1999 Chevrolet Suburban, was traveling on the same roadway in front of V2, intending to turn left at the same drive.  The driver of V1 reported that she did not see V2 ahead of her.  The front of V1 contacted the back of V2.  A fire started in the engine compartment of V1 as a result of the crash.  Both vehicles then came to final rest in the roadway. \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 58-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health-related problems and had taken no medications prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling to the store.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected both hyperopic (far-sighted) and myopic (near-sighted) conditions. V1, was traveling in lane two, when a witness noticed him drifting over the lane line into lane one.  The witness thought he was just making a lane change, but then noticed that he continued to drift off the road and into trees along the right side of the highway.  The witness stated that he saw no brake lights. \nThe trees eventually stopped the vehicle, and it came to final rest in the trees.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 31-year old male who had reported that he had blacked out prior to the crash and did not know what had happened.  He did not remember his speed.  The witness stated that he was traveling 126kmph (78mph) and V1 was keeping up with him prior to the crash.  The driver of V1 had no prior health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  Driver reported that he felt rested.  Driver reported that he had been driving around for four hours before he started heading for work.  He does not wear prescribed lenses.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was, this vehicle traveling off the road edge on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a critical non-performance error, heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act, because he lost consciousness and could not keep control of the vehicle.  An associated factor is that he was upset over his girlfriend and he had sllit his wrists an hour before the crash happened.\n

The driver of V1 was experiencing low blood sugar and passed out at the wheel, relinquishing control of the car.  V1 crossed the double yellow lines and the front of V1 contacted the front of V2.  V2 came to final rest on the roadway facing west.  V1 came to final rest off the south side of the roadway facing north.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 43-year old diabetic male who reported that he had blacked out due to low blood sugar. Medical records indicated that immediately after the crash, his blood sugar was 32, a dangerously low level. The driver of V1 sustained serious injuries during the crash and was transported to a local trauma facility. The driver of V1 told doctors that he had skipped a meal earlier in the day but had still taken his insulin. \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when he traveled over the lane line on the left side of the travel lane. V1 was traveling in the second lane of travel, intending to go straight through a 4-way signalized intersection.  V2, a 1997 Pontiac Sunfire, was traveling westbound on a three-lane undivided dry, asphalt roadway.  V2 was intending to turn right at the intersection. The posted speed limit on both the northbound and westbound roadway was 56 kmph (35 mph). V2 failed to stop for the red light and the front of V2 contacted the right side of V1.  V1 came to final rest in the roadway.  V2 departed the roadway to the left and came to final rest off the west side of the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 45-year old female who was not available for an interview. V1, A 2004 Buick LeSabre, was attempting to enter a five lane, two way, asphalt north/south roadway in daylight conditions. The roadway was dry, straight and level. The posted speed limit was 64 kmph (40 mph).  V2, a 1988 Pontiac Bonneville, was traveling southbound on the roadway, intending to go straight.  V1 began to make a left hand turn out of a driveway onto the roadway when the front of V2 contacted the left side of V1.  Both vehicles came to final rest in the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 90-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected an unknown condition.  He did not sustain any injuries and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when he began to turn left.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was a recognition error - inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see).\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 62-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 67-80 kmph (41-50 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling home.  He did not wear prescribed lenses.  He was uninjured in the crash and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V2 was when another vehicle encroached into his lane from a driveway, turning into the opposite direction.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was not coded to the driver of V2. One associated factor coded to the driver of V2 was excess speed. As per the interview, the driver of V2 reported that he had been traveling between 41-50 mph prior to the crash. The posted speed limit was 40 mph.\n\n\n

V2 initiated a left turn and the front of V2 contacted the right of V1 before they both came to final rest on the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 50-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 2-16 kmph (1-10 mph) prior to the crash. He did not sustain any injuries and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle turning left at intersection. Subsequently, he did not begin braking until one second prior to impact.\n

V1 had stopped at the stop sign for more than 10 seconds.  She then attempted to make a left-hand turn and was contacted on her left side by the front of V2 who was intending to go straight through the intersection. V2 came to final rest in the middle of the intersection.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 19-year old female who had reported that she had been stopped for more than 10 seconds at the intersection before proceeding.  She thought it was a four-way stop so she stopped and then drove thru the intersection.  She did not see V2 coming from her left side.  She sustained moderate injuries from the crash and was transported to a local trauma facility.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was: this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection. She was taking a high blood pressure medicine possible side effects are dizziness and tiredness prior to the crash.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was an 18-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 67-80kmph (41-50mph) prior to the crash. V2, a 2004 Pontiac Grand Am, was traveling eastbound on a 4-lane, one-way dry asphalt roadway in similar conditions.  V2 was also approaching the intersection intending to go straight.  Both roadways had a posted speed of 56 kmph (35 mph). Both vehicles entered the intersection at approximately the same time. The front of V2 contacted the right front of V1. V1 rotated in a counterclockwise direction and the right rear of V1 "slapped" the left rear side of V2. V1 then departed the roadway to the south before coming to final rest. After the initial impact, V2 rotated in a clockwise direction and the left rear side of V2 was struck by the right rear of V1. \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 23-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 34-48 kmph (21-30 mph) prior to the crash. She was uninjured in the crash and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for V1 was this vehicle crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was an illegal maneuver because the driver of V1 went through a red light. Her contention that the sun was in her eyes was discounted due to her direction of travel (south) and the fact that a witness who was traveling in the same direction behind V1 had no problem seeing the red traffic light.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 56-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 50-64 kmph (31-40 mph) prior to the crash.  She noticed that V1 was coming at her so she tried to steer left and hit the brakes.  She was rested and traveling home.  She had a history of high blood pressure and was taking medication for it. preprocessing
The crash occurred on a four-lane interstate divided by a grass median and guardrails in the eastbound direction. The roadway was dry, straight and level. The posted speed limit was 113 kmph (70 mph). The crash occurred in the early hours of the afternoon on a clear day.\n\nV1, a 2001 Chevrolet Malibu, was traveling eastbound in the third lane of travel. A non-contact vehicle swerved from the second lane of travel into the third lane of travel in front of V1. The driver of V1 swerved to the left to avoid striking the non-contact vehicle, and then tried to swerve back into her lane. These steering actions sent V1 into a skid, and V1 departed the roadway to the left, skidding into the median. The front left of V1 contacted a guardrail and then entered the westbound roadway while traveling in a northeast direction. V1 became airborne, its front hit the ground while it rotated to the left, and it then landed on its roof in between the second and third westbound lanes of travel. V2, a 2002 Pontiac Aztec utility vehicle, was traveling westbound in the third lane of travel and swerved to the right while braking in an attempt to avoid striking V1. The front of V2 struck the left side of V1 in its upside-down position. V3, a 1998 Dodge Ram van, was also traveling westbound in the third lane of travel and its driver also braked and swerved in an attempt to avoid V1. V1, which was spinning after being struck by V2, sideswiped the left rear side of V3 as V3 passed by.  All three vehicles then came to final rest in the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 24-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 98-113 kmph (61-70 mph) prior to the crash.  She had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  She was rested and traveling home.  She was wearing her prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  She sustained incapacitating injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  \n\nThe Critical Pre-crash Event for the driver of V1 was when she departed the roadway on the left side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Pre-crash Event was overcompensation, a performance error. No additional associated factors were coded to this driver.  \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 26-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 67-80 kmph (41-50 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling downtown.  He does not wear corrective lenses.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  \n\nNo Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason was coded for the driver of V2.  He was not involved in the first harmful event and took appropriate avoidance actions. One associated factor coded to this driver was excess speed, because the EDR revealed that 5 seconds prior to the crash, he was traveling at 80 mph. The posted speed limit was 70 mph.\n\nThe driver of V3 was a 42-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 98-113 kmph (61-70 mph) prior to the crash.  He had no health related problems and had taken no medication prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling downtown.  He does not wear corrective lenses.  He was uninjured in the crash and refused treatment.\n\nNo Critical Pre-crash Event and no Critical Reason was coded for the driver of V2.  He was not involved in the first harmful event and took appropriate avoidance actions. No associated factors were coded to this driver.\n

V1, a 1998 Saturn SC2, was traveling eastbound on a four lane, two-way, dry, asphalt roadway in daylight conditions.  V2, a 1996 Chevrolet 1500, was also traveling westbound on the same roadway.  V1 was traveling in lane two and attempted to make a lane change into lane one.  She did not see V2 traveling in lane one and the right of V1 contacted the left of V2, before they both came to final rest in the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 41-year old female who reported that she had been traveling between 34-48kmph (21-30mph) prior to the crash.  She stated she was in good health, but was taking hormones.  She was rested and traveling to a tattoo shop.  She and a passenger in the backseat were uninjured while the passenger in right front seat sustained minor injuries but refused treatment.  The vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling, over the lane line on the right side.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see), because the driver reported that she did not see V2 because it was in her blind spot.  An associated factor was unfamiliarity with the road as she stated she rarely drove on it.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 52-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 50-64kmph (31-40mph) prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling home.  He was in good health and wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He was uninjured and was able to drive from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment, from adjacent lane over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.

V1, a 2002 Chevrolet Silverado was traveling westbound on a three-lane, two-way, dry asphalt roadway in daylight conditions.  V2, a 1993 GMC Safari van was stopped at a red light westbound on the same roadway.  V3 a 2004 Pontiac Grand Am, and V4 a 1997 Chevrolet van were also stopped at the red light westbound on the same roadway.  V1 collided with the back of V2, pushing V2 into V3 and V3 into V4.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 60-year old male who reported that he had been traveling between 34-48kmph (21-30mph) prior to the crash.  He was in good health, rested and traveling home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected an unknown condition.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane: other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, inattention because he did not see the line of cars stopped in front of him.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 43-year old female who reported that she had been stopped prior to the crash.  She was in good health, rested and traveling to the store.  She was wearing non-prescription sunglasses.  She was uninjured in the crash and refused treatment.  V2 was driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle in lane traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2, and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n\nThe driver of V3 was a 28-year old female who reported that she had been stopped prior to the crash.  She was in good health, rested and traveling to her friends work.  She was uninjured in the crash.  V3 was driven from the scene.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded for the driver of V3 because she was not involved in first harmful event, and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  \n\nThe driver of V4 was a 32-year old male who reported that he was stopped prior to the crash.  The driver was uninjured.  V4 was driven from the scene.\n\nNo Critical Precrash Event and no Critical Reason were coded for the driver of V4 because he was not involved in first harmful event, and she was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n\n\n

V1, a 2002 Chevrolet Cavalier was traveling northbound on a five lane, two way, dry asphalt roadway in dark conditions.  V1 was attempting to make a left-hand turn.  V2, a 1994 Dodge Ram was traveling southbound on the same roadway.  V2 was intending to go straight.  The front of V2 contacted the right of V1 before they both came to final rest in the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 69-year old female who had reported that she had been traveling 2-16Kmph (1-10Mph) prior to the crash.  She had a history of high blood pressure and took medication to control it prior to the crash.  This was not thought to have contributed.  She was rested and traveling to pick up her granddaughter.  She received minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  Her vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling, turning left at intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, inadequate surveillance (failed to look, looked but did not see).  The driver of V1 stated that she did not see the other vehicle.\n\nThe driver of V2 fled the scene on foot leaving his passenger behind.  The passenger reported that they had been traveling between 67-80Kmph (41-50Mph) prior to the crash.  He stated the driver was in good health, was rested and traveling home. The passenger was uninjured and refused treatment.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment from opposite direction over left lane line.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.
