preprocessing
V1, A 1995 Chevrolet Beretta was traveling southbound on a five lane, two way, dry asphalt roadway in dark but lighted conditions.  V1 was traveling in lane three, intending to turn left at the intersection.  V2 a 2002 Chevrolet Cavalier was traveling northbound on the same roadway intending to go straight.  As V1 began turning left the front of V2 contacted the right of V1.  Both Vehicles came to final rest in the roadway.  \n\nThe driver of V1 was a 16-year old female who was not available for an interview.  She was uninjured but the two other occupants of her vehicle suffered non-incapacitating injuries and were transported to a local trauma facility.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling, turning left at the intersection.  The Critical reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, unknown recognition error, because it is unknown whether V1 saw V2 or not.  Associated factors include driver inexperience as the driver was only 16 and had not been driving for very long.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 41-year old male who reported that he had been traveling 50-64kmph (31-40mph) prior to the crash. He was in good health, rested, and traveling to his girlfriend\'s house.  He was uninjured and his vehicle was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment, from opposite direction over left lane line.  The Critical reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.\n
../resources/summary/2005012696284.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2005 Chevrolet Trailblazer was traveling northbound on a 5 lane, two-way dry asphalt roadway, intending to go straight.  V2, a 2001 Pontiac Montana was also traveling north on the same road.  V2 was stopped at the light and had just started to proceed when the front of V1 contacted the back of V2.  V1 came to final rest in the roadway.  V2 departed the roadway on the right side after impact and came to final rest off the roadway.  .\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 59-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 50-64Kmph (31-40Mph) prior to the crash.  He had reported a history of Parkinson\'s and had taken several medications prior to the crash.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected astigmatism and a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He stated that he was rested and running an errand.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  V1 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was other motor vehicle in lane, other vehicle stopped.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a driver related error, heart attack or other physical impairment of the ability to act because he stated that he had passed out prior to the crash.  An associated factor for this crash was the driver\'s medications as it\'s listed side effects included causing drowsiness and fainting. \n\nThe driver of V2 was a 68-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between stopped prior to the impact.  He had a history of Diabetes and had taken Insulin prior to the crash.  He was rested and traveling to the mall.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a hyperopic (near-sighted) condition.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  V2 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other motor vehicle in lane, traveling in same direction with higher speed.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.
../resources/summary/2005012696362.json
preprocessing
V1, a 2000 Ford Ranger was traveling northbound on a three lane, one way, dry asphalt roadway in dark, but lighted conditions.  V1 was intending to go straight.  V2 a 2005 Chevrolet Monte Carlo was traveling eastbound on a four lane, one way, dry asphalt roadway in similar conditions.  V2 was intending to go straight.  V3 a 2003 Buick Century was also traveling eastbound on the same roadway.   V3 was intending to go straight.  V1 stated that he did not notice the light was red until he did not have time to stop.  The left of V2 contacted the left of V1, V2 came to final rest in the roadway.  The front of V3 contacted the left of V1.  V1 rolled left one-quarter turn before coming to rest in the roadway.  V3 rolled right two quarter turns before coming to rest in the roadway.\n\nThe driver of V1 was a 37-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling 50-64kmph (31-40mph) prior to the crash. He was in good health, rested and traveling to a pool hall.  He sustained minor injuries from the crash but refused treatment.  V1 was towed due to damage.  \n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V1 was this vehicle traveling, crossing over (passing through) intersection.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was a recognition error, inattention.   The associated factors for this crash were inadequate surveillance and traveling too fast for conditions as he was speeding at the time of the crash.\n\nThe driver of V2 was a 64-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling between 50-64kmph (31-40mph) prior to the crash.  He was in good health, rested and traveling to a restaurant.  He did not sustain any injuries from the crash and refused treatment.  V2 was able to be driven from the scene.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V2 was other vehicle encroachment from the crossing street, across path.   The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V2 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.  He took appropriate avoidance actions.\n\nThe driver of V3 was an 87-year old male who had reported that he had been traveling 18-32kmph (11-22mph) prior to the crash.  He had a preexisting condition of Diabetes and takes Insulin (but this was not thought to have contributed to the crash).  He was rested and traveling home.  He was wearing his prescribed lenses that corrected a myopic (near-sighted) condition.  He sustained minor injuries and was transported to a local trauma facility.  V3 was towed due to damage.\n\nThe Critical Precrash Event for the driver of V3 was other, not involved in first harmful event.  The Critical Reason for the Critical Precrash Event was not coded to the driver of V3 and he was not thought to have contributed to the crash.
